site_title: Gold set for first weekly drop in nine; focus on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices are set for their first weekly drop in nine weeks amid a stronger US dollar and higher interest rates. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $2,879.09 an ounce, but is down nearly 2% for the week. Investors focus on US inflation data and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy trajectory, with a key inflation report due later in the day. A stronger US dollar makes gold more expensive for foreign buyers, and higher interest rates dampen its appeal as a hedge against inflation and political risks.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent at US$2,918.22 an ounce.

site_title: S&P keeps French debt rating but revises outlook down
summary: S&P maintains France's AA- credit score but revises its economic outlook to negative, citing pressure on public finances and political strife over the country's budget. The downgrade opens the door to a future demotion of France's sovereign debt rating, which would increase the cost of servicing the country's mounting public borrowing. The ratings agency warns that a weakening of France's 2023 pension reform could create downward pressure on the ratings. France's economy ministry says the outlook downgrade highlights the scale of the task of restoring public finances.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump (right) and French President Emmanuel Macron (left) shake hands at the end of a joint press conference in the White House in Washington, D.C., Feb 24, 2025.

site_title: Mars readying over US$25 billion bond sale for next week: sources
summary: Mars is preparing to sell bonds worth between $25 billion and $30 billion to finance its takeover of Pringles maker Kellanova, with banks Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase leading the market. The deal could be one of the top 10 largest M&A financing deals in the investment-grade bond market since 2013. Synopsys is also selling bonds worth $10 billion to $15 billion to finance its $34 billion takeover of Ansys, contributing to a potential $40 billion rush of acquisition financing bonds.

images.alt_text: MrBeast is best known for his work on YouTube, where he posts videos of large-scale challenges and giveaways that generate hundreds of millions of views.

site_title: China’s new-home sales steady on continued policy support
summary: China's new-home sales rose 1.2% in February, reaching 188 billion yuan, a slight rebound from a 3.2% decline in January. The growth is seen as a sign of the real estate market stabilizing with continued policy support. A solid rebound in transactions is crucial to stabilizing prices, according to Fitch Ratings. Investors await the National People's Congress for further policy announcements, which may include more support for genuine demand for housing.

site_title: New World Development’s debt repayment in focus amid US$875 million expected H1 loss
summary: New World Development, a Hong Kong-based property developer, is set to report an interim net loss of up to US$875 million, driven by a prolonged property downturn and high interest costs. The company's market value has shrunk to US$1.5 billion from US$14 billion in 2019. New World has faced liquidity stress for three years and has undergone two CEO changes in two months, raising concerns over corporate governance. The firm's deepening debt woes have sparked worries of a sector crisis in Hong Kong's property market.

images.alt_text: New World Development had consolidated net debt of HK$123.8 billion as at Jun 30, according to its 2024 annual report.
New World Development had consolidated net debt of HK$123.8 billion as at Jun 30, according to its 2024 annual report.
After New World posted its first loss in 20 years, Adrian Cheng stepped down as CEO in September in a surprise move. Just two months later, the company replaced his successor.
Concerns are growing over the financial state of New World Development controlled by the family of Hong Kong tycoon Henry Cheng.

site_title: Vietnam steel body seeks tariffs on Chinese, South Korean galvanised steel
summary: Vietnam's Steel Association has requested the government to impose tariffs on galvanized steel imports from China and South Korea, citing a significant threat to domestic production. The imports from these countries account for 64-67% of total imports, putting pressure on the domestic industry. Vietnam has already imposed anti-dumping duties on some steel exports and producers, with rates as high as 25%. The move aims to protect the domestic industry and prevent further damage.

images.alt_text: Vietnam now directs 29 per cent of its exports to its former foe, according to Vietnamese customs data.
China’s sent the most steel overseas in nine years in 2024, as its producers turned to global markets to offset a deep construction slowdown at home.
The survey is based on input from more than 100 of AmCham Vietnam’s members, which include big multinational companies such as Intel and Nike.

site_title: Trump kicks Zelensky out of White House after shouting match
summary: US President Donald Trump abruptly kicked Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky out of the White House after a shouting match in the Oval Office, citing Zelensky's lack of readiness for peace with Russia. The meeting, meant to discuss a potential truce and joint development of Ukraine's minerals resources, ended without a deal. Trump's behavior has raised concerns among US allies in Europe, who expressed support for Zelensky. The incident has led to a deterioration in relations between the US and Ukraine, with Russia reportedly delighted by the collapse.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index ended flat at 557.19 points on Friday but closed higher for the week and extended its longest winning streak since early 2024.

Russian Security Council Secretary Sergei Shoigu met Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim on Thursday (Feb 27) in Putrajaya for talks on expected to have been focused on enhancing security and defence ties between the two nations.
Brent crude futures, which expired on Friday, settled at US$73.18 a barrel, down 86 cents, or 1.16 per cent.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 1.4 per cent at 43,840.91 on Friday.

site_title: Genting Bhd, Genting Malaysia take big tumble after news of CEO change; Genting Singapore edges marginally lower
summary: Genting Bhd and Genting Malaysia shares plummeted 11.8% and 19.5% respectively after Lim Kok Thay stepped down as CEO of Genting after nearly two decades, with Tan Kong Han taking over as CEO of Genting Malaysia on March 1, 2025. Both companies reported a net loss in their latest earnings, with Genting Bhd and Genting Malaysia net losses of RM169.4 million and RM457.9 million respectively. Shares of Genting Singapore also fell 1.4% as part of the market's reaction.

images.alt_text: Tan Sri Lim Kok Thay, Chairman and CEO of Genting Group
Crystal Heng

site_title: AirAsia owner Capital A expects return to profit this year after 2024 loss
summary: Capital A, owner of AirAsia, reported an annual attributable loss of RM475.1 million (US$106.5 million) in 2024, largely due to foreign exchange fluctuations. However, the company expects to return to profit this year, with earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) from continuing operations projected between RM500 million and RM600 million. This marks a significant turnaround from a loss in 2024, driven by increased travel demand and the expected activation of 19 aircraft currently in storage.

site_title: Creative on ‘global search’ for new leader as CEO Song Siow Hui retires
summary: Creative Technology's CEO Song Siow Hui, 70, is retiring and the company is searching for a new leader. Dr. Tan Jok Tin, 73, has been named as interim CEO, bringing expertise in driving business transformation and market expansion. The board is seeking a dynamic and visionary leader to drive growth, with a focus on audio innovation and profitability. Song expressed gratitude for his role in the past two years and looks forward to the new management team taking the reins, driving transformative actions and fresh strategy.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: India builds world’s longest LPG pipeline to cut costs, mishaps
summary: India's state-run refiners will fully commission the world's longest LPG pipeline by June, cutting fuel transportation costs and preventing deadly road accidents. The $1.3 billion project will replace hundreds of trucks, reducing transportation costs by 70% and increasing the pipeline's capacity to 8.3 million tons annually, accounting for 25% of India's total demand. The project, which has faced delays, will help reduce the risk of accidents and improve the country's LPG supply chain.

images.alt_text: An oil pipeline is laid next to the Vopak-Dialog oil storage facility (R) and a Refinery and Petrochemical Integrated Development (RAPID) project construction site in Pangerang in Malaysia's southern state of Johor October 6, 2015. Liquefied Petroleum Gas, long a niche product used by the poor to cook and the rich to barbecue, has become a rare bright spot amid a broad commodities rout, riding on the wave of strong economic growth in India and parts of Southeast Asia.   REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: Sherman Kwek saying ‘there was no attempt to oust me misses the point’: CDL chairman Kwek Leng Beng
summary: CDL chairman Kwek Leng Beng accused his son, group CEO Sherman Kwek, of attempting to oust him, claiming Sherman's denial of this alleged attempt "misses the point." Kwek Leng Beng stated that his son's actions were an "attempt to distract everyone from the matter at hand" and questioned the appointment of two new directors without proper vetting. The dispute revolves around allegations of corporate governance lapses and Sherman Kwek's attempts to undermine his father's authority. The matter is currently before the court.

images.alt_text: CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng said he has filed court papers on Feb 25 to deal with the “attempted coup” by his son and group chief executive, Sherman Kwek.
Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Allianz profit beats as Pimco parent starts new buyback programme
summary: Allianz reported a 8.7% increase in full-year earnings to 16 billion euros, driven by a 11% rise in operating profit to 4.17 billion euros. The company announced a new share buyback program of up to 2 billion euros and proposed a 12% dividend increase. CEO Oliver Baete aims to raise the profit payout ratio and increase the medium-term profit target to between 15 billion and 17 billion euros for 2025.

site_title: ECB’s multi-trillion payments breakdown sends shudders through Europe
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) experienced a multi-trillion euro payment breakdown, affecting ordinary bank payments, such as wages, pensions, and social welfare transfers, on February 28. The issue, caused by a "hardware defect" in the Target two system, led to a 7-hour outage, delaying transactions worth trillions of euros. The ECB fixed the issue late on Thursday, but residual effects persisted on Friday. The incident has raised concerns over the credibility of digital payment systems and may impact the functioning of the eurozone's economy.

images.alt_text: The consensus is that the ECB will take this year’s staff changes in its stride, with markets still very much focused on data rather than personnel as they calibrate their interest-rate bets.

European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde says Europe’s economy will remain frail in the near term, with risks to the outlook still tilted to the downside due to the possibility of greater global trade frictions.
A view of Paris, France. The yield spread between French OATs and German Bunds falls to 74 basis points as French budget talks teeter on the brink of collapse.
Wage growth is easing, the labour market is softening, oil prices have come off early-year highs and the US dollar’s relentless firming seems to have stopped for now.
Any new duties on EU exports to the world’s biggest economy could hit the already stumbling eurozone hard.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, February 28, 2025
summary: Asian chip shares declined due to Nvidia's earnings and tariff fears, while Indonesia's rupiah hit a five-year low. Olam's H2 profit plummeted 83.4% to S$38.4 million, and the company pared its proposed dividend to S$0.03 per share. These market movements were influenced by the recent Trump tariff salvo, fueling fresh fears in the region.

images.alt_text: Tokyo briefly shed three per cent, while Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta were all well in the red.
Olam's revenue for the second half rose 24 per cent to S$29.2 billion from S$23.6 billion.

site_title: Japfa’s H2 net profit more than doubles to US$61.9 million
summary: Japfa, an agri-food group, reported a net profit of US$61.9 million for the second half of 2024, more than doubling from US$22.8 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 2% to US$2.4 billion, while cost of sales contracted 5%. Gross profit increased 47% to US$464.2 million. The company's improved financial performance was driven by lower feed costs and stable day-old chick and broiler prices in Indonesia and higher swine prices in Vietnam. Japfa proposed a final dividend of S$0.01 per share for FY2024.

images.alt_text: 总部设在新加坡的佳发公司是印尼和东南亚最大的家禽生产商之一，在印尼每个月生产5000万只鸡。（佳发公司提供）
Tay Peck Gek

site_title: From summer camp to world champion: Yin Ruoning’s road to the top in golf
summary: Yin Ruoning, a 22-year-old Chinese golfer, has achieved remarkable success, winning the KPMG Women's PGA Championship in 2023 and becoming the second female golfer from China to win a Major. She rose to the top of the Women's World Golf Rankings and is now ranked fourth on the US-based LPGA Tour. Yin attributes her passion for golf to her father, who taught her the sport at age 10. She advises young golfers to play for fun and enjoy the process, rather than focusing solely on winning. Yin aims to win at least five Majors in her career and has partnered with Rolex as a brand ambassador.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
From left: Golfers Yin Ruoning, Jeeno Thitikul, Hannah Green, Shannon Tan, Lilia Vu and Charley Hull by the SkyPark Infinity Pool at Marina Bay Sands.

Hannah Green of Australia reacts in jubilation after sinking a birdie on the 18th to win the HSBC Women's World Championship at Sentosa Golf Club’s Tanjong Course on March 3, 2024. Fellow golfer Andrea Lee (back facing camera) of USA raises her arm simultaneously to celebrate her competitor’s win.
Tanasugarn, who retired in 2016, now runs her own tennis academy in Bangkok where she coaches about 100 young players.

"Our main goal is to support the World Aquatics Championships as best as we can and make sure that everything runs smoothly, so that Singapore can shine brightly as a world-class host and sports destination," says Mazda Singapore managing director Chong Kah Wei.

site_title: Rupiah sinks to 5-year low as Trump tariffs, Prabowo’s fiscal plans rattle markets
summary: Indonesia's rupiah hit a 5-year low on February 28, falling 0.74% to 16,568 against the US dollar, amid escalating trade tensions and uncertainty over Jakarta's fiscal policies. The US-China crossfire, led by Donald Trump's tariffs, has spooked foreign investors, pulling out of stocks and contributing to the rupiah's underperformance. Bank Indonesia is facing a growing dilemma: defend the rupiah or loosen policy further to prop up growth, with President Prabowo Subianto's fiscal tightrope act heightening concerns among investors.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
A helicopter flies over Indonesia's capital Jakarta. The nation’s housing market is expected to remain strong for the rest of 2024.
At the launch event, Prabowo highlighted that the creation of Danantara marks a historic step for the country towards achieving prosperity.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices soften for a second month in January
summary: Hong Kong home prices fell 0.4% in January, marking a second consecutive month of decline, as potential buyers seek more positive market signals amid a weak economic outlook. The price drop is nearly 30% from 2021 peaks, driven by higher mortgage rates, reduced demand, and a weak economy. The government recently cut stamp duty for small home transactions, which could encourage first-time buyers and boost home transactions by 5-10%. Experts forecast home prices in 2025 could rise or fall 5% depending on interest rate cuts and trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Paul Chan (above), Hong Kong's financial secretary, emphasises artificial intelligence as a core industry.
Financial Secretary Paul Chan says the government will seek to cut regular spending by 7 per cent over the next three years, as falling land sales continue to hurt a key source of tax revenue.

Anthony Cheung, a former government minister, says that the challenge for Hong Kong is not just to balance its books, but to find fiscal sustainability amid US-China tensions and a slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: Singapore’s fiscal strength is a competitive advantage, not detrimental to Singaporeans: PM Wong
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the country's fiscal strength as a competitive advantage, stating it enables swift responses to unexpected shocks and crises. He countered opposition criticism of the government's accuracy in fiscal forecasts, citing the average deviation of 5% over the past decade. Wong also defended the goods and services tax hike, citing a need to plug the funding gap from higher projected expenditure. The government will allocate any surplus towards future needs or support for Singaporeans, with a focus on ensuring higher real incomes through a strong economy and productivity gains.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
PM Wong said the government will provide short-term support to businesses “without blunting the incentive for them to restructure”.
WP chief Pritam Singh calls for help with business rents, questions GST hike at start of Budget debate
PM Lawrence Wong arriving at Parliament House to deliver the Budget speech on Feb 18.
Eight MPs from the labour movement proposed measures to help various groups of workers.

site_title: Pagani unveils S$20 million masterpiece for purists here
summary: Pagani has unveiled the Utopia Roadster, a hypercar with a price tag of S$20 million, making it one of the most exclusive cars in the world. Only 130 units will be produced, with all examples already sold. The Utopia features a 6-litre twin-turbo V12 engine, a manual gearbox, and a unique design. Horacio Pagani, the company's founder, emphasized the car's focus on mechanical purity and beauty, defying industry trends. The Utopia represents the pinnacle of Pagani's obsession with creating a perfect car, and its exclusivity and price make it a true masterpiece.

images.alt_text: The Jaecoo J6's twin-motor set-up delivers 279 hp and 385 Nm, enough to give it seriously punchy acceleration.
The 911's performance has never come cheap, but the car's sales are stronger than ever. Last year, Porsche produced 50,941 911s – an all-time record.

site_title: New scheme for public tenders covering both pilot and deployment phases; simpler tenders for construction, ICT
summary: Singapore has introduced changes to its public tender system to make government procurement more accessible to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). A new Innovative Procurement Partnership will cover both pilot and deployment phases, allowing businesses to scale up innovative products or services if the pilot is successful. Additionally, a Tender Lite scheme will be extended to construction and infocomm technology contracts, offering simpler conditions and reduced risks for businesses. These changes aim to ease access to government contracts and promote entrepreneurship.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
PM Wong said the government will provide short-term support to businesses “without blunting the incentive for them to restructure”.

site_title: British Airways owner IAG launches 1 billion euro share buyback
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways, launched a 1 billion euro share buyback plan after reporting a 27% jump in annual operating profit, beating market expectations. Adjusted operating profit reached 4.44 billion euros, surpassing analysts' predictions of 4.08 billion euros. The company attributes its success to its effective strategy and transformation program, which has enabled it to outperform its European rivals. IAG is confident in delivering strong margins and returns despite the challenges faced by European airlines due to spiralling costs and delivery delays.

images.alt_text: British Airways, which is owned by IAG, said on its official X account that it did not have a timeframe on when it expects the issue to be resolved.

site_title: China’s Chery Automobile applies for Hong Kong IPO
summary: China's Chery Automobile has applied for an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong to raise funds for new vehicle development and global expansion. The company, China's largest exporter of passenger vehicles in 2023 and 2024, reported a 59% increase in net profit to 11.3 billion yuan and a 68% surge in revenue to 182.2 billion yuan in the first nine months of 2024. Chery's main export markets are Russia and Turkey, and the company considers the risk of being sanctioned by the US for operating in Russia low.

images.alt_text: Chery Holding Group has selected JPMorgan as it moves forward with an initial public offering of Chery Automobile, which could help it raise up to US$1 billion.

In addition to finished car imports into Russia, Chery, which makes up almost a fifth of Russia’s passenger car sales, is importing nearly finished cars and completing the assembly in three Russian factories.
The new plan has caused friction with workers who were promised more than 600 full-time jobs,  with Chery's all-electric Omoda 5 rolling out in the fourth quarter of this year.

site_title: Minority shareholders request UOI to distribute Haw Par shares, unlock shareholder value
summary: Minority shareholders of United Overseas Insurance (UOI) have proposed resolutions to be tabled at the insurer's upcoming AGM, seeking to distribute Haw Par shares to unlock shareholder value. The group, led by independent investor Ong Chin Woo, aims to distribute 4.27 million shares of Haw Par Corporation to UOI shareholders, which could help mitigate investment concentration risk while preserving cash for operational needs. The proposal also includes appointing an independent financial adviser to facilitate informed investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
CMG20230824-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 /  大华银行 United Overseas Bank (UOB)  [Raffles Place]
OCBC has always emphasised the importance of Great Eastern as one of its strategic pillars.
The rationale for insurance groups Great Eastern Holdings and United Overseas Inusrance to remain listed on the local bourse is weak.
The insurer's total weighted new sales in Q4 fell 16% to S$432.7 million from S$514.1 million.
Helen Wong says: “We know a balanced portfolio can help us to overcome, in particular, the uncertainty and the volatility in the market over the next decade.”

site_title: How cheap can investing get?
summary: Fees on new exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are rising, contradicting decades-long trends of decreasing costs. Most new ETFs have fees of 0.5% or higher, even though some larger, more established funds offer fees as low as 0.03%. The industry's model, which emphasizes low fees for retail investors, may not be over, as investors can still opt for cheaper, more traditional ETFs or diversify into larger funds with lower fees. However, some new funds, such as those tracking niche or actively managed indices, may charge higher fees due to complexity and lack of scale.

images.alt_text: Vanguard unleashed its largest-ever fee reduction this week, slashing its average asset-weighted expense ratio to just 0.07 per cent across its US$10 trillion under management – a sliver of the industry average of 0.44 per cent.

site_title: Europe: Shares close 10th week higher; focus remains on US tariffs
summary: European shares closed flat at 557.19 points but extended their 10th consecutive weekly gain, driven by a slowdown in US inflation and optimism around Russia-Ukraine peace talks. Despite trade tariff threats from US President Trump, luxury stocks like LVMH and Christian Dior rose, while mining stocks declined due to lower gold and copper prices. The European Central Bank is expected to cut interest rates by at least 25 basis points next week, supporting the market's recovery.

images.alt_text: German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, February 11, 2025.    REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Does airline loyalty pay? Frequent fliers take off for more rewarding horizons
summary: Airlines are reevaluating their loyalty programs due to customer dissatisfaction, with some carriers making changes to their frequent flier programs to appease irate customers. British Airways recently revised its Gold rank requirement to be spending-based, while Singapore Airlines (SIA) has changed its criteria for its KrisFlyer program. This shift is attributed to the realization that accruing miles may no longer be a travel hack, as airlines are monetizing benefits and making it harder to qualify for elite status. Experts argue that loyalty programs have become niche, and the pursuit of elite status may not be worth it for average travelers.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Media roundtable with SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong at SIA Training Centre on May 30, 2023.
SIA extends loyalty memberships for 3rd year, adds benefits

site_title: LBC rates up average 0.1% to 3% for commercial, residential, industrial and hotel use groups
summary: The Singapore government has raised land betterment charge (LBC) rates for various use groups, with commercial use groups seeing a 0.1% to 3% average increase, while the place of worship and civic and community institution use group has seen a 6% average increase. LBC rates for landed residential use have risen by 2.9% on average, and for non-landed residential use, they have increased by 0.3%. The rate changes are attributed to the growth in Singapore's land value and the sale of high-value sites. The adjustments will be in effect for the next six months.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Generic pictures of private properties in Singapore.
Generic pictures of Singapore Skyline
Margins are at a point where one could question the rationale for continuing the Singapore private housing business.
Generic photos for Budget 2024

site_title: Jaecoo J6 review: A box of surprises
summary: The Jaecoo J6, a Chinese electric sport utility vehicle, boasts a chunky design and twin-motor setup delivering 279 hp and 385 Nm, offering punchy acceleration. While it handles more like a 4x4, it lacks refinement and precision, with a fiddly user interface and wind noise at highway speeds. However, the J6 has a surprisingly posh interior and ample cargo space, making it a charmer for those who want a rugged, off-road-inspired vehicle. With a range of 342 km and a price of S$192,888, the J6 is a unique option for those seeking a post-combustion era vehicle.

images.alt_text: The 911's performance has never come cheap, but the car's sales are stronger than ever. Last year, Porsche produced 50,941 911s – an all-time record.

site_title: UMS posts 29% drop in Q4 earnings to S$11.1 million
summary: UMS Integration, a semiconductor equipment manufacturing and engineering services provider, posted a 29% year-on-year drop in Q4 earnings to S$11.1 million due to lower revenue and higher expenses. Revenue declined 9% to S$67.2 million, primarily affected by a decline in semiconductor integrated system sales and the material and tooling distribution business. The company expects "significant" improvement in delivery with the ramp-up of its new 300,000-square-foot production facility in Penang, which is operational.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
UMS Integration says it managed to secure more orders from a new major customer in Malaysia, with new product introductions in the coming months.
Property developers, tech firms and Sarawak-focused companies have emerged as top performers in Bursa Malaysia this year.

site_title: Malaysia’s palm oil giant FGV expects higher profit margins in 2025
summary: Malaysia's palm oil giant FGV Holdings expects higher profit margins in 2025 due to improved productivity and elevated palm prices in the first half of the year. The company's 2024 revenues rose to RM22.2 billion from RM19.4 billion in 2023, with a final dividend payment of 5 cents a share. Production of fresh fruit bunches from FGV's own palm oil crop is expected to grow between 5% and 8% in 2025, driven by palm oil's premium prices due to supply disruptions in Indonesia and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: XXX
The weather woes have raised concerns about palm oil’s availability ahead of the Ramadan and Eid al-Fitr holidays, which typically drive up consumption.

Malaysia’s exports of palm oil to China declined in 2024 due to lower soybean prices compared to palm oil and lower consumption of cooking oil, says Deputy Minister of Plantation and Commodities Chan Foong Hin.

FILE PHOTO: A worker pushes a wheelbarrow of fresh fruit bunches of oil palm tree during harvest at a palm oil plantation in Kuala Selangor, Selangor, Malaysia April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo
Above: Harvested palm oil fruit. The company says crude palm oil prices will continue to be influenced by shifts in supply and demand, and currency and financial market uncertainty.
Market watchers have revised CPO price forecasts in 2025 on limited production increase.
In November, Malaysia’s CPO production declined 9.8 per cent from a month ago to 1.62 million metric tons, the lowest for the month since 2020.

Palm oil production in Malaysia may slump as much as 10 per cent during the first 25 days of November from a month earlier due to rain.
Malaysia, the world’s second-largest palm oil producer, is in a strategic position to become one of the world’s leading SAF producers.

site_title: Singapore hedge fund with 33% gain bets big on Suzuki Motor
summary: A Singapore-based hedge fund, Kings Court Capital, has invested in Suzuki Motor, citing the Japanese automaker's robust India strategy as a key factor in its 33% gain last year. Suzuki's limited US and China exposure makes it less vulnerable to global trade risks, including US tariffs and the rise of Chinese electric vehicles. The fund's portfolio is 70% invested in Japanese stocks, with Suzuki being its top long holding, and it expects petrol cars and hybrids to remain in demand in India for the foreseeable future.

images.alt_text: Suzuki now faces renewed competition in India from both local and foreign automakers with more attractive hybrid and electric car offerings.
Osamu Suzuki got his start in the automotive business thanks to his arranged marriage to Shoko Suzuki, a granddaughter of Michio Suzuki, who founded Suzuki Motor’s predecessor.
The Alto currently weighs 680 kg and the company hopes to lower that by 100 kg.

site_title: Why Mexican manufacturers seem unfazed by threat of Trump tariffs
summary: Mexican manufacturers remain optimistic about their business relationship with the US despite the impending 25% tariffs on Mexican imports, set to take effect on Tuesday. The value of Mexico's exports to the US now exceeds its imports, making the industry less vulnerable to tariffs. Companies like SMK Electronica and BMW have invested heavily in Mexico and plan to continue doing so, citing long-term strategic decisions that pre-date Trump's presidency. The auto industry may be impacted by tariffs, but US-Mexico trade is seen as too big to fail, with major US companies like Ford maintaining production in Mexico.

images.alt_text: A worker cuts steel sheets at an auto parts manufacturer in San Luis Potosi, San Luis Potosi state, Mexico, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. US President Donald Trump's potential tariffs against Canada and Mexico will threaten production at automakers across North America and send record vehicle prices even higher. Photographer: Mauricio Palos/Bloomberg
US President Donald Trump said on Thursday (Feb 27) in a social media post that drugs from the country’s North American neighbours are still entering “at very high and unacceptable levels.”

site_title: Skype to shut down in May, 14 years after Microsoft’s US$8.5 billion purchase
summary: Microsoft will shut down Skype in May, 14 years after acquiring the service for $8.5 billion. The company's daily user count has dwindled from 36 million in 2023 to 36 million, surpassing smartphone-native apps and Zoom. Skype struggled in the workplace, losing out to Slack, and Microsoft is now shifting focus to Teams, a chat, voice, and video communication service for the workplace, which has gained 320 million monthly users. Users will be offered the option to migrate to Teams before Skype shuts down.

images.alt_text: The push towards AI comes as videogame development costs continue to rise.
Microsoft’s announcement indicates that its engineers have found a way to deploy the particles that make quantum computing possible in a system.
FILE PHOTO: The ChatGPT logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration taken January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Microsoft still retains the rights to most of the hosting of OpenAI’s models for commercial purposes.

site_title: China’s Zara tries going global in hopes of Shein-like success
summary: Urban Revivo, a Guangzhou-based Chinese apparel brand, plans to open its first US flagship store in New York City's Soho, marking its entry into the global market. The company aims to replicate the success of Chinese fashion giant Shein by expanding to 25 stores outside China this year, including two in London, and reaching 100 stores globally by next year. Urban Revivo's founder, Leo Li, aims to build a parallel supply chain to counter US President Donald Trump's punitive trade policies, and will start production in Turkey this year for Europe and the US market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shein and Temu app icons are seen in this illustration taken August 22, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
Shein’s net profit was down almost 40 per cent at US$1 billion in 2024, the report said, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.
Shein shareholders are suggesting that an adjustment is needed to help get its potential initial public offering in the UK over the line.

site_title: Thailand picks central bank board chair after contentious search
summary: Thailand's Bank of Thailand (BOT) has appointed 63-year-old Somchai Sujjapongse as the new chairman of its 12-member board, following a contentious selection process. Somchai was a compromise candidate proposed by the Ministry of Finance after the government's initial pick, former Finance Minister Kittiratt Na-Ranong, was opposed by former governors and economists. As chairman, Somchai will have a say in rate-setting and financial institutions committees, but not directly in monetary policy. His appointment is seen as a bid by Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra's administration to exert influence over the central bank.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand logo is pictured in Bangkok, Thailand, January 30, 2025. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa

site_title: Citigroup mistakenly credits customer account US$81 trillion in ‘near miss’, FT reports
summary: Citigroup mistakenly credited a customer's account with $81 trillion instead of $280, a "near miss" that highlights the bank's operational issues. The error, discovered three hours after processing, was reversed after a third employee caught it. The incident, which occurred in April, was disclosed to the Federal Reserve and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. Despite the mistake, Citi reported a decrease in near misses of $1 billion or more to 10 last year, down from 13 the previous year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers exit the Citi Headquarters in New York, U.S., January 22, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: The disciplined pursuit of cybersecurity innovation
summary: Cybersecurity innovation is crucial to stay ahead of evolving threats, and AI-driven tools are revolutionizing the approach to defense. The industry has shifted from basic firewalls and encryption to sophisticated AI-powered tools that predict, detect, and neutralize threats in real-time. Companies must balance incremental and disruptive innovation to ensure steady progress and prepare for the future. Purposeful and systematic innovation, coupled with diligent execution, is key to translating ideas into value-creating products or services. Ensign InfoSecurity's approach harnesses researchers' discontent and customer feedback to drive innovation, resulting in patented AI-powered cyberanalytics solutions.

images.alt_text: Ensign Labs vice-president of machine learning and cloud research Lee Joon Sern demonstrates the use of Aletheia, a real-time deepfake detection solution developed by Ensign.
Battling scams has mainly been left up to banks, which have spent heavily on compensating customers and investing in education and warning systems.
Today, cybersecurity approaches tend to adopt a layered approach to defence. In doing so, they often overlook the most fundamental element of all network communications: DNS.

site_title: EFishery ex-CEO shows salary slips to refute claims of billion-rupiah salary
summary: EFishery co-founder and ousted CEO Gibran Huzaifah has denied media reports claiming he received a gross monthly salary of 1.28 billion rupiah (US$77,000) in 2024, stating the amount is "untrue" and citing his actual salary slips showing around 313 million rupiah (US$19,138) per month. Huzaifah's bank statements also confirm his take-home pay was around 206 million rupiah (US$12,550) per month. The discrepancy raises questions about the accuracy of a "forensic investigation document" used to support the claims.

images.alt_text: The company, which deploys feeders to fish and shrimp farmers in Indonesia, incurred several hundred million dollars in losses between 2018 and 2024 and misrepresented its financial figures for years.
A recent internal probe into the startup alleged that eFishery inflated its revenue and profit over several years.

site_title: US consumer spending falls in January; monthly inflation rises
summary: US consumer spending dropped 0.2% in January, following a revised 0.8% increase in December, and inflation rose 0.3% for the month, matching expectations. The moderation in annual inflation is unlikely to be sustained due to President Trump's administration increasing tariffs on imports, which economists warn will raise prices. Consumer inflation expectations soared in February, and economists expect the Federal Reserve to resume cutting interest rates in June, despite a slowdown in economic growth in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: The report showcases an economy that continued to expand at a solid pace on the shoulders of resilient consumer spending.

site_title: Corporate governance risks and opportunities in CDL’s family feud
summary: A family feud is brewing at City Developments Ltd (CDL), with executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng accusing his son and CEO Sherman Kwek of attempting a "coup" by bypassing the nominating committee to make major changes to the board. Sherman Kwek denies the allegations, citing a dispute over the role of Dr Catherine Wu, Kwek Leng Beng's adviser. The dispute raises corporate governance concerns, potentially affecting CDL's ESG ratings and indices, and investors may face higher risks of stock downgrades. The outcome could have significant implications for CDL's operations and minority shareholders.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim

CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng (right) said he has filed court papers to deal with the attempted coup by Sherman Kwek, Philip Lee, Wong Ai Ai and a group of directors acting with them to allegedly consolidate control of the board and the group.
CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng (right) and group chief executive Sherman Kwek.
Catherine Wu, adviser to the board of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels, and CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng at GeekCon, a cybersecurity hackathon held in Singapore in May 2024.
CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng said he has filed court papers on Feb 25 to deal with the “attempted coup” by his son and group chief executive, Sherman Kwek.
Dr Catherine Wu graced the cover of a magazine in Taiwan.

site_title: China, Hong Kong stocks close the week lower on fresh Trump tariffs, focus on NPC meeting
summary: China and Hong Kong stocks closed the week lower, ending weeks of gains, as US President Donald Trump announced fresh tariffs on Chinese imports, escalating geopolitical tensions. The Hang Seng Index slumped 3% and the CSI 300 Index fell 2% on Friday, with tech stocks declining 5.3% and AI shares losing 6%. Investors shifted focus to the upcoming National People's Congress meeting, where Premier Li Qiang is expected to announce an unchanged 2025 growth target of 5%.

images.alt_text: Washington has already imposed anti-dumping duties on multiple Vietnamese steel exports and producers, in some cases even higher than 25 per cent
Demand has been a long-running drag on the world’s second-largest economy, fuelling a deflationary spiral that has kept prices stubbornly low.
US President Donald Trump said on Thursday (Feb 27) in a social media post that drugs from the country’s North American neighbours are still entering “at very high and unacceptable levels.”
US data show that imports from China declined to 13.4 per cent of total imports in 2024 from 21.6 per cent in 2018.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng’s H2 profit up 9% on Oatly compensation, higher sales
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's (YHS) 6-month net profit rose 9% to S$3.7 million, driven by higher sales volumes in Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia, and compensation from oat milk maker Oatly. Revenue increased 7.7% to S$163.2 million. The company plans to focus on higher-margin products and improve operational efficiency, with a proposed final dividend of S$0.02 per share.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Yeo Hiap Seng says that the affected employees were "specifically hired" to support Oatly’s production at its  Senoko plant.

site_title: HPL swings into the black with S$32.1 million H2 net profit, reversing H1 loss
summary: HPL, a Singapore-based hotel operator, reported a net profit of S$32.1 million for the second half of 2024, reversing a net loss of S$4.9 million in the first half. The company's earnings per share (EPS) decreased to S$0.0547, down from S$1.1024 in 2023. Revenue grew 7% to S$345.6 million, but finance costs widened due to higher borrowings and interest rates. A final dividend of S$0.04 per share was proposed, subject to shareholder approval.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Forum The Shopping Mall may be redeveloped as part of a mixed-use redevelopment by Hotel Properties Limited

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 28)
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of maintaining public finances and raising revenues to meet new demands. He stated that the country's fiscal strength is a competitive advantage, not a detriment to its citizens. Meanwhile, Genting Malaysia's CEO, Lim Kok Thay, will step down after nearly two decades. The Singapore government has expressed its full confidence and support for its mission to stay relevant.

images.alt_text: More investment will go to developing “bilingual” scientific talent: researchers with expertise in both AI and domain knowledge.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng to plead guilty on Apr 2
summary: Property tycoon Ong Beng Seng, 79, will plead guilty to two criminal charges related to dealings with former transport minister S Iswaran on Apr 2. The charges include abetting an offence under Section 165, related to a US$7,700 private jet flight and hotel stay in December 2022. Ong Beng Seng's bail of S$800,000 has been extended as he receives treatment for a rare form of white blood cancer.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Forum The Shopping Mall may be redeveloped as part of a mixed-use redevelopment by Hotel Properties Limited

site_title: Consumer lending unlocked: Opportunities and risks in a US$27 trillion market
summary: The US consumer lending market has grown to a $27 trillion market, with exponential growth predicted to reach $40 trillion by Apollo Global's Akila Grewal. Consumer loans have become a dynamic segment, evolving alongside technology and consumer behavior, offering investors diverse opportunities. However, this growth also brings unique challenges, including navigating new risk-return profiles, addressing gaps in regulation and transparency. Emerging products like buy now, pay later (BNPL) loans pose challenges due to their ultra-short maturities and interest-free structures, introducing risks for lenders and investors. Regulatory frameworks must adapt to address the complexities introduced by new products and platforms.

images.alt_text: Alfonso Ricciardelli

Bank of America’s buildup of advisory work on upcoming mergers and acquisitions is strong, while its pipelines for IPOs “are full and ready to go,” CEO Brian Moynihan told attendees at the Clearing House Annual Conference, New York City, US, Nov 13, 2024..
Despite the recent backlash against ESG investing, so-called “green” investments in clean energy, climate mitigation, and resilience continue to increase.
Retail investors are trading speculative investments like binary options and cryptocurrencies. Though liquid, these assets are complex, risky and no safer than the options in private markets.

site_title: Mother and son jailed 2 weeks each over lying in ‘99-to-1’ property purchase arrangement
summary: A Singapore mother and son, Ng Chiew Yen and Keith Tan, have been sentenced to two weeks' imprisonment each for providing false information to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) during an audit of a "99-to-1" property purchase arrangement. The arrangement, which involves selling a small share of a property to avoid Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD), is punishable with a maximum sentence of two years in prison or a fine of up to S$10,000. This is the first prosecution and conviction of its kind in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Ng Chiew Yen (left) and Keith Tan Kai Wen arriving at the State Courts on Sept 20, 2024.
PropNex's wholly owned unit PropNex Realty has been named as one of the three co-defendants.

site_title: Straits Trading’s H2 loss narrows to S$12.5 million from S$43.5 million
summary: Straits Trading Company reported a narrower loss of S$12.5 million for the second half of 2024, compared to S$43.5 million in the previous year. Revenue increased 22% to S$312.1 million, driven by higher tin prices and sales, as well as a profitable real estate segment. The company's net fair value of investment properties improved to S$7.7 million. A proposed interim dividend of S$0.08 per share is expected, with a full-year loss of S$7.2 million and revenue 14.8% higher at S$564.6 million.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The company launched a S$55 million multicurrency debt issuance programme last year to issue digital securities.

site_title: Thai factory output beats expectations in January but car output slump weighs
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) dropped 0.85% in January from a year earlier, beating expectations, but was influenced by a continued slump in car output. The industry ministry attributed the decline to government stimulus measures supporting confidence, investment, and consumption. In a separate move, Thailand is in early discussions with carmakers to introduce a car trade-in and scrapping scheme to revive the industry, which has faced its biggest crisis in decades.

images.alt_text: Foreign tourists take photographs at a shopping district in Bangkok, Thailand, Feb 24, 2025.
Thai exports increased 13.6 per cent in January from a year earlier, beating a forecast for a 7.15 per cent rise in a Reuters poll, and compared with December’s 8.7 per cent increase.

FILE PHOTO: EV cars are pictured inside BYD's first electric vehicle (EV) factory in Southeast Asia, a fast-growing regional EV market where it has become the dominant player, in Rayong, Thailand, July 4, 2024. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo

site_title: Bank of Japan vows to keep tapering bond buying despite rise in yields
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) will maintain its tapering of government bond purchases despite rising yields, according to deputy governor Shinichi Uchida. The central bank is keeping its stance on short-term interest rates and bond operations unchanged, citing the strong stimulus effect of its huge bond holdings on the economy. The BOJ expects Japan's economy to recover moderately and inflation to accelerate towards its 2% target, with a possible rate hike in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Hedging costs for Japanese investors having largely fallen since October.
Bank of Japan board member Hajime Takata said the BOJ must keep raising interest rates if companies continue to increase prices, wages and investment.
The BOJ began to buy the stock funds in December 2010 as part of a monetary stimulus programme aimed at stoking inflation.

site_title: Singapore shares fall as trade tariff concerns re-emerge overnight; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.7% on Friday, Feb 28, as investors reassessed the potential impact of US tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump. The Straits Times Index (STI) lost 25.49 points to 3,895.70, with 379 losers beating 226 gainers. Market strategist Yeap Jun Rong said US tariffs pose downside risks to global growth, potentially bringing higher business costs and weaker trade activities. Regional markets also fell, with South Korea's Kospi and Hong Kong's Hang Seng down 3.4% and 3.3%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
United states US home housing property Photographer: Sam Hall/Bloomberg

“The Fed’s job is to monitor and adapt to the conditions, whatever they are,” Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee told AFP in an interview, adding that the independent US central bank had made “a lot of progress” on inflation.
Seatrium has proposed a final dividend of S$0.015 per share. It will be paid on May 19, after the record date of May 7.
As at end-2024, ST Engineering's order book stood at S$28.5 billion.

site_title: Asian chip shares tumble on Nvidia earnings, tariff fears
summary: Asian chip stocks plummeted on Friday, February 28, 2025, after Nvidia's earnings and US tariff fears took a toll. Nvidia's 8.5% drop in New York, citing tighter profit margins, led to a 4.5% decline in Japan's chip-related stocks, with Disco Corp. falling 12%. SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics in South Korea also tumbled 4.8% and 2.3%, respectively, while Foxconn Industrial Internet and Sunny Optical in China dropped 4.3% and 5%, respectively. Global trade war concerns, fueled by US President Trump's tariff announcements, contributed to the market downturn.

images.alt_text: The Nvidia Corp.'s logo on the company's Blackwell GPU chip displayed at the Nvidia AI Summit Japan on Wednesday, Nov. 13, 2024. SoftBank will be the first Nvidia customer to build a supercomputer based on the chipmaker’s new Blackwell design, a move to meet growing demand in a country eager to catch up in artificial intelligence. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Chinese banks heed PBOC call to cut dollar deposit rates
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has instructed banks across the country to cut dollar deposit rates, aiming to curb dollar hoarding and prop up a weakening yuan. The move comes as onshore dollar deposits have risen to nearly $1 trillion, with some banks announcing rate cuts. The PBOC's guidance is seen as an effort to reduce the yield gap between the US and China, which has eroded the yuan's appeal with onshore investors, and to encourage more conversion of dollars into yuan.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China has not cut interest rates in nearly half a year despite its most pro-easing stance in 14 years.
Yields have been rising as the PBOC held back on further monetary easing to prioritise yuan stability in the wake of a renewed trade war with the US.
Spot gold was up 0.2 per cent at US$2,847.33 per ounce.

site_title: TikTok to invest US$8.8 billion in Thailand over five years
summary: TikTok plans to invest US$8.8 billion in Thailand over five years, focusing on digital infrastructure, workforce development, and online safety initiatives. The investment includes training programs, anti-fraud campaigns, and a new data hosting service. This move comes as TikTok faces potential US ban over data security concerns and follows major tech investments by Amazon, Google, and Microsoft in the country. Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra hailed the investment as a major opportunity for the country to position itself as a global hub for the digital industry.

images.alt_text: Despite TikTok Shop’s breakneck growth, the video app’s future in the US is at doubt, given the continued threat of a ban should it fail to sell the US portion of its business.

site_title: Temasek-backed companies should not face obligation to list in Singapore: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat stated that Temasek-backed companies should not be obligated to list on the Singapore Exchange, citing the need to preserve Singapore's attractiveness to founders and investors. He emphasized that commercial objectives should guide company decisions, rather than government pressure. Chee also proposed strengthening corporate governance standards and investor education, while the MAS review group will focus on improving shareholder engagement and enhancing investor recourse.

images.alt_text: Budget 2025: Enhancing our Technology and Innovation Engines; Strengthening our Enterprise Ecosystem; Supporting our Enterprises in Workforce Transformation
Ranamita Chakraborty

site_title: Costs and competition are unavoidable, but the government will help businesses transform: PM Wong
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for businesses to transform amidst rising global uncertainty and competition. The government will provide short-term support to businesses willing to restructure, citing measures such as a corporate income tax rebate and topping up the National Productivity Fund. Wong also highlighted the importance of improving productivity and adapting to technological changes, warning against xenophobia and emphasizing the government's support for workers to adapt to change through initiatives like SkillsFuture.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Eight MPs from the labour movement proposed measures to help various groups of workers.
WP chief Pritam Singh calls for help with business rents, questions GST hike at start of Budget debate

site_title: US: Wall St opens subdued after in-line inflation data
summary: US stocks opened subdued on Friday, February 28, after data showed inflation rose as expected in January. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.05%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell 0.08% and 0.36%, respectively. Investors remained cautious due to concerns about US President Donald Trump's policies potentially fueling price pressures.

site_title: SGX sees ‘robust’ IPO pipeline as Singapore explores ‘sweet spot’ to draw listings
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) expects a "robust" initial public offering (IPO) pipeline as the country seeks to attract listings from regional firms. The bourse's head of global sales and origination, Pol de Win, notes that Singapore must find its "sweet spot" to compete with other South-east Asian bourses. The IPO market has been quiet for three years, but de Win expects a positive ripple effect from the US, where IPOs are starting to pick up. Companies in the "new economy" space, such as tech-focused industries, are expected to play a larger role, and SGX is working to attract regional firms seeking access to international markets.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
Budget 2025: Enhancing our Technology and Innovation Engines; Strengthening our Enterprise Ecosystem; Supporting our Enterprises in Workforce Transformation
On Friday (Feb 21), the MAS review group announced that it will inject S$5 billion into a programme for fund managers to invest in Singapore equities, in a bid to boost liquidity.
In 2024, 17 companies listed on the SGX were the subject of privatisation offers.

site_title: Far East Orchard H2 net profit down 29.4% on lower fair value gains, higher costs
summary: Far East Orchard's net profit fell 29.4% to S$40.7 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2024, due to lower fair value gains and higher expenses. Revenue rose 1.9% to S$94.5 million, driven by rental growth in the PBSA segment. The company proposed a first and final dividend of S$0.04 per share and a special dividend of S$0.01 per share. Despite headwinds, including lower international student acceptance and weaker hospitality segment performance, Far East Orchard expects a "flattening" of rent and room rate growth as it scales its lodging platform.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
In a bourse filing on Friday (Jan 24), FEO said Tannery and FECE agreed to purchase all of Sekisui House’s interest in Woodlands Square.

site_title: Indonesia to strongly intervene as rupiah drops to five-year low
summary: Indonesia's central bank pledged to intervene strongly in the foreign exchange market after the rupiah dropped to its lowest level in almost five years, falling 0.7% to 16,568. The currency has slumped 3% this year, the worst performance among major emerging-Asian peers, due to US tariffs on Canada and Mexico set to take effect next week and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's easing cycle. Authorities will enter the market to maintain balance and confidence, amid growing pressure from US President Trump's trade policies.

site_title: Hong Fok’s H2 net profit plummets 75.2% as revaluation gain dives
summary: Hong Fok's H2 net profit plummeted 75.2% to S$20.1 million, largely due to a 86.4% decline in revaluation gain on investment properties. Revenue remained flat at S$59.7 million, despite a 6% fall in revenue from the sale of its residential units in Concourse Skyline.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Property developer Hong Fok Corporation has acquired five ground-floor units at International Building for S$27.8 million.
Hong Fok, which has a market cap of S$879.3 million, has businesses in property investment, property development and construction, and property management.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on Friday, shrugging off Trump-Zelensky clash
summary: US stocks closed the week on a positive note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.4% at 43,840.91, the S&P 500 gaining 1.6% to 5,954.50, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 1.6% to 18,847.28. The rally came despite a public clash between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky, with investors shrugging off concerns. The late-session surge was attributed to "short-covering" after heavy selling in recent days, and was also encouraged by US inflation data not showing an uptick in pricing pressures.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index ended flat at 557.19 points on Friday but closed higher for the week and extended its longest winning streak since early 2024.

site_title: Oil falls on White House spat, tariffs, Iraq exports
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, marking the first monthly drop since November, amid a White House spat between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, and the announcement of Iraq's resumption of oil exports from the Kurdistan region. Brent crude futures settled at $73.18 a barrel, down 86 cents, or 1.16%, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures finished at $69.76 a barrel, losing 59 cents, or 0.84%. The market volatility is attributed to the US tariffs on Mexican and Canadian goods, as well as rising concerns about global demand.

images.alt_text: FGV, one of the world’s biggest palm oil producers, said 2024 revenues rose to RM22.2 billion from RM19.4 billion in 2023, with a final dividend payment of 5 cents a share.
Brent crude oil futures settled up US$1.51, or 2.1 per cent, at US$74.04 a barrel.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble as Trump tariff salvo fans fresh fears
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Friday as US President Donald Trump's new tariff measures sparked fresh fears of a global trade war, causing Tokyo to shed 3% and Shanghai to fall. The losses were exacerbated by disappointing earnings from Nvidia and concerns over a potential slowdown in the global economy. Economists warn that Trump's plans to slash taxes, regulations, and immigration will reignite inflation, while investors seek alternative growth opportunities in China's tech sector.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong retreated on Thursday as investors took a breather following a thundering start to the year, while there were also losses in Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Jakarta.

site_title: Trump compares UK’s demand for Apple user data to Chinese monitoring
summary: US President Donald Trump compared the UK's demand for Apple user data to those made by China, stating he told British Prime Minister Keir Starmer he "can't do this". This comes after Apple ended an advanced security encryption feature for cloud data for UK users in response to government demands. A US intelligence official has reportedly examined whether the UK government violated the Cloud Act, which bars issuing demands for US citizen data. The UK government has maintained a close intelligence relationship with the US, but did not comment on the specifics of the Apple case.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and U.S. President Donald Trump shake hands during a joint press conference in the East Room at the White House, February 27, 2025 in Washington, D.C., U.S. Carl Court/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: HP sees weaker profit on tariffs; will cut over 1,000 jobs
summary: HP has reported weaker-than-expected profits due to rising component costs and US tariffs on imports from China. The company will cut 1,000 to 2,000 jobs and make "specific adjustments" to product pricing. Despite a 10% expansion in business computer sales, revenue growth is expected to be impacted by tariffs, with less than 10% of North American goods sold coming from China by the end of the fiscal year. The company reaffirmed its 2025 free cash flow and annual profit guidance.

images.alt_text: HP has touted cost, security and speed as benefits of delivering some generative AI features locally, rather than through the cloud.
Dell fell 13 per cent in trading before the bell, with the company set to shed nearly US$13 billion from its US$99.50 billion market value, after it forecast quarterly revenue below estimates.
PC makers had hoped that new machines touted as better for artificial intelligence workloads would spur demand.

site_title: Seven & i plots Europe growth as Couche-Tard bid pressure mounts
summary: Seven & i Holdings, a Tokyo-based operator of convenience stores and supermarkets, aims to expand in Europe and add 10 more nations by fiscal 2030, with a focus on investing in local companies. The company faces pressure from a proposed takeover by Alimentation Couche-Tard, and is also considering a joint venture with other businesses to enter European markets. Seven & i has already set up stores in Scandinavia and plans to re-enter Indonesia "at all costs" after its withdrawal in 2017.

images.alt_text: The failure of Seven & I Holdings' buyout heightens the likelihood of Couche-Tard pulling off a mammoth acquisition of one of Japan’s best-known and most beloved retailers, which owns 7-Eleven convenience stores.
The retailer has sought to separate non-core businesses that include its supermarket operations into York Holdings.
In the 1970s, Seven & i imported the convenience-store concept and improved on it over the following decades, making them ubiquitous and essential to daily life in Japan.
Seven & i’s market capitalisation was around 6.2 trillion yen as at Thursday.

site_title: China’s leaders gather to hash out Trump tariff battle plans
summary: China's leaders will convene for closed-door meetings to discuss plans to shield the ailing economy from US President Donald Trump's tariffs and trade threats. The "Two Sessions" gatherings will provide a rare glimpse into the leadership's priorities, which face an unpredictable US-China trade relationship. Demand has been a long-running drag on China's economy, fueling a deflationary spiral and keeping prices low. Policymakers are under pressure to address this issue and slow the country's GDP growth, which is set to slow in 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Chinese national flag is seen in Beijing, China April 29, 2020. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: IHH Healthcare ‘on track’ for double-digit ROE despite medical inflation woes
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysian integrated healthcare operator, is "on track" to achieve double-digit return on equity (ROE) in the coming years, according to its management. Despite medical inflation woes in Malaysia, which reached 15% in 2024, the group expects the situation to stabilize over time. IHH Healthcare reported a net profit of RM732 million for the quarter ended Dec 31, up 1% from the previous year. The company's ROE for FY2024 stood at 8.7%, while its total dividend increased by 11% to RM0.10 per share.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
The group declared a final dividend per share of RM0.055, to be paid on Apr 28.
The quality of foreign operators that come to China will be also crucial for the development of the sector.

NTK in October 2023 filed a lawsuit in the Tokyo District Court alleging that Daiichi Sankyo caused losses by preventing NTK from proceeding with open offers to buy a stake in Indian hospital network Fortis Healthcare in 2018.

The plan comes as healthcare assets across South-east Asia gain favour with investors betting on the region’s growing affluence and ageing population while eyeing the sector’s potential to weather challenging economic conditions.

site_title: When being the China alternative isn’t enough
summary: US President Donald Trump's policies signal a shift away from globalization and towards regional alignments, as he imposes tariffs on Canada and Mexico and seeks to curb China's access to US industries. This represents a new era of "nearshoring" where goods are manufactured closer to their final destinations, rather than relying on supply chains that transit through friendly partners. As China remains the world's largest manufacturer, this shift may lead to a decline in US manufacturing and a rise in regional trade, with Asia being pulled further into China's orbit.

images.alt_text: Singapore remained the most attractive destination for global investors, the investment inflows accounting for over 60 per cent of FDI in the Asean region.
Restructuring the supply chains of SME globally will need a vast amount of long-term capital infusion.
US President Donald Trump said on Thursday (Feb 27) in a social media post that drugs from the country’s North American neighbours are still entering “at very high and unacceptable levels.”

site_title: Issue 137: CDL’s governance red flag; S-E Asia bullish on sustainable finance
summary: A family feud at City Developments Ltd (CDL) has raised corporate governance red flags, potentially affecting ESG ratings and indices. The dispute involves controlling family members Sherman Kwek and Kwek Leng Beng, who are father and son, over board appointments and the role of Catherine Wu, an adviser to the board. The situation may lead to a prolonged fight for control, affecting CDL's leadership and minority shareholders' rights. Meanwhile, sustainable finance in Southeast Asia is expected to continue growing, driven by government support, regulatory stability, and increasing interest in transition finance and social development.
