site_title: Trump team weighs pulling funds for Moderna bird flu vaccine
summary: The US government is reviewing a $590 million contract for bird flu shots awarded to Moderna, amid a record-breaking outbreak affecting dozens of cattle herds and poultry flocks nationwide. The review is part of a broader push to examine spending on messenger RNA-based vaccines, as Moderna's Covid vaccine sales decline. The contract was awarded in the Biden administration's final days, sending Moderna's stock up 13% and raising concerns about the company's reliance on government funding.

images.alt_text: A sign at supermarket Trader Joe's hangs by cartons of eggs in Merrick, New York, Feb 10, 2025. Shipments of eggs to the US from Turkey began this month and will continue until July.
Genetic sequencing has shown that the H5N1 virus that infected the Louisiana patient was different from the version of the virus detected in many dairy herds and poultry farms around the country.
The USDA currently only requires testing of lactating dairy cattle moving across state lines, a requirement laid out in its only other federal bird flu order issued in April.
As bad as the Biden administration has been on pandemic prevention, of course, it's about to be replaced by something far worse.

site_title: Some analysts downgrade CDL, reduce price target on boardroom tussle
summary: Analysts downgrade City Developments Ltd (CDL) due to the ongoing boardroom tussle between executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and CEO Sherman Kwek, citing uncertainty about the company's strategic direction. DBS analysts reduce their target price to S$6.70 from S$10.50, citing a 60% discount to revalued net asset value (RNAV). Despite the uncertainty, analysts remain optimistic that CDL's core business will remain unaffected and that the company's fundamentals remain intact. A resolution to the feud is expected to lead to a gradual recovery in the group's share price.

images.alt_text: CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng said he has filed court papers on Feb 25 to deal with the “attempted coup” by his son and group chief executive, Sherman Kwek.
Chong Xin Wei

site_title: US multifamily homes, offices find favour among private equity investors
summary: US multifamily homes and offices are attracting private equity investors, including those from Asia, as demand for housing and office space increases due to rising migration and housing costs. Despite a modest growth in multifamily homes last year, Freddie Mac predicts a 2.2% rent rise in 2024. The US office sector is also gaining traction, with companies pushing employees to return to offices, boosted by the government's push for in-person work and corporate giants demanding five days a week at the office.

images.alt_text: United states US home housing property Photographer: Sam Hall/Bloomberg

site_title: Kwek family feud sours CDL’s prospects, but can catalyse value unlocking
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL), a Singapore-based property developer, is embroiled in a family feud between billionaire Kwek Leng Beng and his son Sherman Kwek, who serves as CEO. The dispute centers on corporate governance issues, including a $1.9 billion loss in 2020 and poor investment decisions. Kwek Leng Beng has filed court papers to remove Sherman as CEO and has appointed his nephew, Kwek Eik Sheng, as interim CEO. The conflict may catalyze value-unlocking moves, such as restructuring or a merger, potentially benefiting CDL's undervalued share price.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Kwek Leng Beng, executive chairman of Hong Leong Group Singapore during Sumiko's lunch interview at Hua Ting Restaurant in Orchard Hotel on Oct 20, 2023. In September 2019, Forbes estimated Kwek's net worth to be US$3.4 billion. Kwek is also the chairman of City Developments Limited (CDL), an international property and hotel conglomerate and the leading real estate developer in Singapore. It operates in 20 countries in Asia, Europe, North America and Australasia. CDL has over 250 subsidiaries and associated companies including 8 companies listed on the stock exchanges of Singapore, London, Hong Kong, Amsterdam, New Zealand and Manila. CDL has a market capitalization of US$5.8 billion and ranks just outside Singapore's top 10 listed companies. It is also the second-biggest property developer in Southeast Asia. [Lunch With Sumiko]
Leslie Yee

site_title: Axa plans up to 1.2 billion euro buyback as earnings beat estimates
summary: AXA reported a 6% increase in underlying earnings to 8 billion euros and a 10% rise in net income last year, beating analyst estimates. The company plans to repurchase up to 1.2 billion euros of stock this year and raise its dividend by 9%. AXA aims to achieve 6-8% average growth in underlying earnings per share and an underlying return on equity of 14-16% between 2024 and 2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A BNP Paribas sign is pictured on a building of the bank in Geneva November 26, 2014.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Bitcoin ETFs are hit by a record US$1 billion outflow in one day
summary: Bitcoin ETFs experienced a record $1 billion outflow on February 25, with Fidelity Wise Origin Bitcoin Fund and iShares Bitcoin Trust ETF leading the exodus. The outflows come amid Bitcoin's price slump to its lowest level since mid-November. Experts attribute the outflows to hedge funds unwinding a popular trading strategy, as well as inexperienced investors panicking. The Bitcoin funds have shed $2.1 billion over six consecutive days, the longest stretch of outflows since June.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins often serve as a bridge between crypto and the traditional financial system, in addition to being used to facilitate trades and serving as a haven from the price volatility of most other cryptocurrencies.
Losses from cryptocurrency-related scams surged to 24.3 per cent of total scam losses last year - from about 6.8 per cent in 2023.
The surging interest may challenge Indian authorities who have discouraged trading in cryptocurrencies by levying steep taxes and have warned against their risks and volatility.

site_title: Actor Gene Hackman and wife found dead alongside dog at home
summary: Actor Gene Hackman, 95, and his wife pianist Betsy Arakawa, 64, have died at their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Foul play is not suspected, but the cause of death has not been determined. Hackman, a two-time Oscar winner, appeared in over 80 films and was known for his intense performances. He passed away alongside his wife and their dog, according to the Santa Fe County Sheriff's Office. Hackman's death marks the end of a 60-year acting career.

images.alt_text:
Cinema still: Runaway Jury starring Gene
Hackman

site_title: Golden Agri’s H2 profit soars about 17 times to US$262.1 million on higher palm oil prices, sales
summary: Golden Agri-Resources' second-half profit surged 17 times to US$262.1 million, driven by higher palm oil prices and sales volumes. The company's revenue climbed 18.2% to US$5.8 billion, and its full-year net profit rose 84.5% to US$364.6 million. The board proposed a final dividend of S$0.00804 per share. Palm oil output is expected to recover in 2025, particularly in Indonesia, as El Nino weather conditions dissipate.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Therese Soh
Market watchers have revised CPO price forecasts in 2025 on limited production increase.
The markets are expecting a seasonally low production period for palm oil in the first half of 2025, when Indonesia is planning to implement an increased B40 biodiesel blending mandate.

site_title: Mercedes set to cut jobs in China as local competition heats up
summary: Mercedes-Benz plans to cut up to 15% of its workforce in China, mainly in financing and sales units, due to intensifying competition from Chinese institutions offering more attractive car loans. The job cuts have accelerated this month and may not affect the local head office or production units. This move highlights the struggles of foreign carmakers in China, where legacy brands have lost ground to agile domestic marques like BYD. Mercedes' sales in China dropped 7% last year, contributing to a decline in global deliveries.

images.alt_text: The sales decline undermines Mercedes-Benz’s strategy to push further upmarket by selling more of its most luxurious vehicles to boost profit.
Exports of such vehicles are tiny relative to the number of cars that companies including GM produce locally with joint venture partners.
Mercedes-Benz, which is due to report full-year results on Feb 20, was confident it would achieve its full-year margin target of 7.5 to 8.5 per cent, analysts’ notes said.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, February 27, 2025
summary: Asian markets experienced mixed results, with Hong Kong's stock index reaching a 24,000-point milestone since 2022. Bitcoin ETFs saw a record $1 billion outflow in the US. Companies like Bumitama Agri, Golden Agri, ST Engineering, and Sembcorp Industries reported strong earnings for the second half of 2024. Sembcorp Industries doubled its dividend, while Bumitama Agri's profit increased 13.5% to 1.43 trillion rupiah.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.

site_title: HSBC cutting staff numbers by 900 at China Pinnacle unit: sources
summary: HSBC is cutting staff numbers at its China digital wealth business Pinnacle by nearly half, or about 900 people, as part of a broader restructuring effort. The move reverses the bank's previous ambitions to expand in the market, which have been hindered by sharp costs and revenue challenges. The staff reduction involves layoffs, natural attrition, and transfers to other units, and is part of a sweeping cost-cutting drive launched by new CEO Georges Elhedery to boost profits.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu//File Photo

site_title: Bain Capital mulls US$10 billion sale of Rocket Software: sources
summary: Private equity firm Bain Capital is considering a sale of Rocket Software, potentially valuing the US automation software provider at up to $10 billion, including debt. The sale process, advised by Moelis and RBC Capital, is expected to launch in the coming weeks. Rocket aims to command a valuation equivalent to 12 times its earnings, a deal that could attract interest from private equity firms and mark one of the biggest leveraged buyouts in recent times.

images.alt_text: Bain had said last week it might withdraw its proposal for Fuji Soft, after KKR raised its offer above Bain’s in a months-long bidding war.
Bain’s possible concession would bring to an end months of intense competition with its US rival to take control of Fuji Soft.
Bain has been ramping up investment in Japan, a hive of dealmaking activity.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield slips to 2.75%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore announced a cut-off yield of 2.75% for its latest six-month Treasury bill auction, down from 2.9% in the previous auction. The auction received S$20.1 billion in applications for the S$7.5 billion on offer. This is part of Singapore's plan to issue up to another S$450 billion in government securities. The move is seen as a sign of a relatively stable interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
XXX

site_title: US cuts overseas development programme budgets by more than 90%: State Department
summary: The US State Department announced a 92% reduction in overseas development and aid programme budgets, with a $54 billion cut in multi-year contracts. The move was triggered by President Donald Trump's "America First" agenda, which aimed to eliminate programmes not aligned with it. The review targeted 5,800 awards worth $54 billion, and 4,100 grants worth $4.4 billion were eliminated, resulting in a 28% reduction. Exemptions included food assistance, life-saving medical treatments, and support for certain countries.

images.alt_text: Moderna has been under pressure to find new sources of revenue as its Covid vaccine sales fall sharply and it spends heavily on its pipeline.
Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent at US$2,918.22 an ounce.

“The Fed’s job is to monitor and adapt to the conditions, whatever they are,” Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee told AFP in an interview, adding that the independent US central bank had made “a lot of progress” on inflation.
US data show that imports from China declined to 13.4 per cent of total imports in 2024 from 21.6 per cent in 2018.

site_title: Centurion’s planned Reit will do the ‘heavy lifting’ of its assets, says CEO
summary: Centurion Corporation plans to establish a real estate investment trust (Reit) to "take the heavy lifting" of its assets, focusing on becoming asset-light. The Reit will comprise some worker and student accommodation assets, mainly "stabilised assets", and is expected to be of a "reasonable size". The company aims to rationalise its assets to grow bigger, despite having a low net gearing ratio of 29%. Centurion shares closed flat at S$1.02 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Housing migrant workers who work in areas such as construction is a lucrative business for Centurion Corporation.
Revenue for the second half stood at S$129.2 million, 18 per cent higher from S$109.3 million in the year before.

site_title: Can Singaporeans reverse ageing? Longevity clinics think so
summary: Singapore's longevity movement is gaining momentum, with various clinics and facilities offering biomarker testing, oxygen therapy, and personalized health plans to slow or reverse the effects of aging. Lim Tiat, a 53-year-old co-founder of Bespoke Fitness, has achieved a biological age of 32 through a rigorous, disciplined lifestyle. The industry is booming, with global billionaires investing in de-aging research, and Singapore is becoming a key hub. However, critics caution against unproven treatments, and experts emphasize the importance of evidence-based interventions and data-driven healthspan optimization.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Darcel Al Anthony
How to live to 100
Want to live a long life? Start by preventing the key causes of death.
Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.

site_title: CDL saga has ‘no impact on Hong Leong Asia’, says HLA CEO
summary: Hong Leong Asia's CEO Stephen Ho stated that the company does not see an impact from the ongoing dispute between CDL's executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and his son Sherman Kwek, despite being part of the same conglomerate. The company has an independent board and professionals running the business, and its corporate governance is separate from CDL. Hong Leong Asia reported a 35.3% rise in net profit to S$87.8 million for the full year, driven by growth in its powertrain solutions and building materials segments.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng said he has filed court papers on Feb 25 to deal with the “attempted coup” by his son and group chief executive, Sherman Kwek.

CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng (right) said he has filed court papers to deal with the attempted coup by Sherman Kwek, Philip Lee, Wong Ai Ai and a group of directors acting with them to allegedly consolidate control of the board and the group.

site_title: Hong Kong budget plans for real estate and finance sectors disappoint investors
summary: The Hong Kong Budget announced by Financial Secretary Paul Chan has failed to excite investors, who had hoped for more support for the finance and real estate markets. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.3% after Chan emphasized artificial intelligence as a core industry and pledged HK$1 billion for an AI research institute. However, analysts deemed the budget "non-event" due to lack of significant measures, citing a continued GDP growth outlook of 2-3% and limited support for the real estate sector, which may exacerbate excess inventory.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index of Chinese shares in Hong Kong is up 17 per cent this year and more than 40 per cent since Sep 11, when Chinese stock markets embarked on a rally.

New York’s main indexes have struggled this year as the long-running US tech surge has hit the buffers after Chinese startup DeepSeek unveiled its bombshell chatbot last month, upending the AI scramble.
Hong kong property housing Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore to launch applied AI initiative, large-scale research programmes in next five-year RIE plan
summary: Singapore plans to launch an applied AI initiative and two large-scale research programs in its next five-year Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) plan. The programs, called Flagships and Grand Challenges, will focus on key economic sectors and national strategic priorities. The applied AI initiative will explore major use cases in sectors like healthcare, education, and finance, while the Flagships and Grand Challenges will bring together research and translational capabilities from various sectors. The government will also invest in developing "bilingual" scientific talent and strengthening international partnerships.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
MPs note upskilling moves in last week’s Budget, but have further ideas.

Attracting investments and good jobs to Singapore is critical to the city-state’s survival, said Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC MP Saktiandi Supaat, noting that there it cannot be taken for granted that corporates will always choose to stay.

site_title: GuocoLand inks MOU to jointly develop UEM Sunrise’s land bank in Iskandar Puteri
summary: GuocoLand and Malaysia's UEM Sunrise signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to jointly develop land parcels in Iskandar Puteri, marking the first Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) agreement between Malaysian and Singaporean private-sector companies. The partnership aims to enhance infrastructure, nurture talent, and create a business-friendly ecosystem to attract high-value investments. GuocoLand will leverage its expertise in real estate development and asset management, while UEM Sunrise brings its local expertise in master planning. The partnership is expected to focus on improving connectivity, fostering talent development, and creating a business-friendly ecosystem in Iskandar Puteri.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Sarawak is benefiting from federal and state government cooperation, aimed at driving high-value projects.
The landmark JS-SEZ, signed in January this year, is expected to create 100 projects, 20,000 jobs and investments across 11 sectors.
Billionaire Kwek Leng Beng could look to drive value unlocking at CDL if he is firmly in the driver's seat.

site_title: UK services firms report falling profits, higher costs: CBI
summary: UK services firms report declining profits and morale, with a -55 rating among consumer-facing firms in February, the joint-lowest since August 2022. Profitability among business and professional firms fell to -37, the fastest drop since August 2020, and employment fell across both sectors. Businesses expect to reduce staffing in the coming months, citing weak demand conditions and increased costs from government measures.

images.alt_text: The fresh sanctions target those who support Russia’s military regime and the supply networks it relies on, the UK’s Foreign Office says.

In December last year, the UK officially joined the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). With the UK on board as the first non-founding member, the CPTPP now spans five continents and nearly 600 million people.
Job search company Adzuna said the number of vacancies on offer in Britain fell by 4.5 per cent compared with January last year to just under 828,500, the lowest January figures since 2021.

site_title: Top Thai hospital operator hastens expansion on foreign demand
summary: Bangkok Dusit Medical Services (BDMS), Thailand's largest private hospital operator, plans to add 800 new beds to its 9,600 beds by 2027, exceeding its initial target. The expansion is driven by foreign demand for affordable healthcare services and the country's status as a regional medical hub, with the government planning to attract more patients from abroad. BDMS' fourth-quarter net income rose 10% to 4.3 billion baht, exceeding analyst estimates, and its shares climbed 5.2%. The company will also invest in a new wellness center in central Bangkok, expected to drive earnings growth when it opens in 2030.

images.alt_text: In December, concerns about factory hygiene prompted China to suspend imports of syrup and premixed powder from Thailand, the world’s second-largest sugar exporter.
Thai exports increased 13.6 per cent in January from a year earlier, beating a forecast for a 7.15 per cent rise in a Reuters poll, and compared with December’s 8.7 per cent increase.

FILE PHOTO: EV cars are pictured inside BYD's first electric vehicle (EV) factory in Southeast Asia, a fast-growing regional EV market where it has become the dominant player, in Rayong, Thailand, July 4, 2024. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo

site_title: Toyota global output rises for the first time in a year in January
summary: Toyota's global vehicle output rose 6% year-over-year to 781,729 units in January, driven by a 22% increase in domestic production. This offset an overseas production decline, with North American output rising 3% and Mexico production increasing 3.5 times. Global sales were flat, with a 13% increase in domestic sales balancing out a 14% drop in China sales and a 1% decline in US sales. The company attributed the January increase to a ramp-up in production in Japan after recovering from last year's certification scandal.

images.alt_text: Isuzu Motors trucks bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan, Feb 6, 2025. Japan's exports rose 7.2 per cent year-on-year in January.
The batteries Toyota is buying from LG can be used in either EVs or hybrid vehicles.
Nissan has been working on a turnaround programme under which it plans to reduce its workforce by 9,000 people and global manufacturing capacity by 20 per cent.

site_title: Qantas splurges on dividends as strong travel demand boosts profit, shares jump
summary: Qantas Airways announced a special dividend of 9.9 Australian cents per share, its first in over two decades, and reported a first-half profit of A$1.39 billion, beating estimates. The airline's shares surged 5.7% as it resumed dividend payouts after a six-year hiatus. Strong travel demand, driven by its dual brand strategy, contributed to the profit. The move is seen as a sign of the company's financial strength, with Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson stating it gives confidence the business can deliver strong earnings.

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways is still awaiting government approval for its purchase of a 25 per cent stake in Virgin Australia from the US private equity firm Bain Capital.
It’s the first time Qantas has been pushed from the top spot since early 2022.

site_title: Acrophyte Hospitality Trust’s H2 DPS falls 55.9% to US$0.00848
summary: Acrophyte Hospitality Trust's half-year distribution per stapled security (DPS) declined 55.9% to US$0.00848, down from US$0.01929 in H2 FY2023. Revenue fell 5.2% to US$84.9 million, and net property income (NPI) dropped 9.2% to US$23.3 million. The trust's portfolio size contracted 8.3% in 2024 due to hotel sales and asset enhancement initiatives. Despite this, management remains committed to strengthening the portfolio and building resilience.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after latest Trump tariff threat
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Thursday as investors assessed US President Donald Trump's latest tariff threat, while chip titan Nvidia's earnings failed to impress. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 20% year-to-date, pushing it above 24,000 points, driven by Chinese tech giants. However, losses in Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, and Jakarta offset gains in Tokyo and Sydney. Economists remain optimistic about Trump's economic policies, citing potential benefits from deepening AI adoption and macroeconomic reform.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index was up 1 per cent at 559.67 points on Wednesday, boosted by banks for a second consecutive session.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent lower at 43,433.12 on Wednesday.
The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.2 per cent to as high as 24,076.53 on Wednesday, its highest level since February 2022.

site_title: Tariffs on China risk hurting US economy more than data suggest
summary: US tariffs on imports from China may have a more significant impact on the US economy than initially suggested by official data, according to a study from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The tariffs, imposed by President Trump's administration, could hit the US economy harder if the "de minimis" exemption threshold for direct-to-consumer imports is ended. The exemption threshold, currently set at $800, allows for the duty-free importation of goods valued below that amount.

images.alt_text: Under the current restrictions, chipmakers only have to notify the government before exporting the equivalent of as many as 1,700 graphic processing units to most countries.
China’s share of global shipbuilding capacity has surged over the past decade to account for around half of new builds, partly driven by its own domestic demand for more ships.
The Trump administration has ramped up pressure on Mexico to put its own tariffs on imports from China.

site_title: Gemini’s Winklevoss says SEC closed investigation with no action
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has closed its investigation into Gemini Trust, a cryptocurrency exchange owned by billionaire Winklevoss twins, with no action. The agency's investigation, which began 699 days ago, was deemed to have "no basis" for enforcement action, according to a letter dated February 24. The decision is seen as a victory for Gemini, which had incurred "tens of millions of US dollars in legal bills" due to the investigation.

images.alt_text: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has moved to ease its crypto-related regulations under Trump’s leadership.
“The war against crypto, at least as it applies to Coinbase, is over,” Coinbase said.
The industry has been calling for years for the SEC to create clear cryptocurrency rules.

site_title: China Aviation Oil H2 profit falls 8.1% to US$36 million
summary: China Aviation Oil reported an 8.1% decline in net profit to US$36 million for the second half of 2024, mainly due to a 55.7% drop in gross profit from lower gains from jet fuel supply and trading. The company's revenue for the period fell 2.1% to US$8 billion, attributed to a decline in oil prices. A final dividend of S$0.0372 per share for FY2024 is proposed.

images.alt_text: Above: China Aviation Oil's (CAO) into-plane refuelling operations at Hong Kong International Airport. The group attributed the drop in net profit to the decrease in gross profit and share of results from associates, which was impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic.
Crystal Heng

site_title: The battle for scraps of collapsed developer China Evergrande is intensifying
summary: China Evergrande Group, once facing $300 billion in liabilities, remains insolvent a year after being ordered into liquidation by a Hong Kong court. Creditors have yet to receive any returns, as the liquidation process drags on. Oaktree Capital Management, a US distressed-debt investor, is maneuvering to claim assets outside the Hong Kong liquidation process, potentially putting it at odds with the court-appointed liquidators. The complex process highlights the challenges of clawing back assets from a massive corporate implosion, with many of Evergrande's mainland assets remaining difficult to reach.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company logo is seen on the headquarters of China Evergrande Group in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China September 26, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Australia’s Q4 business investment dips 0.2%, misses forecasts
summary: Australia's Q4 business investment fell 0.2% in the fourth quarter, missing forecasts, as a decline in mining and construction outweighed growth in data centres. This suggests a slight drag on economic growth. Spending on buildings and structures rose 0.2%, while spending on plant and machinery fell 0.8%. Firms plan to spend A$148 billion in the fiscal year to June 2026, according to an ABS survey.

site_title: Seven & i says founding family unable to secure funding for US$58 billion buyout
summary: Seven & I Holdings, the parent company of 7-Eleven convenience stores, has failed to secure funding for a US$58 billion management buyout led by the founding Ito family. The company will consider a rival offer from Alimentation Couche-Tard, a Canadian retailer, amid heightened speculation of a potential acquisition. Seven & I's shares plummeted 12% following the announcement, while Couche-Tard's shares rose over 6%. The bid from Couche-Tard, valued at US$47 billion, remains a prominent example of international interest in Japanese assets.

images.alt_text: The level of fresh food prices has risen 71.9 per cent since 2010, about five times more than that of inflation excluding it.
The takeover effort values the sprawling convenience store conglomerate at an estimated US$58 billion.

site_title: Despite ‘welcome addition’ of OCBC capital return plan, analysts are split on its impact
summary: Analysts are divided on the impact of OCBC's capital return plan, which includes returning S$2.5 billion to shareholders over two years via special dividends and share buybacks. Despite the plan being seen as a "welcome addition," RHB upgraded its target price to S$19.10 and called the stock a "buy," while Maybank downgraded its call to "hold" due to limited yield impact. CGS International maintained its "add" call and raised its target price to S$19.50, citing potential for further capital releases from the privatisation of insurer Great Eastern and growth in wealth management.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
For the financial year 2025, OCBC is targeting a net interest margin (NIM) of around 2 per cent and a mid-single-digit loan growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stock index tops 24,000 for first time since 2022
summary: Hong Kong's main stock index, the Hang Seng Index, reached a three-year high of 24,076.53 on Wednesday, jumping 1.2% due to a surge in Chinese technology giants. The rally comes after Chinese startup DeepSeek unveiled a chatbot that upended the AI scramble, attracting investors to long-neglected tech names. This marks the first time the Hang Seng Index has surpassed 24,000 points since February 2022.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering on Thursday reported a net profit of S$365.7 million for the second half ended Dec 31, up 19.6 per cent from S$305.9 million in the previous corresponding period.
The Stoxx 600 index was up 1 per cent at 559.67 points on Wednesday, boosted by banks for a second consecutive session.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent lower at 43,433.12 on Wednesday.
Straits Times Index constituents OCBC and City Developments posted earnings that missed analyst expectations on Wednesday.

site_title: Bitcoin’s slide has traders hedging against a drop to US$70,000
summary: Bitcoin has tumbled 20% from its record high since Donald Trump's inauguration, prompting investors to hedge against a decline to US$70,000. The cryptocurrency's slide is attributed to a risk-off environment, Trump's combative stance, and concerns about elevated inflation. Liquidations of long and short crypto bets accelerated, with over US$2 billion of bullish bets wiped out in the past three days. Other tokens like Ether and Solana have also declined, with declines of 7-10%. The lack of a decisive signal for another bull run has led investors to rotate out of cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins often serve as a bridge between crypto and the traditional financial system, in addition to being used to facilitate trades and serving as a haven from the price volatility of most other cryptocurrencies.
Losses from cryptocurrency-related scams surged to 24.3 per cent of total scam losses last year - from about 6.8 per cent in 2023.
The surging interest may challenge Indian authorities who have discouraged trading in cryptocurrencies by levying steep taxes and have warned against their risks and volatility.

site_title: China quant says funds must adopt AI to survive after DeepSeek
summary: China's quantitative hedge funds face cut-throat competition and must adopt artificial intelligence (AI) to survive, according to Feng Ji, CEO of Baiont Quant. The industry, worth 1.3 trillion yuan, is under pressure from DeepSeek's AI model, which has been adopted by dozens of firms to reduce costs and boost efficiency. Quants that don't use AI risk becoming obsolete, with Feng stating that those that don't will "inevitably be eliminated" in three years. Baiont Quant has developed a new generation of methods combining customised features, which can improve algorithm efficiency and reduce strategy crowding.

images.alt_text: Over the past two weeks, home appliance manufacturers such as Haier, Hisense and TCL Electronics have joined automakers and tech heavyweights like Huawei and Tencent in saying they will be using DeepSeek’s models.
DeepSeek’s arrival reinvigorated the Chinese tech scene and triggered a rally in mainland and Hong Kong stocks.

The logos for the DeepSeek AI service next to a Chinese flag arranged in Beijing, China, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. Optimism over AI's potential has sparked a blistering rally in China's stock market over the past month, turning the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index into the world’s best-performer. Photographer: Andrea Verdelli/Bloomberg

site_title: Trump axes Chevron‘s Venezuela oil license, citing lack of electoral reforms
summary: US President Donald Trump has revoked Chevron's license to operate in Venezuela, citing the country's lack of electoral reforms and migrant returns. The license, granted by his predecessor Joe Biden in 2022, had provided a steady source of revenue to President Nicolas Maduro's administration. Trump accused Maduro of not meeting electoral conditions and not transporting Venezuelans back to the US at the agreed pace. The move is seen as a significant escalation of US pressure on Maduro's government, which has rejected sanctions and blamed them for economic hardships.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chevron logo is seen in this illustration taken, October 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Nissan CEO Uchida’s future in focus as sources say management shake-up due soon
summary: Nissan is set to announce a management shake-up, with CEO Makoto Uchida's future in focus. The company is expected to unveil the changes on March 12, amid a turnaround plan to address dismal performance and a failed merger with Honda. The board will assess the plan's strength and team's capability. If Uchida steps down, Nissan may choose an interim CEO instead of a permanent one. Analysts say a change at the top won't be a quick fix for the automaker, and shares have risen 3.7% in Tokyo.

images.alt_text: Nissan’s shares have been volatile since it announced it was in talks with Honda Motor over a potential tie-up in December, then dropped those talks this month.

ALHAMBRA, CALIFORNIA - JANUARY 02: The Tesla logo displayed at a Tesla dealership on January 2, 2025 in Alhambra, California. The electric vehicle (EV) company reported its first annual sales dip in 2024, down one percent from 2023.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Nissan has been working on a turnaround programme under which it plans to reduce its workforce by 9,000 people and global manufacturing capacity by 20 per cent.

site_title: Gold gains on Trump tariff worries; US inflation data in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,918.22 an ounce, driven by concerns over US President Donald Trump's tariff plans. Trump announced plans for tariffs on European cars and other goods, raising hopes for a pause in tariffs on Mexico and Canada. Investors await the Friday release of the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) index, the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure, for further insights on monetary policy easing.

images.alt_text: A 100 gram gold bar arranged at Gold Investments Ltd. bullion dealers in London, UK, on Tuesday, May 21, 2024. Gold slipped — after hitting an all-time high in the previous session — with investors assessing recent hawkish commentary from Federal Reserve officials that downplayed the possibility of imminent rate cuts. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: South Korea to tighten household borrowing rules from second half
summary: South Korea's household debt reached 1,927.3 trillion won (S$1.8 billion) at the end of 2024, a 2.2% increase from the previous year and the fastest growth in 2-1/2 years. To manage this growth, the Financial Services Commission will tighten "stress debt-to-service ratios" starting from July, aiming to curb household debt. This move follows previous tightening in February and September 2024.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s government has spent hundreds of billions of US dollars over the years in a campaign aimed at encouraging more people to get married and procreate.

A supporter of South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol waves a flag during a rally in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 25, 2025. Yoon’s policy to grow more closely aligned with Washington amid trade tensions between China and the US has increased South Korea’s reliance on the US market, leaving its businesses more vulnerable to potential tariff changes.

Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong said market expectations of two to three cuts this year were in line with views at the central bank, his first indication of the long-term outlook for the latest easing cycle.

site_title: Nvidia’s solid earnings report falls short of blowout level
summary: Nvidia reported solid quarterly earnings, exceeding analyst estimates with revenue of $43 billion, despite falling short of a "blowout" level. The company's data centre unit generated $35.6 billion in sales, beating estimates, while gaming-related sales were lower than projected. Nvidia shares dipped less than 1% in extended trading, following concerns about slowing spending by data centre operators and the potential impact of Chinese startup DeepSeek's affordable AI model. Despite this, key customers such as Microsoft have maintained their capital expenditure plans, suggesting the AI spending surge will remain strong.

images.alt_text: Nvidia’s shares have been a safe bet for a long time, gaining nearly 900 per cent from the start of 2023 to late Januar.
Nvidia reported a position of 1.7 million shares in China’s self-driving startup WeRide, sending its shares up 88 per cent.
DeepSeek has said it used Nvidia’s H800 chips, which it could have legally purchased in 2023.

site_title: eBay forecasts quarterly revenue below expectations on weak demand
summary: eBay forecasts first-quarter revenue between $2.52 billion and $2.56 billion, below analysts' average estimate of $2.59 billion, due to weak demand for collector's items and refurbished goods. High interest rates and inflation have hampered US consumer spending, leading to sluggish demand for non-essential items. The e-commerce company faces intense competition from Amazon and Alibaba, resulting in a 7% drop in shares.

images.alt_text: SAN JOSE, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 26: The eBay logo is displayed on a sign in front of eBay headquarters on February 26, 2025 in San Jose, California. Online marketplace eBay will report fourth-quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Is Trump doing a Kissinger?
summary: US President Donald Trump's diplomatic efforts with Russia may lead to a detente with Moscow, potentially isolating China. Trump's strategy mirrors Henry Kissinger's approach in the 1970s, where the US divided the communist bloc to create a new balance of power. Trump hopes to incentivize Russian President Vladimir Putin to reassess his partnership with China, similar to how China drew away from Russia after 1972. This could lead to improved ties between Washington and Moscow, placing the US in a stronger position to negotiate with Beijing.

images.alt_text: as transitions often are. In the first instance, it means greater volatility, which in the capital markets means risk. It also means uncertainty, and the lack of visibility is often associated with cautiousness on the part of business in making investment decisions.
China’s share of global shipbuilding capacity has surged over the past decade to account for around half of new builds, partly driven by its own domestic demand for more ships.

site_title: Goldman Sachs adds Waldron to board, lining up potential CEO succession
summary: Goldman Sachs added John Waldron, its president and chief operating officer, to the board of directors, cementing his potential succession to CEO David Solomon. The move comes a month after Waldron received a retention bonus, which vests in five years. Waldron oversees the bank's three main divisions and has been president and COO since 2018. The addition of Waldron to the board, along with Accenture's former CFO KC McClure, signals firmer succession planning at the bank.

site_title: US: Nasdaq rises while Dow falls on latest Trump tariff talk
summary: US stocks experienced mixed results on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.3% to 19,075.26, driven by gains in Nvidia ahead of its earnings report. In contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4% to 43,433.12, amid concerns over potential tariffs on the European Union. The S&P 500 remained flat. The market's uncertainty over the new administration's policies continues to impact investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 14.3 points, or 0.03 per cent, at the open to 43,635.42.

site_title: Fu Yu not convening EGM requisitioned by largest shareholder as requirement not met
summary: Fu Yu Corporation will not convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) as requisitioned by its largest shareholder Victor Lim due to a failure to meet the required special notice to independent, non-executive directors Christopher Huang and Royston Tan. Lim's second attempt to call for an EGM did not meet the necessary requirement, resulting in the company not proceeding with the meeting.

Fu Yu's largest shareholder Victor Lim says substantial shareholder value has been erased since the appointment of directors Christopher Huang Junli and Roystan Tan Tong Loong.

site_title: Even as MAS plans an SGX revival, privatisations are still taking place
summary: Singapore's SGX has seen a surge in privatisation offers, with 17 companies listed on the exchange being targeted in 2024, and several more announced this year. Analysts cite low trading volume, challenging business environments, and cost savings as reasons for companies opting to go private. Despite efforts to revitalize the market, the trend suggests that companies are prioritising private ownership over public listing, potentially affecting the SGX's growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

Generic picture of Paragon Mall along Orchard Road on Feb 11, 2025. Cuscaden Peak Investments – formerly Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) – proposed to privatise and delist Paragon Reit by way of a trust scheme of arrangement, they jointly announced on Feb 11. Paragon Reit currently owns Paragon mall, which accounts for 72 per cent of the Reit’s value, as well as The Clementi Mall and South Australia’s Westfield Marion Shopping Centre.

site_title: Expanding networks, finding partners for better third-party logistics
summary: JGL Worldwide, a logistics provider, is expanding its networks and service offerings across South-east Asia and India, serving over 80 trade routes. The company aims to deepen its foothold in the region and become a digitalised supply chain service provider. It has fostered close relationships with international logistics networks and trade associations, and is implementing sustainable practices to achieve net-zero emissions. JGL's digitalisation platform streamlines processes, enhances transparency, and improves efficiency, while its corporate volunteering and employee well-being initiatives promote a collegial culture and environmental sustainability.

site_title: US Federal Reserve will ‘adapt’ to any policy changes: Goolsbee
summary: US Federal Reserve President Austan Goolsbee stated that the central bank will "adapt" to any policy changes made by the Trump administration, acknowledging the Fed's role in monitoring and responding to economic conditions. Despite concerns over the potential inflationary effects of the administration's proposed tariffs, Goolsbee noted the Fed has made "a lot of progress" on inflation. However, it remains unclear how the tariffs will affect inflation, making it challenging for the Fed to disentangle their impact from other economic factors.

site_title: Trump tariffs on North America hint at first stirrings of what’s to hit South-east Asia
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Canada and Mexico, the two largest trading partners, signal the start of a broader "America First" policy, potentially disrupting global supply chains and impacting South-east Asia. Analysts predict a secondary shockwave affecting Vietnam, Thailand, and Malaysia, with end-users in the automotive, agri-commodities, energy, and packaged foods sectors facing higher prices. While direct negative effects on the region are expected to be minimal, a broader trade war could lead to economic losses, with companies potentially facing significant earnings drops and consumers feeling the impact.

site_title: Is Warren Buffett’s true successor Bill Ackman?
summary: Warren Buffett, 94, is planning to step down as CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, with 58-year-old Bill Ackman emerging as a potential successor. Ackman, founder of Pershing Square Capital Management, has a strong track record of investment performance and a similar business model to Berkshire Hathaway. While Ackman lacks Buffett's pedigree, his public profile, wealth, and connections make him a viable candidate. Buffett has acknowledged that Ackman is a potential successor, saying "it won't be long before Greg Abel replaces me as CEO and will be writing the annual letters."

Berkshire Hathaway chairman Warren Buffett writes in his annual shareholder letter: “Often, nothing looks compelling; very infrequently we find ourselves knee-deep in opportunities.”

site_title: Bumitama Agri’s H2 profit climbs 13.5% to 1.43 trillion rupiah
summary: Bumitama Agri, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 13.5% increase in H2 net profit to 1.43 trillion rupiah, driven by higher average selling prices of palm products and the appreciation of the Indonesian rupiah. Revenue rose 14.9% to 9.13 trillion rupiah, with crude palm oil and palm kernel product revenues increasing 10.7% and 57.2% respectively. The company attributed the improvement to higher average selling prices and the appreciation of the Indonesian rupiah.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The weather woes have raised concerns about palm oil’s availability ahead of the Ramadan and Eid al-Fitr holidays, which typically drive up consumption.

Malaysia’s exports of palm oil to China declined in 2024 due to lower soybean prices compared to palm oil and lower consumption of cooking oil, says Deputy Minister of Plantation and Commodities Chan Foong Hin.

site_title: EU vows swift, firm response after Trump says tariffs coming on EU imports
summary: The European Commission has vowed a swift and firm response to US President Donald Trump's announcement of a 25% tariff on EU imports. In response, a European Commission spokesperson stated that the EU will react against unjustified barriers to free and fair trade, including tariffs used to challenge legal and non-discriminatory policies. The EU aims to protect European businesses, workers, and consumers from such tariffs.

site_title: Two new CDL directors will not exercise any powers until further notice from court: Kwek Leng Beng
summary: CDL's new directors, Jennifer Duong Young and Wong Su Yen, have agreed not to exercise their powers as directors until further notice from court due to "irregular and hastily appointed" appointments. The move halts attempts to destabilize the board committees and management of CDL's subsidiaries, following a court hearing. The irregularly constituted Nominating and Remuneration Committee has also been suspended. CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng said strong corporate governance is crucial for the company's stability and sustainability.

site_title: Beyond Meat sees weak annual revenue, posts wider-than-expected quarterly loss
summary: Beyond Meat reported weaker-than-expected annual revenue and a wider-than-expected quarterly loss. The company expects annual revenue of $320-335 million, below analysts' estimates of $337.6 million. It also plans to suspend operations in China, lay off 20 employees (3% of global workforce), and cut jobs in North America and Europe to strengthen its financial profile. The company targets a positive core profit run-rate by 2026 and is implementing cost-reduction measures.

images.alt_text: Beyond Meat is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings next week.

site_title: UK in ‘open dialogue’ on rich foreigner taxes, minister says
summary: The UK is in open dialogue with wealthy foreigners about their taxes, following a crackdown on the non-dom regime introduced by Chancellor Rachel Reeves. There were 74,000 individuals claiming non-dom status in the UK for the 2022-2023 tax year, with many from India, the US, and Western Europe. Reeves' plan to replace the non-dom regime with a residency scheme has sparked concerns from the ultra-rich, who fear overseas earnings will be subject to inheritance tax. Investment Minister Poppy Gustafsson said there has been an "open dialogue" with Indian investors and Reeves, and the government is trying to create a fair tax structure while attracting talented people.

images.alt_text: united kingdom uk london Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Ben & Jerry’s founders discuss buying back brand from Unilever
summary: Ben & Jerry's founders Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield are considering buying back their namesake ice cream brand from Unilever, with potential discussions of partnering with socially minded investors. The business could be valued at several billion US dollars, requiring deep-pocketed financial backers. The spinoff is planned to go public primarily in Amsterdam, with secondary listings in London and New York.

images.alt_text: The company and its advisers are evaluating a range of options including a listing in the US, which is the biggest market for its ice cream brands like Ben & Jerry’s.

site_title: Special Economic Zones: One size doesn’t fit all
summary: A proposed Special Economic Zone (SEZ) between Sarawak and Brunei, two resource-rich nations on the island of Borneo, has sparked discussions on cross-border collaboration. The idea is inspired by the successful Johor-Singapore model, but its success is uncertain due to the distinct economic realities of the two nations. Brunei's economy relies heavily on oil and gas, while Sarawak's economy is limited by its reliance on natural resources and slow infrastructure development. To succeed, both sides must address infrastructure gaps, diversify their economies, and cultivate a competitive business environment.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Sarawak has been gaining control over key assets as it seeks greater political and economic autonomy from the federal government.
The Sarawak State Legislative Assembly. Last November, Sarawak became the first state in Malaysia to enact legislation on carbon trading.

site_title: Sembcorp doubles dividend on higher earnings, shuffles business leadership
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 14% rise in total net profit to S$471 million for the second half of 2024, driven by a 17% increase in earnings per share. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.17 per share, more than double the previous period. Sembcorp is reorganizing its business into three segments and appointing new CEOs for each, citing the need for strong leaders to drive strategy towards 2028 and beyond. The company's net profit for the full year rose 7% to S$1.01 billion, and revenue declined 9% to S$6.4 billion.

images.alt_text: The Manah II Solar Power Plant is Sembcorps first foray into the Middle East renewables market and also its largest utility scale solar farm in its global renewables portfolio.

site_title: ST Engineering H2 profit rises 19.6% to S$365.7 million
summary: ST Engineering reported a 19.6% increase in H2 net profit to S$365.7 million, driven by a 9.9% rise in revenue to S$5.8 billion. Defence and public security revenue grew 20% to S$2.6 billion, while commercial aerospace revenue rose 5% to S$2.2 billion. The group's order book stood at S$28.5 billion as of end-2024, with expected deliveries of S$8.8 billion in 2025. A final dividend of S$0.05 per share was proposed, with the group's net asset value per share increasing to S$0.8574.

site_title: ‘Buffy’ actress Michelle Trachtenberg dies at 39: US media
summary: Michelle Trachtenberg, actress known for roles in 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer' and 'Gossip Girl', has died at 39. Emergency medical workers pronounced her dead without giving a cause, with police ruling out foul play. Trachtenberg recently underwent a liver transplant, possibly contributing to her death. She began her career as a child star, with notable roles in films and TV shows. Her death was confirmed by US media outlets, citing anonymous sources.

site_title: Amazon unveils long-awaited AI version of Alexa assistant
summary: Amazon has unveiled a revamped AI version of its Alexa assistant, marking the biggest overhaul since its introduction over a decade ago. The new AI-powered Alexa will integrate with partner apps such as Uber and OpenTable, and is aimed at revitalizing the consumer electronics franchise. Former Microsoft Surface boss Panos Panay, now in charge of Amazon's Devices & Services unit, said the technology has been re-designed to overcome previous limitations. The move aims to boost Alexa's capabilities and competitiveness in the voice-activated market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, CLI, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Sembcorp, Golden-Agri
summary: ST Engineering reported a 19.6% increase in net profit to S$365.7 million for the second half ended Dec 31, driven by revenue growth in its defence and public security, as well as commercial aerospace segments. CapitaLand Investment posted a net profit of S$148 million, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding saw a 50.5% increase in net profit to S$659.3 million. Sembcorp Industries reported a 14% rise in net profit to S$471 million, and Golden-Agri Resources posted a net profit of US$262.1 million, up 1,617.1% from the previous year.

site_title: Salesforce gives tepid outlook while touting AI progress
summary: Salesforce provided a fiscal-year revenue forecast of $40.5 billion to $40.9 billion, slightly below analyst estimates of $41.5 billion. The company's new AI product, Agentforce, is expected to contribute modestly to revenue in 2026 and more significantly in the following year. Despite a weaker-than-expected revenue guidance, Salesforce reported strong AI data points, including 3,000 paying customers and $900 million in recurring revenue. The company also announced significant changes to its leadership, including the departure of CFO Amy Weaver and COO Brian Millham.

site_title: Ahoy, me hearties! Aren’t these beauties
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels' Treasure Island high jewellery collection is a playful tribute to Robert Louis Stevenson's classic novel. The collection features whimsical, colourful designs with gemstone-studded silhouettes, including a Hispaniola clip, Ecume Mysterieuse necklace, and Coquillage Mysterieux clip. The collection is divided into three chapters: The adventure at sea, Exploring the island, and The treasure hunt, each showcasing unique pieces such as a golden map clip and a treasure chest ring. The collection's playful and precious designs have already captured the hearts of many, with several pieces sold.

images.alt_text: Illustrations by French comic-book artist and writer David Beauchard accompany the Treasure Island collection by Van Cleef & Arpels.

site_title: Alphabet’s Google cuts employees in cloud division
summary: Google has cut employees in its cloud division, impacting a few teams, following slower growth and massive spending on artificial intelligence. The layoffs come as the tech industry continues to downsize corporate workforces amid pressure to invest in AI technologies without risking profits. Alphabet's cloud business, a key area of investment, remains a growth area despite missing revenue projections and exceeding capital expenditure guidance earlier this month.

site_title: Europe: Shares close at record high after upbeat earnings; US-Ukraine deal in focus
summary: European shares closed at a record high on Wednesday, driven by upbeat earnings from banks and insurers, and boosted by a critical minerals agreement between the US and Ukraine. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1% to a record high, with most sub-sectors closing higher, while media stocks declined 2.5%. The agreement, ahead of talks between Russia and the US, and optimism around pro-growth policies in Germany, contributed to the gains. Investors are positioning for a potential trade war and expect a correction in the European stock market before new highs in 2026.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent lower at 43,433.12 on Wednesday.

site_title: MPs raise concerns over business costs, effective training on first day of Budget debate
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 debate focused on economic concerns, including rising rents, manpower costs, and business costs. MPs proposed ideas to support local businesses, such as rent subsidies and grants, as well as wage increases to align with productivity trends. The government also emphasized the need for effective training and upskilling, with suggestions to extend the SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support scheme and make training more accessible. Social policies, including support for seniors, caregivers, and persons with disabilities, were also discussed.

summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) reported a net profit of S$148 million for its second half, up from a net loss of S$170 million in the previous period. The group's earnings per share (EPS) rose to S$0.03, driven by reduced losses from revaluation of investment properties. CLI proposed a special distribution of 0.031 CICT units per share, valued at S$0.06 each, to improve its return on equity and align with its capital management and asset-light growth strategy. summary: CSE Global's second-half net profit decreased 1.7% to S$11.3 million, primarily due to a US$8 million settlement. Revenue rose 15% to S$432.3 million, driven by the electrification segment in the Americas and Asia-Pacific regions. The company's order book stood at S$672.6 million, positioning it for a healthy financial performance in 2025. CEO Lim Boon Kheng believes the group will benefit from growing data centre demand, particularly with its electrification and communications focused strategies.

site_title: Mapletree Investments bags HK$3.7 billion Hong Kong logistics site
summary: Mapletree Investments has won a bid for a logistics development site in Hong Kong worth HK$3.7 billion (S$633 million), with a site area of 44,318 square meters. site_title: US: Wall St opens higher with spotlight on Nvidia results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, February 26, as investors awaited Nvidia's results and a crucial tax-cut proposal's progress through Congress. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 14.3 points, or 0.03%, to 43,635.42. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 15.6 points, or 0.26%, and the Nasdaq rising 82.9 points, or 0.44%. site_title: International aid organisations should commit a lot more money and energy to fighting tuberculosis
summary: International aid organizations are urged to increase funding and energy to combat tuberculosis, which kills more people than HIV and malaria combined, despite being curable. The Global Fund has allocated only 18% of its budget to tuberculosis, with nearly $2.4 billion spent in 2023-2025. Experts recommend increasing funding to $6.2 billion annually to save approximately 1 million lives per year, with a 90% reduction in deaths by 2030. The disease disproportionately affects the world's poorer half, claiming nearly 1.3 million lives annually, and is often neglected due to its prevalence in wealthier countries.

Revenue rose 5.5% to 13.5 billion yuan. The company attributed the growth to record-high shipbuilding newbuild orders, reaching 17-year highs. However, it noted potential downside risks from US proposed service fees on Chinese-exposed ships and extended delivery lead times, which may impact shipowner willingness to place new orders.

site_title: How to survive when superpowers are behaving badly
summary: Small and medium-sized nations must adapt to a world where great powers are flouting international conventions, such as the US and China. The Non-Aligned Movement, a Cold War-era group of independent countries, offers a valuable lesson in unity and cooperation. Smaller states can work together, enhance surveillance and security measures, and appeal to international organizations to address concerns. Countries like Singapore and Australia can also build alliances and advocate for a liberal international system, promoting open trade and free markets. Failure to adapt risks becoming collateral damage in a increasingly dangerous world.

site_title: Hong Kong to reduce property tax for low-end home transactions
summary: Hong Kong's government has announced a move to boost the lackluster property market by reducing stamp duty for low-end home transactions. Residential units valued at HK$4 million (S$688,292) or below will now be subject to the minimum stamp duty bracket of HK$100, down from 1.5% of the deal value. The change, effective immediately, is expected to benefit 15% of total transactions and aims to stimulate the market, which has been suffering from a prolonged downturn due to expensive borrowing costs, a weak economy, and oversupply of homes.

The market's broader performance was largely unaffected by the disappointing earnings, with 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.7 billion changing hands.

As of December 2024, 54 properties, 33 vehicles, and 11 country club memberships had been liquidated, with proceeds paid into the Consolidated Fund, totaling S$1.8 million. Local governments are burdened by debt loads accumulated during the Covid and property boom, resulting in delayed payments and withholding of public workers' paychecks. Li proposes the central government sell more bonds to buy regional authorities' debt, and hand out cash subsidies to households during major holidays to boost consumption.

The deal comes as Indonesia seeks to reduce its reliance on foreign companies as sales hubs, and President Prabowo Subianto's administration aims to boost domestic standing. site_title: Arctic doomsday seed vault gets more than 14,000 new samples
summary: The Svalbard Global Seed Vault, a doomsday vault storing food crop seeds, received over 14,000 new samples on Tuesday, bringing its total to 30,000. The seeds come from around the world, including Sudan, Sweden, and Thailand, and include varieties of sorghum, Nordic tree species, and rice. The deposits aim to preserve biodiversity and cultural heritage, particularly in regions affected by conflict and climate change. The vault, which protects seeds from nuclear war and global warming, has played a key role in rebuilding seed collections damaged during the Syrian war.

site_title: China to start bank recapitalisation with at least 400 billion yuan
summary: China plans to inject at least 400 billion yuan (S$73.7 billion) into its six biggest state-owned banks, including Agricultural Bank of China, Bank of Communications, and Postal Savings Bank of China, as part of a broader stimulus package to support the struggling economy. The move is aimed at replenishing core tier-1 capital and strengthening the banks' ability to fend off risks and spur lending. This is the first capital injection for Chinese banks since the 2008 global financial crisis.

summary: China's DeepSeek AI has revolutionized home devices by slashing off-peak pricing by up to 75%. Major home appliance brands such as Haier, Hisense, and TCL Electronics, as well as automakers and tech giants like Huawei and Tencent, are using DeepSeek's models. The company's large language models have outperformed Western systems at a lower cost, prompting pride and celebration in China. DeepSeek's founder Liang Wenfeng has been feted by Chinese authorities, and the company plans to release its R2 model soon, further solidifying its position in the AI sector.
