site_title: China Everbright Water’s FY2024 profit falls 14% to HK$1 billion
summary: China Everbright Water's FY2024 net profit fell 14% to HK$1 billion, with earnings per share decreasing 14% to HK$0.3564. The company proposed a final dividend of HK$0.0581 per share, a 4% decrease from FY2023. Revenue inched up 2% to HK$6.9 billion, while gross profit margin decreased to 38% due to higher construction service revenue. The company highlighted its healthy financial position and plans to focus on water-related areas and drive endogenous growth.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
China Everbright Water's board is proposing an interim dividend of HK$0.0609, or the equivalent of S$0.015 per ordinary share, for H1 FY2024.

site_title: SingPost must quickly find a new group CEO to deliver it from its troubles
summary: SingPost, Singapore's national postal-service provider, faces challenges amid a series of high-profile departures, including the exit of CEO Shahrin Abdol Salam and the firing of three senior executives. The company has laid off 45 employees to restructure amid macroeconomic challenges and is struggling to find a new group CEO. The upcoming sale of its Australian business, which generated a profit of S$20.3 million, will shape the slate of candidates and the final pick of helmsman. Without a clear strategy, SingPost risks navigating its way out of its troubles without a leader at the helm.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
SingPost intends to use a portion of the proceeds from the Australian business sale to repay borrowings.
Ng Chin Hwee and Chng Lay Chew were appointed non-executive, independent directors of SingPost effective Feb 17 the company said in a bourse filing on Monday (Feb 17).

SingPost’s board of directors is helmed by chairman Simon Israel, whom SingPost has said will provide increased guidance to and exercise greater oversight of the senior management leadership team in the interim.

site_title: Vietnam’s US exports account for 30% of GDP, making it highly vulnerable to tariffs
summary: Vietnam's exports to the US account for 30% of its GDP, making the country highly vulnerable to US tariffs. The US corporations Apple, Intel, and Nike have invested heavily in Vietnam as a production hub for goods exported to the US. Last year, Vietnam's goods exports to the US were worth $142.4 billion, making it the sixth-largest exporter to the US. The country's reliance on US trade makes it comparable to Mexico, which faces explicit tariff threats from US President Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: China’s sent the most steel overseas in nine years in 2024, as its producers turned to global markets to offset a deep construction slowdown at home.
The National Assembly building in Hanoi.

site_title: India’s February gold imports to hit 20-year low on record high prices: sources
summary: India's gold imports are expected to drop 85% in February to their lowest in 20 years, averaging around 15 metric tonnes, due to record-high prices. The decline could help narrow India's trade deficit and support the rupee, which is trading near a record low against the US dollar. Demand for gold, particularly in the form of jewelry, has been sapped by high prices, with weddings, a major driver of gold purchases, also seeing reduced demand.

images.alt_text: The global gold market has been in upheaval in recent weeks, at a time when prices were already near record highs

site_title: Scam losses surge to S$1.1 billion in 2024, with crypto-related cases making up a quarter
summary: Singapore's scam losses surged 70.6% to S$1.1 billion in 2024, driven by a small number of cases with very high losses. Cryptocurrency-related scams accounted for 24.3% of total scam losses, up from 6.8% in 2023. The total number of scam cases increased 10.6% to 51,501. The most common scam types were e-commerce scams, investment scams, and government-official-impersonation scams, with losses ranging from S$17.5 million to S$320.7 million.

site_title: Tesla sales fall 45% in Europe as rivals’ EV registrations soar
summary: Tesla's European sales plummeted 45% in January to 9,945 cars, the lowest monthly total since July 2021. The company's rival carmakers, including Volkswagen, Stellantis, and Renault, saw a surge in electric vehicle demand, with EV sales soaring 37% for the industry. The decline in Tesla's sales comes as the company faces increased regulatory pressure to sell more EVs and amid Elon Musk's polarizing figure in global politics, including criticism of Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky.

images.alt_text: Driver-assistance technology is becoming increasingly common in China, with EV leader BYD recently having announced a system it’s marketing as God’s Eye.

The Tesla gigafactory in Austin, Texas. Tesla was cited and fined about US$7,000 for two other workplace safety violations at its Texas plant last year, both involving violations of rules to protect workers from chemical hazards.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding dives further after US proposed fees for Chinese-built ships
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's shares plummeted 12.7% to S$2.61 after the US Trade Representative's office proposed fees on Chinese-built vessels entering US ports, ranging from US$500,000 to US$1.5 million. This marks the second consecutive day of losses for the stock. The proposal aims to investigate China's dominance in global shipbuilding and logistics sectors, citing state subsidies and preferential treatment for state-owned businesses.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Yangzijiang Financial said it continues to diversify and reduce its exposure to China.

site_title: China aims to eliminate severe air pollution this year
summary: China aims to eliminate severe air pollution by the end of 2025, with efforts including improved air quality forecasting, enhanced PM2.5 and ozone pollution management, and promoting long-distance transportation of bulk goods by rail and water. The move is expected to reduce air pollution-related deaths, which currently account for around two million annually, according to the WHO. Authorities will also increase coordination and monitoring of pollution levels to ensure a "battle for blue skies."

images.alt_text: epa10948526 Vehicles move near a traffic sign reading 'Drive carefully because of fog' amid heavy smog in Beijing, China, 30 October 2023. The Municipal Air Pollution Emergency Headquarters in Beijing issued an orange warning, the second-highest alert for heavy air pollution, from 30 October to 02 November. Additionally, China’s National Meteorological Center issued a forecast for heavy smog for the next three days in Anhui, Jiangsu and Sichuan provinces.  EPA-EFE/MARK R. CRISTINO

site_title: Why vouchers instead of cash: PM Wong answers burning questions on Budget 2025
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong defended the government's Budget 2025 as a responsible and well-managed plan, despite its perceived generosity. The budget coincides with the upcoming general election, but Wong said it's not an election Budget. He also clarified that measures in the budget are not temporary, making up only 5% of the overall budget. The government is investing in structural programs and long-term initiatives, including the SkillsFuture program and social support measures. Vouchers were chosen over cash support due to positive responses to Community Development Council Vouchers, and a support calculator is available on the government's website for Singaporeans to track their benefits.

images.alt_text: Minister Indranee Rajah (left) and DBS’ Han Kwee Juan will engage in a panel discussion on the Budget
PM Wong taking pictures with residents at the Chingay@Heartlands celebration on Feb 22.

The NPF supports productivity improvements and training, though the government has not given details of its use. In 2023, its scope was expanded to cover grants to companies investing or carrying out economic activities in Singapore, PwC Singapore tax partner Tan Tay Lek noted.
Singapore has placed S$10 billion into its Coastal and Flood Protection Fund, but has used only 4.4 per cent of it so far.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, February 25, 2025
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday as US President Trump targeted Chinese tech companies, casting a shadow over global trade. The Bank of Korea cut interest rates to boost demand, but the impact was limited. Layoffs were reported in financial services and tech sectors in 2025. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Tan Teck Long is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index dropped more than one per cent on Tuesday, with Alibaba and ecommerce rival JD.com off more than four per cent and Tencent off more than two per cent.

Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong said market expectations of two to three cuts this year were in line with views at the central bank, his first indication of the long-term outlook for the latest easing cycle.
From tech to retail, media and finance, major companies are starting to shed employees as they undergo restructuring and adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Trump targets China with biggest salvo so far in second term
summary: US President Donald Trump has issued a memorandum to curb Chinese spending on tech, energy, and strategic American sectors. The move is part of a series of actions targeting China, including proposed fees on Chinese-made commercial ships and a request to Mexico to place levies on Chinese imports. Chinese shipping stocks fell and the yuan rose after the announcement. The actions raise the risk of worsening ties between the US and China, its top economic rival.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration has ramped up pressure on Mexico to put its own tariffs on imports from China.
The Trump administration will consider new or expanded restrictions on US outbound investment to China in sensitive technologies, including semiconductors.
Trump (left) himself has struck a less belligerent tone on China, telling reporters that a trade deal was “possible” and again trumpeting his “very good relationship” with Xi (right).
Trump imposed tariffs of 10 per cent on Chinese goods in early February, citing the country’s failure to stem the tide of ingredients used to make illicit fentanyl.

site_title: US securities regulator closes investigation into Robinhood’s crypto arm with no action
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has closed its investigation into Robinhood's crypto arm with no action, following President Trump's leadership to ease crypto-related regulations. The SEC has established a task force to clarify the regulatory framework around crypto assets and rescinded a key accounting guidance. Robinhood received a Wells notice in May last year, prompting the investigation, but no enforcement action will be taken.

images.alt_text: Robinhood intends to roll out the services with guidance from local regulators by late 2025, although it has not yet set a launch date.
Robinhood has global ambitions for 2025, with plans to launch in Asia with a Singapore home base.
Robinhood and other brokerages are vying for customer loyalty after the pandemic prompted many novice investors to look into capital markets.

site_title: China Evergrande's EV unit to sell 20% stake in Swedish firm for tax needs
summary: China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group agreed to sell a 20% stake in a Swedish real estate property for $5.63 million to meet tax payment needs and other obligations. The sale, valued at 23.8 million krona, is expected to result in a disposal loss. The move comes as China Evergrande Group, the world's most heavily indebted property developer, faces a debt crisis and was ordered into liquidation by a Hong Kong court last year.

site_title: Great Eastern Q4 profit falls 14% to S$134.8 million, reflecting medical insurance provisions
summary: Great Eastern's Q4 profit fell 14% to S$134.8 million due to provisions made for its medical insurance business, primarily linked to changes in Singapore's MediShield Life scheme. Total weighted new sales in Q4 dropped 16% to S$432.7 million, and new business embedded value (NBEV) fell 53% to S$105.7 million. Despite this, the company's investment outperformance contributed to a 28% increase in net profit to S$995.3 million for FY2024. A final dividend of S$0.45 per share is proposed, payable on May 6.

SGX has no objection to granting the extension, the insurer says.
Great Eastern's Malaysian subsidiaries, along with AmMetLife Insurance and AmMetLife Takaful, were expected to sign exclusive deals to issue insurance products.

site_title: Trump says Canada, Mexico tariffs moving ‘forward’ on schedule
summary: US President Donald Trump confirmed that tariffs on Canadian and Mexican imports, initially set at up to 25%, are moving forward as planned, despite recent talks with French President Emmanuel Macron. The tariffs, which were paused for a month, will resume next Tuesday, potentially disrupting supply chains in key sectors like auto manufacturing. Trump reiterated his stance on "reciprocity" in trade, threatening duties on other countries that impose tariffs on the US. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum expressed optimism about reaching a deal, while Canadian Foreign Minister Melanie Joly warned of the "real threat" of tariffs.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump (right) and French President Emmanuel Macron (left) shake hands at the end of a joint press conference in the White House in Washington, D.C., Feb 24, 2025.

site_title: India’s Tata Play, Airtel Digital TV near merger: ET
summary: Tata Group and Bharti Group are finalizing a merger of their satellite TV businesses, Tata Play and Airtel Digital TV, amid mounting losses due to digital streaming migration. The merger, through a share swap, will see Bharti Airtel holding 52-55% and Tata Play shareholders, including Walt Disney, holding 45-48%. This marks a broader trend of consolidation in India's satellite TV sector, driven by video streaming platforms and a shrinking pay-TV subscriber base, similar to the 2016 Dish TV-Videocon d2h merger.

site_title: Brookfield makes US$1.7 billion bet on power needs by AI, data
summary: Brookfield Asset Management agreed to spend $1.7 billion on a US onshore renewables deal with National Grid, betting on robust power consumption growth from data centers and AI. The transaction, expected to be completed in 2026, follows a record-setting deal last year to provide clean energy to Microsoft. Investors remain confident in demand from technology companies, despite concerns about computing needs. The deal is part of National Grid's £6.8 billion capital raise program to fund investments in the UK's power network.

images.alt_text: Brookfield has more than 150 billion euros invested across digital infrastructure, renewable power and semiconductor manufacturing worldwide.
Brookfield will take over asset management of Gajoen, and plans to invest in renovating public spaces in the hotel and offices.

site_title: Chinese navy drill in Tasman Sea forced 49 flights to change paths: Australian official
summary: A Chinese naval live-fire drill in the Tasman Sea forced 49 flights to change their paths, according to Australian air traffic control officials. The drill, which occurred 300 nautical miles off Australia's east coast, was not adequately notified to Australian authorities, raising concerns. China's defence ministry claimed its actions complied with international law and did not affect aviation safety. Australia and New Zealand have expressed concerns to China about the lack of notice, and the incident has sparked calls for improved communication between nations.

images.alt_text: China’s share of global shipbuilding capacity has surged over the past decade to account for around half of new builds, partly driven by its own domestic demand for more ships.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as Trump tariffs, China curbs stunt rally
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping over 1% due to US President Donald Trump's renewed threats of tariffs on China and his call for curbs on Chinese investments in strategic sectors. Trump's announcement followed a negative day in New York, where tech giants were reassessing their investments after China's DeepSeek unveiled a chatbot that disrupted the AI industry. The losses also come ahead of Nvidia's earnings release, which will be closely watched for its views on the global outlook.

site_title: Crypto trading booms in India’s interiors as job growth and incomes disappoint
summary: Retail traders in India's interior cities are driving the growth of the cryptocurrency market, with cumulative trading volumes more than doubling to $1.9 billion in the October to December quarter. Many young Indians, seeking to supplement their low-paying jobs, are turning to crypto trading. Despite Indian authorities' warnings about the risks and volatility of cryptocurrencies, the market is expected to grow to $15 billion by 2035. The surge in interest may challenge the government's stance on cryptocurrencies, which have been discouraged by steep taxes and warnings.

images.alt_text: Ether remained under pressure even with the exchange Bybit saying it replenish all of the the estimated US$1.4 billion it lost to hackers last week.

Hong Kong and Singapore, along with Middle East standout Dubai, have cemented their front-runner status of becoming cryptocurrency hubs during a period when US regulators under Joe Biden’s administration were sceptical towards crypto.

site_title: Macron and Trump rekindle Le Bromance - with a touch of tension
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and US President Donald Trump rekindled their close relationship during talks on Ukraine, despite tensions over Trump's pivot to Russia. Macron interrupted Trump when he repeated a false claim about Europe's financial contribution to Ukraine, but the two leaders maintained a friendly demeanor. They engaged in various displays of physical affection, including handshakes, hugs, and backslaps, and Trump praised Macron for restoring the Notre-Dame cathedral. The meeting marked a thaw in their relationship, with Macron described as "friendly but firm" in his handling of Trump.

site_title: UK sanctions Chinese firms in clampdown on supplies to Russia
summary: The UK has imposed sanctions on 10 China-based companies that support Russia's military regime, including firms producing machine tools, electronics, and dual-use goods for Russia's military. The sanctions target those enabling Russia's defence industry and aim to show support for Ukraine amid the country's fourth-year invasion. The move is part of the UK's largest package of economic measures against Vladimir Putin's regime since 2022, and comes as US President Donald Trump signals his desire to pull-back US aid.

images.alt_text: China’s record trade surplus of nearly US$1 trillion last year was equivalent to more than 5 per cent of its gross domestic product, the highest level since 2015.

site_title: Bank of Korea signals more rate cuts as Trump’s tariffs take shape
summary: The Bank of Korea cut its benchmark interest rate to 2.75% and signaled more rate cuts this year to support the economy, which is expected to expand by 1.5% in 2025. The central bank cited Trump's tariff plans as a factor behind the downgrade in its economic forecast. Governor Rhee Chang-yong reiterated the need for the government to step in with more spending to help prop up growth and warned against relying only on monetary policy. The BOK is expected to deliver three more rate cuts in 2025, taking the base rate to 2% by year-end.

images.alt_text: Higher US tariffs on imports would likely shrink demand for items from key trading partners such as South Korea.

The political turmoil and Jeju Air plane crash “led to contractions in domestic consumption and construction investment, likely causing the fourth-quarter growth rate to fall well below the November projection”, Bank of Korea said.
The Bank of Korea held its benchmark interest rate at 3 per cent at its monetary policy review, an outcome expected by only seven of 34 economists polled by Reuters.

site_title: PropNex H2 profit down 14.9% at S$21.9 million; proposes special S$0.025 per share anniversary dividend
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a 14.9% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$21.9 million for its second half ended Dec 31. Revenue fell 7.7% to S$437.4 million, driven by a decrease in commission income from project marketing services. Despite this, the company expects a positive market outlook in 2025, forecasting a 3-4% rise in overall private home prices and a 5-7% price growth in the resale market. PropNex proposes a special S$0.025 per share anniversary dividend and a final dividend of S$0.03 per share for FY2024.

site_title: China’s oil teapots rocked by tax rules that threaten closures
summary: China's independent oil refineries, known as "teapots," are facing significant financial strain due to a stricter tax regime. The government's drive to root out overcapacity has resulted in provinces like Shandong cutting tax rebates on fuel oil purchases, forcing refiners to cut production or shut down. The sector is particularly vulnerable, with teapots operating on razor-thin margins. The situation could worsen as demand for petroleum products declines due to a slowing economy and electrification of transportation.

images.alt_text: China is the world’s biggest crude importer and the teapots are a cornerstone of a market that has driven gains in global oil demand for over a decade.

site_title: CLP to focus capital on Hong Kong and China in clean power push
summary: CLP Holdings plans to focus on investing in Hong Kong and mainland China, prioritizing a greener power generating portfolio, with a goal of phasing out coal consumption by 2040 and achieving net zero emissions by 2050. The company aims to double its renewable capacity in China to six gigawatts over the next four years. In other markets, such as Australia, CLP will seek self-funded partnerships. The company's Australian unit experienced a rebound in operating earnings last year, and CLP has hired a former banker to lead its dealmaking efforts.

site_title: Trump’s chip tariff threats raise stakes for Taiwan
summary: US President Donald Trump's threat of tariffs on semiconductor chips has complicated Taiwan's efforts to maintain its status as a global semiconductor powerhouse and stay aligned with the US. Taiwan produces over half of the world's chips and is crucial to global supply chains. Trump's tariff threats, which could include a 25% tax on imported chips, make it harder for Taiwan to keep its chip production in the US. The island's economic security depends heavily on its leadership in semiconductor manufacturing, and analysts fear that Trump's tariff threats may lead to pressure on Taiwan to make concessions.

site_title: Zoom issues dour revenue forecasts as demand slows
summary: Zoom issues dour revenue forecasts, citing slowing demand for video conferencing as companies transition away from hybrid work models. The company expects fiscal 2026 revenue between $4.79 billion and $4.80 billion, below analyst estimates. CEO Eric Yuan expressed confidence in the company's growth, but senior director Jeremy Goldman notes that Zoom's "pandemic-era surge" may not be sustainable. The company will launch an upgraded AI tool in April to automate workplace tasks.

site_title: Space could be the next frontier for growth-hungry South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asia is poised to reap significant economic benefits from harnessing Earth observation data from satellites and sensors, with the region's gross domestic product expected to increase by US$45 billion annually by 2030. The data can be used to track deforestation, floods, urban planning, and sustainable agriculture, with countries like Indonesia, Vietnam, and Malaysia expected to derive the most benefit. The study highlights the potential for space technology to drive growth in industries such as agriculture and mining, and Singapore is seen as a leader in this field, with its small landmass and supportive regulatory framework.

site_title: Nissan shares drop after Musk denies Tesla investment report
summary: Nissan's shares dropped up to 10% after Tesla CEO Elon Musk denied a report that Tesla was interested in investing in the ailing automaker. The report, published by Financial Times, suggested that a high-level Japanese group was planning to secure investment for Nissan's US plants. Musk later deflected the report on social media, calling it "fake news." Former Tesla board member Hiromichi Mizuno also denied involvement in any plans to secure Tesla investment for Nissan.

Shares in Nissan surged 11 percent on February 21, 2025 after a report said a high-level Japanese group including a former prime minister planned to ask US electric vehicle giant Tesla to invest in the automaker. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

site_title: Google’s AI previews erode the internet, US edtech company says in lawsuit
summary: Chegg, a US educational technology company, has filed a lawsuit against Google, alleging that the search engine is co-opting publishers' content to keep users on its own site, eroding demand for original content and undermining publishers' ability to compete. Chegg claims that Google's AI-generated overviews are eroding demand for original content, leading to a "hollowed-out information ecosystem." Google denies the claims, stating that its AI overviews create new opportunities for content discovery. The lawsuit could have implications for the digital publishing industry and the future of internet search.

images.alt_text: AI is being increasingly deployed in the workplace, from answering calls to carrying out legal research, following the success of ChatGPT and similar models over the past year.
Unlike earlier automation, which replaced routine jobs such as assembly line work and bookkeeping, AI may extend its reach to non-routine and creative work.
xAI plans to open-source preceding versions of its Grok models as soon as the latest one is fully mature, with Musk saying he expects that transition to be complete for Grok-3 in a few months.
Despite TikTok Shop’s breakneck growth, the video app’s future in the US is at doubt, given the continued threat of a ban should it fail to sell the US portion of its business.
Meta plans to work on its own humanoid robot hardware, with an initial focus on household chores.

site_title: UK relaunches free trade talks with India
summary: The UK has restarted free trade talks with India, with growth being the guiding principle in negotiations. The talks, led by Business and Trade Secretary Jonathan Reynolds, come after the UK government, under Prime Minister Keir Starmer, pushed for renewed talks since July. The UK and India are the sixth and fifth-largest global economies, with a £41 billion trade relationship and over 600,000 jobs supported. The UK aims to secure a trade deal that will unlock new opportunities for businesses and consumers, support jobs and boost wages.

images.alt_text: Britain's Secretary of State for Business and Trade Jonathan Reynolds told broadcasters Britain had a balanced trading relationship with the US and he reported “good engagement, good conversations” in his meetings with the Trump administration on the issue.

site_title: Chevron reorganises business structure, reshuffles leadership
summary: Chevron has reorganized its business structure and reshuffled its leadership team, aiming to improve operational efficiency and drive sustained growth. The company plans to lay off up to 20% of its global workforce by 2026 and has announced cost cuts of up to $3 billion. CEO Mike Wirth stated that the new structure and leadership appointments are designed to position Chevron for growth. The company has also reorganized its oil, products, and gas organization into two separate segments, with Clay Neff taking over upstream and Andy Walz leading the downstream, midstream, and chemicals segment.

images.alt_text: Chevron has said it is targeting up to US$3 billion in cost cuts through 2026 from leveraging technology, asset sales and changing how and where work is performed.
The profits of Exxon Mobil and Chevron plunged as the prospect of US tariffs on oil suppliers threatened to worsen the oil refining business.

site_title: Crypto’s ‘poor sentiment’ continues to weigh on altcoins, Ether
summary: Ether, the second-largest cryptocurrency, remains under pressure, with a 5% decline, while altcoins like Solana and Dogecoin drop 8.3% and 7% respectively. The sector is reeling from its biggest-ever hack and poor sentiment, with investors shifting to equities and fixed income. Analysts attribute the decline to exploitation from memecoin failures and lack of capital for new token launches. Bitcoin remains relatively strong, with a 1.4% decline, and shares of crypto-related companies also lower.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Singapore, along with Middle East standout Dubai, have cemented their front-runner status of becoming cryptocurrency hubs during a period when US regulators under Joe Biden’s administration were sceptical towards crypto.

site_title: PropertyBT: Singapore housing market insights - Exclusive interview with ERA’s Eugene Lim
summary: The Singapore housing market is expected to see significant changes in 2025, with HDB resale flat prices rising 9.7% in 2024 and potentially increasing further this year. ERA Singapore's Eugene Lim shares insights on the current market trends, government policies, and future predictions, including the impact of a growing but aging population and increased foreign workforce. Lim discusses affordable options in the resale market and financial assistance schemes for first-time buyers, offering a balanced view of the market dynamics.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro
Some high income earners may need to forego buying new condo units and look for resale condo or HDB homes.
Closer Johor-Singapore ties could mean more residents here relocating to Johor Bahru.
Things could be looking up for the condo market this year, says Ismail Gafoor from Propnex.

site_title: Providing foreign aid is in US interests: Condoms for Gaza?
summary: The US is set to freeze operations of the US Agency for International Development (USAID), potentially cutting off billions of dollars in foreign aid, amid concerns over the agency's size and efficiency. The move has sparked criticism, with experts warning that it could lead to greater global instability, undermine US strategic interests, and cede influence to rival powers like China. A complete dismantling of USAID could impair efforts to prevent crisis, promote health and education, and foster economic development worldwide, ultimately harming the US' humanitarian commitments and moral leadership.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People hold placards outside the USAID building, after billionaire Elon Musk, who is heading U.S. President Donald Trump's drive to shrink the federal government, said work is underway to shut down the U.S. foreign aid agency USAID, in Washington, U.S., February 3, 2025. REUTERS/Kent Nishimura/File Photo

site_title: Roberta Flack of ‘Killing Me Softly’ fame dies at 88
summary: Roberta Flack, the Grammy-winning singer behind 'Killing Me Softly With His Song,' has died at 88. Diagnosed with ALS in 2022, Flack lost her ability to sing but continued to produce timeless works of R&B. She won two Grammy Awards for 'Killing Me Softly' and 'The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face,' and was a key figure in the 'quiet storm' radio form of smooth, slow jams. Flack's legacy includes her music, activism, and her influence on later artists, with tributes from Jennifer Hudson and Questlove.

images.alt_text: Registrations of EVs and hybrid car models have grown, in line with the push to reduce carbon emissions.
Ed Sheeran on stage in Bhutan.

site_title: Changing demographics are driving innovation in Singapore’s insurance landscape
summary: Singapore's insurance premiums surged 27% to US$2.1 billion in the first half of 2024, driven by a rising influx of wealth, a growing mass affluent demographic, ongoing protection gaps, and an ageing population. Despite being a mature market, Singapore faces one of the highest protection gaps in Asia, with significant mortality and critical illness gaps. Insurers must innovate to bridge these gaps and address evolving needs, including retirement planning and legacy planning for high-net-worth individuals.

images.alt_text: As at end-December, about 40,000 more Singaporeans and permanent residents were covered by integrated shield plans.

site_title: Australian regulator pushes market operator ASX on fee transparency, competition
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has ordered the Australian stock market operator ASX to publish a comparison of clearing and settlement fees against foreign providers and justify any fee increases. The move aims to promote competition in the post-trade settlement and clearing market, challenging ASX's near-monopoly status. The new rules, set to take effect in three months, require ASX to ensure its clearing and settlement services are offered transparently and non-discriminarily, and to provide access to its services and technology to third-party providers.

images.alt_text: Perpetual's deal with KKR, which was initially announced in May last year, was deemed to be not in the best interests of shareholders by an independent expert.
In Sydney, housing values have jumped almost 70 per cent over the past 10 years, with the median dwelling price now around A$1.2 million (S$1 million).
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has yet to announce the exact date of elections but surveys show the cost of living is at the top of voters’ minds.

FILE PHOTO: A board displaying stock prices is adorned with the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) logo in central Sydney, Australia, February 13, 2018. Picture taken February 13, 2018. REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial H2 earnings soar to S$197.3 million
summary: Yangzijiang Financial reported a net profit of S$197.3 million in the second half of 2024, a four-fold increase from the previous year, driven by higher contributions from its fund investment and cash management businesses. The company's full-year revenue dipped 6% to S$326.2 million, largely due to a decline in interest income from its debt investments business in China. Yangzijiang plans to diversify and reallocate cash towards maritime-related investments, reducing its exposure to China and debt investments.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Ren Yuanlin, Yangzijiang Financial chief executive and executive chair, said: “The group now sits in a healthier position with lessened single-country risk."

site_title: Oil settles higher on fresh Iran sanctions, Iraq commitment to Opec+
summary: Oil prices rose 0.5% on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling at $74.78 a barrel, after US sanctions on Iran and Iraq's commitment to OPEC+ supply agreement helped alleviate concerns of near-term supply tightness. The US Treasury imposed fresh sanctions on Iran's oil industry, while Iraq promised to present a plan to compensate for overproduction. Despite concerns about ongoing tensions and potential supply disruptions, analysts expect oil prices to recover from Friday's steep selloff.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell 20 cents, or 0.3 per cent, to US$74.23 barrel at 0113 GMT, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures lost 28 cents, or 0.4 per cent, to US$70.12 a barrel.

site_title: UK to reap CPTPP benefits with strong focus on Asia: official
summary: The UK has officially joined the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a 12-member trade pact spanning five continents and nearly 600 million people. The UK's GDP is nearly £12 trillion, making it the pact's second-largest economy after Japan. With the UK on board, investment from CPTPP members in the country exceeded £200 billion in 2024. The UK government estimates that membership will generate around £5 billion a year, with 99% of exports to CPTPP members being tariff-free. This is expected to boost British businesses and drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: A man reads a Vietnamese newspaper with a front page story on the inauguration of US President Donald Trump. While Trump's earlier threats of tariffs are not off the negotiating table yet, pundits say Asean now has more leverage.

European Council President Antonio Costa (left) and Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer at a bilateral meeting at 10 Downing Street in December. Even though it is very unlikely that the UK will rejoin the EU in the next few years, there is nonetheless appetite from both sides to deepen ties.
The pact represents Britain’s first free trade deals with Malaysia and Brunei, but while it had agreements with the other countries.

site_title: Singapore shares slip on Monday after MAS unveils stock market measures; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks closed marginally lower, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 0.1% to 3,927.75, after the Monetary Authority of Singapore unveiled plans to boost the stock market. The top gainers included UOL and SGX, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell 7.1% and the three local banks finished in the red. Analysts expect SGX to benefit from stronger market volumes in the medium term due to the MAS's S$5 billion Equity Market Development Programme.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Will MAS review group's plan transform SGX or fall short?
SGX's share price shot up following strong earnings report, but subsequently fell back on concerns the MAS review group's recommendations would disappoint
Its profit for H2 rose/ fell X% or S$X to S$X.

site_title: Is China investable again?
summary: China's market has rallied this year, prompting questions about its investability. The answer is yes, and it was wrong to dismiss it as uninvestable due to a sharp decline in the broad market this decade. Despite an ageing workforce and crippling debt, China's economy still generates innovation and opportunity, particularly in select sectors. Sentiment has shifted, with investors rediscovering China as a vast market too vast to ignore. Geopolitical risks are receding, and the state is entering a period of retreat, making the country investable at the right price for those aware of the economic downside.

images.alt_text: Since 2023, Xi’s government has eased off on the campaign and indicated that it still sees the trillion-dollar technology sector as an important part of the country’s economy.
Alibaba's Qwen AI model has performed well in official benchmark tests and signalled the company’s growing relevance in the field.

site_title: Citadel Securities plots Jump into crypto trading after Trump’s embrace
summary: Citadel Securities, a global trading behemoth, plans to enter the cryptocurrency market after US President Donald Trump's endorsement. The firm aims to become a liquidity provider for cryptocurrencies, seeking to be added to exchanges like Coinbase and Binance. This move comes after years of pushing for regulatory rules around digital assets, paving the way for institutions to get involved. Citadel's pivot marks a significant shift from its previously cautious stance on crypto market-making.

images.alt_text: Citadel’s US$1 billion bond offering this week required Ken Griffin’s secretive hedge fund to produce a prospectus for investors.
Citadel Securities is also a designated market maker, helping to list companies on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: That online investment scam is a geopolitical problem
summary: Online scams have become a full-fledged industry with sophisticated supply chains and connections to nations like Russia, China, and North Korea, posing a significant global, geopolitical problem. Estimated losses are over $1 trillion annually, with victims often being trafficked into forced labor for scam groups. Governments must take online scams more seriously, investing in education, awareness, and international cooperation to combat the issue, which is also linked to state interests and could be exacerbated by AI tools.

images.alt_text: Generic picture of automated teller machines (ATMs) for DBS, OCBC, MayBank and UOB at Jewel Changi Airport on Oct 7, 2023.

site_title: The Business Times’ post-Budget dialogue on business resilience to be held on Mar 18
summary: The Business Times is organizing a post-Budget dialogue, "The Business Times Singapore Budget 2025 Dialogue", on March 18 at Sofitel Singapore City Centre. The event will feature a panel discussion with Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Indranee Rajah and DBS group executive Han Kwee Juan, moderated by BT deputy news editor Anita Gabriel. The discussion will analyze critical Budget measures and explore how businesses can leverage them for growth and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Merz in pole position after big German ballot
summary: Friedrich Merz's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) has secured the largest share of votes in Germany's snap national election, paving the way for him to become the next chancellor. Merz's top priority will be to rejuvenate the German economy, which has shrunk for two consecutive years. He may seek a core coalition partner in the Social Democrats (SPD) and could consider reaching out to the Greens, but faces challenges in dampening the rise of the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD). The election result will have significant implications for Germany's foreign policy, particularly with regards to China and Russia.

images.alt_text: Christian Democratic Union (CDU) party leader Friedrich Merz speaks at the party headquarters after exit poll results were announced, Berlin, Germany, Feb 23, 2025.
Frontrunner Friedrich Merz, in his final CDU/CSU campaign event in Munich on Saturday, said Europe needed to walk tall to be able to “sit at the main table” of the world powers.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly fall as markets await key economic data
summary: US stocks fell mostly on Monday ahead of key economic data and earnings, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.1% and the S&P 500 shedding 0.5%. The Nasdaq Composite Index slid 1.2%. US President Donald Trump signaled plans to proceed with tariffs on Canada and Mexico, citing high uncertainty in markets. Analysts say data points, including Nvidia earnings and US inflation data, could affect investor sentiment. Individual companies like Starbucks rose and Apple climbed, while Alibaba tumbled after announcing AI spending plans.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 65.1 points, or 0.15 per cent, at the open to 43,493.12.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, FCT, Yangzijiang Financial, PropNex, EC World Reit
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore stocks saw new developments on Tuesday. Great Eastern reported a net profit of S$134.8 million for Q4, down 14% from the previous year. FCT is offering S$80 million in fixed-rate green notes. Yangzijiang Financial reported a net profit of S$197.3 million for the second half, up 16% from the year-ago period. PropNex saw a 14.9% fall in net profit, while EC World Reit's net property income halved to S$11.2 million. The trading of units in EC World Reit has been suspended since Aug 31, 2023. Shares of these companies have been affected by the announcements.

site_title: Manchester United to cut 200 more jobs in bid to stem losses
summary: Manchester United is cutting up to 200 jobs, including reducing its London office, in an effort to return to profitability after five years of losses. The club's CEO, Omar Berrada, stated that the move is necessary to invest in the pitch and facilities. The cuts follow 250 job losses last year and trimming employee perks. The club will also end free lunches at Old Trafford, saving over £1 million a year. The move aims to improve the club's financial performance and deliver success on the pitch for fans.

images.alt_text: Manchester United's Amad Diallo (in white) scores the team's second goal past Liverpool's Alisson Becker, Liverpool, England, Jan 5, 2025.
Flags are displayed at a makeshift stand outside Old Trafford. Manchester United are in 14th place in the EPL, 23 points behind their next opponents, Liverpool.

site_title: Anthropic slated to hit US$61.5 billion valuation in new round
summary: Anthropic, a leading AI company, is set to raise $3.5 billion at a valuation of $61.5 billion in a new funding round. This marks a larger funding round than initially planned and follows similar recent deals by companies like xAI and OpenAI. The funding round is a significant milestone for Anthropic, which develops large language models, and highlights the growing interest in AI startups among investors.

site_title: Tesla deploys long-awaited FSD features to drivers in China
summary: Tesla has begun rolling out a software update in China that enables driver-assistance features similar to Full Self-Driving (FSD) in the US. The update allows Tesla owners to use features such as exit ramp guidance, traffic signal recognition, and lane changing on city streets. The update is initially available in cars with HW 4.0 hardware and is expected to expand to more vehicles. The capabilities, which require constant human supervision and frequent interventions, are priced at 64,000 yuan (S$11,805) in China, but Tesla has avoided using the term FSD in its publicity.

images.alt_text: ALHAMBRA, CALIFORNIA - JANUARY 02: The Tesla logo displayed at a Tesla dealership on January 2, 2025 in Alhambra, California. The electric vehicle (EV) company reported its first annual sales dip in 2024, down one percent from 2023.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

The Tesla gigafactory in Austin, Texas. Tesla was cited and fined about US$7,000 for two other workplace safety violations at its Texas plant last year, both involving violations of rules to protect workers from chemical hazards.
Tesla and India have engaged on and off for years, but the carmaker had stayed away from the South Asian nation over concerns on high import duties.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, February 24, 2025
summary: Asian markets tracked Wall Street's loss, while Australia's new ban on foreign property investors is expected to have limited impact. Indonesia launched a $20 billion sovereign wealth fund, and Olam sold 44.58% stake in Olam Agri for $1.8 billion, resulting in a record high for the company.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong advanced in early Asian trade, building on Friday’s blockbuster rally fuelled by tech firms, particularly an eye-watering rise of more than 14 per cent in ecommerce titan Alibaba.
In Sydney, housing values have jumped almost 70 per cent over the past 10 years, with the median dwelling price now around A$1.2 million (S$1 million).
The deal is estimated to place Olam Agri at a valuation of about US$4 billion.

site_title: Apple plans US$500 billion in US investment, 20,000 research jobs in next four years
summary: Apple plans to invest $500 billion in the US over the next four years, including 20,000 research and development jobs. The investment will cover purchases from US suppliers, TV show and movie filming for Apple TV+, and a new factory in Texas for AI servers. The move is seen as a gesture towards the Trump administration, with President Trump thanking Apple and CEO Tim Cook for the pledge. The investment is part of Apple's efforts to boost US semiconductor production, with the company working with Foxconn to build a facility in Houston and increasing its Advanced Manufacturing Fund to $10 billion.

images.alt_text: China is weighing a probe into Apple’s policies and the fees it charges app developers.
Apple touted the iPhone 16e as having many features found in more expensive models, including Apple-tailored artificial intelligence features and integration with OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

Apple late last month forecast strong sales growth signalling that the company will recover from a dip in iPhone sales as it rolls out artificial intelligence features in the coming months to more regions and languages.
Apple is also adding a new app to the Vision Pro for viewing spatial content tailored to the device, including 3D images and panoramas aggregated from outside sources.
Apple is working with Alibaba Group Holding and Baidu to create a system that passes muster with Chinese regulators.
Alibaba has become a Chinese AI favourite among investors early in 2025, with its stock price up over 40 per cent so far this year.
Taking this step suggests that Apple is trying to boost the appeal of TV+ and challenge streaming services such as Netflix and Disney+.
The iPhone maker is likely to stop offering encrypted storage in the UK, rather than break the security promises it made to its users everywhere.

site_title: Pentagon, DOJ tell workers to ignore Musk demand to justify jobs for now
summary: The US government agencies, including the Pentagon and Department of Justice, have advised their employees to ignore Elon Musk's demand to justify their jobs, citing potential legal pitfalls and agency autonomy. Despite the directive, Musk expects the "mess to get sorted out this week," signaling his plans remain in place. The move has added to confusion and panic among the over 2 million federal workers, who were instructed to provide five bullet points describing their accomplishments last week by late Monday.

images.alt_text: Tech billionaire Elon Musk and his young aides at the cost-cutting Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) are in the midst of a radical downsizing of the federal bureaucracy at the behest of Trump, who views the government as bloated and corrupt.

site_title: From EVs to concert tickets: 5 ways Singapore’s consumption patterns have changed since 2019
summary: Singapore's consumer price index (CPI) has been rebased to 2024, reflecting changes in household spending patterns since 2019. The CPI tracks the average price changes of a fixed basket of goods and services, with a greater weight given to housing and utilities, now accounting for 29.4% of the index. In contrast, spending on cars declined, with transport accounting for 13.1% of the index. The rebased CPI also includes more EVs and hybrid car models, as well as changes in leisure spending, education, and healthcare.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Lower inflation was recorded for the majority of categories in January.

site_title:
DBS CEO Piyush Gupta sees job cuts 
of 4,000 temp staff as AI replaces roles
summary: DBS Group Holdings, the largest lender in South-east Asia, plans to cut around 4,000 contract and temporary staff over the next three years due to the increasing adoption of artificial intelligence. The move, expected to shrink the workforce by 10%, will come from natural attrition as temporary and contract roles roll off, with permanent staff not affected. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta stated that 1,000 new positions will be added in AI, highlighting the bank's focus on embracing technology.

images.alt_text: CMG20241203-LongKH03/龙国雄/DBS [Marina Bay Financial Centre]
The landmark JS-SEZ, signed in January this year, is expected to create 100 projects, 20,000 jobs and investments across 11 sectors.
From tech to retail, media and finance, major companies are starting to shed employees as they undergo restructuring and adapt to changing market conditions.
Pang Yuheng pleaded guilty to three counts of cheating involving $324,000.

Singapore and Malaysia-based banks, including DBS Group Holdings, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, Malayan Banking and CIMB Group Holdings, say they remain committed to the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA).
The current Singapore head of corporate banking, Chen Ze Ling, is due to succeed as group head of corporate and SME banking from Apr 1.
SoundEye, one of the awardees this year, uses technology to detect and prevent falls for the elderly. It was established by Tan Yeow Kee in 2015.
Before Derrick Goh became the head of DBS' audit team in 2018, he led its regional wealth management programme.
DBS posted net profit of S$2.52 billion for Q4 ended Dec 31, 2024, up 11 per cent from S$2.27 billion in the year-ago period, amid broad-based growth.
DBS deputy chief executive and incoming CEO Tan Su Shan during an interview with The Straits Times at DBS HQ on Aug 12, 2024.

site_title: Still room for Singapore’s SkillsFuture lifelong learning movement to update itself
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture lifelong learning movement received upgrades in the 2025 budget, including a redesigned SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit and a new Workforce Development Grant. The SkillsFuture Credit scheme for individuals remains unchanged, but could be reviewed to prioritize certain economic areas and tailor credits to different groups, such as vulnerable workers and caregivers. Employers could also be allowed to top up workers' SkillsFuture credit allowances, and the focus of SkillsFuture could be better aligned with economic needs. The government may consider further tweaks to the program to improve accessibility and encourage training, particularly for Singaporeans who need guidance in navigating the SkillsFuture portal.

images.alt_text: Training participation levels declined across the board last year – for both the employed and unemployed, across age groups, education levels and in almost all industries.
Changes made to SkillsFuture schemes will ease logistical, administrative and cost burdens.

site_title: Fewer uni graduates in 2024 found full-time work, though more had higher pay: Survey
summary: A recent graduate employment survey in Singapore found that 79.5% of graduates secured full-time positions in 2024, down from 84.1% in 2023. The proportion of unemployed graduates increased to 12.9% in 2024, up from 10.4% in 2023. However, those who found full-time jobs saw higher median gross monthly salaries, with median earnings reaching S$4,500. The survey also showed that graduates in health sciences, business, and information and digital technologies had the highest full-time permanent employment rates, with median salaries increasing by 4.2% compared to the previous year.

site_title: GIC, Silver Lake complete US$1.7 billion acquisition of billing software firm Zuora
summary: GIC and Silver Lake have completed their US$1.7 billion acquisition of billing software firm Zuora. The deal was approved by shareholders at US$10 a share earlier this month. As a result, Zuora will cease trading on the New York Stock Exchange and will continue to be led by CEO Tien Tzuo. The acquisition marks Silver Lake's investment in the company, which it made in 2022 with a US$400 million strategic investment. Zuora will remain a private company, employing over 1,200 employees globally.

images.alt_text: GIC's additional US$150 million investment into Asia Healthcare Holdings follows their first investment of US$170 million in the company in Feb 2022.

site_title: No Time to Die, no seats to buy: Cathay’s losing battle
summary: Cathay Cineplexes, a Singapore-based cinema chain, has shuttered its West Mall location due to declining cinema attendance. In 2023, Singapore's cinema attendance reached 10 million, down from a peak of 22.1 million in 2011. Meanwhile, casinos in Singapore and the US saw significant revenue growth, with MBS reporting a 6.9% increase in Q4 2024 casino revenue. The decline of cinema attendance is attributed to industry strikes, creative bankruptcy, and the rise of streaming services, which people prefer for their convenience and escapism.

images.alt_text: Joyce Hooi
Global ticket sales fell at a double-digit clip last year due to a sharp drop in China, the world’s second-largest market, along with contractions in Japan, South Korea and Germany.
The cinema chain has five other existing outlets – Causeway Point at Woodlands, Downtown East at Pasir Ris, JEM at Jurong East, Century Square at Tampines and Clementi 321.
Occupancy at MBS is largely stable for the quarter.

site_title: Bybit hit by crypto’s worst hack with almost US$1.5 billion stolen
summary: Bybit, a major crypto exchange, was hit by a hack resulting in the loss of almost US$1.5 billion in tokens, the largest ever crypto theft. A hacker took control of an offline Ethereum wallet, with estimates suggesting US$1.46 billion in assets were stolen. Bybit's CEO, Ben Zhou, has assured clients that their money is safe and withdrawals are still open, with the exchange taking out bridge loans and securing funding to cover the loss. The hack has caused significant market volatility, with Ether and other cryptocurrencies dropping in value.

site_title: US: Wall St rebounds after last week's selloff
summary: US stocks rebounded on Monday, February 24, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 65.1 points, or 0.15%, to 43,493.12. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased, with gains of 13.6 points, or 0.23%, and 66.8 points, or 0.34%, respectively. The rebound followed a sharp selloff in the previous week. Apple rose after announcing a $500 billion investment plan.

site_title:
Property players more optimistic in Q4 but risk 
of cooling measures looms large: NUS poll
summary: Singapore property executives are more optimistic in the fourth quarter of 2024, with a 4% current net balance, but risk of cooling measures looms large. Almost 80% of respondents pointed to government intervention as a top risk in the next six months. Despite this, new launches are expected, with 80% of respondents anticipating more projects, and 66.7% expecting moderately higher launch prices. Strong sales momentum continues, with 3,375 private homes launched in November and 2,557 units sold, driven by lower interest rates and inflation. Analysts predict private residential prices could rise 4-7% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Singapore's once high flying Reit sector could be in trouble if more Reits get privatised.
The 501-unit Elta in Clementi starts booking sales this weekend, with analysts expecting the project to sell well on the launch weekend.
In Sydney, housing values have jumped almost 70 per cent over the past 10 years, with the median dwelling price now around A$1.2 million (S$1 million).

site_title: EC World Reit’s Q4 net property income more than halves to S$11.2 million
summary: EC World Reit's Q4 net property income more than halves to S$11.2 million, down from S$22.7 million in the same period last year. The Reit's revenue fell 36.6% to S$15.9 million. Due to insufficient funds, the Reit will continue to suspend distributions until sufficient free cash is available. The decline in operating performance is attributed to the expiry of master lease agreements and the novation of underlying leases from master leases and related party leases.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The unauthorised mortgage for Fu Heng Warehouse has been discharged.

site_title: FCT prices S$80 million green notes due 2032 at 3.3%
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) issued S$80 million in fixed-rate green notes due 2032 at 3.3% interest, semi-annually. The notes will be used to finance or refinance FCT's eligible sustainable projects. The issuance is part of FCT's S$3 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. Units of FCT rose 0.48% on the news, and the sole lead manager for the Series 002 notes is UOB.

images.alt_text: Northpoint City mall
Jessie Lim

site_title: Europe: German shares steal spotlight after Merz’s conservatives win vote
summary: German conservatives led by Friedrich Merz won the national election with promises of pro-growth policies, boosting the country's economy. German stocks outperformed the pan-European Stoxx 600 index, with the domestically-focussed German mid-cap index jumping 1.5% and the blue-chip index ending 0.6% higher. A reform-minded government could lead to increased confidence, driving investments and consumption, according to UBS chief investment officer Maximilian Kunkel. However, potential reforms to the debt brake and coalition negotiations with the far-right Alternative for Germany party may create uncertainty.

images.alt_text: German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, February 10, 2025.    REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Thailand unicorns remain elusive as banks’ dominance stifles fintechs
summary: Thailand's fintech sector lacks unicorns due to the dominance of six major banks, which stifle competition and innovation. Many fintechs in Thailand are designed to support banks rather than scale into independent ventures. The country has few foreign venture capital firms, and those available are mostly corporate venture capitalists, limiting access to funding. Analysts predict that virtual banks, which have lower overhead costs, will not disrupt the market significantly, and the lack of a competitive environment hinders innovation. Thailand needs to increase venture capital, incubators, and accelerators to stimulate innovation and support startups.

images.alt_text: Chin Sophonpanich founded Bangkok Bank in 1944, when he branched out from selling construction materials and canned goods.

site_title: Euro treads water as focus shifts to German coalition talks; US dollar steadies
summary: The euro reached a one-month high of US$1.0528 in Asian trade before stabilizing at 0.03% at US$1.04635 due to a shift in focus to German coalition talks following the election victory of conservatives. Meanwhile, the US dollar steadied after a two-month low amid concerns over the US economy's growth outlook. German Chancellor Friedrich Merz faces complex coalition negotiations after his party emerged victorious, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Trump U-turn on NYC’s congestion pricing programme could dampen ST Engineering sentiment, but limited impact expected
summary: The Trump administration has reversed federal approval for New York City's congestion pricing programme, but analysts expect a minimal impact on ST Engineering's stock, as the company's subsidiary TransCore has already completed the engineering phase of the contract. The programme, which charges drivers $9 during peak hours, is expected to raise $15 billion for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Analysts believe the revocation introduces uncertainty, potentially deterring other municipalities from implementing similar systems, but TransCore's operations and maintenance revenue constitutes only 2-3% of ST Engineering's revenue.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
The commercial aerospace segment clinched several new contracts across its maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO), as well as its aerostructures and systems sub-units.

Drivers entering parts of Manhattan will be charged US$9 during peak hours in a programme following similar initiatives in London, Stockholm and Singapore that aims to reduce the worst traffic in the world.

site_title: Thai finance minister sees room for easing ahead of central bank rate review
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Pichai Chunhavajira, anticipates room for an interest rate cut to boost economic growth and weaken the baht. With inflation at 1.32% in January, below the central bank's target range, he believes reducing interest rates will help heat up the economy. However, 16 out of 26 economists polled by Reuters predict the Bank of Thailand will maintain the 2.25% interest rate. The central bank's rate review is scheduled for this week.

images.alt_text: Tourism, which accounts for about 12 per cent of the country’s gross domestic product and a fifth of total employment, is forecast to bring in an estimated US$55 billion this year.

site_title:
ETC, OrangeTee to merge, eyeing 
regional expansion
summary: Real estate consultancy ETC and property agency OrangeTee Group are merging to form a new entity, aiming to be the region's "most comprehensive real estate company". The merged group will offer end-to-end real estate brokerage and consultancy services to clients, including individual buyers, developers, and corporations. The new entity, led by ETC's Desmond Sim as group CEO and OrangeTee's Justin Quek as deputy CEO, will comprise over 520 employees and 2,800 agents, with the incorporation expected to be completed by March 31.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

site_title: Nominations for Sustainability Impact Awards open until May 16, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Awards 2025 applications are now open, with a deadline of June 30. The awards recognize and celebrate the growth and achievements of early-stage businesses. The event aims to provide a platform for entrepreneurs to showcase their innovative ideas and connect with industry experts. Winners will be announced in August 2025, and the awards ceremony is scheduled to take place in the fall. The Emerging Enterprise Awards 2025 is presented by [Organization Name], a leading industry organization.

site_title: South Korea’s stimulus plan likely to drive up bond yields
summary: South Korea's proposed 35 trillion won fiscal stimulus to boost its slowing economy may drive up bond yields and steepen the yield curve. The plan, proposed by the opposition party, could lead to increased supply of government debt, putting pressure on the won and bond market. Analysts expect the actual amount to be determined in the coming weeks, with some seeing it as an opportunity for trading. The move comes amid concerns over US tariffs and a recent brush with martial law, which has battered consumer confidence and weakened the won.

images.alt_text: A global rush to develop artificial intelligence technology has been a boon for companies such as SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics that produce advanced memory chips.
A Ministry of Justice vehicle (blue) carrying South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol drives en route to the Seoul Central District Court, Seoul, South Korea, Feb 20, 2025.
The regulation divides the world into tiers, with South Korea among about 18 countries essentially exempt from the restrictions.

site_title: Hedging trade war and inflation risks
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies and immigration plans may lead to higher inflation, increasing the likelihood of higher-for-longer inflation. Investors should factor this into their investment strategies. A balanced approach is suggested, allocating 45% to global equities, 30% to global bonds, and 25% to other asset classes, such as gold and private credit. Alternative assets like hedge funds and private equity can also provide diversification and potentially strong returns in an inflationary environment.

images.alt_text: Diversification gets its magic from the fact that the prices of different assets do not all move together.

site_title: Gold steady near record highs amid tariff concerns, inflation data awaited
summary: Gold prices remained near record highs on Monday, steady at US$2,934.82 an ounce, amid concerns over US President Donald Trump's tariff plans and inflation data. Trump's proposed tariffs on lumber, forest products, and other imported goods are seen as inflationary, potentially reducing gold's appeal as a non-yielding asset. The Federal Reserve's interest rate trajectory will be closely monitored, with a key inflation report due later this week.

images.alt_text: The global gold market has been in upheaval in recent weeks, at a time when prices were already near record highs
Prices reach new highs this week as uncertainties surrounding global economic growth and political instability underscores investor appetite for bullion.

site_title: SoftBank, Temasek among eFishery investors facing near wipeout
summary: SoftBank and Temasek, among other investors, are facing a near wipeout of their investments in eFishery, a failed Indonesian startup. The company incurred hundreds of millions of dollars in losses between 2018 and 2024 and misrepresented its financial figures. An investigation found that eFishery is not commercially viable, with only 6,300 of its 400,000 promised fish feeders sending back data. Investors can expect to recover only 8.3-9.5 cents for every dollar invested, according to a presentation by FTI Consulting Singapore.

images.alt_text: eFeeder, an automatic fish and shrimp feeder created by eFishery.

site_title: PBOC’s policy flip-flop sows confusion over timing of rate cuts
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has not cut interest rates in nearly half a year, despite its most pro-easing stance in 14 years, sparking confusion over the timing of rate cuts. Beijing's priorities are shifting in favor of the yuan, with officials hinting at lowering cash reserve requirements but not following through. The delay in monetary easing has deprived the economy of stimulus, and global banks now expect rate cuts in the second quarter instead of the first. The PBOC's balancing act between unleashing stimulus and defending the yuan will further test the economy, which is struggling with its worst property slump since the 1990s.

images.alt_text: The central bank has been draining funds in most daily operations this year, widening the gap between the benchmark money market rate and the policy rate to the most in four years.
Yields have been rising as the PBOC held back on further monetary easing to prioritise yuan stability in the wake of a renewed trade war with the US.
China's one-year loan prime rate (LPR) was kept at 3.10 per cent, while the five-year LPR was unchanged at 3.60 per cent.

site_title: UK firms seek fewer staff but offer higher salaries, Adzuna says
summary: UK job vacancies fell 4.5% in January to 828,500, the lowest since 2021, according to Adzuna. Despite this, average advertised salaries rose 7.0% year-over-year, driven by strong competition for talent in key sectors. The Bank of England expects a slowdown in the labor market in 2025, which could help reduce inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: epa11906972 People walk across London Bridge on their way to work in London, Britain, 19 February 2025. Improvements in life expectancy in England have seen the sharpest decline across Europe, according to research in The Lancet Public Health journal. site_title: Chinese firms dump Europe for Hong Kong to raise funds
summary: Chinese companies are shifting their focus from European listings to Hong Kong, following Beijing's securities regulator tightening rules. Companies like Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Ltd (CATL) are now preparing for Hong Kong listings instead of global depositary receipts in Europe. This trend is a sign of Europe's diminishing popularity as a listing destination, with the China Securities Regulatory Commission restarting GDR approvals after introducing new rules. Many mainland companies are favoring Hong Kong due to Beijing's support, making it a share-sale venue.

images.alt_text: Alibaba operates some of China’s most widely used online shopping platforms, making its performance a bellwether for consumer sentiment.
Mixue is best known for selling fruit and tea drinks, coffee and ice cream, typically for about US$1.

CATL’s Hong Kong listing plan comes as the city sees increased interest for second listings from Chinese A-share companies, which are seeking to tap into overseas liquidity.

The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index closed up 3.5 per cent at a fresh three-month high. The Hang Seng Tech Index surged 5.1 per cent, and Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng index added 2.8 per cent.
Donald Trump’s actions potentially mark the beginning of a series of threatened trade attacks, though he has so far scaled back his planned actions against China.
At least six firms have said they intend to hold initial public offerings in Hong Kong by late January, raising a combined HK$3.3 billion (S$578 million).

site_title: Adani plans 1.1 trillion rupees of new investments in India growth push
summary: Billionaire Gautam Adani announced plans to invest over 1.1 trillion rupees (S$17 billion) in India, focusing on domestic growth amid ongoing legal challenges and project setbacks globally. The investments will fund projects in pumped storage, cement, mining, smart-metres, and thermal energy. Adani also discussed a greenfield smart city, airport project, and coal-gasification project in Madhya Pradesh, despite facing US corruption charges and funding challenges.

images.alt_text: President Anura Kumara Dissanayake’s administration opened probes into the company’s local projects after billionaire founder Gautam Adani (top) was charged with bribery in the United States late last year.
This is the first phase of Adani Group’s exit from the joint venture in which it holds 44 per cent.
Adani Enterprises will sell a 13 per cent stake in Adani Wilmar to comply with India’s minimum public shareholding requirements.

site_title: Musk’s Starlink races with Chinese rivals to dominate satellite internet
summary: Elon Musk's Starlink satellite internet network faces increasing competition from Chinese state-backed rival SpaceSail and other services, including Jeff Bezos's Project Kuiper Internet. SpaceSail aims to deploy 648 LEO satellites this year and 15,000 by 2030, while Starlink currently has about 7,000 satellites and plans to operate 42,000 by the end of the decade. China's push for satellite broadband has raised concerns among Western policymakers, who fear it could extend Beijing's internet censorship regime.

images.alt_text: Trump denounced Zelenskiy as “a dictator without elections" after the latter said the US President was trapped in a Russian disinformation bubble.

site_title: MAS could ease policy in April, after Singapore core inflation slowed sharply to 0.8% in January: economists
summary: Singapore's core inflation slowed to 0.8% in January, its lowest rate since 2021, and headline inflation was 1.2%, lower than expected. Economists expect another easing of monetary policy in April, with some predicting a further flattening of the slope of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate policy band. However, official forecasts for 2025 remain unchanged, with MAS and MTI predicting core inflation to average between 1-2% and headline inflation between 1.5-2.5%. The decline in inflation is attributed to broad-based moderation and base effects from past goods and services tax hikes.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Registrations of EVs and hybrid car models have grown, in line with the push to reduce carbon emissions.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects Singapore’s growth momentum to slow over this year, after “outperforming” in the second half of last year.

site_title: New Zealand retail sales rebound in sign recession has ended
summary: New Zealand's retail sales rebounded in the fourth quarter with a 0.9% increase, after being unchanged in the third quarter. This marks the second time in the past 12 quarters that sales have risen, following the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's interest rate cuts. The economy is seen to have grown 0.3% in the fourth quarter, ending signs of recession. Economists attribute the rebound to improved consumer sentiment and lower borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has now cut rates by 175 basis points since August, with a slowdown in inflation giving policymakers leeway to extend their easing efforts in a much needed boost for an economy struggling to emerge from a deep recession.
The RBNZ will publish its decision at 2 pm local time on Wednesday and Orr will hold a press conference an hour later.
Net arrivals of foreigners dropped by more than 97,000 from 2023 but were still the second-highest on record at around 74,100, today’s report showed.

site_title: Why market expectations of the US Fed’s rate path may be wrong
summary: The US Federal Reserve's rate path may be misinterpreted due to a divergence between short-term and long-term interest rates. Despite cutting rates, long-term yields have remained high, driven by fiscal deficits, increased government borrowing, and a rebuilding of the term premium. Softening wage growth and cooling housing costs may allow inflation to moderate further, giving the Fed room to continue cutting rates. The Fed is likely to cut rates further, potentially as early as March, which could benefit fixed income investors, particularly those seeking stable income and diversification globally.

images.alt_text: For all the criticism the Federal Reserve received in the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic, US Treasuries never failed to signal elevated inflation rates would recede under president Joe Biden.
The Nasdaq-100 Index remains in a strong uptrend, trading within a rising trend channel, that reflects increasing investor optimism.
The 10-year yield fell as far as 4.4 per cent, the lowest since Feb 7, before slightly paring the move.

site_title: SGX shares climb more than 5% after MAS review group unveils plans to boost stock market
summary: Singapore's stock market saw a 5% surge after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced a $5 billion Equity Market Development Programme to boost trading liquidity and encourage research into Singapore-listed companies. The programme will channel funds to asset managers with a strong track record and focus on Singapore-listed equities. Additionally, the MAS revised the Global Investor Programme, requiring family offices to invest a targeted proportion of their assets in Singapore-listed equities. The measures aim to enhance the competitiveness of Singapore's equities market and attract investor interest.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 24)
summary: Lower inflation rates were recorded for most categories in January, with Singapore's core inflation at 0.8% and overall inflation at 1.2%. ETC and OrangeTee announced a merger to become the region's most comprehensive real estate company. The tech and financial services sectors are experiencing significant layoffs, including giants Meta, Amazon, and HSBC. Meanwhile, Raffles Medical Group rose 6.1% after announcing a 100 million share buyback plan and a 4.3% rise in H2 profit.

site_title: Vietnam adds to global steel turmoil with tariffs hitting China
summary: Vietnam has imposed temporary tariffs on Chinese steel, ranging from 19.38% to 27.83%, set to come into effect on March 7 and last for 120 days. The move follows similar actions by South Korea and other nations amid a surge in Chinese steel exports, which reached a nine-year high in 2024. Analysts say the tariffs should encourage China to reform its steel industry and improve supply discipline. The tariffs will primarily affect Vietnam's imports of hot-rolled coil from China, with about 50% of last year's exports likely to be covered.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration has ramped up pressure on Mexico to put its own tariffs on imports from China.
