site_title: CapitaLand India Trust to buy Bengaluru office project for 14.7 billion rupees
summary: CapitaLand India Trust has agreed to purchase a 1.13 million-square-foot office project in Bengaluru for 14.7 billion rupees. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the first half of 2030, increasing the operational area to 9.9 million sq ft. The project is part of a mixed-use development with retail space, and the trustee-manager expects a net profit of S$7.7 million and distribution per unit to rise to S$0.0696.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Trump eyes tariffs to counter digital taxes big tech loathes
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to sign a memorandum on Friday to counter digital services taxes imposed by countries on US tech giants, including Alphabet and Meta. The memo will propose retaliatory measures, including tariffs, on countries that impose digital taxes, targeting imbalances in trade. Trump views these taxes as "terrible" and will announce his plan to reporters.

images.alt_text: The survey is based on input from more than 100 of AmCham Vietnam’s members, which include big multinational companies such as Intel and Nike.
China is weighing a probe into Apple’s policies and the fees it charges app developers.
Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent to US$2,941.25 an ounce.

site_title: Haw Par posts 5.5% drop in H2 profit; proposes special dividend of S$1 per share
summary: Haw Par Corp reported a 5.5% drop in second-half profit to S$106.3 million, driven by higher costs. Revenue grew 4.8% to S$126.7 million, mainly due to higher sales from the healthcare segment. The company proposed a special dividend of S$1 per share and a final dividend of 20 cents per share. Haw Par expects continued inflationary pressures and uncertain consumption recovery, which may impact its operating profits and margins.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Freehold River Valley Apartments sells for S$56 million to a Singapore family office
summary: A Singapore family office has purchased River Valley Apartments, a freehold four-storey walk-up block, for S$56 million. The sale, the first collective sale of 2025, translates to a land rate of around S$1,622 per square foot per plot ratio. Owners will receive S$2 million to S$2.6 million, depending on unit sizes. The site is zoned for residential use under URA's Master Plan 2019 and has a gross plot ratio of 2.8, with a location close to Great World City.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

The 54-storey V on Shenton (left) comprises 510 apartments. It is part of a mixed-use project by Singapore Land Group that also includes the adjacent 23-storey UIC Building, comprising mostly offices.
Fuji Xerox Towers on Anson Road developing into Newport Plaza, a mixed-use development
The collective sale of Concorde Hotel and Shopping Mall for S$821 million in November was the largest such transaction last year.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends sharply lower on mounting concerns over economy, tariffs
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, Feb 21, as economic data showed dampening business activity and deteriorating consumer sentiment. The sell-off was fueled by new tariff threats and worries of softening demand. All three major US stock indexes declined sharply, posting steep weekly losses. The downturn was attributed to consumer sentiment, tariffs, and corporate earnings surpassing AI and technology as market drivers.

images.alt_text: “The war against crypto, at least as it applies to Coinbase, is over,” Coinbase said.

site_title: Avoiding the own goal in cybersecurity
summary: A 2024 Verizon Data Breach Investigations Report found that 68% of cybersecurity breaches involve a non-malicious human element, such as social engineering or internal mistakes. These breaches often stem from misconfigurations, accidental clicks, or misunderstandings of processes, giving attackers opportunities to cause significant harm. The report highlights the critical role of DNS (domain name system) in cybersecurity, which is often overlooked in layered defense approaches. Advanced DNS security solutions can provide critical visibility, detect anomalies, and block malicious communication, helping organizations avoid internal "own goals" and strengthen their defenses.

images.alt_text: illustration depicting the  cyber threat intelligence with ai, 24/7 cyber security

site_title: Wall Street giant Morgan Stanley eases diversity emphasis in annual report
summary: Morgan Stanley has toned down its emphasis on diversity in its annual report, shifting focus to "meritocracy" and a "workforce that represents the societies in which we live and work." The bank cited an employee survey showing 40% of its global workforce and 29% of its officers are women. This move comes amid a push by President Donald Trump's administration to dismantle diversity, equity and inclusion programs. The change signals a recalibration as businesses adapt to the changing reality.

images.alt_text: The Morgan Stanley headquarters in New York, US, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2025. Morgan Stanley is scheduled to release earnings figures on January 16. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Gold eases from record high on profit-taking, eyes eighth weekly gain
summary: Gold prices eased 0.1% to $2,939.63 an ounce on Friday, after reaching a record high of $2,954.69 on Thursday. Despite profit-taking, gold is set for an eighth straight weekly gain, driven by concerns over US President Donald Trump's tariff plans and global economic uncertainty. The price has risen 1.9% this week, with investors seeking safe-haven assets. Analysts attribute demand to western investors and central banks, while caution remains on the impact of inflation and interest rates.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent to US$2,941.25 an ounce.

site_title: Greenback recovers as markets in consolidation mode; pares gains after data
summary: The US dollar rose against a range of currencies on Friday, but pared gains after S&P Global data showed US business activity dropped to a 17-month low in February. The data kept the prospect of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve intact, with US rate futures pricing in 44 basis points of easing this year. The dollar index was last up 0.2% at 106.59. Despite a selloff in Japanese government bonds, the yen fell 0.4% to 149.02 against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: US stocks tumble as economic data suggests dampening business activity and deteriorating consumer sentiment.

site_title: Mastercard wins UK court nod for £200 million deal to end £10 billion class action claim
summary: Mastercard has won approval from a UK court to pay £200 million to settle a class action claim over fees charged to consumers and businesses, ending a high-profile lawsuit valued at over £10 billion. The Competition Appeal Tribunal rejected Innsworth Advisors' allegations that the settlement undervalued the claim. The settlement, agreed upon earlier, will be finalized subject to a formal order. Mastercard's spokesperson welcomed the tribunal's decision, while spokespeople for Innsworth and lead claimant Walter Merricks declined to comment.

site_title: Peter Kwee registered properties in daughter’s name to avoid estate duty: lawyers
summary: Tycoon Peter Kwee admitted in court that he registered properties in his daughter's name to avoid estate duty, claiming he "genuinely believed" that this would allow him to retain ownership. However, his lawyers argue that this was a legitimate practice for a layperson, as it would not have affected his beneficial interest in the properties. The court has accepted that Kwee views himself as the leader of the family and owner of family assets, and his lawyers point to instances where his daughter, Karen, signed agreements without question, suggesting that the properties would have been used by Kwee. The court will deliver a written judgment at a later date.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Motoring tycoon Peter Kwee and his family arrived in Singapore in 1978. His company Group Exklusiv is involved in the automotive and property development businesses.
It was only after a statutory demand had been served on Karen Kwee in May 2022 that the elder Kwee lodged a caveat for the King's Drive property under her name.

site_title: Thai rice farmers demand better support as prices plummet
summary: Thai rice farmers are dissatisfied with government support measures, which failed to meet their demands as paddy prices plummeted by 30% year-on-year to $256 per ton. The government announced 1.89 billion baht worth of measures, including loans and assistance with storage fees, but farmers say they are not sincere. Protests are planned, with farmers seeking a guaranteed price of $11,000 per ton or help selling rice at the same level. The situation is exacerbated by rising cultivation costs and climate change, threatening Thailand's centuries-old rice cultivation system.

images.alt_text: The stronger baht is impacting liquidity and profits, especially for agricultural goods, says the chairman of the Thai National Shippers’ Council

site_title: Fired and rehired - the dizzying confusion of Trump's government overhaul
summary: US President Donald Trump's government overhaul has led to chaotic and potentially dangerous layoffs, with thousands of federal workers fired and later rehired. The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has adopted a blunt force approach, firing probationary employees and targeting categories of workers. However, many mistakes have been made, including the wrongful firing of nuclear security workers and the rehiring of employees critical to public safety. Critics say the approach shows a disregard for the important role government plays in people's lives and has long-term impacts on national security and morale.

images.alt_text: The judge’s decision comes as around 6,700 workers at the 100,000-strong Internal Revenue Service (IRS) who were on probation were being laid off.

site_title: US homebuilders near S&P 500 bottom on high rates and tariff fears
summary: US homebuilders are nearing the S&P 500's bottom due to high interest rates and tariff fears, with the industry sinking 24% since President Trump's election win. Confidence among US homebuilders has dropped to a five-month low, and housing starts slowed in January. The sector's recent weakness follows two years of solid gains, with investors bracing for more near-term declines. Despite valuations turning cheaper, technical strategists warn of emerging bearish signals suggesting deeper losses, and a potential 25% tariff on imports from Canada and Mexico threatens to raise prices on building materials.

images.alt_text: Housing inflation has remained stubbornly high month after month amid a national shortage, becoming a major issue for voters in the recent election.
China is weighing a probe into Apple’s policies and the fees it charges app developers.
The survey is based on input from more than 100 of AmCham Vietnam’s members, which include big multinational companies such as Intel and Nike.

About 50 per cent of the cars sold in the United States are manufactured within the country. Among imports, about half come from Mexico and Canada and the other half from other major auto-producing countries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 21)
summary: Two National Gallery Singapore restaurants, Odette and National Kitchen by Violet Oon, will remain after seven out of nine F&B tenants were told to leave due to lease expirations. JTC Corporation will appoint a new CEO, replacing Jacqueline Poh, the current EDB managing director. Seatrium achieved its first full-year profit with a net profit of S$120.9 million for the second half. Singapore stocks ended higher on Friday, with the STI expanding 0.1%, following regional gains and earnings reports.

site_title: Deep spending cuts in Indonesia trigger protests against Prabowo
summary: Protests erupted in Indonesia as President Prabowo Subianto's state budget revamp threatened contractual workers' jobs, rolled back scholarships, and dimmed government office lighting. Students, calling for the review of the $30-billion free meal program and cancellation of the $19-billion spending cuts, organized "Dark Indonesia" rallies in Jakarta and other cities. Authorities blocked a major road, while protesters clashed with police. Prabowo's popularity has been record-high, but the austerity drive has sparked opposition, adding to global trade tensions and soft economic growth in the country.

images.alt_text: A screen displays stock figures at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Feb. 15, 2024. Indonesian stocks jumped in early trading as traders bet on policy continuity after Defense Minister Prabowo Subianto declared victory in Wednesday's presidential vote. Photographer: Muhammad Fadli/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall St opens mixed after Thursday’s fall; UnitedHealth drops
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Friday, following a fall on Thursday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 356.5 points, or 0.81%, to 43,820.13. The S&P 500 fell 3.4 points, or 0.06%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 44.3 points, or 0.22%. UnitedHealth Group slid after a US Justice Department investigation into the healthcare conglomerate. The mixed start follows a weaker-than-expected forecast from Walmart on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore stocks end up on Friday as regional indices gain ground; STI expands 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,929.94 on Friday, driven by regional gains and earnings reports. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong jumped 4% on Alibaba's earnings beat, while Japan's Nikkei 225 and Bursa Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index also climbed. Economists warn that US tariffs could have a significant impact on Asian economies, estimating a 0.2% drag on GDP growth for each 10% drop in US-bound exports.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
China is weighing a probe into Apple’s policies and the fees it charges app developers.
Hong Kong stocks soared more than two per cent on Friday on the back of an 11 per cent surge in Chinese ecommerce titan Alibaba.
Genting Singapore said that it remains committed to its RWS 2.0 investments, such as the opening of a super luxury all-suite hotel and the Singapore Oceanarium in the third quarter of 2025.

site_title: Malaysia Starbucks franchise holder triples loss on boycotts
summary: Malaysia's Berjaya Food, a Starbucks franchise holder, reported a net loss of RM70.3 million for the six-month period ending December, due to boycotts of US fast food brands over America's support of Israel's Gaza offensive. The company operates 408 Starbucks cafes in Malaysia, but the boycotts have impacted the brand's performance. Despite this, Berjaya remains committed to growth and diversification, and expects strategic initiatives to enhance performance and drive positive results.

images.alt_text: Starbucks Photographer: Sanjit Das/Bloomberg

site_title: Sats posts 123.5% rise in Q3 net profit on higher business volume, rate increases
summary: Sats, a catering and ground handling company, posted a 123.5% increase in net profit to S$70.4 million for Q3 2024, driven by higher business volume and rate increases. Revenue rose 12.5% to S$1.5 billion, with gateway services climbing 10.1% and food solutions revenue growing 21.1%. The company expects to navigate tariff increases and volatility in trade flows, citing its global network and resilience. Free cash flow improved to S$118.1 million.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Semiconductor-related companies and grocers are among analysts' top picks for stocks favoured to gain from Budget 2025 schemes.
SATS will purchase the remaining 15 per cent stake in SATS Food Solutions (Thailand) for about S$3.4 million.
The new cargo handling and ground handling stations span across North America, the United Kingdom, Europe and Asia.

site_title: Thailand’s tennis trailblazer: Tamarine Tanasugarn still gives back to the sport
summary: Thailand's tennis trailblazer, Tamarine Tanasugarn, recently attended the inaugural Singapore Tennis Open as a community ambassador. The three-time Olympian, who retired in 2016, now runs a tennis academy in Bangkok, coaching about 100 young players. Tanasugarn, a grass-court specialist, enjoyed success at the highest levels, ranking in the top 20 in singles and doubles. She also played doubles with Maria Sharapova, winning two titles in 2003. Tanasugarn assesses Thai tennis, noting the rise of young players like Kasidit Samrej and Mananchaya Sawangkaew, and believes that tennis has changed significantly over the last two decades with advancements in nutrition and technology.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Raducanu, ranked 56th in the world, was eliminated in the first round of the Singapore Tennis Open by Spain's Cristina Bucsa on Jan 27, 2025.
This year's OCBC Cycle features a new virtual ride for cyclists to complete a minimum 120 km in a single round-island journey.
Elise Mertens shows her delight after bagging her ninth career singles title on the WTA Tour.

"Our main goal is to support the World Aquatics Championships as best as we can and make sure that everything runs smoothly, so that Singapore can shine brightly as a world-class host and sports destination," says Mazda Singapore managing director Chong Kah Wei.

site_title: Trust Bank hits one million customers, launches investment products
summary: Trust Bank, a Singapore digital bank, has reached 1 million customers, making up 20% of the adult population in the city-state. Deposits have doubled to S$3.8 billion in 2024. CEO Dwaipayan Sadhu attributes the growth to an unmet need for investment products among Singaporean customers, with a customer demographic mirroring the country's.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

“Our revenue growth is still three times of last year, and we are achieving it at almost flat cost growth, which really gives us a lot of confidence for our trajectory going forward,” said Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO of Trust Bank.
BT

Judy Hsu, CEO for wealth and retail banking at Stanchart, said the lender is looking to cut back on businesses that are not aligned to its affluent strategy, or has very little potential to grow into a scalable business.

site_title: Disclosure-based regulatory system and investor protection ‘not mutually exclusive’: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore's proposed regulatory changes to boost its equity market are not expected to compromise investor protection, said Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat. The measures, announced by the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) equities market review group, include streamlining listing processes and reducing compliance costs, while maintaining high corporate governance standards. Market discipline, where participants monitor risks, will play a bigger role, according to SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye. The changes aim to catalyze investor interest and boost listings, with a second set of measures expected by the end of this year.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Ranamita Chakraborty

site_title: DeepSeek to share some AI model code, doubling down on open source
summary: Chinese startup DeepSeek is set to release five code repositories next week, making its AI models' code publicly available. This move follows the release of its open-source R1 reasoning model, which rivals Western systems in performance while being developed at a lower cost. DeepSeek's commitment to open-source has distinguished it from most AI firms in China, which lean towards closed-sourced models. The company aims to share its "humble building blocks" with full transparency, showcasing its dedication to open-source artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: The investment climate in the Chinese tech sector has turned notably friendlier after artificial intelligence startup DeepSeek fuelled a stock-buying frenzy in firms related to cutting-edge technology.
The need for more AI chips and servers to handle fast-growing usage and support model development drove Deepseek's decision to consider outside funding.

A giant screen shows news footage of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei speaking next to BYD CEO Wang Chuanfu and New Hope's founder and Chairman Liu Yonghao at a symposium on private enterprises with Chinese President Xi Jinping (not pictured), at a shopping complex in Beijing, China February 17, 2025. REUTERS/Florence Lo
xAI plans to open-source preceding versions of its Grok models as soon as the latest one is fully mature, with Musk saying he expects that transition to be complete for Grok-3 in a few months.
DeepSeek has demonstrated a breakthrough lower-cost AI model that is seen as being competitive with those of OpenAI and Meta Platforms.
DeepSeek could well help China restart its economy overall, a critical step in economic reform and restructuring.
In a beta test, Weixin is testing access to DeepSeek for searches, Tencent said in a statement to Reuters.

Nvidia’s shares have been a safe bet for a long time, gaining nearly 900 per cent from the start of 2023 to late Januar.
DeepSeek-R1 was trained using only 2,788 GPUs, achieving a 96 per cent reduction in training costs compared with other leading AI models.

site_title: UOB prices A$2 billion floating rate senior unsecured notes
summary: UOB has priced its A$2 billion floating rate senior unsecured notes, set to be issued on Feb 28, 2025, under its US$30 billion global medium term note programme. The notes have a coupon of three-month bank bill swap rate plus 0.65% per annum payable quarterly. They are expected to be rated "Aa1" by Moody's and "AA-" by S&P and Fitch Ratings. ANZ, Bank of China, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, UBS, UOB, and Westpac Banking Corporation have been appointed as joint lead managers and bookrunners for the notes.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Indonesia to sell bonds to fund Prabowo’s low-cost housing
summary: Indonesia plans to sell government bonds to finance low-income housing projects, with Bank Indonesia agreeing to buy the debt in the secondary market. The finance ministry aims to raise funds for a subsidized mortgage program offering affordable housing to low-income earners. This move expands the government's goal of providing 3 million affordable houses a year, with the central bank committing to buy bonds worth billions of dollars. The bond sale may raise concerns among foreign investors about the country's financial stability.

site_title: Porsche’s icon gets pricier, but the love is still there
summary: Porsche unveiled its latest 992.2-generation 911 Carrera, a fitting tribute to the iconic sports car's legacy. With over 50,941 units produced last year, the 911 continues to be a best-seller, serving up thrills on and off the track. The 911 is described as "the one and always" sports car, capable of delivering exceptional performance and everyday driving prowess. The new model's arrival was celebrated with a special event in Singapore, marking the car's enduring popularity among sports car fans.

images.alt_text: The new X3 is a striking car in the flesh, with its smooth creases and origami-like boxiness lending it plenty of gravitas, and playing up its size.
The N Line packs the same 1.6-litre turbo hybrid, all-wheel drive powertrain as the regular Tucson, and puts plenty of emphasis on making life sweet for occupants.

site_title: Can’t ignore politics, but economics to shape medium-term ESG investment decisions: Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore ambassador for climate action Ravi Menon notes that while US politics may hinder climate action, economics will shape medium-term ESG investment decisions. The cost of renewable energy is declining, but nascent low-carbon technologies like hydrogen and carbon capture have higher costs. Despite this, cost curves for various technologies are trending towards becoming more green, driven by shifts in consumer patterns and relative prices.

images.alt_text:
pasff - Mr Ravi Menon, chairman of the Global Finance & Technology Network (GFTN). The former chief central banker is also Singapore’s Ambassador for Climate Action. 

Credit: GFTN
Janice Lim

site_title: Venture posts 6.6% fall in H2 net profit to S$121.4 million on weakness in lifestyle consumer segment
summary: Venture Corporation posted a 6.6% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$121.4 million for the half year ended Dec 31, 2024, due to weakness in its lifestyle consumer technology segment. Revenue fell 6.3% to S$1.35 billion. The company attributed this mainly to lower demand, but noted revenue growth in other technology domains. Venture aims to grow in 2025 despite an uncertain short-term business environment and plans to implement new business wins and investments to differentiate itself.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
While the decline in net profit is in line with the lower revenue, Venture Corp notes it has a “robust" net profit margin of 8.8 per cent.
Wong Chee Kheong served as Venture's chief operating officer from January 2022 to May 2023.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, February 21, 2025
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Friday as Chinese tech rallied, with Alibaba shares reaching a three-year high due to strong earnings and AI bets. The Japanese yen weakened as investors reconsidered rate hike bets. Meanwhile, gold is on track for its eighth straight weekly gain. These developments come amid concerns over US-China trade tensions and Trump's tariff policies.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Friday.

site_title: Exodus of F&B tenants from National Gallery after leases not renewed in major museum refresh
summary: The National Gallery Singapore underwent a major refresh, with seven out of nine F&B tenants forced to close after their leases expired last September. Only two existing restaurants, Odette and National Kitchen by Violet Oon, were allowed to remain. The remaining eateries that closed include one-Michelin-starred Art di Daniele Sperindio, Gemma Steakhouse, Yan, Smoke & Mirrors, Hachi Restaurant, Courtyard Cafe, and The Great Mischief. Restaurant owners were reportedly blindsided by the decision.

images.alt_text: Daniele Sperindio, chef owner of Art di Daniele Sperindio.
One-Michelin-starred restaurant Sommer will close on Oct 26.

site_title: A fitness tracker rescued me from resolution failure
summary: A writer, struggling to meet their New Year's resolution to run again after a decade of not running due to knee pain, turns to a fitness tracker to help them stay on track. They initially set a goal of 8 miles a day, but after purchasing a smartwatch, they're able to track their progress more efficiently. The writer finds that running helps them log more miles than walking and improves their calorie burn. Despite initial struggles and concerns about their knees, the writer is seeing improvements in their running times and is happy to be back on the road again.

images.alt_text: Musings over miles
Keeping watch on wearable technology

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise as traders pick over week of headlines
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, driven by a strong performance from Hong Kong's tech sector, led by Alibaba's 11% surge. The yen pulled back after rising past the 150-per-dollar mark, amid concerns over rising bond yields and potential interest rate hikes by the Bank of Japan. Meanwhile, US stocks fell on disappointing Walmart earnings, and tensions between the US and Russia have rattled market confidence, with gold prices reaching record levels.

images.alt_text: XXX
Walmart reported quarterly results that met expectations but shares slid 6.5 per cent after its forecast missed expectations.

site_title: Citigroup scraps diversity goals, ‘DEI’ term under Trump pressure
summary: Citigroup is ending its workplace representation goals and removing requirements to interview job candidates from diverse backgrounds, citing pressure from the Trump administration. The bank will also rename its "Diversity, Equity and Inclusion" team to "Talent Management and Engagement." The decision follows a trend of US companies cutting back on diversity initiatives due to political and legal pressures, including a Supreme Court ruling that threw out affirmative action in university admissions.

images.alt_text: Citi expects close to US$30 billion in the country’s total securitisation volume in the fiscal year ending Mar 31, 2026.
Citi led 76 transactions in Asia last year, raising US$2.4 billion, according to the bank.
Cost savings will partly be channelled into investing in areas such as data quality and regulatory controls, Jane Fraser says.
FILE PHOTO: The Citigroup Inc (Citi) logo is seen at the SIBOS banking and financial conference in Toronto, Ontario, Canada October 19, 2017. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: Logistics rent growth slows across the Asia-Pacific; Malaysia defies trend
summary: Malaysia's Greater Kuala Lumpur (KL) outpaced the Asia-Pacific region in logistics rent growth, with a 5% year-on-year increase in 2024, driven by the completion of premium industrial properties and demand from the e-commerce and manufacturing sectors. This growth contrasts with a regional slowdown, where logistics rent growth slowed to 0.2% in 2024. Key factors contributing to the slowdown include excess capacity and supply-chain recalibrations. Despite this, Knight Frank expects the Asia-Pacific's logistics sector to stabilize this year, with moderate rent growth of up to 2% anticipated.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Malaysia's economy expanded at a robust pace in 2024, but growth slowed in the fourth quarter amid increasing external uncertainties.

Gold Peak Technology Group presented the Letter of Intent to invest in Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone to Invest Johor. From left: UOB head of group foreign direct investment Advisory Sam Cheong, Johor state investment, trade, consumer affairs, and human resources committee chairman Lee Ting Han, Invest Johor CEO Natazha Harris, Johor Chief Minister Onn Hafiz Ghazi, Gold Peak Technology executive director and managing director Michael Lam and UOB Malaysia CEO Ng Wei Wei and Gold Peak Technology chairman and CEO Victor Lo.

site_title: Philippine central bank cuts banks' reserve requirements, effective from late March
summary: The Philippine central bank, BSP, announced a reduction in reserve requirements for banks, effective from late March. The new reserve requirement for universal and commercial banks will be 5%, down from 5.2%. The reduction will also apply to digital and thrift banks, with 150 and 100 basis point decreases, respectively. The move aims to stimulate economic growth and is seen as a response to the unexpectedly steady interest rates at the BSP's last policy review.

site_title: Australian shares post worst week in 2½  years as bank stocks bleed
summary: Australian shares closed 0.3% lower, finishing their worst week in nearly 2.5 years, amid a seven-session losing streak for banking stocks exacerbated by the Reserve Bank of Australia's first rate cut in five years. Financial stocks fell 1.3% and the S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 3% for the week, its largest decline since September 2022.

images.alt_text: Macquarie’s shares have lagged behind global banking peers over the past year amid a more tepid performance in its commodities trading arm and a lack of sales from its asset management wing.

site_title: Abrdn in talks to launch China asset management venture with Citic unit: sources
summary: ABRDN, the UK's second-largest independent asset manager, is in advanced talks to launch an asset management joint venture in China with Citic Bank's unit Citic Wealth. The deal would give ABRDN a majority stake, with the rest owned by Citic Wealth, which has $368 billion in assets. The talks follow a warming in British-Sino relations and contrast with Western financial institutions cutting jobs in China or shelving expansion plans due to concerns over the Chinese economy. Regulatory approval is expected later this year.

images.alt_text: Abrdn is not alone in struggling to keep up in an industry rife with redemptions and margin pressure.

site_title: Vicom posts 11% higher H2 net profit on robust demand for vehicle testing
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection company, posted an 11% higher net profit of S$15.2 million for the half-year ended Dec 31, 2024, driven by robust demand for vehicle testing. The company inspected over half a million vehicles in 2024, cornering 72.9% of the market. Vicom expects strong demand for vehicle testing and related work in 2025, fueled by the installation of seamless on-board units for paying ERP and parking fees.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Vicom has declared an interim dividend of S$0.028, payable on Aug 23.

Winners of the Best Managed Board at the SCA 2024. From left: Lim See Wah, CEO of Hyphens Pharma International; Euleen Goh, immediate past chair of Sats; and Stephen Ho, executive director and CEO of Hong Leong Asia.

site_title: Goodbye to the good guys
summary: US President Donald Trump has voiced a pessimistic worldview, making him the first US president to do so, according to columnist Simon Kuper. Trump's stance contradicts the traditional Western progressive ideology, which emphasizes the arc of justice bending towards progress. Historically, this optimism was fueled by Judeo-Christian morality and Enlightenment reason, but Kuper argues that this worldview was largely held by well-off Westerners, whereas others, especially in Russia and lower Western social classes, have long been pessimistic. Trump's pessimism is rooted in his belief that might makes right and that the world is controlled by conspiracies, reflecting a shift away from the traditional Western progressive narrative.

images.alt_text: Trump (left) himself has struck a less belligerent tone on China, telling reporters that a trade deal was “possible” and again trumpeting his “very good relationship” with Xi (right).
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky reacted to US President Donald Trump’s attacks by accusing him of succumbing to Russian “disinformation.”

site_title: China’s SAIC, Huawei to partner in developing new smart EVs
summary: China's SAIC Motor and Huawei have partnered to develop new smart electric vehicles, with the goal of creating "globally competitive" EVs. The partnership will leverage both companies' strengths in manufacturing, supply chain management, and sales services. This collaboration marks another state-owned automaker betting on Huawei's smart driving technologies to boost EV sales and promote China's automotive industry.

images.alt_text: The company has been investing heavily in developing its own advanced driver-assistance system (Adas) by hiring thousands of engineers since last year.
Huawei is taking strides into the EV industry as China promotes advanced manufacturing to become a new pillar of economic growth.
Launched in Singapore last year, Voltality connects electric vehicle drivers with charging points from different operators through a single account.
Visitors look at screens that demonstrate Huawei's intelligent driving software Qiankun.
On Tuesday, Huawei unveiled the S9 sedan, the first model under the premium Stelato brand it launched with Baic.

Huawei’s consumer business has made a strong comeback since August 2023, when it launched new phones with locally-made chipsets that defied US sanctions.
The decline underscores an uneven debut for the latest generation of iPhones, which started off strong in China before losing momentum.

site_title: Jefferies hires two senior traders from CLSA in Asia push
summary: Jefferies Financial Group has hired two senior traders from CLSA, Robert Levine and Cale McCulloch, to build out its Asia-Pacific presence. The hires follow a surge in stock sales and trading revenue in the region, with net revenue from Asia rising nearly 70% to $505 million last year. This marks the latest move by Jefferies to capitalize on the growth in Asia, which now accounts for 13% of its global headcount. The bank has also recently hired Gavin Chu from Citigroup's high-touch desk.

images.alt_text: In 2023, Jefferies referenced a challenging landscape that cut into its overall performance, which it called a “trough year”.

site_title: ChatGPT’s OpenAI reports surge to 400 million weekly users
summary: OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT, has seen its weekly active users jump 33% to 400 million since December, with its enterprise customer base doubling to 2 million paying users. The company is in talks with SoftBank for a potential $40 billion investment, valuing it at approximately $300 billion. OpenAI faces competition from Chinese rival DeepSeek and legal challenges from co-founder Elon Musk, who recently sued the company over its move to convert to a for-profit entity.

images.alt_text: (Right) Mira Murati - who will be Thinking Machines Lab CEO - is among a growing list of former OpenAI executives who have launched AI startups.
xAI plans to open-source preceding versions of its Grok models as soon as the latest one is fully mature, with Musk saying he expects that transition to be complete for Grok-3 in a few months.
Altman and Musk have been at loggerheads for years.

site_title: BlackRock resumes talks with companies following SEC guidance
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, has resumed talks with companies after a brief pause to assess new US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) guidelines on the influence of asset managers on corporations. The company complies with the new requirements by highlighting its "passive" investor role at the start of each engagement. The SEC's policy treats investors seeking to influence corporate behavior as activist investors, similar to hedge funds. BlackRock stated it does not use engagement as a way to control publicly traded companies.

site_title: IMF calls for Thai rate cut to support inflation, ease debt load
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has recommended a further reduction in Thailand's policy interest rate to support low inflation and ease debt burdens. The Bank of Thailand's monetary policy committee is set to meet on February 26 to review the interest rate. The IMF cited Thailand's high household liabilities, which have ballooned to $486 billion, as a concern. The organization also noted that risks to Thailand's economy are tilted to the downside due to global trade tensions and commodity price volatility. The IMF maintains its 2025 GDP growth projection for Thailand at 2.9%.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand logo is pictured in Bangkok, Thailand, January 30, 2025. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa

site_title: Chinese bubble tea chain Mixue aims to raise HK$3.45 billion in Hong Kong IPO
summary: Chinese bubble tea chain Mixue aims to raise HK$3.45 billion in a Hong Kong IPO, selling 17.1 million shares at HK$202.5 each. The company, with 45,000 stores in mainland China and 11 other countries, is due to begin trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange on March 3. Bookbuilding for the IPO started on February 21.

images.alt_text: Mixue plans to start trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in early March.
The Chinese ice cream and bubble tea chain Mixue launched its 1,000th store in Vietnam in April 2023.

site_title: StanChart CEO Winters’ 2024 pay jumps 46% on year
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters' total salary for 2024 jumped 46% year-over-year to nearly £10.7 million (S$18.1 million), mainly due to a 77.5% increase in his long-term incentive award. The bank's overall bonus pool rose 7% year-over-year to $1.7 billion. Despite the increase, Winters downplayed the significance of his pay, stating that his motivation is not about compensation, but rather making progress for the bank.

images.alt_text: StanChart reported pretax profit for 2024 of US$6 billion, up from US$5.1 billion the year before and slightly below the US$6.2 billion average of analysts’ forecasts as compiled by the bank.

site_title: Judge denies union bid to halt Trump firing of government workers
summary: A US judge denied a union bid to temporarily halt the firing of thousands of federal employees on probationary status, handing President Donald Trump another legal win in his plan to slash the government workforce. The decision comes as around 6,700 workers at the IRS, who were on probation, were being laid off. The judge ruled that he lacked jurisdiction to handle the complaint, citing that the Federal Labor Relations Authority should instead be brought in to adjudicate federal labor disputes.

images.alt_text: The survey is based on input from more than 100 of AmCham Vietnam’s members, which include big multinational companies such as Intel and Nike.

More than 50 companies set up booths to recruit people from entry-level to management. Open jobs include police officers, food service, security, sales reps, technicians, customer service, IT, teacher assistants, insurance agents, and account executives.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The dismissals are part of a wave of thousands of terminations across the federal government spurred by Elon Musk’s efforts to rapidly overhaul the federal bureaucracy.

site_title: Transforming Singapore’s CBD will take a whole lot more than new homes
summary: Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) needs more than just new homes to become vibrant after office hours and on weekends. To attract families, the area requires an ecosystem of amenities, community-bonding activities, and supportive policies, such as lowering the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD). Currently, 15 projects with 6,100 homes have been completed in the past two decades, but more are needed. Supporting amenities, including schools, playgrounds, and sports facilities, are essential to attract families and live up the CBD.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
UOL Group tapped the Strategic Development Incentive Scheme to redevelop the former Faber House site in Orchard Road into a hotel that will have sky gardens and a waterfall.
Office decentralisation efforts go as far back as 1991.

National Development Minister Desmond Lee ( centre) with Redas President Tan Swee Yiow (second from left) at Redas' annual Spring Festival lunch. This was the minister's first attendance at the event in over five years.

site_title: Japan to court Tesla on Nissan investment
summary: A Japanese group, led by former Tesla board member Hiromichi Mizuno and former Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, has proposed that Tesla invest in Nissan following the collapse of its merger talks with Honda Motor. The group believes Tesla wants to acquire Nissan's US plants. Nissan has been searching for a strategic tech industry partner, with Tesla and Apple suggested as ideal targets. Nissan's shares rose 9.6% after the report. Tesla's CEO Elon Musk has previously mentioned the Cybercab production line and plans to start production in 2026.

images.alt_text: Nissan has been working on a turnaround programme under which it plans to reduce its workforce by 9,000 people and global manufacturing capacity by 20 per cent.

site_title: Billionaire investor Ryan Cohen boosts stake in Alibaba to US$1 billion: WSJ
summary: Billionaire investor Ryan Cohen has increased his stake in Alibaba Group to approximately $1 billion, representing about 7 million shares, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. This comes after Cohen had previously expressed interest in having a long-term relationship with Alibaba and pushing the company to increase and speed up share buybacks. The move follows recent positive news for Chinese tech stocks, including the emergence of domestic AI startup DeepSeek and a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and business leaders in the sector.

images.alt_text: Alibaba's Qwen AI model has performed well in official benchmark tests and signalled the company’s growing relevance in the field.
One major driver of the rally is Alibaba Group Holding contributing to a surge of almost 60 per cent since Jan 13.
Alibaba has become a Chinese AI favourite among investors early in 2025, with its stock price up over 40 per cent so far this year.

site_title: Trump tariff worries set gold on course for eighth straight weekly gain
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,941.25 an ounce, marking an eighth consecutive weekly gain, amid concerns over US President Donald Trump's tariff plans that could spark trade wars and stoke inflation. Federal Reserve officials are taking note of rising inflation risks and uncertain policy impacts, with gold seen as a safeguard against geopolitical risks and inflation. Trump has announced fresh tariffs on Canada and other countries, and gold exports from Switzerland rose year-over-year in January.

images.alt_text: Spot gold rose 0.2 per cent to US$2,938.57 an ounce.

site_title: Rivian records first gross profit as EV policy risks loom
summary: Rivian recorded its first-ever quarterly gross profit of $170 million in Q4 2024, beating analyst expectations of $32 million. The company expects to sell between 46,000 and 51,000 EVs this year, below analyst estimates of 54,800. Despite this, Rivian's shares rose over 3% in after-hours trading, signaling investor confidence. The company attributes the progress to overcoming supply chain and cost issues. However, policy shifts in Washington may weigh on EV sales this year, according to Rivian.

images.alt_text: Rivian’s architecture requires fewer electronic control units and significantly less wiring, reducing vehicle weight and simplifying manufacturing.

site_title: Payments firm Block’s profit misses estimate on underwhelming holiday spending
summary: Block's fourth-quarter profit fell short of estimates, with 71 cents per share excluding one-time costs, missing analyst expectations of 87 cents per share. The payment firm's shares dropped 7% after market close. Consumer spending growth during the holiday season and gains from bitcoin lagged expectations due to uncertainty over trade policy and the Federal Reserve's rate cuts. This result follows Walmart's sales and profit forecast that fell short of Wall Street estimates, fueling concerns over consumer spending.

site_title: Spirit Airlines to exit bankruptcy under go-private deal
summary: Spirit Airlines has secured court approval to exit bankruptcy under a go-private deal backed by lenders, who will own the company. The restructuring plan, approved by Judge Sean Lane, aims to boost the airline's business through new premium options. Spirit had sought protection from debt of $1.6 billion after losing ground post-pandemic. The deal hands control to top bondholders, including Citadel Advisors, Pacific Investment Management, and Western Asset Management. The move follows a rejected takeover offer from rival Frontier Group Holdings.

images.alt_text: Spirit will also raise US$350 million through an equity rights offering, which is fully backstopped.
FILE PHOTO: Spirit Airlines commercial airliners are shown at Las Vegas International Airport in Las Vegas, Nevada, U.S., February 8, 2024.  REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
Early-stage discussions between the air carriers involved working out terms that holders of Spirit’s roughly US$2.5 billion of debt would agree to.

site_title: EU trade chief says tariff reciprocity ‘must work for both’ sides
summary: EU trade chief Maros Sefcovic said that reciprocity in tariffs should work for both the EU and the US, following talks with US officials. The EU is open to lowering duties for industrial goods and increasing purchases of US products. Sefcovic expressed optimism that the EU and US can address their trade deficit and work together to tackle global overcapacities, particularly involving China. He emphasized that the EU will react firmly and proportionately to unfair import duties, but also emphasized the need for constructive dialogue to avoid unnecessary pain and countermeasures.

images.alt_text: Spot gold rose 0.2 per cent to US$2,938.57 an ounce.

About 50 per cent of the cars sold in the United States are manufactured within the country. Among imports, about half come from Mexico and Canada and the other half from other major auto-producing countries.
The survey is based on input from more than 100 of AmCham Vietnam’s members, which include big multinational companies such as Intel and Nike.

site_title: New Chinese restaurant YongFu delivers a true taste of China
summary: YongFu, a Chinese restaurant in Singapore's Suntec City Mall, offers an authentic taste of China in an opulent setting. The restaurant's menu features a variety of dishes, including swimmer crab marinated in yellow wine, pickled winter melon, and stir-fried conch. The service is attentive and knowledgeable, with a set menu recommended for first-time diners. The meal is priced at S$499 for two, offering a compilation of signature dishes and an introduction to Chinese cuisine. While it may not match its China counterparts in terms of ingredients and cooking skill, YongFu provides a unique dining experience worth considering.

images.alt_text: Nachos Chilangos are addictive corn chips in a cheesy sauce with grilled shrimp.

site_title: Amazon’s MGM Studios gains creative control over ‘James Bond’ franchise
summary: Amazon's MGM Studios has gained creative control over the 'James Bond' franchise in a joint venture with longtime rights holders Michael Wilson and Barbara Broccoli. The deal, announced on Thursday, will allow Amazon to take a more hands-on role with the series ahead of the 26th Bond film. The franchise, which has grossed over $7 billion at the global box office, will continue to be co-owned by the parties involved.

images.alt_text: Under Italian law, an intermediary offering goods for sale in Italy is co-responsible for the non-payment of VAT by non-EU sellers that use its e-commerce platform.
Dr. Janil Puthucheary, Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Digital Development and Information & Ministry of Health, delivering a speech at the launch of AWS Asia Pacific Hub on Feb 12, 2025.
FILE PHOTO: An Amazon Prime truck is pictured as it crosses the George Washington Bridge on Interstate Route 95 in New York City, New York, U.S., October 11, 2022. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: StanChart to return US$1.5 billion more as earnings beat
summary: Standard Chartered reported a strong fourth-quarter earnings beat, with underlying return on tangible equity more than doubling to 11.7% in 2024. The bank announced a fresh buyback of US$1.5 billion, bringing total shareholder distributions to US$4.9 billion since 2023. CEO Bill Winters attributed the success to a high-growth business and a strategy of combining corporate and wealth management expertise. The bank's stock value has almost doubled since Winters took the CEO role, and it now trades at £11.40, higher than its level when he first took the job.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters says: “We’ll see what comes through in terms of tariffs...but we know China is a big part of that in terms of having a gigantic export surplus, and that will be under attack from all parts of the world.”
The Business Times lays out the opportunities presented by the three hubs -- Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong -- and the type of wealth flows they attract.
Bill Winters, Group Chief Executive, Standard Chartered,
Standard Chartered will aim to double the size of its relationship manager team by 2028, as well as upgrading branches and investing in technology to win new clients.
Thousands of runners of the Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon taking off at the start line of the Marathon category on Dec 1, 2024.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity shrinks for 8th straight month: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity declined for an 8th straight month in February, but at a slower pace, according to a private-sector survey. The manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) rebounded to 48.9 from 48.7, above the 50.0 threshold that separates growth from contraction. The slight uptick suggests a modest recovery, driven by a milder decrease in output and new orders. However, future output expectations were the lowest since June 2020, citing factors such as labor shortages and inflation.

images.alt_text: The increase in Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes fresh food prices, compared with a median market forecast for a 3.1 per cent gain and followed a 3.0 per cent rise in December.
Suzuki now faces renewed competition in India from both local and foreign automakers with more attractive hybrid and electric car offerings.
The level of fresh food prices has risen 71.9 per cent since 2010, about five times more than that of inflation excluding it.
Hedging costs for Japanese investors having largely fallen since October.

site_title: The world’s most important market sends a warning
summary: The US$30 trillion market for US government securities is sending a warning signal about faster inflation ahead, contradicting the Federal Reserve's confidence in the economy. The two-year breakeven rate, which measures traders' expectations for inflation, has exceeded the January consumer price index (CPI) rise for the first time since October 2020. This indicates traders are betting inflation will accelerate, contrary to the Fed's assessment that inflation would recede under former President Joe Biden. The bond market's unease is fueled by President Donald Trump's actions, including tariffs and threats to break treaties, and a surge in consumer sentiment expectations for higher inflation.

images.alt_text: Several Fed officials have said they want to wait until inflation ebbs and for further clarity on President Donald Trump’s economic plans before lowering borrowing costs.

site_title: Australia’s central bank cautious on rate cuts, all depends on data
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) remains cautious about cutting interest rates further due to the strong labor market and cost pressures. Governor Michele Bullock stated that the central bank will respond to data, but is not pre-committed to further rate cuts. The RBA cut rates by a quarter-point to 4.1% in February, and officials warned that a strong labor market could delay disinflation. Despite this, investors expect just 40 basis points of policy easing for the year, implying a limited chance of further rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Data centres are one of the hottest property plays at the moment.
Australia's annual jobs growth accelerated to a blistering 3.5 per cent, more than twice the pace seen in the United States.
Telstra posted a net profit of A$1.03 billion for the six months ending Dec 31, in line with the Visible Alpha consensus estimate and ahead of the A$964 million reported a year ago.

site_title: Meta reduces stock options for staff despite trading at record highs: FT
summary: Meta Platforms has reduced its yearly stock option distribution by about 10% for tens of thousands of employees, despite trading at record highs. This decision affects most employees, with the exact reduction varying depending on location and job level. The move comes after CEO Mark Zuckerberg warned of potential job cuts to "raise the bar" on performance management. Meta's shares closed down 1.3% at $694.80 on the same day.

images.alt_text: The e-mail to Singapore employees said the layoffs in the trust and safety team come after months of careful consideration.
(Right) Mira Murati - who will be Thinking Machines Lab CEO - is among a growing list of former OpenAI executives who have launched AI startups.
Meta had relocated its Singapore staff to new offices at Marina One (above), after opting not to renew its lease for seven floors of office space at South Beach Tower.

site_title: Taking stock: Managing wealth in a turbulent time
summary: A high-earning Singapore couple, Dani and David, navigate the complexities of managing their $1 million net worth in a turbulent global financial market. They consolidate their investments onto a single platform, automate rebalancing, and access private markets to achieve aggressive growth. The couple optimizes their portfolio by balancing liquidity with competitive returns, leveraging fintech solutions, and employing a tailored, strategic approach to wealth management. By embracing innovation and maintaining discipline, they can transform complexity into opportunity and achieve financial success and peace of mind.

images.alt_text: One impact project that Arta clients can access on the Co-Axis platform involves technology being utilised to restore coral reefs.

site_title: Apple’s Tim Cook meeting with Trump as tariffs threaten iPhones
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook met with President Trump at the White House, amid a trade dispute between the US and China. China is considering a probe into Apple's policies and fees for app developers, threatening the company's iPhone sales. The meeting comes as Trump's 10% tariff on Chinese-made goods poses a challenge for Apple, which relies heavily on China for manufacturing. Cook's relationship with Trump has helped the company secure tariff exemptions in the past, but Trump has also criticized Apple's privacy policies and called for greater access to encrypted data.

images.alt_text: Apple touted the iPhone 16e as having many features found in more expensive models, including Apple-tailored artificial intelligence features and integration with OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

Apple late last month forecast strong sales growth signalling that the company will recover from a dip in iPhone sales as it rolls out artificial intelligence features in the coming months to more regions and languages.
Apple is also adding a new app to the Vision Pro for viewing spatial content tailored to the device, including 3D images and panoramas aggregated from outside sources.
Apple is working with Alibaba Group Holding and Baidu to create a system that passes muster with Chinese regulators.

site_title: Alibaba rockets more than 14% to boost Hong Kong market
summary: Alibaba's shares surged 14.6% in Hong Kong, reaching a three-year high, after the company reported a 8% increase in sales to 280 billion yuan (S$52 billion) in the three months through December, beating analyst estimates. The strong earnings added to a growing sense of optimism over Chinese tech firms, with the Hang Seng Index rising 3.99% and other household names making significant gains. The rally follows a series of positive news, including a meeting between Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma and Chinese President Xi Jinping, which hinted at a softening towards the private sector.

images.alt_text: A logo of Alibaba is seen outside its offices in Beijing on February 14, 2025. Alibaba shares soared by more than six percent on February 14, following reports that Chinese President Xi Jinping was poised to meet with the tech juggernaut’s co-founder Jack Ma. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)

site_title: Seatrium achieves first full-year profit with S$120.9 million H2 earnings
summary: Seatrium, an offshore and marine specialist, achieved its first full-year profit with a net profit of S$120.9 million for the second half of 2024, compared to a net loss of S$1.8 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company's revenue rose 18.4% to S$5.2 billion, driven by contributions from revenue recognition, fair-value gain on investments, and share of profit from associates. Seatrium has proposed a final dividend of S$0.015 per share, which will be paid on May 19. The company's net debt decreased by 8% to S$689 million, and its order book stands at S$23.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Crystal Heng
In the first phase of development, the Kaskida project will have a capacity to produce 80,000 barrels of crude oil per day.

Representatives from Seatrium and International Maritime Industries (IMI) signed a contract (pictured). Under the agreement, the offshore and marine specialist will provide equipment and a license for the construction of Kingdom 3, a rig in the Middle East and North Africa region.

site_title: PBOC injects most short-term funds this month amid cash crunch
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), injected a record 84 billion yuan (S$15.4 billion) of short-term funds into the financial system on February 21, amid a cash crunch in the bond market. This move aims to support the yuan amidst economic headwinds and rising repo rates. The injection is the largest single-day infusion in February and follows a surge in repo rates and tight liquidity conditions. The move is seen as a response to a renewed trade war with the US and a debt sell-off in the bond market.

site_title: Stirred but not shaken, Singapore’s oil hub status could see opportunities from US tariff poser
summary: Singapore's oil trading hub status may benefit from US tariffs, as the city-state can leverage its robust infrastructure and strategic location to help companies adjust to price fluctuations. US tariffs on Canadian and Mexican energy imports could disrupt global supply chains, but Singapore's position as a regional trading hub could create opportunities for arbitrage and optimizing trading strategies. Experts expect supply-chain disruptions, but Singapore's financial sector and existing measures to help businesses navigate uncertainties may mitigate the impact. Additionally, US President Donald Trump's policy to increase US gas exports to Asia could boost Singapore's position as a liquefied natural gas trading hub.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

US President Donald Trump, alongside Secretary of Treasury Scott Bessent (L) and Secretary of Commerce nominee Howard Lutnick (R), signs an executive order to create a US sovereign wealth fund, in the Oval Office of the White House on February 3, 2025, in Washington, DC. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)
By the time CICT completed the preferential offering to support its acquisition of Ion Orchard, the 10-year Treasury bond yield was beginning to shoot back up
Tit-for-tat: A timeline of the tariff fight between Trump and the rest of the world

site_title: Birkenstock slumps as unchanged outlook overshadows sales boost
summary: Birkenstock Holding's shares fell 7.3% after the company kept its full-year sales forecast unchanged despite a 19% sales increase in the first quarter to 362 million euros. The company attributed the sales boost to strong momentum in Asia and closed-toed footwear. However, a 10% rise in direct-to-consumer sales fell short of analyst estimates, sparking concerns about Birkenstock's momentum. CEO Oliver Reichert defended the decision, citing uncertainty around global trade tariffs and inflation, and promised that the company's direct-to-consumer business will accelerate in the spring and summer.

images.alt_text: Demand for Birkenstock’s footwear has been fortified by a post-pandemic move away from formal dressing to a more casual and informal wear.

site_title: Huawei founder told Xi China’s concerns about lack of chips have eased: state media
summary: Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei told Chinese President Xi Jinping that concerns about a lack of homegrown chips or operating systems have eased, state media reported. This was revealed during a symposium on private enterprises with Xi, where six company founders addressed the president. The meeting was highly controlled, with only Xi's remarks initially released. The news suggests a possible easing of tensions related to Huawei's reliance on foreign technology.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A giant screen shows news footage of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei speaking next to BYD CEO Wang Chuanfu and New Hope's founder and Chairman Liu Yonghao at a symposium on private enterprises with Chinese President Xi Jinping (not pictured), at a shopping complex in Beijing, China February 17, 2025. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: UK consumers are more pessimistic than after recession: GfK
summary: UK consumers are more pessimistic about the economy than a year ago, with a consumer expectations gauge at minus 31, down seven percentage points from February last year. The findings suggest Chancellor Rachel Reeves' tax-raising budget is having a lasting impact on consumers, who are wary about spending due to rising costs and job cuts. The UK economy has barely grown since Labour took office in July, and inflation is at its highest level in almost a year, adding to pressure on the government to deliver short-term results.

images.alt_text: epa11666752 Shoppers on Oxford Street in London Britain, 18 October 2024. UK retail sales have shown modest growth for September. Retails sales grew by 0.3% in September, a slowdown from the 1.0% increase recorded in August.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

A separate survey from the Federation of Small Businesses showed confidence among its members fell in late 2024 to its lowest level since the first quarter of 2020 when the Covid-19 pandemic hit Britain.

Shoppers walk along Oxford Street during traditional Boxing Day holiday sales, in London, UK, on Thursday, Dec. 26, 2024. UK retail sales grew more slowly than expected in November suggesting Christmas shoppers might not boost the economy in the crucial final months of the year. Photographer: Carlos Jasso/Bloomberg
Most of Britain’s major retailers have flagged a tougher year ahead as employer tax increases, and their potential impact on prices and employment, filter through into the economy.

site_title: Oil rises for third day on US fuel stocks draw, worries about Russia disruptions
summary: Oil prices rose for a third consecutive day, driven by US fuel stocks drawing and concerns about Russia supply disruptions. US crude oil stockpiles rose, while fuel inventories fell due to seasonal maintenance at refineries. Russia attacked Ukrainian gas infrastructure and damaged production facilities, reducing oil supply flows. Analysts say potential restarts of Iraqi oil flows and US import tariffs could offset supply risks, keeping prices elevated.

images.alt_text: Brent futures rose 20 cents, or 0.3 per cent, to settle at US$76.04 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 40 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to settle at US$72.25 on Wednesday.

site_title: StarHub H2 net profit up 7.5% at S$78.4 million
summary: StarHub reported a net profit of S$78.4 million for the second half of 2024, a 7.5% increase from the previous year. Revenue fell 0.3% to S$1.3 billion, mainly due to lower contributions from mobile, entertainment, and equipment business segments. However, the broadband and enterprise segments drove growth, with enterprise revenue rising 10.7%. The company declared a final dividend of S$0.032 per share and plans to aggressively scale its enterprise business segment, exploring accretive mergers and acquisitions deals.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
5G use cases remain limited in the consumer space.
For one customer, the lack of verification had resulted in hackers taking control of the phone line and gaining access to information.
The price moves by both StarHub and M1 have not gone unnoticed.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx touches one-week low with earnings in focus, German politics eyed
summary: European stocks closed at a one-week low, with the Stoxx 600 index dipping 0.2% to 551.01. The defense sector led the retreat with a 2.8% drop, following mixed corporate updates. Airbus reported short-term production challenges and a delay in its A350 freighter, contributing to a 2.3% decline in its shares. The upcoming German election, which may change the country's political landscape, also weighed on investors.

images.alt_text: Walmart reported quarterly results that met expectations but shares slid 6.5 per cent after its forecast missed expectations.

site_title: Malaysia says Asean plans US summit to discuss tariff concerns
summary: ASEAN plans a special summit with the US to discuss planned tariffs, which would significantly impact Malaysia's trade, with electrical and electronics products making up 60% of its trade with the US. Foreign Minister Mohamad Hasan stated that the tariffs would be a huge blow if not resolved soon. The summit aims to present the region's case to the US government and mitigate the burden on Asean countries.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of an orthopaedic hospital in Bangkok, Thailand, that CLI's CapitaLand Wellness Fund invested in. The specialist hospital is expected to be operational in 2027 and will focus on musculoskeletal treatments, said CLI.

site_title: Top Republican right-winger McConnell announces leaving US Senate
summary: US Senator Mitch McConnell, a powerful Republican lawmaker, announced on Thursday he will not seek reelection to the Senate, citing his increasingly unsteady health. At 83, McConnell's retirement will mark the end of a US political era and underscore the Republican Party's growing radicalization. McConnell's departure comes as the party is shifting under the leadership of Donald Trump, who has demanded total loyalty from party members. McConnell's legacy includes advancing a right-wing agenda, including the confirmation of conservative justices to the Supreme Court, but he also fell out with Trump after the 2020 election.

Donald Trump has not yet returned to the White House but is already thrusting himself to the front of international stage as he once again shatters diplomatic niceties. site_title: US Federal Reserve’s inflation fight at risk of stalling: official
summary: US Federal Reserve President Alberto Musalem warns that the central bank's battle to bring down inflation is at risk of stalling due to uncertainties in trade, immigration, and energy policies. Despite expecting inflation to converge around 2% with restrictive monetary policy, Musalem notes that changes in the economic environment could affect the path of the economy. The Fed has paused rate cuts, and markets see a high probability of a rate pause next month, amid concerns about the impact of potential tariffs on inflation.

More than 50 companies set up booths to recruit people from entry-level to management. Open jobs include police officers, food service, security, sales reps, technicians, customer service, IT, teacher assistants, insurance agents, and account executives.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

The Fed’s decision to maintain its benchmark interest rate between 4.25 and 4.50 per cent came just days after Donald Trump took office and took place against the backdrop of a small uptick in consumer inflation.

site_title: Chinese builders lean on court for overhaul as debt woes deepen
summary: Chinese developers are increasingly seeking court-led restructuring due to the country's property debt crisis, which is entering its fifth year. The trend is evident across industries, with 29 Chinese listed companies seeking court-led restructuring last year, including nearly a quarter from real estate or construction firms. Court-supervised restructuring offers a novel approach, allowing companies to reduce debt and improve fundraising efficiencies. However, success depends on securing strategic investors and meeting key conditions, and the prolonged crisis has lowered expectations for creditors and investors.

images.alt_text: A residential building under construction at the China Vanke Co. Elegant Lifestyle project in Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024. Vanke, the Chinese state-backed developer that's become the latest flashpoint in the nation's property crisis, is preparing an asset package totaling about 130 billion yuan ($18 billion) to use as collateral as it seeks new bank loans, people familiar with the matter said. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Xi risks becoming top US threat if Trump cuts deal with Putin
summary: US and Russian officials are negotiating an end to the three-year war in Ukraine in Saudi Arabia, prompting concerns in Europe and Ukraine. China is positioning itself to benefit from reconstruction efforts and a deepening rift among the US and its allies. If US President Trump cuts a deal with Putin, it could lead to a shift in US focus away from China, making Beijing the main US threat. This could be a major concern for China, as it would suddenly become the primary target of the US military.

images.alt_text: A conversation or interaction between Chinese President Xi Jinping (right) and US President Donald Trump (left) is seen as crucial to a potential easing or delay of trade tariffs.
On Feb 17 Alibaba CEO Jack Ma and other entrepreneurs met at a symposium in Beijing with Xi Jinping -- which is widely seen as a sign that private sector tech is back in favour.
