REUTERS/Florence Lo
Since 2023, Xi’s government has eased off on the campaign and indicated that it still sees the trillion-dollar technology sector as an important part of the country’s economy.

site_title: ECB reports another record annual loss, says it may suffer more losses
summary: The European Central Bank reported a record annual loss of 7.94 billion euros in 2024, up from 7.89 billion euros in the previous year. The bank attributed the loss to paying out billions of euros to banks. Despite interest rates coming down and a shrinking balance sheet, the financial system still holds almost 3 trillion euros (S$4.19 trillion) in excess liquidity, which could take years to run down. The ECB warned that further losses were possible.

images.alt_text: Companies and households also face a lack of political direction in France and Germany, whose lacklustre economies have been holding back the wider region.
The consensus is that the ECB will take this year’s staff changes in its stride, with markets still very much focused on data rather than personnel as they calibrate their interest-rate bets.

site_title: Budget 2025: National Productivity Fund top-up should help draw MNCs to Singapore, say observers
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 includes a $3 billion top-up to the National Productivity Fund (NPF) to support investment promotion and elevate business productivity. Industry watchers see this as a step towards improving the country's attractiveness to multinational corporations (MNCs). The budget also includes $1 billion in investments in biotech and semiconductor R&D infrastructure, as well as tax deductions for innovation. However, some observers feel that certain measures, such as incentives for the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), were missing. The government's pragmatic approach to global tax changes is also noted.

images.alt_text: Budget 2025: Enhancing our Technology and Innovation Engines; Strengthening our Enterprise Ecosystem; Supporting our Enterprises in Workforce Transformation
Sharon See
Elysia Tan

site_title: China objects to Fentanyl as ‘pretext’ for Trump’s tariff increases
summary: China's embassy spokesperson Liu Pengyu stated that the US is using the fight against fentanyl as a "pretext" for increasing tariffs on Chinese goods. China is willing to build a stable relationship with the US, but hopes the effort will be reciprocal. China has provided support to address the fentanyl issue, but Liu said tariffs cannot hold as a solution, and instead, will hurt US consumers. China may bypass the US and work with the international community to promote global trade and investment.

images.alt_text: A conversation or interaction between Chinese President Xi Jinping (right) and US President Donald Trump (left) is seen as crucial to a potential easing or delay of trade tariffs.
The WTO is upgrading its tariff analysis database and will launch the new version on Mar 4.

About 50 per cent of the cars sold in the United States are manufactured within the country. Among imports, about half come from Mexico and Canada and the other half from other major auto-producing countries.

site_title: Japan’s core inflation hits 19-month high, keeps BOJ rate-hike bets alive
summary: Japan's core consumer price index (CPI) rose 3.2% in January, its fastest pace in 19 months, exceeding market forecasts and keeping interest rate hike bets alive. This increase in core CPI, excluding fresh food prices, followed a 3.0% rise in December. The Bank of Japan is expected to keep raising interest rates as inflationary pressure mounts, with bond yields rising on the news. A separate inflation index, excluding fuel costs, rose 2.5% in January, also above forecasts.

images.alt_text: The level of fresh food prices has risen 71.9 per cent since 2010, about five times more than that of inflation excluding it.
Hedging costs for Japanese investors having largely fallen since October.
Bank of Japan board member Hajime Takata said the BOJ must keep raising interest rates if companies continue to increase prices, wages and investment.
Isuzu Motors trucks bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan, Feb 6, 2025. Japan's exports rose 7.2 per cent year-on-year in January.

site_title: Planet Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump's geo-economic policies, particularly with trading partners, are set to significantly impact the global investment landscape. The new administration has announced unilateral and/or reciprocal tariffs to equalize "unfair" taxes and regulations, targeting countries with large trade deficits, such as China, Mexico, and the European Union. Markets seem to be leaning towards a "transactional" approach, where Trump aims to right wrongs without directly leading to a trade war. As a result, Lombard Odier recommends a diversified portfolio with US and Japanese markets overweight, and a raised USD exposure. However, the benefits of a diversified portfolio cannot be overstated due to the fast-moving markets and goalposts on "Planet Trump".

images.alt_text: (FILES) US President Donald Trump announces his decision on the Paris Climate Accords in the Rose Garden of the White House in Washington, DC, on June 1, 2017. US President Donald Trump on January 20, 2025, announced the United States' withdrawal from the Paris climate accord for a second time, a defiant rejection of global efforts to combat planetary warming as catastrophic weather events intensify worldwide. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)
John Woods

site_title: US: Stocks fall on lackluster Walmart outlook
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday following Walmart's disappointing quarterly results, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.4% and 1.0% respectively. Walmart's forecast missed expectations, causing its shares to slide 6.5%. Banking shares, including Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan Chase, also fell, with the Nasdaq Composite Index declining 0.5%. Despite the downturn, analysts attributed the drop to profit taking and attributed underlying bullishness in the market.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 66.5 points, or 0.15 per cent, at the open to 44,561.11.

site_title: Singapore’s journey to a better tomorrow
summary: Singapore's 2025 budget builds on the foundation of Forward SG programmes introduced in 2024, focusing on strategic moves to attract global founders and develop local corporate leaders. Key highlights include a corporate income tax rebate for new SGX listings of up to S$6 million, a programme to attract global founders, and a renewed focus on grooming local corporate leaders to champion Singapore's interests in the face of AI and global uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Generic photo for Budget 2025 for stories related to Singapore economy, CBD, GDP.
Singapore’s long-term prosperity hinges on its ability to stablish itself as a gold standard for high-value solutions that the world seeks to emulate.
Finance Minister Lawrence Wong has cautioned against complacency, especially in light of new global challenges and “dark clouds over the horizon”.

site_title: US mortgage rates drop for fifth straight week, falling to 6.85%
summary: US mortgage rates dropped for the fifth consecutive week to 6.85%, the lowest point since late December. This decline, while still above 6.5%, could reassure potential buyers and sellers ahead of the spring homebuying season. Supply constraints in the housing market are easing, with new listings rising 4.2% in the four weeks to February 16, the highest level in three years. The US Federal Reserve's policy may keep mortgage rates higher for longer, but the stability in rates could help stabilize the market.

site_title: Valid claims against Jannie Chan’s bankruptcy estate balloon by S$18.9 million
summary: Jannie Chan's bankruptcy estate has seen valid claims rise by S$18.9 million after the High Court accepted previously rejected debts. Chan, co-founder of luxury timepiece retailer The Hour Glass, was declared bankrupt in 2019. A creditor's loan guarantee for JASC, a firm she was the sole director and shareholder of, was the basis for the accepted debts. Additionally, claims of S$4.3 million from SME Care and S$2.6 million from two other sources were also deemed valid, with Chan failing to challenge their validity.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
High Court dismisses Hour Glass co-founder's appeal against bankruptcy
'Recalcitrant' Hour Glass co-founder Jannie Chan starts 2-week jail term for contempt

site_title: Singapore shares decline amid hawkish Fed minutes; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,927.51, amid a hawkish Federal Reserve's January meeting minutes. The Fed's minutes suggested potential changes in trade and immigration policy could hinder disinflation, leading to a possible rate hold. Local stocks ended mixed, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding extending gains to top the STI, while Seatrium was the biggest loser.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Hong Kong stocks, which has climbed around 15 per cent so far this year, dropped two per cent on Thursday as the China tech surge came to an end.
Overall occupancy rate at SingPost Centre (above) was 98.2 per cent as at Dec 31, 2024, compared to 96.2 per cent as at Mar 31, 2024.

site_title: Everybody’s Budget; everybody’s birthday, again
summary: Singapore's 2025 Budget, dubbed "a Budget for all Singaporeans," aims to enhance technology, innovation, and provide respite from cost pressures. The budget includes measures such as the SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit and Productivity Solutions Grant, but critics argue that the support amounts may not be substantial enough to produce significant productivity gains. To achieve desired economic growth, businesses must adopt a long-term mindset and capitalize on available support, while the government must strike a balance between ambition and prudence, ensuring that budgetary measures are well-adopted and yield meaningful results.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong has cautioned against complacency, especially in light of new global challenges and “dark clouds over the horizon”.
Singapore’s long-term prosperity hinges on its ability to stablish itself as a gold standard for high-value solutions that the world seeks to emulate.

site_title: Cosmic dreams
summary: Bell & Ross has released the BR-03 Astro, a limited-edition timepiece featuring a miniature solar system on the dial, with Earth at its center and the Moon, Mars, and a satellite orbiting around it. The watch's design is inspired by the International Space Station's Cupola observation dome. Meanwhile, Sarpaneva Watches celebrates 80 years of Moomin magic with the Sarpaneva Moomin 80, a timepiece featuring a skeletonised shooting star aperture and a modified Swiss automatic movement. Both watches showcase innovative time-telling mechanisms and exceptional craftsmanship.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Ulysse Nardin, known for its wild mindset and unconventional designs, partners with fashion designer Amoureuxpeintre, for the Blast [Amoureuxpeintre].

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, SIA, Genting Singapore, Seatrium, StarHub, FEHT, The Hour Glass
summary: SIA's net profit surged 146.7% to S$1.6 billion for the third quarter, driven by a one-off non-cash accounting gain. Wilmar's net profit fell 39.4% to US$590.2 million for the six months, while Genting Singapore's net profit declined 34% to S$222 million. Seatrium swung into the black with a net profit of S$120.9 million. StarHub posted a net profit of S$78.4 million for the second half. FEHT entered a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a hotel, and The Hour Glass faced a S$18.9 million increase in valid claims against its co-founder.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Singapore shares decline amid hawkish Fed minutes; STI down 0.2%

site_title: Temasek-backed GenZero and Mizuho bank to collaborate on transition credit projects
summary: GenZero, a Temasek-backed investment company, has partnered with Mizuho bank to bring to market transition credits, a new asset class that supports the early phase-out of coal plants. Transition credits are generated when coal power plants are shut earlier than planned and replaced with renewable energy sources. The partnership aims to generate awareness on the benefits of transition credits and pave the way for investments in clean energy projects. The pilot project is being tested in two coal plants in the Philippines, with the goal of making coal-to-clean initiatives economically viable.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The Overall Mitigation in Global Emissions mechanism can raise the price of carbon credits and lower the number of credits traded.
All Singapore-listed companies are required to make climate disclosures aligned with the International Sustainability Standards Board from FY2025
A number of methodologies for transition credits are being developed at the moment.

site_title: Alibaba revenue beats estimates as signs of a comeback mount
summary: Alibaba Group Holding reported its fastest revenue growth in over a year, with an 8% increase to 280.2 billion yuan in the December quarter. The company's commerce business and AI efforts are driving the turnaround, with its US shares climbing. Alibaba has gained US$100 billion of market value in 2025, marking a comeback after a government crackdown gutted its internet business. The company's Qwen AI model has performed well in official benchmark tests, and it is partnering with Apple on AI features, sending shares to a 3-year high.

images.alt_text: The logos for Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., right, and the company's Qwen AI large language models (LLMs) arranged in Beijing, China, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. Optimism over AI's potential has sparked a blistering rally in China's stock market over the past month, turning the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index into the world’s best-performer. Photographer: Andrea Verdelli/Bloomberg

site_title: In-house counsel of four Singapore companies listed in Chambers and Partners ranking
summary: Four in-house lawyers from Singapore companies have been ranked among the top 36 leading in-house lawyers in the Asia-Pacific by Chambers and Partners. They are Loretta Yuen from OCBC, Natasha Sulaiman from Singapore Airlines, Wan Kwong Weng from Mapletree Investments, and Shantini Sanmuganathan from Singtel. The lawyers were recognized for their outstanding contributions to their companies, industries, and legal professions, with expertise spanning finance, aviation, real estate, and telecommunications.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Under the old regime, the Big Four law firms reportedly paid trainees an honorarium of around S$2,000 to S$2,500 per month.

site_title: Booking beats on room nights during holiday travel season
summary: Booking Holdings exceeded expectations with 13% growth in room nights booked to 261 million in the fourth quarter, driven by strong holiday travel demand. Gross travel bookings reached $37.2 billion, and adjusted earnings per share rose to $41.55. The company also authorized a $20 billion share buyback program and issued a $9.60 dividend. Despite concerns over currency fluctuations, Booking's results follow similar upbeat commentary from online travel peers Airbnb and Expedia Group.

site_title: 🥕 Reflections from a Gen Z: What’s the deal with such a generous Budget this 2025?
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 is considered one of the most generous in recent history, with a surplus of S$6.8 billion (0.9% of GDP) due to a 12.9% rise in net investment returns contribution. The budget includes various initiatives, such as a Large Families Scheme offering up to S$16,000 in support for families with three or more children. While some question the government's motives, experts attribute the surplus to the country's strong fiscal position and adherence to fiscal prudence. The budget's generosity may be seen as an "election Budget," but it's unclear whether it will impact election results, as surpluses earned in one term of government cannot be carried over to the next term.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong laid out plans to spur growth, while also tackling immediate cost pressures for households and businesses.

site_title: US labour market stable, disruptions feared from federal government layoffs
summary: The US labor market remains stable, with initial claims for state unemployment benefits increasing moderately to 219,000 for the week ended Feb 15. Despite concerns over federal government layoffs and spending cuts, economists believe the negative effects are yet to be felt in the broader economy. Historically low layoffs have kept the labor market stable, but workers dependent on federal government contracts or funding may face job losses. The Federal Reserve has left interest rates unchanged, citing a solid labor market, but policymakers monitor the economic impact of the Trump administration's policies.

images.alt_text: SUNRISE, FLORIDA - JUNE 26: Elizabeth Brunner (L) and Hope Johnson (R), recruiters for the City of Pompano Beach, speak to job seekers during the JobNewsUSA.com South Florida Job Fair held at the Amerant Bank Arena on June 26, 2024, in Sunrise, Florida. More than 50 companies set up booths to recruit people from entry-level to management. Open jobs include police officers, food service, security, sales reps, technicians, customer service, IT, teacher assistants, insurance agents, and account executives. site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust to acquire Sheraton hotel in Japan for 6 billion yen
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) has agreed to acquire the Four Points by Sheraton Nagoya hotel in Japan for 6 billion yen (S$52.8 million), its first Japanese hotel acquisition. The deal expands the trust's investment mandate to global markets and asset classes, with an expected completion date of April 25, 2025. The acquisition is expected to be 1.7% accretive to FEHT's distribution per stapled security, and the trust's gearing is expected to be around 32.9%. The property is within walking distance of the Chubu Centrair International Airport and is close to Aichi Sky Expo, Japan's fourth-largest exhibition centre.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Rendezvous Hotel, one of Far East Hospitality Trust's assets. The group's revenue for H2 FY2024 was S$54.9 million, 0.2 per cent higher year-on-year.
All of the stapled group’s key markets saw improved RevPAR in the first quarter.

site_title: Fed’s Kugler says inflation risks remain, cites economic policy uncertainty
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Adriana Kugler said inflation still has "some way to go" to reach the Fed's 2% target, citing economic policy uncertainty and moderate restraint on the economy. Kugler supported the Fed's decision to hold short-term borrowing costs in the 4.25-4.50% range, which she believes will exert restraint on the economy. She noted that the downward risks to employment have diminished but upside risks to inflation remain, and the path to the 2% target is bumpy. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates steady next month, with a rate cut unlikely before June.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Adriana Kugler testifies before a Senate Banking Committee hearing on her nomination to be a member of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., June 21, 2023. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo

site_title: US dollar steady as traders consider tariffs; yen surges on BOJ bets
summary: The US dollar remained steady against major currencies, despite President Donald Trump's latest tariff plans, as investors digested the news. The yen surged to a two-month high against the dollar, driven by worries about Trump's tariffs and increasing bets on further Bank of Japan rate hikes. The yen rose against the euro, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars also reacted to the news. Markets are closely watching geopolitical developments, including Trump's comments on Ukraine and China, which may impact currency values.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The employee of a currency exchange shop counts U.S. dollar banknotes in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico July 27, 2023. REUTERS/Jose Luis Gonzalez/File Photo

site_title: Ant Group’s profit rises with Jack Ma back in the public eye
summary: Ant Group's quarterly profit surged over 50-fold to nearly 4.49 billion yuan, largely due to a net investment gain, compared to a loss in the same period last year. The Chinese fintech giant, founded by Jack Ma, attributed the profit to the gain, which translates to an estimated 13.6 billion yuan in profit for Alibaba Group, considering its one-third stake in Ant. This marks a significant turnaround from the second quarter, where Ant's earnings jumped 193% compared to the previous year.

images.alt_text: bizant26// Ant Group Co. signage during the Singapore FinTech Festival in Singapore, on Wednesday, Nov. 15, 2023. The festival runs through Nov. 17.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, February 20, 2025
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday, February 20, 2025, amid concerns over Trump policies and the Federal Reserve's signals. The Japanese yen strengthened on rate hike bets, while gold prices remained near record highs due to Trump tariff worries. Meanwhile, Nasdaq-listed Grab reported a Q4 profit of US$27 million, beating analyst estimates.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks, which has climbed around 15 per cent so far this year, dropped two per cent on Thursday as the China tech surge came to an end.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as markets assess Trump’s tariff threats; Walmart drops
summary: US stock markets opened lower on February 20, 2025, amid concerns over President Donald Trump's tariff threats. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 66.5 points, or 0.15%, to 44,561.11. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 9.6 points, or 0.16%, and the Nasdaq dropping 27.1 points, or 0.13%. Walmart shares plummeted after a downbeat fiscal 2026 sales forecast. Investors remained cautious, avoiding risky bets amidst tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Genting Singapore posts 34% fall in H2 net profit to S$222 million
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 34% decline in half-year net profit to S$222 million, down from S$334.9 million in the same period last year. Despite a 26% quarter-on-quarter increase in gaming revenue, non-gaming revenue fell 15%. The company remains committed to its RWS 2.0 investments, including a super luxury hotel and Singapore Oceanarium set to open in Q3 2025.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 20)
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) carried 29.4 million passengers in the first nine months of FY2025, a 9.6% increase from the previous year. The airline's Q3 net profit rose 146.7% due to a one-off non-cash gain from the Air India-Vistara merger. Despite this, SIA expects demand for air travel to remain healthy in the last quarter of FY2025.

site_title: Singapore’s Abaxx Exchange plans gold futures as metal surges
summary: Singapore's Abaxx Exchange plans to introduce gold futures contracts that will be physically deliverable in the city-state, tapping into Asia's potential. The move comes as gold prices surge, reaching successive peaks this year, driven by demand from central banks and investors seeking a haven. The contracts will connect futures and physical markets in one location, addressing a disconnect seen in the market during the pandemic. This will provide a new marketplace for Asia's kilobar market, which currently lacks a comparable platform to London and New York.

site_title: Japan’s Suzuki aims to boost sales by a third by 2030, invest heavily in India
summary: Suzuki Motor aims to boost global vehicle sales by 33% to 4.2 million by 2030, with 60% of those sales expected in India. The company plans to invest 2 trillion yen (S$18 billion) in India, focusing on manufacturing capacity and exports to Africa and the Middle East. Suzuki also aims to launch four battery electric vehicles in India by 2030, scale back previous plans, and target an operating profit margin of at least 10% by 2030. The company expects revenue of 8 trillion yen by 2030, a 49% increase.

images.alt_text: The Alto currently weighs 680 kg and the company hopes to lower that by 100 kg.
Suzuki now faces renewed competition in India from both local and foreign automakers with more attractive hybrid and electric car offerings.

site_title: Mercedes outlines cost cuts with 2025 earnings seen lower
summary: Mercedes-Benz Group expects lower earnings in 2025 due to weaker demand in China for its top-end vehicles and rising trade tensions. The company plans to cut production costs by 10% by 2027 to boost profitability. Rising US car tariffs and President Trump's threat to impose a 25% levy on imported autos also weigh on the company. Mercedes' carmaking margin dropped to 8.1% in 2024, below the previous year's 12.6%. The company has been shifting resources to more expensive vehicles and moving away from less profitable entry-level models.

site_title: Crypto worth US$99 million withdrawn from Milei-backed Libra token, researchers say
summary: Blockchain researchers Chainalysis reported that eight crypto wallets linked to the creator of the $LIBRA token withdrew around $99 million worth of tokens from the liquidity pool. The token's value surged above $4.50 after Argentine President Javier Milei recommended it, but then plummeted hours later. Milei denied any involvement with the cryptocurrency after deleting a promotional post. A federal judge is investigating the token's launch and Milei's involvement.

images.alt_text: The Argentine leader wants to secure the US president’s support for his country to receive more money from the International Monetary Fund in a new programme.

site_title: South Korean president’s lawyer says martial law bid sought to stop ‘dictatorship’
summary: South Korea's impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol is standing trial for insurrection, with his lawyer claiming the bid for martial law was aimed at thwarting a "legislative dictatorship" by the opposition-controlled parliament. Yoon faces up to life in prison or the death penalty. The trial comes as the Constitutional Court deliberates whether to formally remove Yoon from office following his impeachment in December. The case has plunged the country into months of political turmoil, with protests and online disinformation.

South Korea’s Yoon and his lawyers argued at a Constitutional Court hearing last week in his impeachment trial that he never intended to fully impose martial law but had only meant the measures as a warning to break political deadlock.

site_title: Airbus sets modest 2025 jet delivery goal amid supply snags
summary: Airbus sets a modest 2025 jet delivery goal of 820 aircraft, a 7% increase from 2024, amid ongoing supply chain issues and trade tensions. The European planemaker faces challenges in delivering on its peak production levels due to supplier woes stemming from the Covid-19 pandemic. Airbus expects to meet its annual goal despite engine shortages and production holdups, with CEO Guillaume Faury stating that the situation is expected to normalize in the latter part of the year. Adjusted earnings before interest and taxes are forecasted to be around 7 billion euros in 2025.

site_title: DeepSeek rally helps Chinese tech firms raise more funds
summary: Chinese technology companies have raised over $1 billion globally through share placements this year, with most of it in February, driven by a DeepSeek-fueled rally and Beijing's perceived softer stance on the sector. Companies such as UBTech Robotics, Black Sesame International Holding, and XtalPi Holdings have raised funds for research and development, business expansion, and other purposes. This improved funding environment is attributed to President Xi Jinping's meeting with prominent entrepreneurs, signaling Beijing's endorsement for the private sector.

images.alt_text: The need for more AI chips and servers to handle fast-growing usage and support model development drove Deepseek's decision to consider outside funding.

A giant screen shows news footage of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei speaking next to BYD CEO Wang Chuanfu and New Hope's founder and Chairman Liu Yonghao at a symposium on private enterprises with Chinese President Xi Jinping (not pictured), at a shopping complex in Beijing, China February 17, 2025. site_title: SIA Q3 net profit rises 146.7% on one-off non-cash gain from Air India-Vistara merger
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines' (SIA) net profit rose 146.7% to S$1.6 billion in Q3 FY2025 due to a one-off non-cash accounting gain from the Air India-Vistara merger. The company carried 29.4 million passengers in the first nine months of FY2025, a 9.6% increase from the prior-year period. Operating profit grew 3.3% to S$629 million. SIA expects demand for air travel to remain healthy in the last quarter of FY2025.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Yong Jun Yuan
Asia-Pacific also saw the most growth and remained the biggest market in both passenger and cargo aviation in 2024.

site_title: Delta offers US$30,000 each to Toronto plane crash passengers
summary: Delta Airlines is offering US$30,000 to each passenger on a plane that crashed while landing at Toronto Pearson International Airport on February 17, 2025, as a gesture of goodwill. The plane, a Bombardier CRJ-900, was carrying 80 people, but only one passenger was still hospitalized with injuries. 21 passengers were injured, with various injuries reported, including back sprains, head injuries, anxiety, and headaches. The Transportation Safety Board of Canada and the US Federal Aviation Administration are investigating the incident.

images.alt_text: The crash in Canada comes after some other recent crashes in North America in late January.

site_title: Growth in global private equity deal flow may be slower than expected this year: Preqin
summary: Global private equity deal flow may slow this year due to a persistent pricing mismatch between buyers and sellers, according to a report by Preqin. Despite accumulating "dry powder" from investors, many sellers remain reluctant to lower their valuations. The report forecasts a slower-than-expected deal activity pace in 2025, with deal volume falling to 1,434 in the fourth quarter of 2024. Investors remain optimistic about the asset class, with 50% planning to commit more capital and 49% expecting better performance this year.

images.alt_text: A container ship and gantry cranes at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024. Investors and analysts are expecting China to deploy as much as 2 trillion yuan ($283 billion) in fresh fiscal stimulus as Beijing seeks to shore up the world’s No. 2 economy and boost confidence. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Elon Musk spells danger for Accenture, McKinsey and their rivals
summary: Elon Musk's new administration, the Department of Government Efficiency (Doge), aims to cut federal government spending by $2 trillion. Consulting firms, which rely heavily on government contracts, are concerned about their future. The industry's revenue from federal contracts exceeds $18 billion, with Accenture, McKinsey, and Deloitte being the top recipients. Firms are adapting to Musk's abrupt methods and potential shift away from traditional consulting by exploring alternative technologies, such as AI. The Trump administration's executive order banning DEI efforts has also put the industry in an awkward spot, with some firms seeking to placate the new administration by toning down their diversity goals.

images.alt_text: A logo of Deloitte sits outside the Meta House on the opening day of the 55th annual meeting of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, January 20, 2025. REUTERS/Yves Herman

epa11908844 Billionaire Elon Musk carries an Air Force One plush toy as he arrives back to the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 19 February 2025. Trump returned to Washington after attending an investment summit backed by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund in Miami, Florida.  EPA-EFE/AARON SCHWARTZ / POOL

site_title: Ed Sheeran and Bhutan show the way ahead for music tourism
summary: Ed Sheeran's concert in Bhutan marked a milestone in the country's music tourism efforts, showcasing a more authentic and sustainable approach to the industry. The event, which was the first international concert by a global artist in Bhutan, was organized by the Department of Tourism Bhutan to promote the country's unique culture and values. The concert was capped at 23,000 attendees and ticket prices started at $10, making it affordable for locals. The event was a success, with many locals expressing excitement about the opportunity to experience international music. Bhutan's approach to music tourism prioritizes sustainability, authenticity, and community inclusion, with the country aiming to further explore the concept through a series of intimate performances featuring international and regional artists.

images.alt_text: Boloni's new 5,000 square foot flagship showroom. The brand is targeting the high-end residential market.

site_title: Renault posts record profitability in 2024
summary: Renault reported record profitability in 2024, with revenues rising 7.4% to 56.2 billion euros, and an operating profit margin of 7.6%. However, net profit sank to 800 million euros due to a 1.5-billion-euro loss from the sale of Nissan shares. Without the sale, profit would have been 2.8 billion euros, a 21% increase from 2023. The company attributed its success to its product offensive and cost cutting, and proposed a 19% increase in dividend payments.

images.alt_text: The latest agreement gives Geely better access to South America’s biggest economy.
Nissan's net income slumped 94 per cent in the six months to Sept 30 as profits cratered in the US and China, making it harder to refinance a record amount of bonds due to mature in 2026.

site_title: New lock-in rule for private-hire cars could moderate COE demand
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has introduced a new rule for private-hire cars, requiring a three-year lock-in period for businesses that acquire new vehicles. This rule aims to moderate demand for Certificates of Entitlement (COEs) and reduce speculation by smaller players. By limiting the sale and conversion of PHC vehicles, the LTA hopes to discourage transient fleets from acquiring vehicles for short-term gains, thereby easing COE price pressures. The new rule is expected to encourage major PHC fleets to be more cautious in bidding.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
A licence or special decal which private-hire car drivers who must display on their windscreens. Grab Affixing Centre at Midview City in Sin Ming Lane.
A new rule mandates a three-year lock-in period for recently acquired private hire cars in Singapore.
Senior Minister of State for Transport Amy Khor said that having more platform operators means more competition and choice for both commuters and drivers.
According to driver feedback, earnings may have dropped by 30 per cent in the past six months.
Private hire cars  currently use the same Certificates of Entitlement as passenger cars and have been blamed for driving premiums up.
Industry watchers say that forthcoming regulatory changes will reduce operating costs for taxis, but will not give them a significant advantage.
The government says that having a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private hire cars is possible, but the trade-offs must be studied carefully.
Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose, while those for commercial vehicles and motorcycles remained flat.

site_title: Manulife US Reit to sell Plaza office building for US$40 million as H2 distributable income falls 57.6%
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (MUST) is selling its 500 Plaza office building in New Jersey for US$40 million, as part of its efforts to pare down debt. The sale, expected to be completed this quarter, will help MUST repay US$130.7 million in loans maturing in 2025 and begin paying down debts in 2026. The trust reported a 57.6% drop in distributable income to US$15.4 million for the half year, and revenue declined 25.5% to US$80.8 million.

images.alt_text: Tripp Gantt, chief executive of Manulife US Reit's manager, says priorities for 2024 will focus on asset dispositions and maximising proceeds to further reduce indebtedness and fund capital expenditure.
Manulife US Reit’s Class-A Peachtree building in Atlanta in United States. The counter gained 12.6 per cent in the past week, alongside other Singapore-listed US office Reits.

This decline was driven by higher discount rates and terminal capitalisation rates for certain properties alongside weak occupancy performance across certain US office submarkets, said the manager on Friday (Jan 10).

site_title: TikTok cuts trust and safety jobs in Singapore as part of global layoffs
summary: TikTok has cut trust and safety jobs in Singapore as part of its global layoffs, with at least a dozen employees let go with immediate effect. The cuts follow months of careful consideration for operational efficiency and alignment with business needs. The move is part of a larger effort by TikTok to trim its workforce, which had previously announced plans to lay off hundreds of employees globally. The layoffs are not the first for TikTok, which had previously cut jobs in Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the US, with the company investing over S$2.67 billion in trust and safety efforts in 2024.

images.alt_text: ByteDance’s relationship with Tencent in gaming has warmed after a rancorous period of competition.
Despite TikTok Shop’s breakneck growth, the video app’s future in the US is at doubt, given the continued threat of a ban should it fail to sell the US portion of its business.
TikTok’s fate has been up in the air since a law requiring ByteDance to either sell it on national security grounds or face a ban took effect on Jan 19.
Apple confirmed that TikTok will return to its US app store on Thursday evening.
Apple and Google have still not reinstated TikTok to the App Stores.
YouTube is the latest TikTok competitor to try to capitalise on the app’s looming US ban, which could go into effect in early April.
The app is used by 170 million Americans.
It’s unknown whether ByteDance and the Chinese government consider offers from Tinsley and McCourt as palatable paths forward.

site_title: Lenovo’s profit beats estimates as AI fuels PC recovery hopes
summary: Lenovo's quarterly profit exceeded estimates, with net income more than doubling to $692.7 million and revenue rising 20% to $18.8 billion. The company attributes the growth to AI infrastructure spending, which is helping pull the global PC market out of a slump. Investors expect PC makers, including HP and Dell Technologies, to benefit in 2025 as consumers upgrade to devices with more AI features. However, potential US tariffs and macroeconomic headwinds threaten the industry's recovery, and the concept of AI PCs remains untested with consumers.

images.alt_text: Lenovo aims to make 50,000 AI rack servers and 2,400 graphic processing unit (GPU) servers, which are designed specifically for resource-heavy tasks like machine learning, annually at the plant in Puducherry.

site_title: Trump tariff worries keep gold near record high level
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariff strategies have led to a rise in gold prices, with spot gold increasing 0.2% to $2,938.57 an ounce. Trump's plans for auto and semiconductor tariffs have raised concerns about higher inflation, prompting the Federal Reserve to maintain its benchmark interest rate range at 4.25-4.5%. Traders now expect the Fed to deliver 38 basis points worth of rate cuts by December. The ongoing trade tensions and inflation fears have led to a surge in gold prices, hovering near their all-time high.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held steady at US$2,932.35 an ounce.

site_title: Wilmar posts 39.4% fall in H2 net profit on absence of year-ago gain, weak sugar price
summary: Wilmar International posted a 39.4% fall in net profit to US$590.2 million for the six months ended December 2024, primarily due to the absence of a US$231 million gain from the disposal of its Moroccan associate Cosumar and a US$22.8 million net loss from a share swap exercise. Revenue rose 5.3% to US$36.4 billion, driven by stronger sales volumes, but the company's core net profit was down 43.6% at US$558.2 million. Wilmar proposed a final dividend per share of S$0.10, down slightly from the prior year.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Adani Enterprises will sell a 13 per cent stake in Adani Wilmar to comply with India’s minimum public shareholding requirements.

site_title: Most US manufacturers forecast layoffs at Vietnam operations with Trump tariffs: survey
summary: US manufacturers with operations in Vietnam forecast layoffs if the Trump administration imposes tariffs on the country. A survey by the American Chamber of Commerce found nearly two-thirds of manufacturers expect potential layoffs, while nearly 60% of the country's $500 billion foreign investment is in manufacturing. The US has a huge trade surplus with Vietnam, making it a potential target for new duties. The survey also found that 41% of respondents are considering diversifying their business away from the US market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shoes for export are seen at a shoe factory in Hanoi, Vietnam December 29, 2020. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo

site_title: Trump expects visit from Chinese President Xi without giving timeline
summary: US President Donald Trump expects a visit from Chinese President Xi Jinping without providing a timeline, fueling hopes for a potential easing or delay of trade tariffs. Trump stated that a conversation between Xi and him is crucial for a new trade deal, citing past discussions on issues like TikTok and Taiwan. Trump also mentioned the possibility of making a deal with Russia to end the war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: On Feb 17 Alibaba CEO Jack Ma and other entrepreneurs met at a symposium in Beijing with Xi Jinping -- which is widely seen as a sign that private sector tech is back in favour.
The company will also focus its operations on international markets outside of the US, such as South Korea, Singapore and the Middle East, Peng says.

A giant screen shows news footage of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei speaking next to BYD CEO Wang Chuanfu and New Hope's founder and Chairman Liu Yonghao at a symposium on private enterprises with Chinese President Xi Jinping (not pictured), at a shopping complex in Beijing, China February 17, 2025. REUTERS/Florence Lo

Chinese President Xi Jinping “stressed that the difficulties and challenges currently faced by the development of the private economy have generally appeared during the process of reform and development, and industrial transformation”.
Xi Jinping has long stressed the need for China to achieve self-sufficiency in semiconductors and wants the country to use AI to drive economic development.
“If the US is not willing, if it is bent on suppressing and containing China, then we have no choice but to play along to the end,” Foreign Minister Wang Yi says.

site_title: Australia’s jobless rate rises in January even as employment booms
summary: Australia's annual jobs growth accelerated to 3.5%, more than twice the US pace, in January, but the unemployment rate rose to 4.1% due to an increase in workforce participation. Full-time employment rose 54,100, while part-time employment declined. Despite this, economists believe the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will deliver a shallow easing cycle due to the tight labor market and moderation in wages, which fell to 0.7% in the December quarter. The RBA trimmed its cash rate by 25 basis points to 4.10% and may not guarantee further easing.

images.alt_text: Australia's annual pay growth slowed to 3.2 per cent, from 3.6 per cent, the lowest reading since the third quarter of 2022.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia says the change will be implemented on its eligible business lending products.
Australia’s rate cut will be welcome news for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who must face voters in a general election that is due by May 17 at the latest.
Qatar Airways is still awaiting government approval for its purchase of a 25 per cent stake in Virgin Australia from the US private equity firm Bain Capital.
It’s the first time Qantas has been pushed from the top spot since early 2022.

site_title: Asian currencies face more pain against peers as low carry bites
summary: Asian currencies are likely to face further underperformance against global peers due to low interest rates and the prospect of interest-rate cuts by central banks in China, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand. Emerging Asian currencies earned a total return of just 0.4% this year, compared to 5.7% for Latin American currencies, and 3.1% for EMEA currencies. Rising trade tensions between China and the US and the impact of US tariffs are also expected to weigh on Asian currencies, with policymakers likely to allow some currency depreciation to soften the blow.

images.alt_text: South-east Asian currencies initially weakened as the US dollar gained but have strengthened against the greenback in recent days.

site_title: US to cut size of diplomatic mission in China by up to 10%, SCMP reports
summary: The US is set to cut the size of its diplomatic mission in China by up to 10%, according to a report by the South China Morning Post. The cuts, which could affect embassy staff and local employees, are part of President Donald Trump's effort to overhaul the US diplomatic corps. The move is expected to impact the embassy in Beijing and consulates in several Chinese cities, including Guangzhou and Shanghai. The US State Department has no immediate comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: “If the US is not willing, if it is bent on suppressing and containing China, then we have no choice but to play along to the end,” Foreign Minister Wang Yi says.

Traditional Russian wooden dolls depicting Russian President Vladimir Putin, China President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump displayed at a souvenir shop in Moscow, Russia, Feb 13, 2025. Trump - who has cast himself in his second term as a global peacemaker - said he would consider a summit with Putin and Xi “when things calm down.”

China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs' spokesperson Lin Jian says: "We hope that Panama will make the right decision based on the overall situation of bilateral relations and the long-term interests of the two peoples, and eliminate external interference."

site_title: China leaves benchmark lending rates unchanged as expected in February
summary: China's central bank kept benchmark lending rates unchanged at 3.10% and 3.60% in February, showing a cautious approach to monetary stimulus amid economic uncertainties and trade tensions with the US. Despite a surge in new yuan loans, credit demand remains sluggish, and the yuan has lost 2.4% against the dollar since Donald Trump's election. The authorities are likely to guide deposit rates lower and replenish bank capital to alleviate net interest margin pressure.

images.alt_text: The WTO is upgrading its tariff analysis database and will launch the new version on Mar 4.
On Feb 17 Alibaba CEO Jack Ma and other entrepreneurs met at a symposium in Beijing with Xi Jinping -- which is widely seen as a sign that private sector tech is back in favour.
Ant Group has opened positions related to humanoid robot systems and applications through its subsidiary, Shanghai Ant Lingbo Technology.

site_title: Siemens set to raise 1.4 billion euros in Healthineers stake sale
summary: Siemens is set to raise approximately 1.4 billion euros from the sale of a 2.3% stake in its medical technology unit, Siemens Healthineers. The sale comes after increasing the deal's size to fund its US$10.6 billion acquisition of Altair Engineering. Demand for the shares exceeded supply, and the price is expected to be 54.65 euros per share, representing a 2.9% discount from the previous close. The proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes.

images.alt_text: Chief executive Roland Busch said the company had made a “promising start” to its 2025 fiscal year, which runs to the end of September.
Siemens, whose products range from industrial controllers and software to trains, is targeting comparable sales of 3 to 7 per cent over the next 12 months.
The wind unit is planning to reduce output, focus on European and US markets and slash as many as 4,100 jobs, or about 15 per cent of its workforce.

site_title: Fortescue profit plunges as China’s iron ore demand declines
summary: Fortescue's first-half profit plummeted 53% to US$1.55 billion due to China's declining iron ore demand. Despite record shipments of 97.1 million tonnes, the company's dividend was halved to A$0.50 cents per share. Fortescue's iron ore production remains short of its expected full capacity, and the company aims to ship up to 9 million tonnes of Iron Bridge ore this fiscal year. The decline in demand and iron ore prices cast doubt on the company's plans for green-energy projects, following the election of a second Trump administration.

images.alt_text: Fortescue is currently facing a court case in Western Australia that will determine how much compensation it must pay the Yindjibarndi Ngurra Aboriginal Corporation for mining on their traditional lands without permission.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as Federal Reserve flags concern over Trump policies
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday as the Federal Reserve expressed concerns over US President Donald Trump's policies, citing potential inflation and complicating the disinflation process. Despite a record close on Wall Street, Hong Kong's 15% gain this year came to an end, and other markets such as Tokyo, Shanghai, and Seoul also fell. The Fed's minutes suggested officials would not cut interest rates anytime soon, citing worries about trade and immigration policies, and dealers are now keeping an eye on developments in Europe and the ongoing US-Russia talks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Staff lower Chinese national flag in front of screens showing the index and stock prices outside Exchange Square, in Hong Kong, China, August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
The S&P 500 gained 0.2 per cent to close at 6,144.15 on Wednesday, its second straight record.
Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.4%

site_title: KKR wins control of US$4.4 billion Fuji Soft after clash with Bain
summary: KKR has secured control of US$4.4 billion Fuji Soft after a months-long bidding war against Bain Capital. The New York-based firm secured enough shares in a tender offer to take the company private, with KKR's offer price at 9,850 yen per share. Bain Capital decided not to increase its offer price and proceed with a hostile bid, effectively ending the bidding war. Fuji Soft has over 10,000 employees in its IT solutions business segment.

images.alt_text: Bain had said last week it might withdraw its proposal for Fuji Soft, after KKR raised its offer above Bain’s in a months-long bidding war.
Bain’s possible concession would bring to an end months of intense competition with its US rival to take control of Fuji Soft.
KKR increased its tender offer for Fuji Soft to 9,850 yen per share, putting it above the 9,600 yen per share that Bain Capital said it planned to offer.
KKR will pay 9,451 yen (S$81.49) for each Fuji Soft share, an increase from the 8,800 yen it originally offered and one yen more than Bain’s proposal.

site_title: Apollo Aquaculture’s ex-CEO Ng Woei Kiat charged with taking S$450,000 bribe which went to condo purchase
summary: Former Apollo Aquaculture Group CEO Ng Woei Kiat, 51, has been charged with taking a S$450,000 bribe, allegedly using it to pay for a condominium unit. Ng was accused of accepting the bribe from Alric Projects' director Alan Koh Joon Seong, who was also charged with giving the bribe. The bribery allegedly occurred in 2018, and Ng also faces charges under the Companies Act for failing to declare his interest in related-party transactions. Both men indicated a desire to claim trial.

images.alt_text: Apollo Aquaculture Group was placed under interim judicial management on Mar 17 2022, and subsequently under judicial management on May 4, 2022, said the group's judicial manager Tan Wei Cheong  of professional services company Deloitte & Touche.

An employee at Apollo Aquaculture Group feeding a tank of giant and tiger groupers at the home-grown fish farming company’s new eight-storey fish farm in Lim Chu Kang on February 18, 2021. The company was reported, in 2021, to be building a S$65-million multi-storey fish farming facility.
The $65 million multi-storey fish farming facility has been conditionally sold to a local construction and engineering firm.

site_title: Analysts raise target prices, dividend estimates on UOB as they get positive on earnings outlook
summary: Analysts have raised their target prices for UOB after the lender posted a record full-year net profit of S$6.05 billion. Maybank Securities raised its target price by nearly 15% to S$44.32, while RHB maintained its "buy" rating and raised its target price to S$41.60. UOB plans to distribute surplus capital through special dividends and share buybacks, with analysts forecasting higher valuations and dividend yields. The lender aims for high single-digit loan growth and double-digit fee increases in 2025.

The capital distibution package is a long-awaited move from UOB.

site_title: Citi India plans to buy US$1 billion of asset-backed securities
summary: Citi India plans to buy $1 billion of asset-backed securities, increasing its book by three-fold, as domestic lenders seek liquidity amid sluggish deposit growth. The bank expects around $30 billion in total securitisation volume in the fiscal year ending March 31, 2026. Indian lenders are tapping the securitisation market, with private banks like HDFC Bank and IDFC First Bank, and digital lenders like Navi Finserve, securitising their retail loan portfolios. The market is forecast to grow, driven by the entrance of large private banks and regulatory pressure.

images.alt_text: Citi led 76 transactions in Asia last year, raising US$2.4 billion, according to the bank.
Cost savings will partly be channelled into investing in areas such as data quality and regulatory controls, Jane Fraser says.

site_title: Telstra’s profit jumps, announces A$750 million share buyback
summary: Telstra, Australia's top telecom firm, posted a net profit of A$1.03 billion for the first half of 2025, beating the consensus estimate and surpassing the prior year's A$964 million. The company also announced an A$750 million share buyback, citing cost discipline and confidence in its outlook. Telstra's consumer division saw a 3.1% rise in revenue, driven by increased demand for its network, and the company plans to invest A$800 million over the next four years to upgrade its mobile network.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past a Telstra store in Sydney's CBD in Sydney, Australia, July 3, 2024. REUTERS/Jaimi Joy/File Photo
The heavy trading of Singtel shares comes after the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission filed court proceedings against Optus Mobile over allegations of inappropriate sales conduct.
TPG expects the deal to deliver net cash proceeds between A$4.65 billion and A$4.75 billion.
Singtel must show results from NCS, Optus divisions to help fuel share price uptrend
The agreement will help the company speed up its 5G in 5G-infrastructure roll-out to more of Australia's regional communities, its interim CEO says.

site_title: Seatrium wins offshore rig contract from Saudi Aramco-backed International Maritime Industries
summary: Seatrium Offshore Technology, a subsidiary of Seatrium, has secured a contract from Saudi Aramco-backed International Maritime Industries to provide equipment and a license for a self-elevating drilling unit in the Middle East and North Africa region. This is the third rig, Kingdom 3, in a long-term partnership between the two companies. Seatrium will supply equipment and a license for the rig, which is tailored to meet functional requirements in the region. The contract underscores Seatrium's position in the offshore and marine industry, with the company expecting to sign another contract in the first quarter of 2025.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
In the first phase of development, the Kaskida project will have a capacity to produce 80,000 barrels of crude oil per day.

site_title: China tries to woo foreign firms back after slump in investment
summary: China is reviving efforts to attract foreign investment, releasing an action plan to stabilize foreign investment and remove market access restrictions. The plan aims to ensure equal treatment of goods, improve access to credit, and better understand the needs of foreign firms. Despite this, foreign firms have continued to scale back new investments in China, with a net $4.5 billion in 2024, the lowest since 1992. The Commerce Ministry will visit foreign enterprises to address their concerns and coordinate with local authorities to resolve issues.

site_title: Complex AI chips will drive demand for Lam Research chipmaking tools, CEO says
summary: Lam Research CEO Tim Archer predicts a surge in demand for complex AI chips, driving the need for its chipmaking tools over the next three years. This trend will benefit Lam Research, with investors sending its shares up 1% on the news. As one of three US chip equipment makers used by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) to produce advanced AI and other processors, Lam Research is poised to benefit from the growing demand for AI silicon. Archer described AI as the "biggest fundamental technology revolution of our lifetimes."

images.alt_text: TSMC is the go-to chipmaker for Apple, Nvidia and other companies developing semiconductors that power AI algorithms.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s hawkish stance seen boosting demand for US corporate bonds
summary: The Bank of Japan's recent interest rate hike is expected to boost demand for US corporate bonds, particularly high-grade bonds, as it reduces currency protection costs for Japanese investors. The move, which raised the key policy rate to the highest level since 2008, is also expected to lower hedging costs, making US bonds more attractive. This trend is also drawing companies to Japan, with firms seeking to grow their base of Japanese bond buyers, according to Bank of America strategists.

site_title: Google develops AI co-scientist to aid researchers
summary: Google has developed an AI tool to aid researchers in biomedical sciences, utilizing advanced reasoning to synthesize literature and generate novel hypotheses. The tool, tested by scientists at Stanford University and Imperial College London, showed promising results in inhibiting causes of disease, particularly in the area of liver fibrosis. The AI is designed to complement, not replace, researchers, and is expected to increase scientific collaboration. Google's AI unit, DeepMind, has made science a priority, following the success of ChatGPT and similar models in the workplace.

images.alt_text: Anthropic is best known for its Claude family of large language models, which compete with ones made by OpenAI.
Gemini Flash-Lite cost US$0.019 per one million tokens.

The Google logo is seen outside a building housing Google offices in Beijing on February 4, 2025. China on February 4 said it would probe US tech giant Google over violations of anti-monopoly laws after Washington slapped 10 percent levies on Chinese goods. (Photo by GREG BAKER / AFP)

site_title: Beyond Meat pursues new borrowing to shore up liquidity
summary: Beyond Meat is seeking up to $250 million in a new senior secured loan from private credit lenders, its second attempt in less than a year, to shore up liquidity amid weaker demand due to higher inflation. The company, which reported higher net revenue and gross profit in its last earnings call, is working to tackle its $1.15 billion of convertible bonds due in 2027. This move comes after its stock price plummeted following failed attempts to improve its finances and potentially restructure.

images.alt_text: Despite the low animal cell count, Good Meat says it has received positive consumer feedback on the product’s taste, texture, and look during testing.

site_title: Japan’s food inflation is becoming harder for Bank of Japan to overlook
summary: Japan's food inflation is surging, with fresh food prices rising 71.9% since 2010, outpacing overall inflation. The Bank of Japan is expected to hike its benchmark rate faster than anticipated, as food prices, including rice and cabbage, continue to rise. The central bank's governor, Kazuo Ueda, is paying closer attention to food inflation, which may not be temporary and could affect consumers' inflation expectations. The government is also taking note, with Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba facing pressure to address growing discontent over inflation, including food costs, ahead of a national election.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan board member Hajime Takata said the BOJ must keep raising interest rates if companies continue to increase prices, wages and investment.
Isuzu Motors trucks bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan, Feb 6, 2025. Japan's exports rose 7.2 per cent year-on-year in January.
Rising bond issuance comes alongside a wider surge in dealmaking in the country.
Strong domestic demand is helping support a recovery in Japan, the world’s fourth-largest economy, even as US President Donald Trump’s tariff threats fuel concerns about the export outlook.

site_title: Forever 21 plans hundreds of store closures in second bankruptcy
summary: Forever 21, owned by Authentic Brands, is preparing to close at least 200 more locations as part of a potential bankruptcy process. The US-based retailer, operating over 500 US stores and 800 worldwide, aims to sell its remaining stores or liquidate them if no buyer emerges. Some stores have lost money for years, and the company has withheld royalties and rent payments to keep them afloat. Authentic Brands plans to license the Forever 21 brand to other retailers regardless of the outcome.

images.alt_text: Authentic Brands Group bought the Forever 21 brand name out of bankruptcy in February 2020 and licensed it to Sparc Group.
Authentic Brands bought the Forever 21 brand name out of bankruptcy in February 2020.

The deal would expand Forever 21‘s reach by bringing the label to Shein’s online platform, which serves about 150 million users. The partnership also presents an opportunity for China-based Shein to step into Forever 21‘s retail locations across the United States.

site_title: Rio Tinto opposes bid to cut London listing, 2024 profit hits five-year low
summary: Rio Tinto opposes a bid to cut its London listing, citing the benefits of having global investors. The company, which derives most of its profits from iron ore, expects its lowest full-year underlying earnings in five years due to tropical cyclones disrupting iron ore shipments in Australia. CEO Jakob Stausholm stated that London listing "kind of works for us" and that changing it would not fundamentally alter the company's value. Rio recommends shareholders vote against a resolution to review its dual-listed structure at its annual general meeting in April.

images.alt_text: Rio Tinto is the world’s second-biggest miner.
Rio would gain access to lithium mines, processing facilities and deposits across four continents to fuel decades of growth, as well as a customer base that includes Tesla, BMW and General Motors.

site_title: Sasseur Reit posts 0.1% rise in H2 DPU to S$0.02929 on resilient rental income
summary: Sasseur Reit reported a 0.1% increase in its second-half distributable income (DPU) to S$0.02929, driven by resilient rental income under its entrusted management agreement model. The DPU rose 3.1% to S$40.6 million, supported by lower finance costs and tax expenses. For the full year, DPU fell 2.7% to S$0.06082, attributed to lower first-half DPU and higher retention for loan principal amortisation. The Reit's portfolio occupancy reached an all-time high of 98.9% in Q4, and the manager remains cautiously optimistic about the sales outlook for 2025.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
The Reit’s performance aligns with broader national trends reported in China which has seen a resurgence domestic consumption.

The Reit's Hefei outlet’s outlet sales fell 5.9 per cent to 209.3 million yuan from 222.3 million yuan. Hefei city had recorded four earthquakes in September which affected shopper traffic and sales at the outlet, said the Reit’s manager.

site_title:
Fed officials weighed slowing or pausing 
bond drawdown at last policy meeting
summary: The US Federal Reserve maintained its benchmark interest rate between 4.25-4.5% at its last policy meeting, amid uncertainty over the Treasury's debt issuance and the ongoing balance sheet drawdown. Fed officials considered slowing or pausing the balance sheet run-off until clarity on debt-ceiling dynamics arrived, citing challenges in assessing market liquidity. Fed Chair Jerome Powell indicated that quantitative tightening (QT) has "a ways to go," but officials are uncertain where to stop, balancing the risk of overshooting QT with the need to maintain market liquidity.

site_title: Why Malaysia Airports’ multi-billion ringgit privatisation matters
summary: Malaysia Airports Holdings Berhad (MAHB), the country's largest airport operator, is set to be privatized after a turbulent process, with a RM7.3 billion deal led by the Gateway Development Alliance (GDA) consortium. MAHB will leave Bursa Malaysia after 25 years, marking a historic shift in the nation's aviation and investment landscape. The deal values MAHB at RM18.3 billion, with Khazanah Nasional, EPF, and GIP holding a 70% majority stake, while the government retains a "golden share" for oversight. The privatization aims to improve financial stability and operational performance, but has sparked controversy over foreign influence and national interests.

site_title: Tesla cited by US regulators over worker’s death
summary: US federal regulators have cited Tesla for violating workplace safety rules in connection with the electrocution of a worker at its Austin, Texas auto-manufacturing plant last summer. The US Department of Labor cited Tesla for $7,000 in fines for two workplace safety violations, including failing to protect workers from chemical hazards. The investigation was closed in late January, but the nature of Tesla's workplace safety failures and any imposed penalties were not disclosed.

summary: Investor interest in wellness real estate in South-east Asia, particularly in Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand, is on the rise. CapitaLand Investment's report, "A Well of Opportunities: Wellness and Healthcare in South-east Asia," notes that the region is well-positioned to capitalize on the global wellness trend, driven by a growing ageing population and increasing demand for musculoskeletal treatments. The report highlights the "especially compelling" appeal of these markets, where wellness and healthcare-related opportunities in real estate are evolving rapidly.

site_title: Reviving SGX is not the endgame – creating a vibrant financial ecosystem is
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has seen its shares decline 5.6% despite the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) tax incentives to boost the equities market, which include corporate tax rebates and exemptions for asset managers. The incentives aim to encourage listings, with potential players including blue-chip companies like Keppel and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Additionally, a S$1 billion private credit fund was announced to help high-growth companies access capital, complementing the development of a thriving financial ecosystem.

site_title: Microsoft develops AI model for videogames
summary: Microsoft has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) model called Muse, which can generate visuals and actions for videogames. Collaborating with Ninja Theory, a developer under Xbox Game Studios, Muse aims to help reduce videogame development costs. The model has the potential to benefit both players and game creators, according to Fatima Kardar, corporate vice-president for gaming AI.

site_title: Turkey to export 15,000 tonnes of eggs to US to ease bird flu disruptions
summary: Turkey has begun exporting 15,000 tonnes of eggs to the US to ease disruptions caused by the devastating bird flu outbreak in the country, which has slashed US production and driven up prices. Shipments will continue until July and are expected to generate around $26 million in export revenue. The move aims to alleviate the strain on the US egg supply, which has been severely impacted by the outbreak that has already wiped out about 162 million chickens, turkeys, and other birds.

site_title: Trump brands Zelensky a ‘dictator’ in bitter clash
summary: US President Donald Trump has called Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky a "dictator" in a bitter clash, widening a rift with implications for efforts to end the conflict triggered by Russia's invasion three years ago. Trump's attacks drew shock from Europe and criticism from former Vice-President Mike Pence, who accused him of succumbing to Russian disinformation. Zelensky accused the US of helping Putin break out of isolation, and Ukraine's military expressed disbelief at Trump's claims. The rift comes as both sides try to improve their situation on the battlefield amid Trump's push for a ceasefire.

summary: Ant Group, a fintech giant linked to Alibaba, has opened positions related to humanoid robot systems and applications through its Shanghai Ant Lingbo Technology subsidiary. This move joins a growing list of major Chinese tech companies exploring the emerging humanoid robot industry, driven by the Chinese government's recognition of the sector as a key area for economic growth and technological leadership.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.4% to 3,919.97 at open, tracking overnight European market losses. Losers outnumbered gainers 60 to 46, with banking stocks trading lower. Key movers included Cosco Shipping International (up 6.6%), Genting Singapore (down 0.7%), and Singtel (down 0.3%). The decline follows a choppy US market, where the S&P 500 gained 0.2% despite worries over US tariffs and inflation.

site_title: Australia’s Goodman raises A$4 billion for data centres to tap AI boom
summary: Australia's Goodman Group plans to raise A$4 billion to develop a global network of data centers, driven by the growing demand for AI and cloud-based technologies. The company will raise the capital through a share placement and non-underwritten security purchase plan, with shares selling at A$33.50 apiece. The project is expected to be valued at over A$10 billion and comes after the company's market value reached almost A$69 billion in the past year. Goodman CEO Greg Goodman sees significant demand for data centers, presenting a global opportunity.

images.alt_text: Global “hyperscalers”, or large-scale cloud service providers,  have been spending billions on data centres to cater to the growing demand for AI services.

site_title: Polling district changes for 12 constituencies in latest update ahead of GE2025
summary: Singapore's Elections Department has updated polling districts in 12 constituencies ahead of the 2025 general election, with nine constituencies seeing an increase in polling districts and three remaining unchanged. The changes aim to make voting more convenient and efficient, with each district serving around the same number of voters. The updates are part of the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee's work, which will release its report in the middle to third week of March. The changes do not necessarily impact constituency boundaries, but may be used as a preview of voter numbers in some constituencies.

site_title: Budget 2025 : The power of shared beliefs
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 emphasizes shared beliefs and social responsibility, aiming to empower technologies and create a more equitable and inclusive economy. The budget supports small and medium enterprises with tax rebates and cash grants, and increases co-funding for lower-wage workers. It also provides social support through vouchers and rebates, stimulating consumer spending and economic growth. The government seeks to balance optimism with realism, navigating geopolitical shifts, technological disruptions, and evolving market dynamics. By grounding progress in social responsibility, Singapore aims to ensure its technologies contribute to the collective well-being.

site_title: Lights out for Indonesia civil servants as Prabowo cuts budgets
summary: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto has ordered sweeping budget cuts across government, aiming to save 306.7 trillion rupiah (S$25.2 billion) for his campaign pledges. Civil servants are feeling the pinch, with office lights and air conditioners switched off, and some employees working from home to save on energy costs. The cuts have sparked criticism from civil society groups, who call them "counterproductive and insensitive." The austerity measures are also expected to free up funds for Prabowo's campaign pledges, including a US$4.3 billion free meal plan for schoolkids and a new sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Asia banks stick with net-zero group that Wall Street abandoned
summary: Several large Asian banks, including DBS Group Holdings, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, and CIMB Group Holdings, have reaffirmed their commitment to the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), following a wave of exits by US and Canadian lenders. In contrast, European banks have remained committed to the alliance. The move sets the stage for a global divide in climate-finance strategies, with NZBA exploring a "next phase" to address questions around its operations with a reduced global footprint.

images.alt_text: Climate change can impact portfolio assets in material and unexpected ways, both near-term and in the coming years, as the world attempts to mitigate this systemic risk.

site_title: Starmer faces ‘Trump test’ in Washington
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is set to meet US President Donald Trump in Washington, marking the first European leader visit since Trump's inauguration. The meeting comes as Trump has fallen out with every UK prime minister he has worked with, including Boris Johnson and Theresa May. Starmer aims to use the US-UK special relationship to secure key interests, such as a post-Brexit trade deal and increased military spending. However, Trump's mercurial nature and skepticism on certain issues, like the Chagos Islands, pose challenges to the meeting's success.

site_title: Former manager at DBS Bank admits cheating 4 clients of S$348k
summary: A former wealth planning manager at DBS Bank, Pang Yuheng, pleaded guilty to three counts of cheating clients out of S$348,000. He duped clients into investing in fictitious fixed deposits with "attractive terms" to cover his own significant debts. Pang's scheme involved targeting existing customers, using high interest rates and maturity periods to gain trust. He was terminated in June 2023 and has since repaid S$70,000 to the bank, but still faces a loss of S$189,000. He will be sentenced in March.

images.alt_text: MHA said the proposed law is scoped to strike a balance between protecting the public from scams and maintaining a sense of personal responsibility.

Nasdaq-listed Grab’s Q4 profit falls to 
US$27 million, but beats analyst estimates
summary: Grab, a Nasdaq-listed company, reported a net profit of US$27 million for the fourth quarter, beating analyst estimates of US$10.3 million. Revenue for the quarter reached US$764 million, a 17% increase from the previous year, driven by growth across all segments. This marks a significant improvement from the full-year loss of US$105 million, which narrowed from US$434 million in the previous year.

site_title: Oil holds near one-week high on supply concerns, sanctions on Russia eyed
summary: Oil prices held near a one-week high on Wednesday due to supply concerns, including a 30-40% reduction in Caspian Pipeline Consortium oil flows after a Ukrainian drone attack and potential sanctions on Russia. Brent futures rose 0.3% to $76.04 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.6% to $72.25 a barrel. Analysts expect oil supply disruptions to continue, with Opec and Russia possibly delaying a planned supply increase in April.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose 62 cents, or 0.8 per cent to settle at US$75.84 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Apple adds lower-price iPhone 16e to line-up
summary: Apple has introduced the iPhone 16e, a lower-priced model with features found in more expensive iPhones, including Apple-tailored artificial intelligence and integration with OpenAI's ChatGPT. The iPhone 16e starts at $599, compared to $799 for a standard iPhone, and will be available starting February 28. The move aims to revive sales of the iconic device, as Apple seeks to compete with intense competition in the market, particularly in China. The company's services and digital content unit drove revenue growth, but iPhone sales slipped in mainland China.

images.alt_text: Apple late last month forecast strong sales growth signalling that the company will recover from a dip in iPhone sales as it rolls out artificial intelligence features in the coming months to more regions and languages.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at another record
summary: The S&P 500 index ended at a record high of 6,144.15 on Wednesday, marking its second consecutive record close amid lingering concerns about US tariffs and their potential to reignite inflation. The gain of 0.2% came after a choppy session, with major US indices moving in and out of negative territory throughout the day. Minutes from the Federal Reserve's last meeting showed concern about the effects of President Donald Trump's trade and immigration proposals on inflation.

site_title: Prabowo replaces controversial minister in first reshuffle; critics say the move fails to fix key issues
summary: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto has dismissed a controversial Minister, Satryo Brodjonegoro, in his first reshuffle just 100 days into office. Brodjonegoro was replaced by Brian Yuliarto as Minister of Higher Education, Science, and Technology, amid protests over his abuse of power and temperamental attitude. The move was seen as a distraction by critics, who argue it fails to address pressing social and economic issues. The reshuffle comes as Prabowo faces mounting public scrutiny over his economic policies and a growing tide of discontent among Indonesians.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 marks biggest daily drop in 2025 on tariff woes
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.91% to 552.10 points on Wednesday, its biggest daily drop since the start of 2025, amid escalating US trade war tensions. US President Donald Trump's tariff threats on autos, semiconductors, and pharmaceuticals led to declines in Germany, France, Italy, and Spain. Investors are also concerned about the impact of US trade policies on European economies, with some analysts predicting a potential two-party coalition in Germany's upcoming elections.
