site_title: Singapore shares end Wednesday higher on UOB results, Budget news; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% to a record high on Wednesday, driven by UOB's Q4 profit beat and Budget 2025 announcements. UOB's net profit of S$1.52 billion surpassed analyst expectations, while the lender announced a S$3 billion capital distribution package. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 8.48 points to 3,934.04, with maritime player Yangzijiang Shipbuilding leading gains and agribusiness Wilmar International falling 2.5%.

site_title: SingPost Q3 operating profit down 23.8% at S$21.1 million
summary: SingPost reported a 23.8% decrease in Q3 operating profit to S$21.1 million, driven by higher operating expenses and a decline in revenue from its Singapore and International business units. Despite a 12.1% increase in group revenue, operating expenses grew 14.1% and the Singapore postal and logistics business incurred an operating loss. The company's Australia business, however, saw higher revenue and operating profit due to the consolidation of Border Express. SingPost aims to divest non-core businesses and unlock value, with a proposed A$1 billion sale of its Australian business to Pacific Equity Partners on track.

Co-founder Nikolay Storonsky stated that backers will want an IPO "sooner or later" with the US looking like a preferable listing destination. Revolut, valued at $45 billion, has 50 million customers and has turned a profit three years running, but faces pressure to control costs while expanding globally and product lines.

site_title: Manulife’s profit climbs on wealth management strength, Asia growth
summary: Manulife Financial posted higher fourth-quarter profit, driven by a thriving wealth and asset management business and strong growth in Asia. The company's asset and wealth management unit has become increasingly significant, with insurers expanding their investment advisory and retirement planning services. Manulife's push into Asia has also been successful, as the company captures the financial needs of a growing, under-insured middle class. The results underscore the effectiveness of the company's strategic focus on high-return segments and asset management.

summary: Glencore reported a 16% decline in core earnings to US$14.4 billion, primarily due to slumping coal prices. The company, which posted record profits in 2022, is considering cutting production to support prices in some markets. Glencore is also returning US$2.2 billion to shareholders and may reduce ferrochrome and copper smelting output. The company's shares slid 4.5% in London trading, and it is reviewing its primary listing location, including a potential move to New York.

summary: A businessman, Melvin Li, has sued PropNex and its agent Ian Sng for about S$1.2 million over alleged misrepresentation in '99-to-1' deals. The practice involves tax avoidance arrangements to reduce ABSD payable on residential property purchases. PropNex denied the allegations, citing a defense by law firm Withers KhattarWong. site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly lower as markets assess latest tariff threats
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, February 19, due to concerns over President Donald Trump's latest tariff threats. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 78.2 points, or 0.18%, to 44,478.12, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The lower opening was despite the US stocks reaching fresh records the previous day. Market participants are assessing the impact of Trump's tariff threats on the economy and investing sentiment.

This comes after Musk's close ties with Trump and the return of some advertisers to X have lifted expectations of better finances at the platform. The reported talks follow a surge in valuations of Musk's other companies, including Tesla and SpaceX, after Trump's US presidential victory.

site_title: DeepSeek’s outside funding draws interest from Alibaba, Chinese state funds, The Information reports
summary: Chinese AI startup DeepSeek is considering outside funding for the first time, with interest from Alibaba and state funds, amid a surge in demand for its low-cost AI models. The company, which recently stunned the tech industry with its models, is facing outages due to its fast-growing usage. China Investment Corp and the National Social Security Fund are among the funds expressing interest in investing, while DeepSeek's executives are discussing shifting its focus to generating revenue and profit from research.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit declares 4.2% lower H2 DPU of US$0.0205
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported a 4.2% decline in its half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0205, down from US$0.0214 in the same period last year. Revenue rose 0.4% to US$36.4 million, driven by new leases and rental escalations. However, net property income fell 1.6% to US$24.4 million, mainly due to the absence of contributions from divested properties and higher property expenses. The Reit's portfolio valuation increased by 2.9% year on year, and its net asset value per unit rose to US$0.75.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The manager noted that the US23.2 million net proceeds will be used to repay existing debts, finance capital expenditure, fund potential acquisitions and/or for other general corporate requirements.
Penrose Plaza, a shopping mall in Philadelphia, is among the properties in United Hampshire US Reit's portfolio.

site_title: PepsiCo’s Greenhouse Accelerator supports early-stage startups in sustainability
summary: PepsiCo's Greenhouse Accelerator supports early-stage sustainability startups in the Asia-Pacific region. The third edition of the program, now in its pilot phase, pairs startups with PepsiCo executives to drive innovations focused on the circular economy, sustainable agriculture, and climate action. Ten finalists will pitch their innovations to executives, venture capitalists, and investors, with the winner securing an additional US$100,000 grant. Eligible startups must have pre-revenue of up to US$7 million and business operations in one of the participating Apac markets, with a solution that has an impact on PepsiCo's sustainability goals.

images.alt_text: Gan Kah Shuen (centre in black), a YFS participant in 2021 who is now a Singapore country director, with other country directors for Singapore and Malaysia and co-founder Lim Ee Ling (far right).
Seniors can play VR games to test their mobility and memory, as well as motor and cognitive skills, as demonstrated by the students who developed the project.

site_title: SingPost to lay off 45 employees ‘in the coming months’
summary: SingPost plans to lay off 45 employees in the coming months due to prolonged macroeconomic challenges, such as intense competition. The affected employees are primarily in corporate support units, with a small number from the international business unit. The company aims to "rightsize and devolve corporate functions to its business units" through this restructuring move.

site_title: China proposes new rules to tighten control over rare earth sector
summary: China has proposed new rules to tighten control over its rare earth sector, a move aimed at protecting the domestic industry. The draft regulations cover quotas for mining, smelting, and separating rare earths, as well as monitoring and enforcement. China dominates the global production of rare earths, accounting for nearly 90% of refined output. The new rules are the latest in a series of attempts to bring the sector under tighter state control, following previous export controls and restrictions.

site_title: Thai industrial sentiment hits 10-month high, but trade risks a concern
summary: Thai industrial sentiment has reached a 10-month high of 91.6 in January, driven by government stimulus, exports, and tourism. However, uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's trade policies has negatively impacted business confidence, alongside challenges from Chinese imports and high household debt. The Federation of Thai Industries is calling for more government support to counter global trade risks. Despite this, the central bank's decision to cut interest rates remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: A view of the port of Bangkok, Thailand May 26, 2016.  REUTERS/Jorge Silva

site_title: Hong Kong’s Gold Peak powers up Johor-Singapore SEZ with RM670 million investment for new battery plant
summary: Hong Kong-based Gold Peak Technology Group is investing RM670 million in a new battery plant in Malaysia's Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (SEZ), creating up to 180 jobs and enhancing export capabilities. The facility will produce nickel-zinc batteries for the data centre industry and bolster Malaysia's position in the energy storage market. Gold Peak Technology Group is the first company to invest under UOB's Green Lane initiative, designed to fast-track investment approvals. The new plant is expected to be operational by 2028.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng

Sunway Group founder Jeffrey Cheah and Malaysia's Transport Minister Anthony Loke (second and third standing from left) witnessed the signing of the partnership agreement between Sunway Property CEO Chong Sau Min (second from left) and MRT Corp CEO Mohd Zarif Hashim (third from left).

The properties are located in Senai Airport City, an industrial and manufacturing hub in the Senai region, which is part of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone in Malaysia.
Business across sectors including manufacturing, logistics and the digital economy can benefit from the improved cross-border flow of goods and people, said the Singapore minister of state.

Khairussaleh Ramli, Maybank's group president and chief executive officer, says the Corporate Renewable Energy Supply Scheme in place in the special economic zone to give businesses there access to green electricity will make it an attractive destination for sustainable and transition finance.

site_title: Not all SMEs may benefit from Budget 2025’s business support measures: companies
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 includes various business support measures, but some small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) say the schemes are geared towards larger firms. The government's support for mergers and acquisitions (M&As) and vouchers may not benefit SMEs outside the heartlands. Some SMEs believe that social measures can still encourage consumption and benefit businesses, but the focus on individual support is a concern.

Eligible HDB households will also receive up to S$760 in U-Save rebates to help them cope with utilities expenses.

All companies that have at least three resident employees will receive a fresh S$10,000 in the redesigned SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit, which will be available from the second half of 2026 and last for three years.

site_title: Microsoft unveils quantum computing chip for future data centres
summary: Microsoft has unveiled its first quantum computing chip, the Majorana 1, which harnesses 8 qubits on a small piece of hardware that can eventually host one million qubits. The chip, capable of solving math problems, is a major step towards practical utility of quantum computing. Microsoft engineers have found a way to deploy particles that make quantum computing possible in a system that could power data centers and enable advances in fields like chemistry and healthcare. The company believes Majorana qubits will be less prone to errors than other approaches.

site_title: Backlash against ESG investing in US may be transient, but may also have lasting impact
summary: The US backlash against ESG (environment, social, and governance) investing has intensified since President Donald Trump took office, with some large companies scaling back their diversity and inclusion initiatives. BlackRock, the world's largest fund manager, has dropped the use of the term ESG and toned down its diversity guidance, citing it being "entirely weaponised". The US Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) new guidance has also dampened engagement with companies on climate and social issues. This may leave investors with sustainability concerns, as the gap between US and European managers in supporting ESG issues has widened.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Diversity, equity and inclusion policies have become more important for a majority of Singapore organisations, according to a Workday report.
US President Donald Trump, who took office 10 days ago, turned a press conference on the disaster into a platform for his crusade against diversity, equity and inclusion or DEI.
Big corporations have been facing increasing pressure from conservative groups to cut back on DEI policies aimed at boosting racial and ethnic representation at workplaces.

site_title: Singapore’s next AI wave: From the incredible to everyday
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 aims to scale AI adoption beyond niche pilot projects and into everyday business operations, with a focus on SMEs, workforce development, industry collaboration, governance, and testbeds. The budget allocates S$150 million to the Enterprise Compute Initiative, S$4 billion for mid-career AI reskilling, and S$3 billion to expand the National Productivity Fund. It also reinforces sector-specific governance and expands AI testbeds. The goal is to unlock S$4.1 trillion in economic value by 2030, reinforcing Singapore's top ranking on Salesforce's 2023 AI Readiness Index, and positioning the nation as a global leader in AI-driven progress.

images.alt_text: Singapore Budget 2025

site_title: Hong Kong to tighten union rules to 'protect national security'
summary: Hong Kong's government proposed rules requiring labour unions to seek government approval for nearly all types of foreign funding to "protect national security." Unions must get registrar's approval before accepting funds from "external forces," and the funds cannot be used for local elections. The registrar will have more powers to safeguard national security, and union applications can be rejected on national security grounds. The proposal aims to address the scrutiny unions faced since Beijing's national security law was imposed in 2020, following pro-democracy protests.

A series of protests have erupted over the past few weeks in Hong Kong as tens of thousands of protesters clashed with the police to oppose a proposed extradition bill that would send lawbreakers to face trial in mainland China. Hong Kongers see it as China's steady erosion of civil rights in the territory.

site_title: Former star prosecutor and CAD director Glenn Knight dies at age 80
summary: Former Singapore lawyer Glenn Knight, 80, died while returning from Australia on a Scoot flight. Knight was a renowned prosecutor and director of the Commercial Affairs Department, a specialized agency tackling white-collar crime. He was widowed without children and police do not suspect foul play. Knight's death marks the end of a career marked by both success and controversy, with his rise and fall from prominence being a notable aspect of his life.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
John Soh, Quah Su Ling await verdict in penny stock crash trial

site_title: Cordlife ID Teo Tong Kooi steps down; new ID appointed
summary: Cordlife ID appoints new independent director Yuen Wai, effective Feb 19, replacing Dr Teo Tong Kooi, who stepped down to focus on other commitments. Yuen Wai is a consultant at Preeminent Medical Centre and principal in Canada. Other board changes include appointments to audit and risk committees, and chairmen of nominating and remuneration committees. The company also made changes to its audit and remuneration committees, with non-independent non-executive chairman Zhai Lingyun and group executive director Chen Xiaoling relinquishing their roles.

Cordlife says that the pace of its recovery for FY2025 remains uncertain.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 19)
summary: UOB posted a net profit of S$1.52 billion for Q4 2024, a 8.6% increase from the previous year. The bank remains optimistic about the resilience of Asean economies despite ongoing geopolitical tensions. Meanwhile, Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) will benefit from extended income tax concessions and GST remission for five more years. The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for mainstream cars surged 9.2% to S$92,850 in February's second round of bidding.

site_title: Thailand to curb short selling, high-speed trades amid sell-off
summary: Thailand's stock exchange will limit short selling and high-frequency trading to stocks in the SET100 Index, aiming to revive investor confidence. The move follows a US$10 billion pullout by foreign investors in the past two years, as the benchmark SET stock index has slid 10% this year. The new rules, set to be implemented in the second quarter, aim to stabilize the market and reduce excessive share price swings. The Stock Exchange of Thailand has also ordered high-frequency traders to register and is investigating fraud allegations at several companies.

images.alt_text: The fund could be set up in an existing environmental social governance fund, or ESG, and investors will receive similar tax breaks for five years, Thailand's finance minister Pichai Chunhavajira said.

site_title: All assets of biotech founder in Novo Nordisk suit frozen, including US$218 million in DBS account
summary: Novo Nordisk has obtained a Singapore court's order to freeze the global assets of KBP Biosciences founder Huang Zhenhua, valued at approximately US$830 million, due to alleged misrepresentations about the effectiveness of its kidney drug, ocedurenone. Novo had paid US$1.3 billion for the drug in 2023, but halted the clinical trial after the treatment's failure. The court found evidence of Huang's intention to move assets out of Novo's reach, leading to the freezing of assets, including a US$218 million DBS account.

site_title: Can you turn your private apartment into a dual-key unit? This interior designer shows how – with her own home
summary: Interior designer Corinne Kerk transformed a 1,615 sq ft, three-bedroom apartment in Laguna Park into a dual-key unit, allowing her to accommodate her elderly mother while maintaining her household's privacy. Kerk worked on 15 different layouts before finalizing the design, which included merging the balcony with the living spaces, creating a storage room for her husband's sports equipment, and enlarging the apartment's communal areas. The result is a functional and spacious home, with the smaller unit (335 sq ft) designed for her mother, while the main space remains for her household of five.

images.alt_text: Dual key HDB flats present an option for owners to reconfigure their homes for rental.
This 3-room HDB flat features an oversized, full-height sliding partition door to allow flexibility in usage as a single or dual key unit.

site_title: Prime US Reit posts 51.6% fall in H2 DPU as manager continues to retain funds for capex
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 51.6% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.11 US cents for the six months ended Dec 31, due to retained funds for capital expenditures. Revenue fell 16% to US$67.5 million, and net property income dropped 23.7% to US$35.4 million. The Reit's manager remains cautious but optimistic about return-to-office mandates gaining momentum, citing "good leasing momentum" and "sizable" potential new leases.

Manulife US Reit’s Class-A Peachtree building in Atlanta in United States. The counter gained 12.6 per cent in the past week, alongside other Singapore-listed US office Reits.

site_title: Music tourism the Bhutanese way
summary: Ed Sheeran's concert in Bhutan has changed the music tourism industry's view, offering a unique, uncommercial experience. Music tourism is a growing trend, valued at $6.6 billion and expected to reach $13.8 billion by 2032. In contrast to traditional concerts, Bhutan's event showcased originality and engagement with the local culture. The experience can serve as a lesson for other countries looking to develop their music tourism industry.

site_title: Xi’s rehabilitation of Jack Ma may be the most lucrative ever
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's meeting with tech mogul Jack Ma at a symposium in Beijing is seen as a sign that private sector tech is back in favor, with Ma's rehabilitation potentially being the most lucrative ever. The meeting comes after a prolonged crackdown on the sector, and shares of Alibaba, Tencent, and Xiaomi rose significantly following rumors of the symposium. However, analysts note that the private sector still faces challenges, including regulatory hurdles and the influence of state capital, which may limit the rally's potential.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds rates as expected, pausing easing cycle
summary: Bank Indonesia (BI) maintained its benchmark interest rate at 5.75% during its latest meeting, putting a pause to its easing cycle. Governor Perry Warjiyo hinted at the possibility of future interest rate cuts to fuel economic growth, citing low inflation and the ongoing push to stimulate the economy. The central bank also left overnight deposit facility and lending facility rates steady, and pledged to work towards keeping inflation under control and stabilizing the rupiah amid global uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
The move comes as Indonesia’s huge natural resources sector contemplates other sudden shifts in policy under recently inaugurated President Prabowo Subianto.
Indonesia exports much of its gold to trading hubs such as Switzerland and Hong Kong, where it typically transits as a commodity rather than being used domestically.

site_title: Hong Leong-led group to launch Lentor Central Residences; prices start at S$975,000
summary: Hong Leong Holdings, GuocoLand, and CSC Land Group are launching Lentor Central Residences, a 477-unit condominium in Lentor Hills Road, with prices starting at S$975,000 (S$2,110 per square foot). The development will feature two high-rise blocks of 27 and 28 storeys each. Units range from one-bedroom apartments to four-bedroom apartments, with prices varying from S$975,000 to S$2.37 million. Previews will start on February 21.

images.alt_text: Most of the sites sold so far in the Lentor area are being developed by GuocoLand (above), Hong Leong and TID
The plot along Champions Way in Woodlands is for a residential development with around 350 private homes.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, February 19, 2025
summary: Asian markets experienced volatility on Wednesday as traders assessed the latest tariffs volley, with some investors reassessing their strategies amid the uncertainty. UOB hit a fresh high on Q4 earnings, while Reits, banks, and grocers are seen as potential winners from Budget 2025 measures. Singapore's STI reached a record high, driven by the strong performance of UOB. The market movements reflect the ongoing impact of global trade tensions and the need for investors to adapt to changing economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Singapore, Shanghai, Seoul, Wellington and Manila stocks rose but Tokyo, Taipei, Sydney and Jakarta markets fell on Wednesday.
UOB announced the establishment of a S$3 billion capital distribution package and its fourth-quarter results on Wednesday morning.
Semiconductor-related companies and grocers are among analysts' top picks for stocks favoured to gain from Budget 2025 schemes.

site_title: US federal mortgage insurer to lay off about half its workforce: sources
summary: The US Federal Housing Administration (FHA) plans to lay off at least 40% of its workforce, approximately 3,840 employees, due to the Trump administration's directive to cut non-statutory functions. The FHA, one of the largest mortgage insurers in the world, has insured over 40 million home loans since 1934. The layoffs will affect the agency's ability to provide mortgage insurance to low-income Americans and first-time buyers, potentially impacting the housing market. The cuts are part of a broader effort to reduce the agency's workforce, which had grown to 9,600 employees.

images.alt_text: Homebuyers are getting a slight reprieve as borrowing costs slip further away from the 7 per cent level crossed in early January.

site_title: Porsche, BMW need Germany pivot for way out of crisis
summary: Germany's auto industry is in crisis due to declining sales, soaring production costs, and waning demand for electric vehicles (EVs) in Europe. The industry employs nearly 780,000 people and represents about 5% of the economy. Executives are banking on a new German government to deliver fresh stimulus, citing US President Donald Trump's threat of tariffs on German cars. Key issues include trade wars, high energy costs, and China's intense competition. The next government must cut red tape and jumpstart growth to make Germany competitive again, with Christian Democrat Friedrich Merz seen as a potential leader to strike a conciliatory tone with Trump.

images.alt_text: BMW walked back its outlook in September after a faulty braking system forced it to recall as many as 1.5 million vehicles, which took a particular toll on deliveries in China.
BMW's revenue fell 15.7 per cent to 32.4 billion euros from 38.46 billion euros a year earlier, below analyst expectations of 34.3 billion euros.
Models affected include locally-made 3 Series and 5 Series vehicles, as well as several imported X Series SUVs.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as traders assess latest tariffs volley
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day on Wednesday, with Singapore, Shanghai, Seoul, Wellington, and Manila stocks rising, while Tokyo, Taipei, Sydney, and Jakarta markets fell. The mixed performance came amid US President Donald Trump's widening tariff threats, which revived concerns about the global economy. Despite a record close on Wall Street, investors struggled to pick up the baton, and regional markets were weighed down by the uncertainty. Moody's Analytics expects the Trump administration to scale back its measures by next year, but warns of restrictions on Chinese goods remaining in place.

site_title: Musk the enforcer-in-chief: Trump outlines Tesla boss’ role
summary: US President Donald Trump has designated Elon Musk as his "enforcer-in-chief," tasking the Tesla CEO with leading the newly created Department of Government Efficiency to root out waste and abuse in federal spending. Musk will oversee the implementation of Trump's executive orders, which have been challenged in court as potentially unconstitutional. Trump described Musk as instrumental in pushing forward his policies, stating that the billionaire tech executive will ensure orders are carried out without delay, or face consequences.

site_title: HSBC unveils share buyback, cost cut targets as new CEO looks to boost returns
summary: HSBC reported a profit before tax of $32.3 billion in 2024, beating estimates, as it increased revenue in wealth and markets businesses. The bank's new CEO, Georges Elhedery, has set cost-cut targets of $300 million in 2025 and an annualized reduction of $1.5 billion in its cost base by 2026. Elhedery aims to boost returns and focus on Asia, where HSBC earns the bulk of its profit, with a performance target of a mid-teens return on average tangible equity. The bank also announced a $2 billion share buyback program.

site_title: Budget 2025: Income tax concessions, GST remission for S-Reits extended for 5 years
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 has announced the extension of income tax concessions and Goods and Services Tax (GST) remission for Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) for five more years, until Dec 31, 2030. The changes aim to promote the listing of Reits in Singapore and sustain its position as a global Reit hub. Key enhancements include expanded tax transparency treatment for co-location and co-working income, removal of incorporation requirement for wholly owned companies, and recognition of shareholder loans and return of capital as qualifying modes of remittance.

site_title: The Future of Food: Can we feed 8.8 billion people sustainably?
summary: A series of events, "The Future of Food," is exploring food sustainability through food-tasting sessions and panel discussions. By 2034, the global population is projected to rise to 8.8 billion, putting pressure on meat and dairy production. The event, organized by Synthesis, aims to raise awareness and inspire change, showcasing businesses shaping the future of food through innovation and traditional methods. Attendees sampled unconventional ingredients, such as cricket-infused madeleines and locally grown produce, and discussed challenges and solutions to food sustainability, including changing consumer mindsets and scaling sustainable food practices.

site_title: HSBC expects cost-cutting drive to hit less than 8% of global headcount
summary: HSBC aims to generate $1.8 billion in cost cuts through 2025 and 2026, with a focus on removing duplicated roles, particularly at senior levels. The bank expects the impact on global headcount to be under 8%, with most job cuts coming from roles supporting mergers and acquisitions in Europe and the Americas. Despite the US-China trade war, HSBC's China business remains resilient, and the bank is optimistic about its Hong Kong operations, driven by the city's vast real estate sector and relaxed housing rules.

site_title: Cisco and IBM show old-school tech names can be AI winners too
summary: Legacy tech companies Cisco, IBM, and Oracle are outperforming this year, driven by their ability to adapt to the growing demand for artificial intelligence. Despite being less popular and having lower valuations, these companies are offering attractive dividend yields and defensive growth attributes. Cisco's recent beat on earnings and strong AI-related demand sparked a rally, while IBM's forecast for strong revenue growth and AI-related bookings is also boosting its stock. These stocks are seen as a safer play on AI compared to the more expensive tech megacaps, offering a buffer against macro uncertainties.

site_title: China condemns US ‘tariff shocks’ at WTO
summary: China has condemned the US "tariff shocks" imposed by President Donald Trump, warning they risk triggering inflation, market distortions, and a global recession. China's ambassador to the WTO, Li Chenggang, stated that US unilateralism threatens the multilateral trading system, citing the imposition of tariffs on China, Canada, and Mexico. The US has imposed or threatened tariffs on its trading partners, including China, in violation of WTO rules, China said, urging the US to withdraw the tariffs and engage in multilateral dialogues.

The financial pull of the US is relatively undiminished, despite predictions of its demise at the hands of emerging markets or the newly integrated eurozone.

site_title: Singapore’s Foundation Healthcare eyes over US$100 million fundraising: sources
summary: Foundation Healthcare Holdings, a private healthcare group in Singapore, is planning a fundraising round that could raise over US$100 million, valuing the company at more than S$1 billion. The funding round, which could precede a potential initial public offering, comes as healthcare assets in South-east Asia gain favor with investors due to the region's growing affluence and ageing population. The company is in talks with an adviser and has received interest from potential investors.

site_title: Singapore evolves to meet commodity sector’s changing needs amid trade tensions: EnterpriseSG’s Cindy Khoo
summary: Singapore is evolving to meet the changing needs of the commodity sector, particularly in the face of growing trade tensions and commodity demand. The country aims to grow new trade flows, specialized trade expertise, and technologies to support the global energy transition. This includes expanding biofuel trade and investing in green commodities and data-related competencies. Singapore will also partner with industry players to deepen their artificial intelligence (AI) presence, with initiatives such as the Carbon Markets Academy of Singapore and AI Singapore's 100 Experiments programme.

site_title: ‘Pokemon Go’ maker nears US$3.5 billion deal to sell games unit
summary: Niantic, the company behind Pokémon Go, is in talks to sell its video game business to Saudi Arabia-controlled Scopely for approximately US$3.5 billion. The deal, which could be announced in the coming weeks, would involve the Pokémon title as well as other mobile games. This move comes after Niantic's struggles to replicate the success of Pokémon Go, which remains the most downloaded and profitable augmented reality app of all time.

images.alt_text: Pokemon Go has generated over US$5 billion of in-app purchases since launching in 2016, according to Apptopia data

site_title: FTX estate starts paying out billions to creditors; Temasek likely among beneficiaries
summary: FTX's estate has started paying out billions to creditors, with the next distribution expected on April 11 and the following one on May 30. The platform owed approximately $11.2 billion to creditors, with an estimated $14.5-16.3 billion to distribute after selling all assets. Big investors like Temasek, Tiger Global Management, and BlackRock are among the beneficiaries, along with high-profile celebrities. The payments are being made through crypto companies BitGo and Kraken, with customers expected to receive their funds within one to three business days.

images.alt_text: Gary Wang is the last member of Bankman-Fried’s former inner circle to be sentenced by Kaplan.
FTX was one of the largest cryptocurrency firms in the world before it collapsed in late 2022.

site_title: Dollar rises as traders mull Ukraine peace talks, Trump tariffs
summary: The US dollar rose 0.19% to 107.2, while the yen strengthened against the dollar, as traders focused on Ukraine peace talks and US President Trump's tariff threats. The pound received a boost from UK inflation data, but was later unchanged. Trump announced plans to impose 25% auto tariffs and similar duties on semiconductors and pharmaceutical imports. Despite concerns over tariffs, market sentiment remains focused on a potential Ukraine peace deal, with some analysts predicting fewer tariffs than expected.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The employee of a currency exchange shop counts U.S. dollar banknotes in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico July 27, 2023. REUTERS/Jose Luis Gonzalez/File Photo

site_title: UOB proposes special dividend, share buyback programme as it unveils long-awaited capital return plans
summary: UOB announces a S$3 billion package to distribute surplus capital over three years, aiming to bring down excess capital. The lender proposes a S$0.50 per share special dividend of S$800 million and a S$2 billion share buyback programme. This move is part of its commitment to bring its CET-1 ratio down to 14%. The package is expected to return surplus capital to shareholders and enhance the bank's capital efficiency.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
UOB posted a net profit of S$1.52 billion for Q4 ended Dec 31, 2024, up 8.6% from S$1.4 billion a year earlier.
UOB announced the establishment of a S$3 billion capital distribution package and its fourth-quarter results on Wednesday morning.
The local banking trio are due to report their fourth quarter and full year 2024 results in February, with DBS on Feb 10, UOB on Feb 19 and OCBC on Feb 26.

site_title: New 3-year lock-in for business-owned private-hire cars, which could change COE bid behaviour
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has introduced a mandatory 3-year lock-in period for business-owned private-hire cars (PHCs), requiring them to remain classified as PHCs and transfer only to other businesses, not individuals. This rule aims to prevent the premature conversion of PHCs out of the chauffeured PHC scheme, which could affect the supply of vehicles available for point-to-point services. The rule applies to new vehicles acquired by businesses after February 19, and may moderate company behavior in securing Certificates of Entitlement (COEs).

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Senior Minister of State for Transport Amy Khor said that having more platform operators means more competition and choice for both commuters and drivers.
With this revision, the platform fee for rides booked through the Zig, DBS PayLah! and Kris+ apps will be adjusted to a range of S$1 to S$1.20, depending on the distance travelled and waiting time.
The Land Transport Authority said that all existing point-to-point sector operator licencees will have their respective licences renewed,
Private hire cars  currently use the same Certificates of Entitlement as passenger cars and have been blamed for driving premiums up.

Given changing travel patterns post-Covid, LTA assessed it would be able to inject up to 20,000 additional COEs across the vehicle categories over the next few years without the worries of causing traffic gridlock, said Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat.

site_title: Providing caregivers with more than just homecare products
summary: Yeap Medical Supplies, a Singaporean wholesaler and retailer of medical and homecare supplies, aims to support caregivers beyond just providing healthcare products. The company, founded by Victor Yeap in 2000, has expanded its retail business, Pharmex Healthcare, to make medical-grade products more accessible and affordable to the public. YMS has also prioritized societal well-being by lowering the retail price of surgical masks during the pandemic. The company is committed to sustainability, exploring eco-friendly options for its products, and fostering a positive work environment to nurture innovative leaders.

images.alt_text: The group opened its first physical retail store under the Novela brand in 2014. Today, it has seven Novela stores.

Group general manager Sean Mak (far left) and CEO Elayne Soh (far right) celebrating the opening of Beyond Medical Group's new clinic, Alpha Asia Aesthetics, along with its interior designer Kenneth Ng, director of Watermark Interior Design.

site_title: COE bidding: Mainstream car premium spikes 9.2% to S$92,850
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for mainstream cars in Singapore increased by 9.2% to S$92,850 in the second round of bidding in February. Category B saw a 1.4% decrease, while Category E rose by S$2 to S$110,002. Dealers attributed the spike to lower premiums from the previous round and sales promotions, which drove up showroom traffic and buying. The increase reflects pent-up demand for cars, especially in Category A, with oversubscription rates doubling. The Land Transport Authority's new rules on private-hire cars are expected to have a delayed impact on COE bidding.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
A new rule mandates a three-year lock-in period for recently acquired private hire cars in Singapore.
The Yangwang U8 sport utility vehicle on display at the Japan Mobility Show in late 2023.
NISSAN DISPLAY AT SINGAPORE MOTORSHOW 2025. CAN BE USED AS GENERIC NISSAN PIC
The Yangwang U9, a fully-electric supercar from BYD's sub-brand, with more than 1,000 horsepower, on display at the Singapore Motorshow 2025.
Land Transport Authority (LTA) did not reveal specifics on the time frame of the additional COEs, nor on individual COE categories.

site_title: New Zealand central bank cuts rates by 50bps, flags more easing to revive frail economy
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) cut its benchmark interest rate by 50 basis points to 3.75% on February 19, 2025, in an effort to revive the struggling economy. This is the fourth consecutive rate cut, and policymakers signaled further reductions in borrowing costs amid moderating inflation. The decision is in line with market expectations and is seen as a boost to the economy, which has been struggling to emerge from a deep recession. The RBNZ projects that rates will fall to 3.45% by June and 3.10% by year-end.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ will publish its decision at 2 pm local time on Wednesday and Orr will hold a press conference an hour later.
Net arrivals of foreigners dropped by more than 97,000 from 2023 but were still the second-highest on record at around 74,100, today’s report showed.

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand began cutting interest rates in August and is tipped to maintain an aggressive pace with another 50 basis-point reduction next week, taking the Official Cash Rate to 3.75 per cent.
New Zealand has one of the world’s most prohibitive policies on foreigners buying residential real estate.

site_title: Man gets 10 years’ jail for throwing pipe bomb at Japan ex-PM: reports
summary: A Japanese court has sentenced Ryuji Kimura, 25, to 10 years in prison for attempting to kill former Prime Minister Fumio Kishida with a pipe bomb in 2023. The attack occurred at a campaign event, and Kimura denied intending to kill Kishida. Prosecutors sought a 15-year sentence, while Kimura's defense team argued for three years. The judge cited Kimura's actions as undermining democracy, stating that carrying out the act at an election speech venue was particularly egregious.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan board member Hajime Takata said the BOJ must keep raising interest rates if companies continue to increase prices, wages and investment.
Isuzu Motors trucks bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan, Feb 6, 2025. Japan's exports rose 7.2 per cent year-on-year in January.
Kazuto Oku , 65, will step down at the end of March, source says.
The revised energy policy aims for renewables to account for up to 50 per cent of Japan’s electricity mix by fiscal year 2040
Rising bond issuance comes alongside a wider surge in dealmaking in the country.

site_title: Hong Kong expands virtual asset push with new licensing, trading options
summary: Hong Kong's regulators have issued nine virtual asset trading platform licenses, expanding the city's push to become Asia's digital assets hub. The Securities and Futures Commission aims to boost market efficiency and investor protections by establishing new licensing regimes for over-the-counter trading, custody services, and reviewing derivative trading and margin financing options. The move is part of Hong Kong's efforts to attract capital and stay competitive in the region.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority loaned out HK$5.5 billion through its discount window.
HSBC’s latest restructuring is being led by its CEO Georges Elhedery, who took the helm in September.
Robinhood intends to roll out the services with guidance from local regulators by late 2025, although it has not yet set a launch date.
A merry-go-round is seen at New World Development's K11Art Mall. Adrian Cheng, 45, abruptly stepped aside as chief executive officer of the company last year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Singtel, Parkson Retail Asia, Cordlife
summary: UOB posted a net profit of S$1.52 billion for the fourth quarter, up 8.6% from the previous year, with a higher final dividend of S$0.92 per share. Singtel's net profit climbed 183.4% to S$1.3 billion, driven by a net exceptional gain. Parkson Retail Asia reported a net loss of S$5.8 million, while Cordlife expects a loss for the 2024 fiscal year due to financial fallout from storage lapses.

site_title: China’s new home prices stagnate in January as demand struggles
summary: China's new home prices stagnated in January, marking the second straight month of no growth, according to official data. On a year-on-year basis, new home prices fell 5% due to declining demand and high housing inventory. Analysts expect the property market to take a protracted time to recover, with Nomura stating the property meltdown in China has yet to end. Local governments are loosening restrictions on new home prices, but efforts to reduce inventory are being offset by abundant supply in the secondary market.

images.alt_text: china property housing home Photographer: Andrea Verdelli/Bloomberg
Government steps to prevent a real estate crisis from leading to broader contagion have tended to result in only short-lived rallies.
Vanke and its affiliates would also be allowed to tap other financing sources including new bond sales and bank loans for debt payments.
Under the deal, Vanke will provide asset collateral worth up to four billion yuan to Shenzhen Metro through an 18 per cent stake in its property management unit Onewo.
China's 2019 property investments solid, but first sales drop in 5 years dents outlook

site_title: UK pay growth holds at lowest level since 2021: Brightmine
summary: The UK's median pay award has held steady at 3% for the second consecutive quarter, the lowest level since 2021, according to a Brightmine survey. Employers attribute this to the upcoming 7% minimum wage increase and government plan to boost social security contributions from April, which may reduce hiring and wage growth. The economy stagnated in the third quarter of 2024 but unexpectedly grew 0.1% in the last three months of the year. Labour turnover rates remain largely unchanged, but employers are concerned about turnover levels and may need to balance cost control with competitive pay measures.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past the Lincoln Plaza residential apartment building complex developed by Galliard Homes Ltd in the Canary Wharf business, financial and shopping district in London, U.K., on Thursday, May 21, 2015. Developers are seeking to appeal to foreign buyers, who favor apartments, with high-rise, high-volume projects, particularly in east London. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

A separate survey from the Federation of Small Businesses showed confidence among its members fell in late 2024 to its lowest level since the first quarter of 2020 when the Covid-19 pandemic hit Britain.

Britain's Secretary of State for Business and Trade Jonathan Reynolds told broadcasters Britain had a balanced trading relationship with the US and he reported “good engagement, good conversations” in his meetings with the Trump administration on the issue.
Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds says the UK government reiterated a commitment to invest £2.5 billion in order to support the steel industry.
Most of Britain’s major retailers have flagged a tougher year ahead as employer tax increases, and their potential impact on prices and employment, filter through into the economy.

site_title: Making kids’ swimming lessons a ‘premium’ experience for the whole family
summary: Happy Fish Swim School, founded by Tan Jian Yong in 2007, offers premium swimming lessons for children in Singapore. The school's indoor heated pools and small class sizes have contributed to its success. In 2022, Happy Fish introduced its "Home" outlets, which feature lounges for parents and premium bathrooms. Lessons at these outlets are 20% more expensive but have seen 20% higher take-up rates. Tan plans to expand the premium features to other outlets within the next two years, aiming to open 200 outlets in the Asia-Pacific by 2030.

images.alt_text: Koh Kar Siong, Managing Director & Group Head, Corporate and SME Banking, Institutional Banking Group, DBS Bank Limited
Only 52 per cent of respondents expect a more positive economic outlook for the year ahead than the past 12 months, versus 60 per cent in 2024, the survey found.

site_title: Safe-haven gold hovers near record high on Trump tariff worries
summary: Gold prices hovered near a record high on Wednesday, staying steady at $2,932.35 an ounce, amid concerns of a global trade war following US President Donald Trump's tariff announcements. Trump plans to impose 25% duties on auto imports and similar duties on semiconductors and pharmaceuticals. Investors are closely watching the Federal Reserve's January meeting minutes for clues on interest rate trajectory. The market views gold as a hedge against inflation and geopolitical uncertainties.

images.alt_text: The global gold market has been in upheaval in recent weeks, at a time when prices were already near record highs.

A selection of one kilogram gold bars at Conclude Zrt bullion dealer arranged in Budapest, Hungary, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. Gold advanced, following its biggest one-day decline in two months, on nervousness over President Donald Trump’s latest trade threats. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

site_title: iPhone parts maker Murata eyes supply chain shifts towards India
summary: Murata Manufacturing, a Kyoto-based maker of iPhone components, is considering shifting production capacity to India due to growing demand and business continuity planning purposes. The company, which supplies components to Apple, Samsung, and Nvidia, sees opportunities to increase production overseas. Murata President Norio Nakajima stated that the company is running simulations to determine the feasibility of expanding its operations in India, following Apple's recent trial production of AirPods wireless earphones in the country.

images.alt_text: The iPhone maker has not yet unveiled a longer-term partner for its AI offerings in China, after signing a landmark deal with OpenAI to integrate ChatGPT into iPhones.
Apple is planning a broader shake-up to the iPhone lineup this year
Apple has been in discussions with the government over an investment package that would lift the restrictions.

site_title: China’s tech rally turns Pony AI founder into a billionaire
summary: Pony AI founder James Peng has become a billionaire after his company's stock surged 41% since its November IPO, valuing his 17% stake at $1.1 billion. The rally was fueled by China's tech rally and the nation's growing AI ambitions, with Chinese President Xi Jinping signaling endorsement for the private sector. Peng, a longtime AI industry stalwart, co-founded Pony AI in 2016 and operates a fleet of 250 robotaxis in cities including Beijing and Shanghai, with plans to expand into international markets.

images.alt_text: James Peng Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

A safety driver monitors a Lexus vehicle equipped with Pony.ai's autonomous driving system as the car drives on a road during a test event, Beijing, China, May 13, 2021. Pony.ai plans to provide robotaxi commuting services for airport staff within Hong Kong International Airport before expanding into other urban areas in the city, the company said on Friday.

site_title: Vietnam raises 2025 GDP growth target to at least 8%, approves policies for major projects
summary: Vietnam's parliament has revised the country's 2025 GDP growth target to at least 8%, from a previous range of 6.5-7%. This decision aims to sustain double-digit growth from 2026 to 2030 and achieve high-income nation status by 2045. The country's GDP expanded by 7.09% last year, beating forecasts from major international think tanks. To achieve the higher growth target, the government plans to boost domestic demand, increase public investment, and streamline regulations. Challenges include trade-reliant export prospects and potential trade headwinds due to US President Trump's tariff tantrums.

images.alt_text: Attempts by Musk's SpaceX to enter Vietnam – a market of nearly 100 million people – were put on hold in late 2023 after the government declined to lift a ban on foreign control of satellite Internet providers.
Some expect Vietnam to join the ranks of the original Four Asian Tigers, while others question whether it will eventually be locked in the middle-income trap.
Vietnam's bureaucratic reform is expected to be finalised by the end of the first quarter of 2025.
An underground metro station at District 1. The line is funded primarily through Japan’s official development assistance.
A vendor walks along a railway track as she sells cakes for tourists outside cafes in Hanoi, Vietnam October 8, 2019. Picture taken October 8, 2019. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo

site_title: Reits, banks and grocers: Potential winners from Budget 2025 measures
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 aims to spur growth through tax incentives, rebates, and investments in critical sectors. Semiconductor-related companies, such as AEM and Frencken, may benefit from research and development funding. Grocers like Sheng Siong and DFI Retail Group could gain from measures to ease inflationary pressures. The budget also includes tax incentives for local bourse operator Singapore Exchange and financial sector stocks, potentially boosting credit demand and trading volumes. Additionally, companies with clean energy businesses, such as Sembcorp Industries and Keppel, may see a long-term positive outlook due to the government's commitment to clean power.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
In his first Budget speech since becoming prime minister, Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced broad-based measures for households and businesses.

site_title: Hong Kong banks tap most funds since 2019 as stock demand soars
summary: Hong Kong banks borrowed a record HK$5.5 billion from the Hong Kong Monetary Authority in February, the largest amount since December 2019, amid a booming demand for local equities. The loan comes as Chinese stocks and Hong Kong equities have outperformed global peers, driven by optimism over China's business-friendly stance. Chinese investors bought HK$22.4 billion worth of Hong Kong stocks on Tuesday, the largest daily purchase since early 2021. The tightening of liquidity is expected to remain tight in the near term due to continued momentum in Hong Kong equities.

site_title: US: S&P 500 edges to fresh record
summary: The S&P 500 closed at a record 6,129.58 on Tuesday, up 0.2% after a choppy session. Treasury yields rose, making a rate cut less likely, but Intel surged 16.1% after reports of takeover interest. Other stocks rose, including Nike, while Southwest Airlines fell 0.9% after announcing job cuts. Homebuilder stocks retreated due to concerns about tariffs.

images.alt_text: Investors today are more rational unlike in the dot-com bubble, and tech earnings have come under great scrutiny.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 37.8 points, or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 44583.91.

site_title: Vietnam parliament approves US$8 billion rail link to China
summary: Vietnam's parliament approved a $8 billion rail link from its northern port city to China, boosting trade and economic ties between the two communist-ruled countries. The 390 km rail line will run through key manufacturing hubs, including Hanoi, and is expected to cost more than $8 billion, with China providing funding through loans. The project is part of Vietnam's "Two Corridors, One Belt" initiative, which aims to connect to Beijing's Belt and Road global infrastructure programme, and is expected to be completed by 2030.

images.alt_text: A man walks with his bicycle along a railway track in Hanoi on February 13, 2025. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP)

site_title: Blackstone extends US$1.3 billion loan on Chicago’s Willis Tower
summary: Blackstone extended a nearly US$1.3 billion commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) loan on Chicago's Willis Tower, positioning the building for success after a transformative renovation. The loan's maturity was extended by three years, allowing the property owners to manage debt loads amid high interest rates. Willis Tower, a 1970s landmark, has seen better office market conditions in the West Loop, with a 23% vacancy rate, compared to nearly 28% in the Central Loop.

images.alt_text: Blackstone has structured its fund so that investors can withdraw as much as 3 per cent of the fund’s net asset value each quarter.
Office and residential buildings remain lit at night New York City on November 20, 2024. (Photo by CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)
A view of Midtown Manhattan in New York City. Blackstone is betting the worst is over for the city's beleaguered office market, sources say.

site_title: Ford cuts bonuses for half of middle managers
summary: Ford Motor has cut bonuses for about half of its middle managers, affecting around 3,300 US salaried employees, in an effort to boost performance amid declining profits and high costs. The move is part of the company's plan to cut $1 billion in costs this year. CEO Jim Farley is pushing for a high-performance culture, recognizing and rewarding employees for business contributions, as the automaker confronts a $7 billion to $8 billion disadvantage compared to rivals. This comes after Ford forecasts a year of earnings before interest and taxes falling by $2 billion or more.

site_title: Toyota is backing LG battery plant with US$1.5 billion order
summary: Toyota has agreed to a US$1.5 billion order with LG Energy Solution to bolster its Michigan battery plant after General Motors backed out of the project. The deal is part of LG's efforts to find new customers amid a slowdown in electric vehicle sales and potential policy rollbacks. The Lansing plant, initially meant to support GM's EV push, will now produce batteries for both EVs and hybrid vehicles, and may also supply stationary storage units.

images.alt_text: Toyota, the world’s top-selling automaker, raised its profit forecast for the current year through March 2025 to 4.7 trillion yen (S$41.5 billion) versus 4.3 trillion yen expected previously.
Sales of Toyota’s parent-only vehicles fell 1.4 per cent from a year earlier in 2024 to 10.2 million vehicles due to a double-digit decline in Japan.
Factoring in parallel imports, Toyota was the top selling car brand in Singapore, but BYD was number one in authorised dealer sales.

site_title: Norinchukin CEO plans to resign after massive bond losses
summary: Norinchukin Bank CEO Kazuto Oku, 65, plans to resign at the end of March, taking responsibility for the lender's massive losses from wrong-way bets on foreign bonds. The bank's losses total 1.4 trillion yen, with 1.57 trillion yen in paper losses on bond holdings. A government panel of experts had urged the bank to diversify its portfolio and bring in more outside talent. Managing executive officer Taro Kitabayashi will replace Oku, effective April 1.

images.alt_text: The Temasek logo at the Temasek Holdings office at The Atrium@Orchard on 9 February 2021.

site_title: HSBC to sell Bahrain retail banking operations as restructuring progresses
summary: HSBC agreed to sell its retail banking operations in Bahrain to the Bank of Bahrain and Kuwait (BBK), transferring the accounts of about 76,000 customers. The deal excludes corporate and private banking businesses, with no financial details disclosed. This sale is part of HSBC's global restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: HSBC’s latest restructuring is being led by its CEO Georges Elhedery, who took the helm in September.
Once a sprawling behemoth spanning more than 100 countries, HSBC has spent the last decade slowly shrinking its global footprint and exiting low-return businesses.

Georges Elhedery  is reducing costs with a restructuring that has so far included combining the commercial banking division with its global banking and markets unit and pulling out of some underwriting and advisory businesses in Europe and the Americas.

site_title: Cordlife expects to be in the red for FY2024; ‘no assurance’ of profitability in FY2025
summary: Cordlife expects to post a loss for FY2024 due to the suspension of its Singapore operations, primarily caused by lapses in cord-blood unit storage. The company was barred from collecting and testing new cord blood between Dec 2023 and Sep 2024, resulting in a $9.7 million revenue decrease. With the full resumption of operations since Jan 14, the pace of recovery and outlook for FY2025 remain uncertain, with no assurance of profitability.

images.alt_text: The different equipment in Cordlife’s laboratory are maintained at different temperatures.
Navene Elangovan

site_title: China revamps power market rules in challenge to renewables boom
summary: China has introduced new power market rules allowing market forces to determine the price of new wind and solar power, starting from June 1. The move is expected to slow clean energy additions, but consumers will benefit from lower electricity rates. Energy storage providers may face greater uncertainty, while battery sales are likely to decline due to the abandonment of compulsory installations. However, the shift to more liberalized power markets is expected to make energy storage more attractive in the long term, and could lead to renewed vigor in solar installations.

images.alt_text: Long-term coal-power contracts are also reinforcing the fuel’s dominance at the expense of renewables.
China now has almost 887 gigawatts of installed solar power, more than six times the capacity of the United States.

site_title: Bank of Japan must keep raising rates gradually, says board member Takata
summary: Bank of Japan board member Hajime Takata stated that the central bank must continue to raise interest rates gradually to avoid upside price risks from materializing. With inflation approaching the 2% target, Takata emphasized the importance of maintaining monetary policy momentum to prevent excessive expectations of continued easing, which could lead to overheating in financial activity.

images.alt_text: Isuzu Motors trucks bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan, Feb 6, 2025. Japan's exports rose 7.2 per cent year-on-year in January.
Nissan has been working on a turnaround programme under which it plans to reduce its workforce by 9,000 people and global manufacturing capacity by 20 per cent.
Rising bond issuance comes alongside a wider surge in dealmaking in the country.
The BOJ began to buy the stock funds in December 2010 as part of a monetary stimulus programme aimed at stoking inflation.

site_title: Japan’s exports rise in January on brisk auto exports to US, but tariff threat looms
summary: Japan's exports rose 7.2% in January, driven by auto shipments to the US, but the growth may be short-lived due to the threat of hefty tariffs on car imports. The US tariff rate for passenger cars stands at 2.5%, while 25% is levied on highly profitable imported pickup trucks. The solid trade report contrasts with economists' concerns that President Trump's tariff threat could hurt future shipments and undermine the economy's growth momentum.

images.alt_text: Isuzu Motors Ltd. trucks bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan, on Thursday, Feb. 6, 2025. In Japan, nominal wages rose at the fastest pace in nearly three decades in December, supporting the Bank of Japan’s latest rate hike decision and keeping the bank on track for further tightening steps. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg
The batteries Toyota is buying from LG can be used in either EVs or hybrid vehicles.
Nissan has been working on a turnaround programme under which it plans to reduce its workforce by 9,000 people and global manufacturing capacity by 20 per cent.
Rising bond issuance comes alongside a wider surge in dealmaking in the country.

site_title: New York City’s 590 Madison goes up for sale at roughly US$1.1 billion
summary: New York City's 590 Madison office tower, valued at approximately $1.1 billion, is up for sale. This marks one of the first major tests of the market for trophy office building sales since the pandemic. Demand for high-quality buildings in midtown Manhattan has strengthened in recent weeks, with the property being marketed by Eastdil Secured. The sale is seen as a significant event in the city's office market, with the State Teachers Retirement System of Ohio owning the building. The sale price and terms have not been disclosed.

site_title: UOB beats expectations with Q4 profit up 8.6% to S$1.52 billion; announces S$3 billion capital distribution package
summary: UOB posted a net profit of S$1.52 billion for Q4, beating expectations with an 8.6% increase from the previous year. The lender proposes a S$3 billion capital distribution package, including a S$2 billion share buyback program and S$800 million in special dividends. This will optimize UOB's capital position and position the bank for continued growth momentum, with a record full-year net profit of S$6.05 billion.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The local banking trio are due to report their fourth quarter and full year 2024 results in February, with DBS on Feb 10, UOB on Feb 19 and OCBC on Feb 26.
Marina Bay Sands’ expansion plans come as Singapore’s tourism industry has staged a sharp rebound since the pandemic.

site_title: China, India natural gas imports will impact Apac prices: panellists
summary: China and India's natural gas imports, primarily through pipeline deals, will impact Asia-Pacific gas prices, particularly for Japan, South Korea, and Australia, which rely heavily on liquefied natural gas imports. The long-term pipeline deals will allow China and India to lock in lower prices, reducing their reliance on LNG, and are expected to affect regional gas pricing.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% at the open on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,943.23 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 54 to 36, driven by gains in Mapletree Logistics Trust, Thai Beverage, Singtel, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, which rose 1-1.5% and attributed to strong quarterly earnings reports. The S&P 500 edged up 0.2%, while the Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite remained flat, weighed down by higher Treasury bond yields and uncertainty over US interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: UOB on Wednesday posted a net profit of S$1.52 billion for the fourth quarter ended December, up 8.6 per cent from the previous corresponding period.

site_title: UOB hits a fresh high, with Singapore’s STI reaching yet another record
summary: UOB shares hit a new high of S$39.15 after the bank announced a S$3 billion capital distribution package, including a special dividend of S$0.50 per share and a share buyback program. The move follows a net profit of S$1.52 billion for Q4, beating consensus forecasts. The Straits Times Index (STI) also broke through to a new record, trading at 3,943.23, driven by positive analyst upgrades and government initiatives to revive the local bourse. Analysts expect the STI to reach 4,200, representing a 6.5% upside.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
On the Singapore Exchange,
UOB beats expectations with Q4 profit up 8.6% to S$1.52 billion; announces S$3 billion capital distribution package

site_title: Budget 2025: Building a stronger enterprise ecosystem and economy for all
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025, themed "Onward together for a better tomorrow," aims to propel forward into inclusive and sustainable economic growth. The budget reflects the government's commitment to fiscal discipline, with accumulated surpluses from 2021 to 2024. Measures include a new Enterprise Compute Initiative to help businesses adopt technology, a SkillsFuture Workforce Development Grant, and a S$5 billion investment in clean energy. The budget also sets aside S$5 billion for coastal and flood protection, aiming to ensure the country's sustainability 75 years down the road.

images.alt_text: The Budget for FY2025 is expected to run Singapore’s second consecutive surplus.
Singapore’s long-term prosperity hinges on its ability to stablish itself as a gold standard for high-value solutions that the world seeks to emulate.

site_title: Trump floats 25% tariffs on cars, pharmaceuticals and chips
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose 25% tariffs on auto imports, pharmaceuticals, and semiconductor chips, starting as early as April 2. The move is expected to significantly impact the global auto industry, which is already reeling from uncertainty caused by Trump's tariff drama. The tariffs on automobiles would be a game-changer, with the European Union collecting a 10% duty on vehicle imports, four times the US tariff rate of 2.5%. The move is part of Trump's efforts to reshape global trade and increase US imports of cars and other products.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 37.8 points, or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 44583.91.
The end of de minimis, a rule that had allowed American shoppers to avoid paying customs on most Shein purchases, was widely expected.
Nato Secretary General Mark Rutte. The Europeans have been facing the likelihood of having to meet their own defence obligations since the end of the Cold War.

site_title: Australia wage growth slows to 3.2% y/y in Q4
summary: Australia's annual wage growth slowed to 3.2% in Q4, the lowest reading since the third quarter of 2022. This marks a decrease from 3.6% in the previous quarter. Despite this, unemployment remains near historic lows, suggesting the strong labor market is not driving inflation. The result is likely to reassure policymakers that the labor market is not generating price pressure, which may influence future monetary policy decisions.

images.alt_text: Commonwealth Bank of Australia says the change will be implemented on its eligible business lending products.
Australia’s rate cut will be welcome news for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who must face voters in a general election that is due by May 17 at the latest.
It’s the first time Qantas has been pushed from the top spot since early 2022.

site_title: Tapping partnerships and people to raise scam awareness
summary: Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore is launching a series of digital clinics for seniors to raise awareness about online scams and improve digital literacy. The workshops, held from August to February 2025, were attended by over 120 seniors and featured StanChart volunteers, IMDA digital ambassadors, and experts from the Singapore Police Force and National Crime Prevention Council. The bank partnered with various organizations to curate the workshops and provide a positive social impact. CEO Patrick Lee emphasized the bank's commitment to creating a caring society and driving sustainable economic growth through its community efforts.

images.alt_text: Gardens “Byte” the Bay event in June, as part of Standard Chartered’s global employee volunteerism month, where I joined 1,000 of my colleagues to spend time with more than 1,200 seniors, aged from their 50s to 90s, and taught them how to connect to Wi-Fi, use mobile apps and plan their daily commutes using their smartphones.
Guided by StanChart and Prudential volunteers, the children were given a limited budget to shop for groceries.

site_title: BP weighs sale of Castrol lubricants unit amid Elliott push
summary: BP is considering a potential sale of its Castrol lubricants business, valued at around $10 billion, amid pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management. Elliott wants BP to make drastic cost cuts and divestments to strengthen its future as a standalone company. The move comes as BP struggles to regain investor confidence after years of underperformance. A potential sale could be announced during BP's capital markets day on February 26, but no final decisions have been made.

images.alt_text: BP joins other majors that have experienced a decline in earnings throughout 2024.
BP’s management team and board of directors have changed little since Looney’s era, potentially making it a target for Elliott.

site_title: Singtel’s Q3 profit surges 183.4% to S$1.3 billion on exceptional gains
summary: Singtel's third-quarter profit surged 183.4% to S$1.3 billion, driven by a net exceptional gain of S$639 million from the disposal of stakes in Thai associates. Operating revenue rose 1% to S$3.6 billion, while earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) increased 0.9% to S$943 million. The company expects a total dividend of around S$0.165 per share for FY2025, with underlying net profit rising 21.6% to S$680 million.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
An artist's impression of Singtel's upcoming data centre in Tuas. It is designed to support artificial intelligence, as well as drive greater energy and water efficiency.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end at record high with defence spending spike in focus
summary: European stocks closed at a record high on Tuesday, driven by a 0.32% rise in the Stoxx 600 index, with defense stocks leading the gains. The sector surged 0.8% as investors anticipated increased domestic military spending amid ongoing peace talks to end the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Banking stocks also rose 1.9%, while utilities declined 0.5%. The news came as US and Russian leaders agreed to press ahead with efforts to end the war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 veered in and out of negative territory before finishing at 6,129.58 on Tuesday, up 0.2 per cent, narrowly topping its earlier record.

site_title: Borrowing strain hits NAB’s Q1 profit, shares dive
summary: NAB shares plummeted 7% on Wednesday, their largest intraday decline in five years, as the bank reported a Q1 profit hit by competition for customers and rising arrears. The result marked the end of a tough period for Australian banks, which had sacrificed margins to win inflation-weary customers after interest rates rose 13 times since 2022. The announcement came after Australia's central bank cut interest rates for the first time in five years, a relief for borrowers but too late for this earnings season.

images.alt_text: Commonwealth Bank of Australia says the change will be implemented on its eligible business lending products.

Suncorp said it would return the net proceeds of A$4.1 billion (S$3.5 billion), which it earned from the sale of its banking arm to ANZ Group, to its shareholders through a capital return of A$3 per share and a special dividend of 22 Australian cents per share.
Macquarie Group Ltd. signage on a building in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday May 1, 2024.  Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Budget 2025: SkillsFuture changes make upskilling more accessible for businesses, employees
summary: The Singapore government has introduced various changes to the SkillsFuture scheme to make upskilling more accessible for businesses and employees. The changes include extending training allowances to part-time courses, redesigning the SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit to allow immediate offsets, and combining existing schemes into a single grant. The enhanced Workforce Development Grant will also provide higher funding support for job redesign and workforce transformation. The changes aim to balance the need for upskilling with companies' and employees' cost and time concerns, and are expected to make upskilling more pragmatic and doable for individuals.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

All companies that have at least three resident employees will receive a fresh S$10,000 in the redesigned SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit, which will be available from the second half of 2026 and last for three years.
A new SkillsFuture Workforce Development Grant, which will provide higher funding support of up to 70% for job redesign activities.

site_title: Budget 2025: Tax incentives to beef up equities market could have ‘limited impact’, say industry experts
summary: Singapore has introduced tax incentives targeting corporate listings, fund manager listings, and fund managers' qualifying income to boost the equities market. The incentives include a 20% corporate income tax rebate for new primary listings and a 10% rebate for new secondary listings, as well as tax exemptions on fund managers' qualifying income. Industry experts caution that these measures may have limited impact, particularly for high-growth companies that are not yet profitable, and that other measures are needed to attract listings.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
The listing Corporate Income Tax rebate will be introduced for companies and registered business trusts that are tax residents in Singapore.

Further details on these proposed tax incentives, introduced last Thursday (Feb 13) as part of the review group’s initial measures to strengthen Singapore’s equities market, will be announced this Friday (Feb 21).
Firms that are active and have at least one local employee in 2024 will also receive a minimum S$2,000 cash grant.

site_title: Former OpenAI tech chief Murati launches AI startup, poaching staff from ChatGPT maker
summary: Former OpenAI chief technology officer Mira Murati has launched an AI startup called Thinking Machines Lab, poaching about 30 researchers and engineers from competitors including OpenAI, Meta, and Mistral. The startup aims to build AI systems that encode human values, targeting a broader range of applications than rivals. Murati's departure follows a string of high-profile exits from OpenAI, with co-founder John Schulman joining as chief scientist. The company plans to raise venture capital funding and contribute to AI alignment research by sharing code and datasets.

site_title: Higher carbon taxes may be needed for Singapore to meet its 2035 climate targets
summary: Singapore's carbon tax rate may need to increase above S$80 to meet its 2035 climate targets, which aim for a 45-50 million tonnes reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. The current rate of S$25 per tonne is insufficient, and the country may need to adopt a more aggressive approach to reduce emissions and reach its net-zero carbon emissions goal by 2050.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
All Singapore-listed companies are required to make climate disclosures aligned with the International Sustainability Standards Board from FY2025
The accounting Big Four’s wishlists for the 2025 Singapore Budget suggest widespread demand for clearer rules on sustainability.

site_title: Budget 2025: Corporate income tax rebate to ease business costs, but impact limited for some
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced the corporate income tax rebate of 50% for the year 2025, with a minimum S$2,000 cash grant for eligible employers. The total benefits, including the rebate and grant, will be capped at S$40,000. The Progressive Wage Credit Scheme will increase its co-funding levels to 40% in 2025 and 20% in 2026. The government also introduced additional household support measures, including S$800 CDC Vouchers, up to S$760 in U-Save rebates, and S$500 in LifeSG credits for each Singaporean child aged 12 and below.

site_title: KFC shifts US headquarters from Kentucky to Texas
summary: KFC is shifting its US headquarters from Louisville, Kentucky, to Plano, Texas, as part of its parent company Yum! Brands' plan to have two US headquarters, one in Texas and another in California. The relocation of about 100 KFC US corporate roles will take place over six months, with US-based remote staff also being asked to relocate. Both Yum! Brands and the KFC Foundation will maintain corporate offices in Louisville, while Taco Bell and Habit Burger & Grill will remain headquartered in California.

site_title: China moves to seize on US upheaval with appeal to strengthen UN
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi has called for a stronger United Nations, citing the need for multilateralism and cooperation among countries, amid US President Donald Trump's move to roll out broad-based tariffs and sever ties with the UN. Wang's charm offensive in Europe aims to position China as a counterweight to Trump's administration, while China seeks to capitalize on US upheaval. The US has also withdrawn from several UN institutions, sparking concerns about the future of global cooperation. Wang emphasized China's commitment to multilateralism and vowed to work with all countries to build a better future.

images.alt_text: “If the US is not willing, if it is bent on suppressing and containing China, then we have no choice but to play along to the end,” Foreign Minister Wang Yi says.
