site_title: Budget 2025 delivers SG60 goodies while keeping long-term needs in sight – and with funds to spare
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 delivers SG60 goodies and long-term plans, with a surplus of S$6.8 billion. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced measures to tackle cost anxieties, including an extra S$800 for households and a 50% corporate tax rebate for businesses. The budget also includes enhancements to internationalization and M&A schemes, a top-up for the National Productivity Fund, and investments in clean power and infrastructure. PM Wong emphasized the need for Singapore to navigate a turbulent external environment and chart its next phase of growth, while maintaining sound public finances.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Even while handing out help for short-term costs, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong noted that the longer term strategy against higher prices is pursuing economic growth.

site_title: Budget 2025: Enhancements to internationalisation and M&A schemes will help local enterprises compete on a global scale
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 aims to enhance internationalisation and mergers and acquisitions (M&A) schemes to help local enterprises compete globally. The government extended the Market Readiness Assistance grant and Double Tax Deduction for Internationalisation scheme until 2030. A new Enterprise Compute Initiative was also launched to support businesses in leveraging artificial intelligence. The Enterprise Financing Scheme was enhanced with increased loan quantum and scope for M&A loans. The initiatives aim to support companies in scaling up amid global uncertainties and increasing competition, with the goal of making Singaporean businesses more resilient and globally competitive.

site_title: Oil settles up on supply hits, traders cautious on Ukraine peace talks
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures increasing 0.8% to settle at $75.84 a barrel, driven by supply disruptions in Russia and the US. Disruptions included a 30-40% reduction in oil flows through the Caspian Pipeline Consortium pipeline and Russia's suspension of loadings at the Black Sea port of Novorossiisk. However, gains were capped by ongoing Ukraine peace talks, which could boost supply from Moscow if a deal is reached.

site_title: Time to clean up the ungoverned regions of South-east Asia
summary: Scam call centres have proliferated in ungoverned regions of South-east Asia, particularly along the Myanmar-Thai border. The recent rescue of 260 people from a scam centre is part of a larger trend. The military junta's loss of control in Myanmar has created a power vacuum, allowing scam operators to flourish. The Golden Triangle, where Myanmar, Thailand, and Laos meet, is also a hub for illicit drug production, further exacerbating the problem. The lack of action from governments in the region has enabled scam operators to thrive, with an estimated US$1.03 trillion global scam call business in 2024.

images.alt_text: Mohan Kuppusamy

site_title: Trump ‘more confident’ of Ukraine deal after talks
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed increased confidence in a deal to end the Ukraine war after talks with Russia in Riyadh. The US and Russia agreed to establish teams to negotiate a path to ending the war, which began in February 2022. Trump suggested he could meet Russian President Vladimir Putin "very soon" as the US overhauls its stance towards Russia, sparking concerns among European leaders. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky criticized his country's exclusion from the talks, calling it "disappointing" and "betraying."

images.alt_text: (COMBO) This combination of pictures created on February 12, 2025 shows (L-R) US President Donald Trump in Washington, DC, on February 11, 2025, Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky in Brussels on December 19, 2024, and Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow on January 17, 2025. Russian President Vladimir Putin told his US counterpart Donald Trump in a phone call on February 12, 2025, that "peaceful negotiations" on ending the Ukraine conflict were possible, the Kremlin said. Trump said on Truth Social that both leaders had extended invitations of "visiting each other's nations," while the US leader said he would be calling Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky "right now" to inform him about the call. site_title: US: Wall St opens higher with Fed policy, Trump tariffs in focus
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, February 18, as investors focused on potential tariff developments and the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate strategy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 37.8 points, or 0.08%, to 44,583.91, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased, reaching fresh records. Despite uncertainty surrounding US tariffs and the Fed's policy, investors remained optimistic, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to new highs.

site_title: SMEs should start ESG reporting before regulation catches up
summary: SMEs in Singapore and Hong Kong are being asked to provide ESG data for customers' US, UK, and Australian listed firms. Despite regulations looming in 2025 and 2026, many SMEs are not starting ESG reporting due to lack of skills, resources, and knowledge. A survey found 85% of SMEs believe good ESG practices increase customer trust and build a positive brand image, but 48% have not started due to resource constraints. SMEs are advised to start ESG reporting early to take "baby steps" towards getting reports right, utilizing existing financial information.

images.alt_text: Tax professionals can help companies in their sustainability journey

site_title: Over 1,000 organisations are finding out if they are ready for operational disruptions
summary: Over 1,000 organizations in Singapore are participating in "Exercise SG Ready 2025", a two-week table-top exercise co-led by the Ministry of Defence and Energy Market Authority. The exercise aims to test and enhance the country's ability to withstand crises, focusing on business-continuity plans for power disruptions and cyberattacks. Managing director of Concord Clean Energy Research Center, Dr Zhang Bo, shared insights on dealing with power disruptions during the exercise, highlighting the importance of contingency plans against such threats. The exercise will help organizations strengthen their preparedness for operational disruptions.

site_title: Budget 2025: Incentives for cleaner heavy vehicles will cut carbon, costs, but more details needed
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 includes incentives for cleaner heavy vehicles to reduce carbon emissions and costs. The Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme and Electric Heavy Vehicle Charger Grant aim to accelerate the adoption of electric heavy vehicles and buses. The government will provide targeted support for the logistics and transport industries to encourage large-scale fleet electrification. Electric heavy vehicles will also pay an additional road tax component from 2026. Industry observers say the initiatives are a "positive and necessary step" towards decarbonization, but effectiveness depends on factors such as financial support and charging infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
More electric heavy goods vehicles (eHGVs) will enter the Singapore market in 2023, but incentives and infrastructure developments are needed to boost adoption.

site_title: Budget 2025: SG60 gifts with up to S$800 in vouchers, 60% personal income tax rebate; arts, hawkers support
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 includes a package to celebrate the country's 60th birthday, featuring the SG60 Vouchers, which will be disbursed in July and expire on Dec 31, 2026. The vouchers will be worth S$600 for those aged 21-59 and S$800 for those 60 and above. The government will also provide a 60% personal income tax rebate, capped at S$200, and allocate more than S$600 million in matching funds for charity fundraising and social causes. Additionally, hawkers and the arts will receive support, including rental assistance and credits for heritage activities.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong laid out plans to spur growth, while also tackling immediate cost pressures for households and businesses.

site_title: How AI will divide the best from the rest
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is expected to widen social divides, contrary to initial hopes that it would be a great equaliser. Unlike earlier automation, which replaced routine jobs, AI may extend its reach to non-routine and creative work, benefiting high performers. Recent findings suggest that experts are best positioned to work with AI, while lower-skilled workers may be left behind. This trend is similar to past technological revolutions, which widened workforce divides. Experts predict that AI will lead to the "largest change to the global labour market in human history", but may not democratise opportunity as previously thought.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo is seen in this illustration taken, March 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
For much of this year already, AI researchers have been looking at new paths for improving their models that don’t just involve throwing more data and computing power at them.

The seeming success of ChatGPT, which became the fastest-growing online service of all time soon after its launch, sparked a race between Google and Microsoft to plug generative AI into many parts of their software.

Big Tech has provided us with electronic wonders that put much of the world’s knowledge at our fingertips. Likewise AI is also empowering regular workers by making it easier to find and present information, in effect, providing us all with our own research assistant.

site_title: Budget 2025: Quick takes on S$1 billion private credit growth fund
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong introduced a S$1 billion private credit growth fund to provide financing for high-growth local enterprises. This fund complements existing investment funds and is part of a broader effort to support enterprise growth. Analysts and experts praise the initiative, citing its potential to enhance Singapore's position as a financing hub and provide local businesses with more funding options to accelerate their growth. The fund is expected to create a flywheel effect, attracting deeper pools of capital and contributing to a more vibrant financing ecosystem.

site_title: BT Branded Podcasts: Maybank driving economic growth and supporting SMEs in the Johor-Singapore SEZ and beyond
summary: Maybank is driving economic growth through its branded podcasts, which focus on supporting small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (SEZ). The podcasts aim to provide valuable insights and information to SMEs, helping them navigate the market and make informed decisions. By promoting economic growth and supporting SMEs, Maybank is contributing to the overall development of the region. This initiative is part of Maybank's efforts to foster a positive business environment and promote economic stability.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro

site_title: DBS names new heads of operations, and corporate and SME banking
summary: DBS Bank has appointed Chen Ze Ling as group head of corporate and SME banking, effective April 1, replacing Koh Kar Siong. Chen, who has over 20 years of experience in banking, will report to Han Kwee Juan, group head of institutional banking. Meanwhile, Welson Jamin, the current head of institutional banking operations and international centres technology and operations, will become group head of operations from April 1, succeeding Derrick Goh, who will assume the newly created role of group chief operating officer.

Before Derrick Goh became the head of DBS' audit team in 2018, he led its regional wealth management programme.

site_title: Budget 2025: Support for elderly and persons with disabilities, including more subsidies for long-term care
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 aims to support elderly and persons with disabilities. The government will introduce a five-year Matched MediSave Scheme, matching voluntary top-ups to MediSave accounts for lower-income seniors aged 55-70. Subsidies for long-term care will rise by up to 15 percentage points, and the maximum Home Caregiving Grant will be raised to S$600 per month. The government also extends the Enabling Employment Credit for employers and expands the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme to include eligible persons with disabilities.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong notes that more seniors are staying employed as the population ages.

site_title: G20 gyrations threaten multilateral forum’s future
summary: The 2025 G20 foreign minister meeting in South Africa is set to be marred by US opposition, with Secretary of State Marco Rubio declining to attend and President Donald Trump threatening to cut off funding to the country. The US is opposed to key G20 agenda items, including South Africa's expropriation law and climate change policies. This comes as tensions between the US and China, and Russia, are high, and the US absence from the G20 may benefit Moscow and China. Despite this, other countries, including the European Union, are backing South Africa's leadership of the G20, and the US can still play a key role in driving projects in Africa, such as the Mozambique LNG project.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s remarks add further strain to relations between the US and South Africa, which counts America as its second-biggest trading partner, after China.

site_title: Intel has biggest rally since 2020 on breakup speculation
summary: Intel shares surged 16% on speculation of a potential breakup deal involving Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) and Broadcom. TSMC may operate Intel's US factories and hold a controlling stake in the venture, while Broadcom has discussed a bid for Intel's chip design and marketing business. Additionally, Silver Lake Management is in talks to acquire a majority stake in Altera, Intel's programmable chip unit, in an exclusive deal. The news has lifted Intel's market value, marking the company's biggest rally since 2020.

images.alt_text: Intel was among the largest beneficiaries of the US push to onshore critical chip manufacturing led by former president Joe Biden’s administration.
TSMC is the go-to chipmaker for Apple, Nvidia and other companies developing semiconductors that power AI algorithms.
The recent gain has only taken shares to their highest since December, and has done little to offset last year’s 60 per cent collapse.

site_title: Budget 2025: Government to reorganise for greater focus on nuclear energy, build new capabilities
summary: Singapore has announced plans to reorganise its government to focus on nuclear energy capabilities, with a $5 billion top-up to the Future Energy Fund to support the development of small modular reactors (SMRs). The move aims to assess the feasibility of integrating nuclear energy into the country's energy landscape, with the goal of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The government will also allocate $5 billion to the Coastal and Flood Protection Fund to address climate adaptation efforts.

site_title: Dollar firms, Aussie steady after RBA's 'hawkish' rate cut
summary: The US dollar firmed on Tuesday as traders weighed tariff worries, geopolitical uncertainties, and the path to US rate cuts. The dollar index rose 0.25% to 106.99, while the Australian dollar held near two-month highs after the Reserve Bank of Australia's 25 basis point rate cut. The euro fell 0.26% to US$1.04535, and sterling eased 0.27% to US$1.25925. Markets expect rate cuts to resume in the second half of 2025, but are only pricing in 40 basis points of cuts for this year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 18)
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong outlined plans to spur growth while addressing immediate cost pressures for households and businesses in Budget 2025. The budget expects a surplus of S$6.8 billion in FY2025, driven by a 12.9% rise in net investment returns. The US's export restrictions on AI-related chips are expected to have limited impact on Singapore's semicon sector. PEC will be delisted from the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading after receiving a privatisation proposal.

images.alt_text: In 2024, a total of 20 companies delisted from the Singapore Exchange, with just four new entrants to the Catalist board.

site_title: Trump wants US allies to ‘do something’: What happens if they won’t?
summary: US President Donald Trump is pressuring US allies in Europe and the Middle East to take care of their own strategic interests, rather than relying on Washington. He has agreed to talks with Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine, with Russia's core demands including no Nato membership for Ukraine and no US support for its defense against Russia. Trump has also proposed transferring the Gaza Strip's Palestinian inhabitants to Jordan and Egypt, contrary to Arab demands for an independent Palestinian state. This shift in geo-strategy may force the US to remain involved in Europe and the Middle East, despite some in Washington wanting to disengage.

site_title: Goldman hoists gold target to US$3,100 on central-bank demand
summary: Goldman Sachs has raised its year-end gold target to US$3,100 an ounce, citing central-bank demand and inflows into bullion-backed exchange-traded funds. The bank expects central banks to buy 50 tonnes a month, driving prices up 26% annually. This follows a seven-week winning streak for gold, fueled by increased central-bank purchases, rate cuts from the Fed, and investor concern over US tariffs. Other banks, including Citigroup, have also predicted higher prices.

site_title: Budget 2025: Singapore primed to navigate troubled world with confidence
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 aims to navigate global uncertainties with confidence, thanks to a strong fiscal position. The budget offers a range of support measures, including a one-off SG60 package and vouchers for all Singaporeans, as well as specific groups such as mid-career workers and seniors. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong notes that the government is pursuing economic growth while addressing short-term cost-of-living anxieties. The budget is expected to result in a surplus of S$6.8 billion, marking a significant improvement from previous years, and will focus on investments in innovation, technology, and high-growth local enterprises.

site_title: Beijing party chief, Politburo member Yin Li to visit Singapore
summary: Beijing Party Chief Yin Li will visit Singapore from February 19 to 22, marking his first high-level engagement in his current capacity. The four-day visit coincides with Singapore and China's 35th anniversary of diplomatic ties in 1990. Yin will meet with Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong, and other officials, and will also visit various institutions, including the National Cancer Centre Singapore and Changi Airport. This visit highlights the strengthening bilateral relations between the two nations, which have been Singapore's largest trading partner and China's largest foreign investor since 2013.

site_title: Indonesia to launch first bullion banks
summary: Indonesia is set to launch its first two state-owned bullion banks, Pegadaian and Bank Syariah Indonesia, on Feb 26. The banks aim to facilitate gold trading and provide related services, reducing reliance on foreign institutions and improving domestic liquidity. The move is part of Indonesia's strategy to ascend the commodities value chain, with an annual gold output of 110,000 kg. The bullion banks will also support haj savings and stimulate the local industry by expanding financing opportunities. The launch is expected to create a more self-sustaining ecosystem for the gold industry.

site_title: Budget 2025: More than S$600 million in matching funds for charity; self-help groups get S$60 million
summary: The Singapore government has announced a budget of over S$600 million to support charity fundraising and social causes. The government will provide dollar-for-dollar matching grants for donations made through platforms and registered charities, with a focus on larger donors who make a minimum three-year commitment of at least S$250,000 per year. The government will also provide additional funding to self-help groups, including S$60 million over the next five years.

site_title: Budget 2025: S$1 billion private credit fund will help high-growth companies bridge financing gaps
summary: Singapore has introduced a S$1 billion Private Credit Growth Fund to provide financing options for high-growth local enterprises, aiming to bridge financing gaps and raise awareness of private credit as a source of funding. The fund, announced by Finance Minister Lawrence Wong, will help local businesses access a fast-growing but underutilized market in Asia. The private credit market has gained traction globally, but few funds focus on Asia or Singapore-based enterprises. The fund is expected to create more financing options for high-growth local enterprises, particularly those that may not be eligible for bank loans, improving their odds of survival.

site_title: Budget 2025: A strategic blueprint for a new era
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 aims to differentiate the country as a gold standard for high-value solutions in global innovation, sustainability, and enterprise excellence. The budget allocates S$150 million to the Enterprise Compute Initiative, S$1 billion to new research and development facilities, and S$1 billion to the Private Credit Growth Fund to enhance Singapore's status as a premier financial and innovation hub. The budget also prioritizes workforce development and leadership capacity-building, including a new SkillsFuture Workforce Development Grant, and a S$5 billion injection into the Future Energy Fund to support the country's decarbonization targets.

site_title: Climate change doesn’t care what we think about it
summary: Climate change's impact on the real world is undeniable, with immediate consequences such as increased natural disasters and rising insurance costs. Despite debates about the science, markets like insurance and energy are already adapting to the effects of climate change. Homeowners in Florida face high insurance premiums, while the wind energy market in Texas is thriving. As unit prices drop and charging infrastructure grows, electric vehicles are becoming increasingly popular, with EVs now making up 9% of the US auto market. The writer concludes that climate change doesn't care what individuals think, and the real world is already changing due to its immediate consequences.

summary: Robinhood plans to launch crypto products in Singapore by late 2025, with guidance from local regulators. Robinhood acquired Bitstamp, a European digital-assets exchange, for $200 million in June 2024, which holds licences in Singapore, the EU, and other countries. site_title: Vietnam paves way for Musk’s Starlink, seen as ‘olive branch’ amid US tariff threats
summary: Vietnam is set to adopt rules allowing Elon Musk's Starlink to provide satellite internet services in the country while maintaining full ownership of any local subsidiary, paving the way for Starlink's launch in Vietnam. The move, seen as an "olive branch" to SpaceX amid US tariff threats, comes after protracted talks between the two parties. The draft rules allow for full foreign control of operations for internet providers with low-orbit satellites under a pilot scheme until 2030, which could help trim Vietnam's large surplus with the US.

The decline was attributed to the restructuring of loans for large businesses and government measures to boost the tourism industry, including visa waivers and debt-relief programs. Total outstanding loans fell 0.4% in the fourth quarter, and the NPL ratio dropped for the first time in several quarters, indicating an improvement in the country's debt repayment ability.

site_title: Budget 2025: Unexpected rise in corporate income tax boosts government revenue
summary: Singapore's corporate income tax collection rose significantly, becoming the single largest contributor to the city-state's total revenue, surpassing net investment returns. Collections are projected to reach 4.1% of Singapore's gross domestic product in FY2024. This is attributed to industry-specific cyclical factors, such as the finance and wholesale trade sectors. The unexpected rise in corporate income tax boosts government revenue, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong attributing it to a combination of factors.

site_title: Budget 2025: Singapore expects S$6.8 billion surplus in FY2025, contrary to economists’ deficit predictions
summary: Singapore expects a fiscal surplus of S$6.8 billion, or 0.9% of gross domestic product, for the 2025 financial year, contrary to economists' deficit predictions. The surplus is driven by a 12.9% rise in net investment returns to S$27.1 billion. Despite a generous spending plan, the government's total expenditure is outstripped by operating revenue, yielding a primary deficit of S$1 billion, which widens to a basic deficit of S$4.8 billion. The surplus reflects the government's strong fiscal position and adherence to its principle of fiscal prudence.

This is due to an upward revision in operating revenue by S$8 billion, which more than offset an upward revision in total expenditure. The better-than-expected performance is attributed to 'industry-specific cyclical factors' in finance and wholesale trade.

site_title: Budget 2025: Quick takes on SkillsFuture workforce development grant, enterprise credit and more
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 includes several workforce development initiatives. The SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit will be redesigned, providing S$10,000 to companies with at least three resident employees, available in the second half of 2026. The SkillsFuture Workforce Development Grant will offer up to 70% funding support for job-redesign activities. Additionally, a training allowance of up to S$3,000 per month for 24 months will be available for selected full-time courses, and a part-time training allowance will be given to Singaporeans aged 40 and above. These initiatives aim to enhance workforce development and support businesses in upskilling their employees.

site_title: New World proposes additional US$3.8b for loan collateral
summary: New World Development, a Hong Kong developer, has proposed using US$3.8 billion of additional properties as collateral to refinance bank loans maturing in 2027 and beyond. This move aims to ease liquidity pressure amid a challenging property market. The company has consolidated net debt of HK$123.8 billion (S$21.4 billion) and has already pledged US$15.3 billion in assets to refinance loans this year and next. Bank support is crucial for New World, which faces mounting pressure due to its high debt burden.

site_title: Budget 2025: New workforce development grant to provide higher funding, more SkillsFuture credit for staff training

The credit will also be available to all companies with at least three resident employees, with an initial S$10,000 payment in the second half of 2026. Additionally, NTUC's Company Training Committee grant will receive an extra S$200 million to support more workforce transformation projects.

Earnings per share declined to S$0.0086, and no dividend was declared due to net current liabilities and accumulated losses. Retail operations in Malaysia saw a marginally higher revenue of S$57.7 million, while investment holdings generated S$743,000. summary: LG Electronics has started roadshows for its US$1.5 billion initial public offering (IPO) in India, with plans to sell up to 101.82 million shares. The company aims to list its Indian unit in Mumbai this year. Representatives for LG Electronics and its LG Electronics India unit declined to comment on the roadshows.

images.alt_text: Hyun Shin-Gyoon, chief executive officer of LG CNS Co., strikes the drum during the company's listing ceremony at the Korea Exchange (KRX) in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday, Feb. 5, 2025. The IPO for LG Electronics India is valued at 152.4 billion rupees, as per a Moneycontrol report, ranking it among the top five in the country this year.

site_title: Budget 2025: All Singaporean households to get $800 in CDC vouchers
summary: The Singapore government has announced Budget 2025, providing additional support to households. Every Singaporean household will receive $800 in Community Development Council (CDC) vouchers, with $500 disbursed in May and the remaining $300 in January 2026. Eligible households will also receive up to $760 in U-Save rebates and $500 in LifeSG credits for each child under 12. The government will also increase support for lower-income households through ComCare Assistance schemes and the Singapore Allowance.

site_title: Budget 2025: Government to pay ‘close attention’ to public housing as HDB launches over 50,000 new flats over next three years
summary: Singapore's government will continue to focus on public housing, with over 50,000 new Build-to-Order (BTO) flats to be launched over the next three years. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced the plan in his Budget speech, citing the government's ramped-up BTO supply and stabilised application rates. The government aims to stabilize the resale market with cooling and supply measures, while offering more options for home seekers.

site_title: PEC receives privatisation proposal of S$0.64 per share and S$0.20 per share via special dividend
summary: Alliance Energy Services is proposing to take engineering company PEC private with a scheme of arrangement offering S$0.64 per share in cash and S$0.20 per share as a special dividend. The offer represents a 12.8% premium over PEC's last transacted price. If approved, PEC will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading. The deal involves acquiring all issued shares, excluding treasury shares held by PEC.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
For the second half of its 2024 financial year ended Jun 30, PEC posted a net profit of S$10.8 million, almost trebling the S$3.9 million raked in during the corresponding year-ago period.

site_title: Budget 2025: S$5 billion injection to Coastal and Flood Protection Fund
summary: Singapore's government is injecting S$5 billion into the Coastal and Flood Protection Fund, a top-up to the initial S$5 billion announced in 2020, to protect the country from rising sea levels. The fund will support various solutions, including sea walls and land reclamation, which may be implemented over two decades starting from the 2030s. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of setting aside funds now to ensure future generations can benefit from these investments.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
All Singapore-listed companies are required to make climate disclosures aligned with the International Sustainability Standards Board from FY2025

site_title: DeepSeek: Another piece in the puzzle of China’s post-bubble recovery
summary: China's AI startup DeepSeek has upended investors' understanding of the AI space, suggesting a new path forward in the ongoing AI race. Founded by Liang Wenfeng, DeepSeek appears to be less reliant on US and US-allied technology, forging an alternative way forward in AI. This development could help China restart its economy, providing a critical step in economic reform and restructuring. If successful, DeepSeek could democratize AI training, supporting new industries, employment, and private consumption growth, potentially offsetting job losses. This could be another crucial step in China's post-bubble recovery, following coordinated monetary and fiscal policies and bank recapitalization.

site_title: Budget 2025: Workfare Skills Support to be enhanced for lower-wage workers; IHLs to be developed
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 includes enhancements to the Workfare Skills Support (WSS) scheme for lower-wage workers, providing longer-form courses and a fixed monthly allowance of up to S$300. Mid-career workers will also receive a S$300 allowance for part-time courses. The government plans to develop new city campuses for Institutes of Higher Learning, including the Singapore University of Social Sciences. The SkillsFuture Level-Up Programme will be expanded to benefit workers aged 30-39 and 40+, with up to 24 months of monthly training allowance.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Budget 2025: More Climate Vouchers for HDB households, Singaporeans in private properties
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced in the 2025 budget that Climate Vouchers will be extended to private households, with an additional S$100 to be issued to Housing and Development Board (HDB) households. The vouchers aim to boost individual sustainability efforts and encourage households to adopt energy- and water-efficient products. The programme was previously enhanced in 2024, with a S$300 voucher for HDB households and expanded use of the vouchers. The goal is to promote sustainable habits and realise a green future.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Budget 2025: EASE scheme for seniors to be expanded to private properties; Matched MediSave scheme to be introduced
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 introduces measures to support seniors, including expanding the Enhancement for Active Seniors (EASE) program to private properties, introducing a Matched MediSave scheme for eligible lower-income seniors, and increasing subsidies for long-term care services. The government also plans to enhance grants for home healthcare and caregiving, with estimated costs of around S$300 million in FY2026. These enhancements aim to provide better support for seniors as the population ages.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Are the glory days over for Big Tech stocks?
summary: Big Tech stocks have underperformed investors' expectations in the fourth-quarter earnings season, despite solid financial performance. Only Meta's 22.93% year-to-date gain surpassed the S&P 500's 4.29% performance. The majority of tech giants, including Alphabet, Microsoft, and Amazon, trailed the S&P 500, with their earnings not satisfying investors' lofty expectations. This presents an opportunity for long-term investors to raise their exposure to the sector, as investors today are more rational and scrutinize tech earnings more closely than in the past.

site_title: Budget 2025: S$150 million Enterprise Compute Initiative to enable AI access; support for internationalisation, M&A schemes enhanced
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a S$150 million Enterprise Compute Initiative to enable local enterprises to access AI tools and computing power through partnerships with major cloud service providers. The initiative aims to help enterprises leverage AI more effectively in their transformation journey. The government also extended support schemes for internationalisation, mergers and acquisitions, and enhanced the Enterprise Financing Scheme to support targeted asset acquisitions. Additionally, the Singapore Economic Development Board plans to launch a Global Founder Programme to encourage global founders to anchor and grow new ventures in Singapore.

images.alt_text: In the Singapore Budget unveiled on Feb 18, there was bad news for some homeowners - property taxes rates will rise starting from 2023, with high-end homes seeing a steeper increase.

site_title: Budget 2025: Government to spur zero-emissions heavy vehicles adoption through new scheme
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced the introduction of a Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme and an Electric Heavy Vehicle Charger Grant to encourage the adoption of clean energy variants of heavy vehicles. The government aims to address limited model availability, higher upfront costs, and less-accessible charging infrastructure. The grant will provide co-funding for charging infrastructure, while an additional flat component of road tax for electric heavy goods vehicles and buses is also on the cards. The goal is to spur the adoption of zero-emissions heavy vehicles.

site_title: Honda ready to revive takeover talks if Nissan CEO Uchida leaves: report
summary: Honda is willing to revive takeover talks with Nissan if CEO Makoto Uchida steps down, according to a Financial Times report. Nissan's board of directors has started informal discussions about Uchida's departure, following the collapse of merger talks with Honda. Nissan is working on a turnaround program to reduce its workforce by 9,000 and global manufacturing capacity by 20%. Honda CEO Toshihiro Mibe has ruled out a hostile takeover bid, but is open to negotiations with a new Nissan leader. Uchida's departure could provide an opportunity for Honda to revive talks and potentially form the world's fourth-largest automaker.

images.alt_text: Nissan's net income slumped 94 per cent in the six months to Sept 30 as profits cratered in the US and China, making it harder to refinance a record amount of bonds due to mature in 2026.

site_title: Budget 2025: New S$1 billion private credit fund for high-growth local companies
summary: Singapore has introduced a new S$1 billion Private Credit Growth Fund to provide financing options for high-growth local enterprises, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong citing the growing global traction of the private credit market. This fund aims to support local companies, which currently face limited access to financing options. The government has previously invested S$1.8 billion in enterprise growth through investment funds, and this new fund is expected to further support local businesses.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares started trading flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) opening 0.03 points higher at 3,904.88. Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 46 to 44, with local banking stocks trading in positive territory. US stock markets were closed due to President's Day. In Europe, the pan-European Stoxx 600 index reached a record closing high, boosted by defence stocks and aerospace gains.

site_title: Investing lesson from DeepSeek: Be wary of perfection
summary: Nvidia shares dropped, causing many other shares to rise as investors redistributed funds. A lesson from DeepSeek, a Chinese software company, is to be wary of perfection in valuations, as companies like Nvidia are often overvalued and vulnerable to disruption. This lesson is also linked to investing within one's circle of competence and building a diversified portfolio to manage risk. By being realistic and diversifying investments, investors can minimize risk and maximize returns.

summary: Singapore's government has allocated S$5 billion to the Changi Airport Development Fund to support the construction of Terminal 5, which will increase the airport's capacity by over 50%. The top-up will ensure sufficient resources for the project, which aims to maintain Singapore as a critical gateway for global travel and trade. Prime Minister Wong also announced a guarantee to Changi Airport Group to lower borrowing costs, further supporting the project. Groundbreaking for Terminal 5 is expected to take place in the coming months.

The company plans to expand its brick-and-mortar stores and quick deliveries to compete with rivals like Zomato and Swiggy, with a goal of 50 stores by March 2026. Licious aims to capitalize on India's growing demand for meat and seafood, with the country's fish and seafood market valued at US$59 billion annually.

site_title: Musk debuts Grok-3 AI chatbot to rival OpenAI, DeepSeek
summary: Elon Musk's AI startup xAI unveiled the Grok-3 chatbot, boasting "more than 10 times" the compute power of its predecessor and outperforming rivals like Google Gemini, DeepSeek's V3 model, and OpenAI's GPT-4o in math, science, and coding benchmarks. Grok-3 has completed pre-training and will be rolled out to Premium+ subscribers on X immediately, with a new subscription called SuperGrok available soon. Musk also announced plans to open-source previous Grok models and release a voice-based chatbot "as soon as possible."

site_title: With Thailand’s new booze law, David wins a small, sweet victory over Goliaths
summary: Thailand's new Community Liquor Bill, passed by the Lower House with bipartisan support, aims to give small brewers a fair chance to compete in the market dominated by duopolies. The bill, championed by opposition party member Taopiphop Limjittrakorn, would relax regulations on distilleries and breweries, allowing smaller players to access oak barrels and increase production capacity. While major players like ThaiBev are unlikely to lose significant market share, the bill's supporters see it as a step towards leveling the playing field and promoting fair competition.

images.alt_text: ThaiBev, the maker of Chang Beer, has built up an entrenched distribution network in Thailand over several years, analysts said.

site_title: Developer Greentown China plans additional dollar bonds to refinance debt
summary: Greentown China, a state-backed property developer, plans to issue additional dollar bonds to refinance its existing debt. The new bonds will have the same tenor and coupon as its previously issued 8.45% senior notes due in 2028. The proceeds will be used partly to fund the repurchase of two US dollar bonds, worth $741 million. This move aims to boost liquidity and provide room for new investments. The developer's refinancing comes amid heightened investor caution following a spate of defaults in China's property sector.

site_title: Gold inches higher on concerns over Trump tariff threats
summary: US gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,898.99, driven by concerns over President Trump's tariffs, which may spark a global trade war. The uncertainty reinforced gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset. Meanwhile, the European Union agreed to give Ukraine security guarantees, but a ceasefire would require a peace agreement. Goldman Sachs raised its gold price forecast to $3,100 per ounce, citing structurally higher central bank demand.

images.alt_text: Spot gold rose 0.1 per cent to US$2,885.95 per ounce.

site_title: Budget 2025: Singapore enters next phase of growth amid ‘a new global contest’
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 aims to navigate the country into its next phase of growth amidst a new global contest marked by increased uncertainty and downside risks. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that Singapore has "done well so far," bouncing back from the Covid-19 pandemic with a 4.4% economic growth rate. The government will focus on supporting workers, addressing income inequality, and providing extra assistance to low-income families, including Aljunied seniors. The budget also aims to foster a more business-friendly environment through industry feedback and talent acquisition.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
MTI's growth forecast range for 2025 remains unchanged at 1 to 3 per cent.

site_title: China’s Sany Heavy Industry aims to raise up to US$1.5 billion in planned Hong Kong listing: sources
summary: Chinese equipment manufacturer Sany Heavy Industry plans to raise up to US$1.5 billion in a Hong Kong listing, according to sources. The company, listed in Shanghai with a market capitalization of US$20 billion, has tapped Bank of America, JPMorgan, and Citic Securities to work on the potential float. The listing could happen in the second half of 2025. Sany Heavy Industry is primarily engaged in equipment manufacturing, with a significant year-on-year growth in net profit for the third quarter of 2024, reaching 96% and 20% year-over-year growth for the first nine months.

site_title: Vietnam endorses sweeping reforms to spur economic growth
summary: Vietnam's parliament approved a plan to overhaul the government, slashing thousands of jobs and streamlining bureaucracy in an effort to achieve 8% economic growth. The reforms, aimed at reducing the size of ministries and workforce by 20%, will abolish five ministries and merge others. The move is seen as key to meeting Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh's growth targets and comes ahead of next year's leadership reshuffle. The plan includes significant cuts to government agencies, state-run TV channels, and publications, with payouts offered to affected workers.

site_title: Tesla hires in India, signalling entry plans after Modi’s US trip
summary: Tesla has begun hiring in India, signaling its plans to enter the market, following a meeting between CEO Elon Musk and Prime Minister Narendra Modi in the US. The carmaker is seeking candidates for 13 roles, including customer-facing and back-end jobs, with positions available in both Mumbai and Delhi. This move comes after India reduced its basic customs duty on high-end cars priced above $40,000. Tesla aims to tap into India's growing electric vehicle market, which saw 100,000 units sold last year, compared to China's 11 million.

site_title: Why China investors finally believe Xi’s tech crackdown is over
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has signaled the end of the country's tech crackdown, easing restrictions on the private sector after a years-long campaign. The Hang Seng Tech Index surged following reports of the meeting with influential entrepreneurs, including Alibaba's Jack Ma and Huawei's Ren Zhengfei. Beijing now sees the trillion-dollar technology sector as crucial to the country's economy and its rivalry with the US, with a focus on industries such as AI, cloud computing, and advanced semiconductors. However, regulators remain cautious, with guardrails in place for wild investment and competitive excesses, and a focus on data security and national security.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping “stressed that the difficulties and challenges currently faced by the development of the private economy have generally appeared during the process of reform and development, and industrial transformation”.
Xi Jinping has long stressed the need for China to achieve self-sufficiency in semiconductors and wants the country to use AI to drive economic development.

site_title: Budget 2025: S$3 billion top-up to National Productivity Fund; S$1 billion for biotech, semicon R&D
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced in the 2025 budget that the government will top up the National Productivity Fund by S$3 billion to support innovation. The government will also invest S$1 billion in research infrastructure for the biotech and semiconductor sectors. A new national semiconductor R&D fabrication facility will be developed to provide industry-grade tools for researchers and industry partners. Additionally, companies will receive full tax deductions for payments made under approved cost-sharing agreements for innovation activities.

summary: Singapore's semiconductor sector is expected to face only a "limited impact" from US technology restrictions, with the country producing "mature node chips" that are not targeted by the US controls. The US export restrictions focus on advanced semiconductor technology, primarily on AI-related chips, but Singapore's industry is more focused on consumer appliances, automotive applications, and industrial equipment. Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng stated that the Singapore government will ensure adequate access to AI compute for local and international companies, while also maintaining the integrity of its business environment.

site_title: Asia: Tech rally helps Hong Kong lead markets higher
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose, extending its impressive start to the year, driven by a tech rally and hopes that China's crackdown on the private sector is ending. A meeting between President Xi Jinping and top business leaders, including Alibaba's Jack Ma, sparked optimism. The tech revival has offset worries about US President Donald Trump's tariffs and foreign policies. State news agency Xinhua reported Xi's statement that Beijing is focused on removing obstacles to commerce and promoting fair competition, providing relief to investors and fanning hopes for a sector revival.

site_title: Thailand’s central bank and government must work together, PM says
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra urged cooperation between the government and central bank to support small businesses and boost economic growth. The country's fourth-quarter GDP growth missed forecasts at 3.2%, but still marked the strongest annual rate in nine quarters. The government aims to reach 3.5% growth this year, with a focus on increasing credit access for small and medium enterprises to address low lending to these businesses. Paetongtarn will hold discussions with the central bank to address the issue, which she believes will help the economy.

site_title: Petronas mulls over US$1 billion loan for Malaysian LNG project
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned energy company, is in talks with banks for a potential US$1 billion loan to fund a liquefied natural gas (LNG) project. The 15-year loan will be used to construct a LNG facility in the South-east Asian nation. The company is seeking project financing to support its gas supply from the hydrocarbon-rich Borneo state. Discussions with potential financiers are ongoing, and the deal's details could change.

site_title: Japan approves new climate, energy and industry policies through 2040
summary: Japan's government has approved new climate, energy, and industry policies through 2040, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 60% by 2035 and 73% by 2040. The revised energy policy targets 50% of electricity from renewables by 2040 and 30% from nuclear power, while promoting decarbonization and industrial growth. Despite public comments calling for more ambitious targets, the government has finalized the goals without changes, citing prior climate expert deliberations.

images.alt_text: Rising bond issuance comes alongside a wider surge in dealmaking in the country.
Strong domestic demand is helping support a recovery in Japan, the world’s fourth-largest economy, even as US President Donald Trump’s tariff threats fuel concerns about the export outlook.

site_title: HSBC axes 40 dealmakers in Hong Kong as part of revamp to cut costs: source
summary: HSBC has laid off around 40 investment bankers in Hong Kong as part of a global restructuring exercise to cut costs. The job cuts, which include at least four managing directors, started on Monday, ahead of the bank's full-year results release on Wednesday. The move is part of CEO Georges Elhedery's efforts to revamp the bank, following his leadership takeover in September.

images.alt_text: Once a sprawling behemoth spanning more than 100 countries, HSBC has spent the last decade slowly shrinking its global footprint and exiting low-return businesses.

Georges Elhedery  is reducing costs with a restructuring that has so far included combining the commercial banking division with its global banking and markets unit and pulling out of some underwriting and advisory businesses in Europe and the Americas.
HSBC last year announced it was combining its commercial banking and global banking businesses – as part of a major overhaul under new chief executive officer Georges Elhedery.

site_title: Delta plane flips upside down at Toronto airport, injuring 18
summary: A Delta Air Lines regional jet, operated by Endeavor Air, flipped upside down and caught fire upon landing at Toronto Pearson Airport on Feb 17, injuring 18 of the 80 people on board. Three people, including a child, suffered critical injuries. The cause of the crash is unknown and under investigation by Canadian authorities, with assistance from the US National Transportation Safety Board. The incident occurred amid windy weather following a snowstorm at the airport, leading to ground delays and diversions.

images.alt_text: Delta reported operating revenue of US$15.6 billion, alongside US$843 million in net income in the fourth quarter of 2024.

site_title: TPG proposes to privatise Econ Healthcare in S$88 million deal
summary: US private equity firm TPG is proposing a S$88 million deal to privatize Catalist-listed nursing operator Econ Healthcare through a scheme of arrangement. The offer represents a 20% premium to the counter's last traded price on Jan 14 and offers shareholders a choice of S$0.33 in cash or S$0.224 in cash plus 0.32 Enabler Holdco shares. The deal aims to provide flexibility for the company to focus on long-term execution and save costs associated with maintaining its listed status.

images.alt_text: Econ Healthcare's (Asia) audit committee will undertake a comprehensive review of its investment policy and related controls and safeguards, which will include strengthening the due diligence process.

site_title: Thai Airways set to emerge from debt with plan to double fleet
summary: Thai Airways plans to emerge from debt restructuring by the end of this year, with the resumption of stock trading expected in the second quarter. The airline aims to double its fleet to 143 aircraft by 2029, up from 77 currently. Thai Airways' court-appointed administrator has ordered 45 Boeing aircraft with an option for 35 more, allowing for increased flight capacity. This move is part of an aggressive international expansion plan, five years after the airline filed for bankruptcy protection.

images.alt_text: The airline aims to emerge from its debt-restructuring plan in 2025, five years after it filed for bankruptcy protection.

site_title: Aussie “Big Four” banks cut rates, mirroring central bank
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut its cash rate by 25 basis points to 4.1 per cent, mirroring the rate cuts by Australia's "Big Four" banks: Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, Westpac, and ANZ Group. The rate cuts aim to support economic growth amid inflation concerns. The RBA's decision was its first since November 2020, while the banks' rate cuts will be implemented on various lending products starting February 28 and March 4, respectively.

images.alt_text: Australia’s rate cut will be welcome news for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who must face voters in a general election that is due by May 17 at the latest.

site_title: HP Showcases Cyber Security Preparedness and Care for Society in Commemoration of Total Defence
summary: HP Singapore commemorated Total Defence Day with a commemoration event and participated in Exercise SG Ready (ESR) on February 17, 2025. The event highlighted the importance of being prepared for cyberattacks and disruptions, as well as caring for others in times of crises. HP's employees underwent simulated cyber-attack and power outage tests, assessing their internal response strategies and crisis management procedures. The company reaffirmed its commitment to strengthening Singapore's resilience through innovation and collaboration, with Managing Director Koh Kong Meng emphasizing the need for preparedness in an era of evolving threats.

site_title: Australian central bank cuts rates for first time since November 2020
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut its key interest rate by 0.25 percentage points to 4.1% for the first time in over four years, effective immediately. This decision comes as inflation has dropped from a peak of 7.8% in December 2022 to 2.4%. The RBA remains cautious about further rate reductions due to global turmoil, warning that further easing is uncertain. The rate cut is seen as a welcome move for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese ahead of the general election due by May 17.

images.alt_text: Outside the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) building in Sydney. Photographer: David Gray/Bloomberg

site_title: YouTube is stealthily dominating our living rooms
summary: YouTube has quietly dominated living rooms by taking over the podcast-sphere and video streaming services. In the US, 31% of weekly podcast listeners aged 13 and older used YouTube as their primary app, surpassing Spotify and Apple Podcasts. Younger listeners expect a visual experience, driving podcast creators to produce YouTube-friendly content. YouTube's ad-supported model and lack of funding requirements have contributed to its success, with the platform now accounting for 11.1% of US TV viewing time and reaching a record $10.5 billion in ad sales.

images.alt_text: Joyce Hooi
According to Google, more than 500 hours of video are uploaded to YouTube every minute.
Apple has invested billions of US dollars in original programming over the last few years, earning industry awards and critical praise.
