site_title: Indonesia amends mining law to boost access, support processing
summary: Indonesia's parliament passed a bill to revise the country's mining law, aimed at boosting domestic mineral processing industries and regulating mining access. The amendment gives priority access to mining concessions for companies that build processing facilities, taking into account investment size, value addition, and job creation. Smaller-scale firms, religious groups, and certain private businesses will also receive priority access to mining areas. The revised law is intended to encourage participation from smaller businesses and ensure ore supply security for mineral processing industries, as Indonesia seeks to further develop its domestic metals sector.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's President Prabowo Subianto on Monday (Feb 17) said he had signed a regulation requiring exporters across a wide swathe of Indonesia’s natural resources industry to retain all of their overseas earnings in the country for a year.
Containers at a terminal in Tanjung Priok Port, Jakarta's main seaport, which handles large vessels and high cargo volumes, Jakarta, Indonesia, Jan 24, 2025.

Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto said the fund will invest in sustainable high impact projects across sectors such as renewable energy, advanced manufacturing, downstream industries and food production.

site_title: DeepSeek in running to power China weather agency’s forecasts
summary: China's state weather agency, the China Meteorological Administration (CMA), is considering using DeepSeek, a local startup's AI model, to power its forecasts and observations. DeepSeek has demonstrated a lower-cost AI model competitive with those of OpenAI and Meta Platforms. The CMA discussed integrating and applying DeepSeek in a meeting, with plans to continuously improve the AI meteorological model. This move follows Beijing's apparent shift towards embracing domestic tech companies, with DeepSeek showcasing a breakthrough in AI technology.

site_title: Australia backs Virgin-Qatar Airways tie-up citing improved air services
summary: Australia's competition watchdog has backed a planned alliance between Virgin Australia and Qatar Airways, citing improved air services and products for travelers. The alliance, which includes a 25% stake purchase by Qatar Airways, is awaiting government approval. The two airlines have agreed to operate 28 weekly flights between Australian cities and Doha, starting as early as June, using Qatar Airways aircraft and crew in a "wet leasing" arrangement. The ACCC's draft determination supports the alliance, saying it will benefit consumers with improved services and products.

images.alt_text: It’s the first time Qantas has been pushed from the top spot since early 2022.

site_title: Malaysia to host inaugural summit of Asean, China, Gulf bloc
summary: Malaysia will host the inaugural joint summit of Asean, China, and the Gulf Cooperation Council in May, aiming to enhance regional engagement and ensure Asean's strategic relevance in a multipolar world. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim stated that strengthening ties with emerging economies, such as China and the Gulf Cooperation Council, is not about choosing sides, but rather about maintaining regional stability. The summit comes as tensions between the US and China grow, with Malaysia positioning itself as a neutral base.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim speaks at the Malaysia-Turkey Business Forum during a working visit of President of Turkey Tayyip Erdogan to Malaysia, in Putrajaya, Malaysia, February 11, 2025. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain

site_title: Opec+ considers delaying April supply restart, delegates say
summary: Opec+ is considering delaying its plan to increase oil production by 120,000 barrels per day in April, citing fragile global oil markets. The coalition aims to restore 2.2 million barrels per day by late 2026, but no decision has been made yet. The decision comes as US President Donald Trump urges Opec to "cut the price of oil," despite prices remaining too low for many Opec members to cover government spending.

images.alt_text: Opec and its allies will decide in the next few weeks whether to press on with plans for resuming halted production from April.

site_title: Complaints targeting BYD flood Chinese consumer portal after smart EV launch
summary: Over 4,700 complaints flooded a Chinese auto quality platform about BYD cars following the company's move to offer free smart driving features. The complaints, filed between Feb 11-17, come as a result of a prolonged price war and hyper competitiveness in the Chinese market. BYD cars, including the best-selling Ocean and Dynasty series, took the top 10 spots on the platform's complaint list. The complaints center around customers feeling they overpaid for their cars and seeking free upgrades and compensation from the company. BYD responded to the complaints, passing them on to relevant departments.

images.alt_text: The BYD sign at a dealership in Singapore.
BYD will make its God’s Eye driver-assistance system standard in vehicles priced from 100,000 yuan in China.

site_title: Virgin overtakes Qantas as Australia’s largest domestic airline
summary: Virgin Australia surpassed Qantas as Australia's largest domestic airline, taking 35% of the market share in December, while Qantas held 34.6%. This marks the first time Qantas has been pushed from the top spot since early 2022. Virgin's success was attributed to its ability to pick up passengers after the collapse of regional carrier Rex, and it had the busiest December in its 24-year history. The airline's reliability, with only 0.6% of flights scrapped, also contrasted with Qantas' 2.7% cancellation rate.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A passenger walks past a Qantas Airways emblem at the Sydney International Airport terminal July 18, 2014. REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: NVPC’s Great Singapore Give campaign encourages more volunteering, donation efforts
summary: The National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) has concluded its 4-month-long Great Singapore Give (GSG) campaign, encouraging corporates and charities to participate in volunteerism and donations. The campaign, which ran from November 2024 to February 2025, involved over 300 partners and 135 corporate organizations, raising more than S$74,000 for various charities. The campaign's recurring donation feature and volunteering learning journeys helped charities reach a wider audience and inspire more contributions. NVPC aims to cultivate deeper and more meaningful giving activities, with plans to continue launching initiatives for SG60 this year.

images.alt_text: President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (centre in red) and Jane Ittogi (centre in green) with the PVPA winners on Wednesday.
Vincenzo Vinzi, dean and president of Essec Business School (left) and Tony Soh, chief executive of NVPC, at the MOU signing.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sri Trang Agro-Industry, Sri Trang Gloves, Oiltek International, Aoxin Q&M
summary: Sri Trang Agro-Industry swung to a net profit of 854.3 million baht for its fourth quarter, while Sri Trang Gloves posted a net profit of 556.7 million baht, both turnaround from previous net losses. Oiltek International applied to move its listing from the Singapore Exchange Catalist board to the mainboard, and Aoxin Q&M Dental Group's largest shareholder called for an extraordinary general meeting to remove its executive director.

site_title: RBNZ set to deliver third half-point rate cut to revive economy
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) is set to cut interest rates for the third time this year, lowering the Official Cash Rate (OCR) by 50 basis points to 3.75% on February 19. The move aims to revive economic growth, which contracted 2.1% last year. Projections indicate the OCR will continue to fall towards 3%, but in smaller steps, with a 40% chance of a third 25-point reduction by the end of the year. The decision comes amid uncertainty over global growth and inflation due to US policy changes.

images.alt_text: Net arrivals of foreigners dropped by more than 97,000 from 2023 but were still the second-highest on record at around 74,100, today’s report showed.

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand began cutting interest rates in August and is tipped to maintain an aggressive pace with another 50 basis-point reduction next week, taking the Official Cash Rate to 3.75 per cent.
New Zealand has one of the world’s most prohibitive policies on foreigners buying residential real estate.

site_title: OpenAI co-founder Sutskever’s startup is fundraising at US$30 billion-plus valuation
summary: OpenAI co-founder Ilya Sutskever's startup, Safe Superintelligence, is fundraising at a valuation of over US$30 billion, according to a source. The round, led by Greenoaks Capital Partners, aims to raise more than US$1 billion, with the venture capital firm planning to invest US$500 million. This valuation jump marks a significant increase from the US$5 billion valuation before, making Safe Superintelligence one of the world's most valuable private technology companies.

images.alt_text: Ilya Sutskever has long been a prominent researcher in the AI field.

site_title: China's Xi tells business leaders private sector challenges 'surmountable'
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has reassured business leaders, including Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma, that the challenges facing China's private sector are "surmountable" and "temporary." During a meeting, Xi emphasized that the difficulties are partial, temporary, and solvable, urging entrepreneurs to "unify thought and action" around the ruling Communist Party's economic policies. Xi also pledged to remove obstacles to commerce, promote fair competition, and protect business interests, as China battles a slowing economy and high youth unemployment.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping has long stressed the need for China to achieve self-sufficiency in semiconductors and wants the country to use AI to drive economic development.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 17)
summary: Singapore's IPO scene is expected to rebound in 2025 with a pipeline of Reits, healthcare, and new economy candidates. The country's key exports declined 2.1% in January due to distortions from the Chinese New Year. New home sales surged 256% in January, driven by new project launches. PropertyGuru laid off 174 employees and shut three business units. Pritam Singh was fined S$7,000 for lying to Parliament, but his eligibility for election remains unaffected.

images.alt_text: MTI's growth forecast range for 2025 remains unchanged at 1 to 3 per cent.

site_title: Dubai developers score red-hot profits from global homebuyers
summary: Dubai's luxury property market has seen a surge in profits and record sales, driven by expats and overseas buyers. Developers such as Emaar Development and Binghatti Holding reported significant earnings increases, with Emaar's profit doubling to 7.6 billion dirhams in 2024. The market is expected to continue rising, with analysts predicting a 16.9% increase in prime real estate value in 2024, driven by population growth and the government's liberal visa policies. Property firms are now using their profits to build new projects to attract more buyers.

images.alt_text: The waterfront of the Palm Jumeirah in Dubai. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil rises as drone strikes Caspian pump station, while Russia-Ukraine peace talks loom
summary: Oil prices rose 48 US cents to $75.22 a barrel as drone strikes on a Russian oil pipeline pumping station in the Caspian Sea slowed oil flows from Kazakhstan, supporting prices. The US dollar index also boosted oil prices, making crude less expensive for non-US buyers. The strikes, attributed to Ukraine, are a concern for supply risks, while a possible Moscow-Kiev ceasefire agreement could ease sanctions and increase global supplies.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures slid 20 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to US$74.59 a barrel by 0112 GMT on Monday.

site_title: South Korea aims to secure 10,000 GPUs for national AI computing centre
summary: South Korea plans to secure 10,000 high-performance GPUs within this year to keep pace with the global AI race. The move aims to launch services at its national AI computing centre early, despite a US regulation restricting the export of advanced AI chips and technology. South Korea is exempt from the restrictions, but the government will still work with private companies to finalize details such as budget and GPU models by September. This comes as the global AI industry faces increased competition and the emergence of Chinese startups like DeepSeek.

images.alt_text: The outlook for chip sales is turning less optimistic this year as growth in shipments has slowed in recent months.
FILE PHOTO: The deepseek logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration taken January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
outh Korea faces lingering uncertainty over President Donald Trump’s threats to impose tariffs.

site_title: BHP sees recovery in steel and copper demand, logs lowest profit in six years
summary: BHP, the world's largest listed miner, reported its lowest first-half profit in six years, with an underlying attributable profit of US$5.08 billion, down 23% from last year. Despite global economic and trade uncertainties, demand for BHP's products, including steel and copper, remained strong, driven by central bank rate cuts and early signs of recovery in China. The company expects a near-term recovery for steel and copper demand across the OECD, but notes potential risks from trade tensions.

images.alt_text: This file photo taken on February 21, 2023 shows the company logo adorning the side of the BHP global headquarters in Melbourne. Mining giant BHP reported an 86 percent slump in half-year net profit on February 20, 2024, hit by a write-down of its nickel assets and costs related to a 2015 Brazilian mining disaster. (Photo by William WEST / AFP)

BHP’s fiscal 2024 profit was underpinned by a record iron ore output for a second straight year and resilient average realised prices, which offset weak coal prices and the sale of two of its coal mines.

site_title: TransportBT: The future of EV charging in Singapore - Insights from SP Group
summary: SP Group's Dean Cher discusses the future of electric vehicle (EV) charging in Singapore, highlighting the country's existing 15,000 EV charging stations. Cher shares insights on the technicalities of EV charging infrastructure and the company's role in sustainable energy solutions. The conversation provides an overview of the EV charging landscape in Singapore, offering a glimpse into the country's efforts to support the growth of electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro
Nine new Chinese car brands made their debut at the Singapore Motorshow 2025.
More than 40 per cent of new light goods vehicles registered in Singapore are now electric.
Details on the cost and scale of HSBC's investment in SP Mobility were not released.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M’s largest shareholder calls for EGM to oust executive director
summary: Aoxin Q&M's largest shareholder, Q&M Dental Group (Singapore), has called for an extraordinary general meeting to remove executive director Ong Siew Hwa, citing two reasons: the expiration of Acumen Diagnostics' clinical laboratory licence and Ong's failure to resign from her position as Aoxin's director despite being obliged to do so under a service agreement. The meeting must be held by April 16, and the resolution aims to oust Ong with immediate effect.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Q&M Dental says Acumen's lab business volume has been "small" since the shift away from PCR testing in Singapore for Covid-19 since late 2022.
One of Acumen Diagnostic's labs had to cease operations on Sep 15 as its licence had lapsed.
Q&M's proposed acquisition is in line with expansion plans of its main business in Singapore.

Q&M Dental's proposed H1 dividend
of S$0.004 per share represents a a 150 per cent increase over the prior year.

Under the arbitration filed, QDGM had sought – amongst others – a declaration that it had validly exercised its rights under the shareholders agreement requiring Tye, Chong and Chan to buy back QDGM’s 70 per cent stake in AR Dental.
Dr Ng Chin Siau, Group CEO (left), and Dr Raymond Ang, Executive Director and COO of Q&M Dental Group.

site_title: The revolt against regulation
summary: US President Donald Trump's push for deregulation is unlikely to yield substantial benefits, as regulatory burdens are difficult to measure. Despite claims of increasing regulations, there is no evidence that regulation has become systematically heavier over the last decade. The European Commission also aims to reduce "administrative burdens" by 25%. Critics argue that deregulation is driven by a bias towards special interest groups, potentially harming the economy.

images.alt_text: The EU has historically used omnibus Bills sparingly, reserving them for modernising outdated regulatory frameworks in areas such as consumer protection and financial supervision.

site_title: Southwest Airlines to cut 15% of corporate jobs in first-ever layoffs
summary: Southwest Airlines is cutting 1,750 corporate jobs, about 15% of its leadership positions, marking the carrier's first-ever layoffs. The job cuts are expected to result in $210 million in savings this year and $300 million next year. The reductions will impact senior leadership and directors, starting in late April and expected to be substantially complete by the end of the second quarter. The move comes as the airline rethinks its business model and faces operational changes and financial pressures.

images.alt_text: The crash in Canada comes after some other recent crashes in North America in late January.

site_title: Japan’s historic rate shift is turbo-charging the credit market
summary: Japan's corporate bond market is booming, with 14.7 trillion yen (S$130 billion) in local-currency bonds sold in the current fiscal year, a record. Companies are issuing bonds ahead of anticipated rate hikes, which will push up future borrowing costs. The median forecast of economists is for rates to climb to 1.1% in 2027. Despite concerns about higher rates, many executives see it as a sign of growth and a reflection of Japan's long-anticipated economic recovery. The surge in bond issuance is also driven by governance changes, including rising investor activism and guidance by the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

images.alt_text: Strong domestic demand is helping support a recovery in Japan, the world’s fourth-largest economy, even as US President Donald Trump’s tariff threats fuel concerns about the export outlook.
Import prices may rise further as hot US inflation data on Wednesday led to receding market expectations of near-term US interest rate cut.

Japan's overall consumer price index rose 3.6 per cent in December from a year earlier, much faster than a 3.0 per cent gain in the core index that strips away the effect of volatile fresh food prices.

Honda Motor vehicles bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan, Feb 6, 2025. Japan's trade deficit narrowed by 40 per cent to 3.9 trillion yen on brisk exports of automobiles and chipmaking equipment as well as lower costs of energy imports.

site_title: Renault, Geely deepen partnership with Brazil car sales plan
summary: Renault and Geely Holding Group plan to jointly produce and sell electric and low-emissions vehicles in Brazil. Geely will invest in Renault's Brazilian unit, gaining access to its production, sales, and services network in the country. This agreement deepens the partnership between the two automakers, which are already working together on combustion-engine and hybrid powertrains. The venture is subject to definitive agreements and regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the logo of Chinese automobile manufacturer Geely at a dealership in Moscow, Russia, March 23, 2023. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov

site_title: Indonesia forces exporters to keep more earnings onshore
summary: Indonesia's President Prabowo Subianto has signed a regulation requiring exporters of natural resources to retain all overseas earnings in the country for a year, aiming to bolster the central bank's foreign exchange reserves by $80 billion. The new rule, effective in March, will apply to mining, plantation, forestry, and fisheries sectors, but not to oil and gas exporters. The move aims to reverse a slide in the country's beleaguered currency and boost domestic financing, with officials estimating it will add to the central bank's reserves this year.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's President Prabowo Subianto and Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba (not pictured) give a press statement following their meeting at the presidential palace in Bogor, West Java, on January 11, 2025. (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP)

site_title: Myanmar rescues 1,000 scam centre workers as crackdown widens
summary: Myanmar's military government has rescued approximately 1,000 foreign nationals from online scam centers near the Thai border, mostly from Asian countries including China and India. The victims will be sent back to their home countries after verification of their personal details. The crackdown, launched in response to high-profile trafficking and pressure from neighbors Thailand and China, aims to deport 10,000 foreign nationals working in scam centers in areas controlled by the junta-allied armed group.

images.alt_text: Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra says: “There is no hesitation on this. We can cut off power immediately. We must take care of our people first. This has had a significant impact on Thais and the country’s image.”
While the call-centre scams have been around for years, the issue recently took on greater importance, especially for officials in Beijing and Bangkok.

Scam compounds have mushroomed in Myanmar’s borderlands and are staffed by foreigners who are often trafficked and forced to work, swindling their compatriots in an industry analysts say is worth billions of dollars.

site_title: Singapore at 60: Embracing openness amid global challenges
summary: Singapore is celebrating its 60th anniversary of independence, with the government focusing on economic management to maintain high living standards. The 2024 Budget includes the SkillsFuture Level-Up Programme for mid-career workers aged 40 and above, providing enhanced support for upskilling. The government acknowledges the threat of global economic fragmentation and the need for openness to thrive, particularly with free trade facing significant challenges. Embracing openness and investing in human capital are seen as key strategies to maintain Singapore's relevance on the global stage.

images.alt_text: More incentives to spur innovation in the Singapore economy are expected

site_title: Singapore says Asia sees US as ‘landlord seeking rent’
summary: Singapore's Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen stated that the US has shifted from a moral legitimacy to a "landlord seeking rent" in Asia, reflecting a change in perceptions of the US since World War II. This shift is exemplified by the US' willingness to directly negotiate with Russia over Ukraine, a move seen as undermining Nato allies. The US has also proposed a minerals deal to Ukraine, which has been rejected, and US President Trump has suggested Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky participate in peace talks with Russia.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve's legal status is complicated, but there's no fundamental constitutional principle saying that elected officials must keep their hands off the money supply.

site_title: Thailand tightens proposed casino rules amid growing opposition
summary: Thailand has revised its casino bill to address growing concerns about problem gambling, requiring casinos to make up no more than 10% of their host venue and creating disclosure requirements for locals. The bill also mandates that casinos be separated from other businesses and that Thai nationals be hired to work in the complexes. The Thai government aims to pass the bill this year to draw foreign investment and collect taxes, with potential revenue reaching $9.1 billion. Despite opposition from locals, the revised bill is expected to be approved by the cabinet and then the House of Representatives.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s potential as a gaming destination, with casinos proposed in the capital Bangkok, on the holiday island of Phuket, and three other sites, is underpinned by its role as a regional magnet for tourism.

About 59 per cent of respondents say they disagree with investments in both casinos and so-called entertainment complexes in Thailand, according to the Jan 20-21 survey by the National Institute of Development Administration.

site_title: Talent crunch pushing Singapore’s financial sector to rewrite operations playbook to retain staff
summary: Singapore's financial sector is facing a talent crunch, prompting banks to re-evaluate their operations and employee retention strategies. To address the shortage, firms are adopting alternative approaches, such as offering flexible work arrangements, redefining seniority based on performance, and reskilling existing employees. Market players also highlight the growing demand for skilled professionals in areas like data analytics, cybersecurity, and green finance. As the sector continues to evolve, companies are expected to prioritize internal hiring and talent development to remain competitive.

images.alt_text:

Generic pix of office workers wearing their masks while on their mobile phones at the UOB Plaza office workers near Raffles Place on 22 Aug 2022.
Ranamita Chakraborty

site_title: Kallang/Whampoa, Queenstown BTO projects most popular in Feb launch, but overall demand muted
summary: Singapore's latest Build-To-Order (BTO) sales exercise saw four-room flats in city-fringe estates Kallang/Whampoa and Queenstown being the most popular among first-timer families, with Tanjong Rhu Parc Front being the top choice. However, overall demand was muted due to the concurrent Sale of Balance Flats (SBF) exercise. The first-timer application rate for BTO flats was lower than in previous years, with National Development Minister Desmond Lee attributing it to a more balanced demand-supply situation in the BTO market. Despite this, analysts expect a steady increase in the number of new flats completing their minimum occupation period (MOP) in the coming years.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mark record closing high as defence stocks soar
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index reached a record closing high of 555.42 points, driven by a 0.5% gain, with defence stocks leading the sector. Defence companies such as Leonardo, Saab, and BAE Systems surged, while Thyssenkrupp and Rheinmetall also saw significant gains. The European Commission is set to propose exempting defence spending from EU limits, amid US pressure for increased military spending in the region. Higher bond yields and lower real estate stocks were notable laggards, as investors priced in increased European bond issuance to fund defence spending.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index settled down by 0.3 per cent, after closing the previous four sessions at record high levels.

site_title: Malaysian PM says Petronas will stick to contract commitments
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has assured that state energy firm Petronas will maintain all its contractual obligations, despite a deadlock in talks with Sarawak's Petros over gas distribution. Petros will serve as Sarawak's gas aggregator, and Petronas will continue to provide natural gas for the state's domestic needs. The agreement follows a 2016 state ordinance and aims to ensure transparent commercial principles and cooperation between the two entities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Malaysian energy group National Petroleum Limited, commonly known as PETRONAS, is displayed at their booth during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: New home sales surge 256% on year in January, buoyed by new project launches
summary: New home sales in Singapore surged 256% in January, with 1,083 units sold excluding executive condominiums, the highest volume since 2021. This rebounded from the seasonally low December sales. Major launches, including the 113-unit Bagnall Haus and 777-unit The Orie, contributed to the strong sales. Analysts expect continued demand for new projects, with the 501-unit Elta in Clementi anticipated to sell well on its launch weekend.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng

site_title: Sri Trang Agro-Industry swings back to black with Q4 profit of 854.3 million baht
summary: Sri Trang Agro-Industry, a Thai agri-commodity player, has reported a net profit of 854.3 million baht for its fourth quarter, reversing a net loss of 422 million baht in the previous period. Revenue increased 53.2% to 33.3 billion baht, driven by higher contributions from the natural rubber and gloves segments, with the gloves segment recording a 30.2% revenue increase. The company's full-year net profit is 1.7 billion baht, with a dividend of one baht per share approved by the board.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The company posts a net profit of 517.3 million baht for Q3, up from a loss of 410.2 million baht in the same period last year.

Crude palm oil prices continue to be under pressure due to competition from alternative edible oils, uncertainties over import demand, and expected supply shocks from the La Nina event in the second half-year.
Heavy rainfall could increase the chances of diseases for rubber trees and reduce the number of tapping days, the company says.

site_title: SIA Group logs 8.6% growth in January passenger traffic on Chinese New Year travel rush
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) Group reported an 8.6% increase in January passenger traffic, driven by robust travel demand during the Chinese New Year holiday season. The airline carried 2.4 million passengers, up from 2.1 million last year, while its low-cost arm Scoot ferried 1.2 million passengers, up from 1.1 million. Cargo loads grew 2.6% but trailed behind the 9.5% expansion in cargo capacity. The airline's net profit for the second quarter ended September 2024 decreased 59% to S$290 million.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Generics of SIA and Scoot：SIA , Scoot, 新航，新加坡航空公司，酷航，Singapore Airlines，飞机，客机。

site_title: TikTok grabs US market share from Shein despite looming risks
summary: TikTok's e-commerce feature, TikTok Shop, has seen significant sales growth in the US, outpacing competitors Shein and Temu, with sales increasing 153% in January. TikTok Shop has also gained market share from Shein, with a 16% increase in transactions valued over $25. However, TikTok's future in the US remains uncertain due to the threat of a ban if it fails to sell the US portion of its business, amid President Trump's trade actions and potential tariffs on Chinese exports.

images.alt_text: Food delivery has rebounded in 2024, with GMV growth touching double digits after two years of muted growth.
TikTok’s fate has been up in the air since a law requiring ByteDance to either sell it on national security grounds or face a ban took effect on Jan 19.
Apple confirmed that TikTok will return to its US app store on Thursday evening.
Apple and Google have still not reinstated TikTok to the App Stores.
YouTube is the latest TikTok competitor to try to capitalise on the app’s looming US ban, which could go into effect in early April.
The app is used by 170 million Americans.

site_title: Trump vs the international trade order
summary: President Donald Trump announced a "reciprocal trade policy" where the US will tax foreign imports at the same rate as other countries apply to American products, aiming to restore American manufacturing might and reduce US trade deficits. However, experts question the feasibility of this policy due to its complexity and potential trade disruptions. The US will not immediately impose tariffs, instead ordering federal agencies to investigate adjusting tariffs to those of other countries. The move is seen as a potential shock to the international trade order, raising concerns about the impact on global trade and economies.

images.alt_text: The financial pull of the US is relatively undiminished, despite predictions of its demise at the hands of emerging markets or the newly integrated eurozone.

US President Donald Trump has been promising to introduce reciprocal tariffs, but Thursday’s directive stopped well short of that, instead kicking off what will be weeks or months of investigation into the levies imposed on US goods by other trading partners and then devising a response.

site_title: Oiltek applies to transfer listing to SGX mainboard
summary: Oiltek International has applied to transfer its listing from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Catalist board to the mainboard, citing enhanced image, better liquidity, and improved share performance. The company, which designs and commercializes plants in over 35 countries, has seen consistent growth, with net profit increasing to RM29.6 million in FY2024. The proposed transfer is subject to SGX approval and shareholder approval via a special resolution. Oiltek shares rose 1.7% on the news, and the company believes the move will provide a wider platform for future fundraising and access to a larger investor market.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Oiltek is trading at 15 times based on FY2025 estimates, which is at a discount of about 25 per cent compared to its peers’ average of 21 times.
Oiltek unit bags RM19.5 million in new contracts

site_title: Musk’s DOGE begins firing workers at US federal IT department
summary: Elon Musk's DOGE team is terminating over a dozen US Digital Service (USDS) employees, citing President Donald Trump's executive order establishing the Department of Government Efficiency. The terminations are part of a wave of thousands of federal government layoffs, aimed at rapidly overhauling the bureaucracy. The USDS, a group of federal IT workers, has been used by Musk's group as a vehicle to hire his own team, despite being part of the same entity as the US DOGE Service. The layoffs are the latest in Musk's efforts to overhaul the federal government.

images.alt_text: Tech billionaire Elon Musk speaks as US President Donald Trump looks on in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, Feb 11, 2025. Musk, who has been tapped by Trump to lead federal cost-cutting efforts, said the United States would go "bankrupt" without budget cuts.
Musk’s 42 per cent stake in SpaceX is currently worth US$136 billion, or roughly the same amount as the value of his shares at market close.

The decision to shutter the Washington offices comes less than 24 hours after Russell Vought, President Donald Trump’s newly installed acting CFPB chief, suspended all activities, including supervision of companies overseen by the agency.
Elon Musk, the world’s richest person, is leading President Donald Trump’s federal cost-cutting efforts under the so-called Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).
Speaking more broadly about cutting US expenses and fraud, Elon Musk estimated the Trump administration can cut US$1 trillion from the US deficit next year.

site_title: Amid divergent trends, opportunities arise in small/mid-cap equities and quality income
summary: US markets are expected to benefit from pro-US business, pro-growth, and pro-innovation policies under the new administration, potentially leading to reflation and easing concerns over higher valuations. Small to mid-cap stocks and high-quality income are seen as attractive opportunities, particularly in sectors like technology and defensive stocks. Investors should diversify but remain nimble, with a focus on quality opportunities and defensive assets, such as US investment-grade bonds and Asian investment-grade bonds, to shelter against potential market volatility.

images.alt_text: Several Fed officials have said they want to wait until inflation ebbs and for further clarity on President Donald Trump’s economic plans before lowering borrowing costs.
Trump has ushered in digital-asset initiatives that augur more openness to fintech firms, which proliferated by offering cheaper products and faster payment alternatives than banks.

site_title: The exasperating state of modern marketing
summary: Starbucks is implementing a plan to boost sales by encouraging staff to write personalized notes on coffee cups, including messages such as "you're amazing" and "seize the day". However, critics argue that the messages are insincere and time-consuming, and that the company is overstepping the boundaries of customer service. The idea is part of a larger turnaround strategy by new CEO Brian Niccol, who aims to create "moments of connection" with customers. Similar criticisms have been leveled at Eurostar, which has faced backlash for reciting a corporate slogan during train announcements.

images.alt_text: Local celebrities Li Nanxing (left) and Gurmit Singh now have AI avatars on idoLive, which can handle endorsements at a fraction of the usual price.
Alleged rape at the Confederation of British Industry's (CBI) events suggests that perhaps the “alcohol explanation” is still alive and being used to cover unacceptable activities.

site_title: Books Kinokuniya flagship store in Takashimaya to downsize, space to be partly taken over by new cafe
summary: Kinokuniya's flagship store in Takashimaya Shopping Centre will downsize to 38,000 sq ft, with a portion of the space being taken over by a new cafe. The reduction comes after rental negotiations with the landlord, Toshin Development. The store had previously occupied a 42,000 sq ft space from 1999 to 2013 and restored 5,000 sq ft in 2016. The downsizing is part of the bookstore's efforts to "refine its book collection while incorporating a lifestyle element" as the industry faces declining sales and high rents.

site_title: Evergrande, HNA units ordered to liquidate by Hong Kong judge
summary: A Hong Kong judge ordered the liquidation of two Chinese companies, Tianji Holding, a unit of China Evergrande Group, and an investment arm of HNA Group, citing insolvency. The moves follow a string of court hearings and come as creditors seek to recover funds from distressed companies. The liquidations are a result of the prolonged property crisis in China, which left many firms with large debt piles. The decisions aim to protect creditors and allow administrators to seize assets, following a similar liquidation order for Evergrande's parent company in 2024.

images.alt_text: The company, an electric vehicle (EV) unit of debt-laden property developer China Evergrande, said that it is still looking for strategic investors as it seeks solutions to stabilise operations and address its liquidity crisis.
Sunac China Holdings, one of the first major developers to restructure its offshore debt, said last week that it can’t rule out a second restructuring.
FILE PHOTO: The company logo is seen on the headquarters of China Evergrande Group in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China September 26, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Sri Trang Gloves back in the black with 556.7 million baht in Q4 net profit
summary: Sri Trang Gloves, a Thai glove maker, reported a net profit of 556.7 million baht in the fourth quarter of 2024, a turnaround from a net loss of 59.9 million baht in the same period last year. Revenue rose 27.6% and sales volume increased 18% year-over-year. The company plans to focus on specialty gloves and widen its customer base to over 190 countries. It also proposed a dividend of 0.50 baht per share, up from 0.25 baht last year.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Sri Trang Gloves says it will continue to reduce production costs through automation to eliminate redundancies and achieve economies of scale.
Sri Trang Gloves (Thailand) says it will continue to undertake cost-saving initiatives to achieve economies of scale.

site_title: Indonesia’s trade surplus hits US$3.5 billion in January, but trade tensions threaten outlook
summary: Indonesia recorded a trade surplus of US$3.5 billion in January, driven by 2.7% year-on-year decline in imports, mainly due to weaker demand for consumer goods and raw materials. This marks the country's 57th consecutive month of surplus. However, analysts warn that sustaining this surplus could become challenging due to escalating trade tensions, particularly with US President Donald Trump's tariff threats against countries with trade imbalances with the US.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Indonesia plans to launch a second sovereign wealth fund named Danantara Indonesia on Feb 24, which aims to manage assets exceeding US$900 billion.
Workers protesting at eFishery's headquarters.

Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto said the fund will invest in sustainable high impact projects across sectors such as renewable energy, advanced manufacturing, downstream industries and food production.
Indonesia does not have a free trade agreement or Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with Washington.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, February 17, 2025
summary: Asia markets rose on Monday, with Hong Kong's tech sector driving growth. Japan reported strong economic growth, while gold prices are near record highs. However, oil prices struggled. The Asian markets are reacting to a mix of economic indicators and global market trends. The strong performance of Hong Kong's tech sector suggests a positive outlook for the region's economy.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.3%
Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Jakarta and Wellington stocks rose but Sydney and Manila stocks slipped on Monday.
Strong domestic demand is helping support a recovery in Japan, the world’s fourth-largest economy, even as US President Donald Trump’s tariff threats fuel concerns about the export outlook.
Spot gold rose 0.1 per cent to US$2,885.95 per ounce.

site_title: China’s electric Farizon SuperVan makes Apac debut in Singapore
summary: China's Farizon SuperVan, a full-electric light goods vehicle, made its debut in Singapore on February 18, launched by distributor Hong Seh Motors. The van features advanced technology from passenger electric vehicles, including direct-current fast charging and drive-by-wire controls. Priced at S$80,000, it includes a S$15,000 rebate under the Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme. With 10 units pre-sold, Farizon aims to take market share from popular models like the Toyota Hiace and Ford Transit, contributing to the brand's global sales targets of 150,000 vehicles in 2024.

images.alt_text: Farizon Supervan launches in Singapore on Feb 18 2025 by distributor Hong Seh Motors.
Derryn Wong

site_title: Shein faces investor pressure to slash valuation to US$30 billion: sources
summary: Shein, a fast-fashion retailer, faces pressure from investors to slash its valuation to US$30 billion as it attempts to secure a UK initial public offering (IPO). The company's valuation has been questioned due to concerns over supply-chain operations and labor practices, as well as uncertainty over global trade relations and US President Donald Trump's policies. Shein's investors, including IDG Capital and Tiger Global Management, are urging the company to adjust its valuation to make the IPO more feasible.

images.alt_text: Prices will rise for Americans who buy US$5 shirts, US$10 lamps and US$20 shoes on direct-from-China shopping sites like Shein and Temu after US President Donald Trump this week imposed 10 per cent tariffs on goods from China.
FILE PHOTO: Shein and Temu app icons are seen in this illustration taken August 22, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
Tensions are already running high between Shein and Temu and their suppliers and merchants in China.
Nearly half of all packages shipped under ‘de minimis’ come from China, the US congressional committee on China said in a June 2023 report.
Temu and Shein together likely accounted for more than 30 per cent of all packages shipped to the US each day under the de minimis provision.
Companies found to have broken the law can be hit by fines by national regulators in individual EU member states.
Customs data from the 27 national authorities will be pooled and a new central EU customs authority (Euca) set up, according to the FT.
Shein was valued at US$66 billion in a fundraising round last year.

site_title: Asia: Most markets start week on positive note
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, with Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Jakarta, and Wellington stocks increasing, while Sydney and Manila slipped. Investors assessed the global economic outlook amid uncertainty from US President Donald Trump's trade war. Tariffs on key trading partners remain a significant risk factor for financial markets, according to Stephen Innes of SPI Asset Management. Despite this, some markets, such as Hong Kong, extended their rally fueled by tech firms and reports of Chinese President Xi Jinping meeting with top entrepreneurs.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.3%

site_title: MBS gets record S$12 billion loan; DBS, OCBC, UOB, Maybank coordinating facility
summary: Marina Bay Sands has secured a record-breaking S$12 billion loan from DBS, OCBC, UOB, and Maybank to fund its expansion plans. The loan, the largest in Singapore's history, will be used for refinancing and to support the development of the integrated resort. The move comes as Singapore's tourism industry has rebounded sharply since the pandemic, providing a favorable backdrop for Marina Bay Sands' expansion plans.

images.alt_text: Occupancy at MBS is largely stable for the quarter.
Even though integrated resorts in other parts of the world might not be fully rebranding or repositioning themselves, they are certainly reinvesting and elevating," says MBS COO Paul Town.
Construction of the new tower is scheduled to commence in June 2025, and is expected to be completed by June 2030, with an estimated official opening in January 2031.

site_title: Card-issuing banks in Singapore to require additional verification for mobile wallet users
summary: Major card-issuing banks in Singapore will require additional verification for mobile wallet users starting by July 2025 to prevent phishing scams involving fraudulent card provisioning into mobile wallets. This move follows a rise in such scams, resulting in losses of S$53.9 million in Q4 2024. Banks will implement measures such as in-app controls or digital token authentication to enhance fraud surveillance, and will also remove provisioned cards if there are indicators of fraudulent activity. Customers are advised to set low card transaction notification thresholds and contact their banks immediately if they notice any unauthorized use.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Biometric technologies could help to secure in-store and even online purchases.
Accused Zhang Tianyu (second from left) walking past Li Xueqi (middle, in white top) and Xu Zhaochen (right, in white top) at the iStudio store in Bugis Junction on Nov 14.

site_title: Higher costs, profit squeeze keeping more SMEs up at night: QBE survey
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are facing significant challenges in 2025, with 2/3 citing increased costs and reduced profitability as top business challenges. Only 52% of respondents expect a more positive economic outlook for the year ahead, down from 60% in 2024. Rising operating costs, inflation, and a goods and services tax hike are expected to have a negative impact on the economy. Despite this, 55% of respondents expect to achieve better sales in 2025, and many are taking action to tackle the challenges, including cost control measures and diversification of customer bases.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Despite the risks of AI, half of the SMEs polled note that it has the potential to have a mostly positive impact on their business productivity.

site_title: Indonesia’s INA, Japan’s DBJ launch hybrid fund for mid-sized businesses
summary: INA, Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund, and Japan's DBJ have launched a hybrid fund to provide financing for medium-sized businesses in Indonesia. The fund will offer tailored financing solutions, focusing on senior secured investments to support businesses scaling sustainably. This move aims to address the capital requirements of mid and upper-market corporates, providing an alternative to traditional financing. The hybrid capital solutions are gaining momentum in the Asia-Pacific region, driven by the need for alternative financing options.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto said the fund will invest in sustainable high impact projects across sectors such as renewable energy, advanced manufacturing, downstream industries and food production.
Indonesia does not have a free trade agreement or Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with Washington.
President Prabowo Subianto wants to build 3 million affordable houses each year.

site_title: Is S$2.5 million an affordable price tag for a new leasehold 3-bedroom condo?
summary: New condo prices in Singapore may be becoming unaffordable for high-income earners, with a $2.5 million unit costing around 8.6 times the average annual household income of the second-highest decile of residents. To afford such a home, a household would need to spend 32% of its monthly income on mortgage repayments, straining finances. However, some buyers may be able to afford new condos through enhanced buying power from selling HDB flats, family help, or financial gains. Alternative options, such as resale condos or HDB flats, may be more affordable for high-income earners.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
The new condo Parktown Residence is part of an integrated development featuring a retail mall, the future Tampines North MRT station and a community club
The new condo Elta in Clementi Avenue 1 will house 501 units in two 39-storey blocks.
Located in Toa Payoh, The Orie has 777 units across two 40-storey towers.

site_title: PropertyGuru axes 174 employees, shuts 3 business units
summary: PropertyGuru, a property platform taken private by EQT Capital, has laid off 174 employees (12% of its workforce) across three business units, including Sendhelper, data and software solutions, and PropertyGuru Finance. The company aims to streamline operations and focus on its marketplace business, prioritizing core markets in Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Thailand. Affected employees will receive severance packages, including one month's salary per year of service, performance bonuses, and outplacement assistance.

images.alt_text: 0521 Yy / 陈嘉定 / PropertyGuru Group
Benjamin Cher

site_title: Bain Capital ends acquisition battle with KKR for Fuji Soft
summary: US private equity firm Bain Capital will not launch a tender offer for Fuji Soft, ending a takeover battle with rival KKR. The decision comes after KKR raised its offer price to 9,850 yen per share, above Bain's most recent offer. Bain had argued that the rejection from Fuji Soft's board harmed minority shareholders' interests. The saga highlights the increasingly competitive dealmaking environment in Japan, where global firms target underutilized assets or ineffective corporate governance. Fuji Soft's shares were traded at the KKR-offered price on Monday morning.

images.alt_text: Bain’s possible concession would bring to an end months of intense competition with its US rival to take control of Fuji Soft.
KKR increased its tender offer for Fuji Soft to 9,850 yen per share, putting it above the 9,600 yen per share that Bain Capital said it planned to offer.
KKR will pay 9,451 yen (S$81.49) for each Fuji Soft share, an increase from the 8,800 yen it originally offered and one yen more than Bain’s proposal.

site_title: Why did Microsoft admit that AI is making us dumb?
summary: Microsoft's research paper reveals a disturbing trend: as workers trust AI more, they rely less on critical thinking skills, leading to atrophy in areas such as writing, analysis, and evaluation. A study of 319 knowledge workers found that increased AI usage resulted in decreased self-reported skills in these areas, with some respondents doubting their abilities and automatically accepting AI-generated content. Microsoft's $80 billion AI investment may be an attempt to stay ahead in a rapidly changing job market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo is seen in this illustration taken, March 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
French startup Emobot has created a bot that uses AI to track the emotional state of the elderly to detect depression, anxiety and other mental health concerns.
OpenAI has only given vague outlines of the data it used to create ChatGPT, which included books, websites and other texts.

site_title: New 'Captain America' crushes competition in North American theatres
summary: "Marvel's 'Captain America: Brave New World' dominated the North American box office this weekend, earning an estimated $100 million, despite lukewarm reviews and audience scores. The film's strong opening comes as analysts downplay concerns of superhero fatigue. 'Paddington in Peru' took second place, while 'Dog Man' and 'Heart Eyes' rounded out the top five, with 'Ne Zha 2' earning over $1 billion in China since its release."

images.alt_text: (From left) Tessa Ross, Peter Straughan, Edward Berger, Isabella Rossellini, Juliette Howell, Ralph Fiennes and Michael Jackman pose with the Best Film award for 'Conclave' during the Bafta Film Awards at the Royal Festival Hall in London, Britain, Feb 16, 2025.

site_title: Does Bitcoin deserve a place in your portfolio?
summary: Bitcoin, launched in 2009, has seen a 165% return on investment if held from January 2011 to December 2024. Despite volatility, the cryptocurrency has broken records, with its price exceeding $112,000. US President Trump's support for cryptocurrencies has contributed to its resurgence. However, the cryptocurrency's value is not tied to expected future earnings, unlike traditional investments. This volatility makes it an unconventional addition to a portfolio.

images.alt_text: Capital gains on direct Bitcoin purchases are subject to taxes of up to 55 per cent in Japan.

While Bitcoin has been described as a store-of-value similar to gold because of the cryptocurrency’s in-built scarcity – its supply is capped at 21 million – the token has not lived up to the billing.
World Liberty has been marketed as a DeFi lending platform, it has not become operational yet. So far, the project is known for purchasing niche tokens.
Cryptocurrencies have soared in price and popularity over the past few years as investors chased banner returns and interest in blockchain technology soared.

site_title: Australian unit of ComfortDelGro probes media allegations of wrongful conduct
summary: A2B Australia, a subsidiary of ComfortDelGro, is investigating allegations of wrongful conduct made by media companies The Sydney Morning Herald, The Age, and 60 Minutes Australia. The allegations claim A2B, the country's largest taxi company, has taken the public for a ride by exploiting loopholes in its terminal and payment systems, allowing taxi drivers to overcharge passengers. A2B has denied the allegations, stating it has a zero-tolerance policy towards fraud and has implemented strict measures to prevent and combat fraudulent activity. The company is considering legal action against the media outlets.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The new ComfortDelGro Toyota Alphard Hybrid models will feature LED taxi signs behind the windscreen instead of traditional rooftop-toppers.

site_title: Sri Lanka expects economy to grow at 5%, repay all debt, Dissanayake says
summary: Sri Lanka expects its economy to grow at 5% in the medium term, according to President Anura Kumara Dissanayake, who aims to maintain low inflation and stable exchange rates. The country will maintain a primary surplus of 2.3% of GDP and repay all its debt, with plans to resume debt repayments from 2028. Sri Lanka has made significant progress in recovering from its financial crisis, including completing debt restructuring and posting a faster-than-expected recovery. The country's current reserves are at $6 billion, enough to cover four months of imports.

images.alt_text: Signage at a China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. (Sinopec) gas station in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, March 21, 2024. Sinopec is scheduled to release earnings on March 24. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Shipping giants urge watchdog to avoid biofuels in clean-up push
summary: Shipping companies, including Hapag-Lloyd and the Louis Dreyfus maritime arm, are urging the International Maritime Organization (IMO) to avoid backing crop-based biofuels in its efforts to decarbonize the industry. The companies claim that biofuels like palm and soy can lead to deforestation and have a worse climate impact than traditional fuels. The IMO aims to achieve a zero-carbon emissions target for the industry by 2050, with shipping carrying over four-fifths of global trade.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Monday; STI climbs 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.7% on Monday, driven by positive regional moves, with the Straits Times Index (STI) climbing 27.35 points to 3,904.85. Key indices in South Korea and Hong Kong also gained ground, while Bursa Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.6%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB rose, with Hongkong Land being the top gainer. The market beat decliners 305 to 244, with 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.1 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians exit an escalator that runs past an electronic screen and ticker board that indicates stock figures at the Singapore Exchange Ltd. (SGX) headquarters in Singapore, on Wednesday, Jan. 21, 2015. SGX posted its first quarterly profit growth in more than a year after a world-beating rally in Chinese stocks spurred demand for derivatives. Photographer: Bryan van der Beek/Bloomberg
Megan Cheah

site_title: Singapore’s subdued IPO scene set for a rebound in 2025: analysts
summary: Singapore's initial public offering (IPO) scene is expected to rebound in 2025, with analyst forecasts ranging from four to 10 listings on the local bourse. The market has faced significant challenges in recent years, including poor liquidity and valuations, which led to more companies choosing to list on global exchanges. However, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) proposed tax incentives and initiatives to boost the local market, analysts are hopeful for a turnaround. Several potential IPOs, including Reits and healthcare companies, are in the pipeline, and market watchers expect an improved momentum in the IPO pipeline.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
Generic shots of SGX
Chee Hong Tat, Minister for Transport, Second Minister for Finance and Deputy Chairman, MAS, delivering a speech at the launch of SIAS Corporate Governance Week 2024 on September 16, 2024

site_title: Pritam Singh fined S$7,000 for each of 2 charges of lying to Parliament; his eligibility for election not affected
summary: Leader of the Opposition Pritam Singh was fined S$14,000 for lying to a parliamentary committee, becoming the first sitting opposition MP to be convicted of a criminal charge in nearly 40 years. Singh, who confirmed his intention to contest in the upcoming general election, was convicted of two charges of lying to the Committee of Privileges. The Elections Department stated that Singh's eligibility for election is not affected, as the criteria for disqualification is based on the sentence for a single offense.

images.alt_text: Singapore election 2025: Perera, 54, first contested in a general election in 2015 under the Workers' Party banner.

site_title: China slows rather than halts copper smelting’s breakneck growth
summary: China has introduced a new policy to limit copper smelter capacity, but it's unlikely to halt the industry's growth. The government has tied expansions to companies' control of ore supply, which may not be met by most firms due to China's reliance on imports. This move aims to curb deflation and excessive competition, which has persisted for 28 months. The policy also seeks to boost domestic copper mine resources by 10% over three years, amid a worldwide ore shortage and booming demand for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: The country aims to boost domestic copper mine resources by 5 to 10 per cent in three years to secure raw material supply, according to the government plan.
Copper rods at a factory in Vietnam. Copper peaked at just under US$11,000 per metric tonne in Q2 2024 and fell to the US$9,000 per metric tonne level in December.
Import tariffs will be reduced on ethane and certain recycled copper and aluminium raw materials to advance green and low-carbon development.

site_title: China’s Xi holds rare meeting with business leaders, including Jack Ma, amid US tech rivalry
summary: China's President Xi Jinping held a rare meeting with top business leaders, including Alibaba founder Jack Ma, in a show of support for private companies amid US tech rivalry. The event reflects concerns about China's slowdown in growth and efforts to limit its technological development. Xi's move underscores the importance of private-sector innovation for China to compete with the US. The meeting was seen as a tacit acknowledgement that the Chinese government needs private firms to drive growth and innovation.

images.alt_text: One major driver of the rally is Alibaba Group Holding contributing to a surge of almost 60 per cent since Jan 13.
Attendance by Jack Ma at the planned symposium has the potential to boost business confidence.

site_title: ECB watchers are now forecasting even lower rates for 2026
summary: The European Central Bank is forecast to cut interest rates further in 2026, with economists predicting a reduction below 2% due to growing concerns over inflation and economic growth. The euro area is expected to expand by 0.9% this year, down from 1% in the previous poll. The decision comes as policymakers debate how much further to cut rates, with some warning against using the neutral level as a guide for real-time policy decisions. US President Donald Trump's trade threats also weigh on the outlook.

images.alt_text: Wage growth is easing, the labour market is softening, oil prices have come off early-year highs and the US dollar’s relentless firming seems to have stopped for now.

Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), at a rates decision news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Dec. 12, 2024. The European Central Bank lowered interest rates for a third consecutive meeting, signaling more reductions next year as inflation nears 2% and the economy struggles. Photographer: Liesa Johannssen/Bloomberg
Euro-area consumer-price growth decelerated over the course of last year and went below the ECB’s target in September.

site_title: Thai economic growth in 2024 disappoints as trade risks loom
summary: Thailand's economic growth in 2024 fell short of expectations, with a 2.5% expansion, slower than the median estimate of 2.7%. Household consumption and manufacturing continue to face pressure, while the country's significant trade surplus with the US and China-made imports pose risks. Thailand is planning to boost imports of US ethane and agricultural products to avoid US tariffs. The state planning agency maintains its forecast for 2.3-3.3% growth in 2025, citing the need to energize domestic consumption and negotiate with the US.

images.alt_text: Thailand Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan’s GDP beats forecasts as consumption, business spending perk up
summary: Japan's GDP expanded 2.8% in the fourth quarter, beating forecasts, driven by improved business spending and consumption. However, details suggest the economy's underlying trend remains weak due to rising food prices. Capital spending rose 0.5%, while private consumption increased 0.1%. The data supports the Bank of Japan's interest rate hike plans, but US President Donald Trump's tariff threats pose a risk to Japan's export-reliant economy.

images.alt_text: The BOJ began to buy the stock funds in December 2010 as part of a monetary stimulus programme aimed at stoking inflation.
The latest average retail price of a 5 kg bag was 3,688 yen (S$32.20) according to a government survey in February, up from 2,023 yen last year.
Nissan's net income slumped 94 per cent in the six months to Sept 30 as profits cratered in the US and China, making it harder to refinance a record amount of bonds due to mature in 2026.

This general view shows the Sony Group Corporation company name outside the company's headquarters in Tokyo on May 2, 2024. The Japanese entertainment and electronics conglomerate will release full year earnings on May 14. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)
Import prices may rise further as hot US inflation data on Wednesday led to receding market expectations of near-term US interest rate cut.

site_title: Applied Materials falls as export controls weigh on outlook
summary: Applied Materials, the largest US maker of chip-manufacturing equipment, fell 5.3% after issuing a lukewarm revenue forecast for the current period, citing export controls that may crimp its business. The company expects sales of $7.1 billion in the fiscal second quarter and profit of $2.30 a share, despite maintaining confidence in the overall growth of the industry. Export rules are expected to reduce revenue by $400 million, with half of it hitting the company's service business in China.

images.alt_text: Applied Materials, KLA Corp and Lam Research, which make semiconductor equipment, argued that the three Chinese companies were a major source of revenue.

site_title: Milei stumbles into crypto memecoin scandal before key US trip
summary: Argentine leader Javier Milei faced a political crisis after promoting a crypto memecoin, Libra, on social media, which surged to $4 billion in value before collapsing, causing significant losses for investors. Milei's presidency was in crisis mode, with investors labeling the token as the "biggest rug pull of all time." Milei is now seeking US President's support to secure more money from the International Monetary Fund for Argentina. The incident has drawn criticism from prominent members of the crypto world, with some pointing fingers at each other.

images.alt_text: Argentina's President Javier Milei and Tesla CEO and X owner Elon Musk, in New York City, September 2024. They could be all thumbs when it comes to the public sector.

site_title: Trump says could meet Putin ‘very soon’ as Saudi talks loom
summary: US President Donald Trump said he could meet Russian President Vladimir Putin "very soon" amid ongoing talks in Saudi Arabia to end the Ukraine war. Trump's team has been speaking with Russian officials, including his Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff, whom he said met with Putin for about three hours. Trump believes Putin wants to stop fighting in Ukraine, but it's unclear if Russia will seize the entirety of the country. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky warned that Russia may prepare to wage war against NATO if US support is diluted.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky says that Ukraine was not invited to the talks in Saudi Arabia and Kyiv would not engage with Russia before consulting with strategic partners.
“If the US is not willing, if it is bent on suppressing and containing China, then we have no choice but to play along to the end,” Foreign Minister Wang Yi says.
Vance’s remarks also align with arguments made by European far-right groups, who have condemned restrictions on social media activity and efforts to limit their influence.
European officials got no advance warning of Trump’s (left) call with Putin (right), according to one official.

So far judges have blocked US President Donald Trump’s orders to end birthright citizenship, freeze trillions of dollars in federal spending and allow Elon Musk’s government efficiency effort, DOGE, to access government payments data.

site_title: US sees UK in ‘different light’ on trade: British minister
summary: US views its trade relationship with the UK in a "different light" due to the UK's lack of a large trade deficit with the country, but difficult issues remain on tariffs. British Secretary of State for Business and Trade Jonathan Reynolds reported "good engagement, good conversations" during meetings with the Trump administration, indicating a balanced trading relationship. Despite this, US trade policy under President Trump continues to pose challenges for the UK.

images.alt_text: Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds says the UK government reiterated a commitment to invest £2.5 billion in order to support the steel industry.
Most of Britain’s major retailers have flagged a tougher year ahead as employer tax increases, and their potential impact on prices and employment, filter through into the economy.
UK consumers have been reluctant to spend their real wage gains, preferring to set more money aside after the pandemic.
The Bank of England lowered rates to 4.5 per cent and halved its growth forecast for this year to 0.75 per cent.

site_title: Defaulted Chinese companies face rising risks in court hearings
summary: Defaulted Chinese companies face rising risks in court hearings in Hong Kong, with at least four liquidation hearings scheduled for this month. Companies including Tianji Holding and HNA Group are set to appear in court, with some facing wind-up orders and others seeking loan debt restructuring. A string of defaulted developers have been ordered to liquidate in recent months, despite Beijing's efforts to bolster confidence in the property market. The pace of litigation quickens, raising concerns for the financial stability of these firms.

site_title: Xi-Jack Ma chat seen as next catalyst for blistering China rally
summary: A potential meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Alibaba founder Jack Ma could be a catalyst for China's stock rally, driven by a 60% surge in Alibaba shares since January 13. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index jumped 4.1% on February 14, fueled by growing capabilities in artificial intelligence. Ma's meeting with Xi could signal support for the private sector, coinciding with a recent surge in tech shares in Hong Kong, which entered a bull market earlier this month. The rally could extend if Xi shows support for Alibaba.

site_title: UK firms brace for hit from tax hikes: surveys
summary: British employers expect to raise prices and cut headcount due to government tax increases on businesses, with confidence among small businesses at a five-year low. A survey by the Chartered Institute of Personnel Development found 9/10 employers think payroll taxes will increase employment costs, leading 42% to raise prices and 32% to reduce headcount. Another survey by the Federation of Small Businesses showed a quarter of small companies expect to see a contraction in size, echoing a sharp drop in business confidence since the government's October budget.

images.alt_text: Britain's Secretary of State for Business and Trade Jonathan Reynolds told broadcasters Britain had a balanced trading relationship with the US and he reported “good engagement, good conversations” in his meetings with the Trump administration on the issue.

UK consumers have been reluctant to spend their real wage gains, preferring to set more money aside after the pandemic.

site_title: ‘Conclave’ and ‘Brutalist’ share Bafta honours
summary: Conclave and The Brutalist shared Bafta honors, with Conclave winning Best Film and The Brutalist taking Best Director, Best Actor, and Best Cinematography. Emilia Perez, a heavily favored film, emerged with only two awards, including Best Supporting Actress for Zoe Saldana. The ceremony also honored Mikey Madison for Best Actress for her role in Anora, with Saldana dedicating her award to her trans nephew. The winners diverged from the Oscars, which will be held on March 2.

site_title: Gold gains as investors eye Trump tariff moves
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,885.95 per ounce on Monday, driven by market uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's reciprocal tariff plans. The move follows a 1% decline in the previous session. Trump's tariff threats could heighten global trade tensions, while a slowdown in US retail sales suggests economic growth may slow in the first quarter. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged until the second half of the year due to high inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held its ground at US$2,929.05 per ounce, as of 0303 GMT on Friday.

site_title: New Zealand sees record number of departures amid weak economy
summary: New Zealand recorded a record number of departures in 2024, with 128,705 people leaving the country, up from 101,585 in 2023. This decline in foreign arrivals, combined with a drop in net immigration, reflects a weaker labor market and slowing wage growth amid an economy in recession. The country's economy contracted 2.1% in the six months to September, and slower population growth may hinder an economic recovery ahead of the 2026 election.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand began cutting interest rates in August and is tipped to maintain an aggressive pace with another 50 basis-point reduction next week, taking the Official Cash Rate to 3.75 per cent.

site_title: The unicorn boom is over, and startups are getting desperate
summary: A record 1,200 venture-backed unicorns remain undervalued, according to CB Insights, as the "unicorn boom" comes to an end. Since 2021, only six unicorns have gone public, four through Spacs, and 10 have been acquired, with many others struggling financially. Startups are finding it difficult to sell investors on their momentum as they transition to fiscal discipline, highlighting a shift in the fundraising reality. The decline is attributed to rising interest rates, a slowing IPO market, and the focus on AI.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Effective budgeting vs income growth insights

Saavedra highlights the impact of mental health on financial management, and provides actionable strategies for listeners to improve their financial literacy and manage their money effectively. The episode aims to empower listeners to take control of their financial future in a current environment of rising costs and inflation.

site_title: Oil falls for fourth day on expectations Russia-Ukraine peace may lift supply
summary: Oil prices fell for a fourth day on Monday, with Brent crude futures sliding 20 cents to US$74.59 a barrel, amid expectations of a Russia-Ukraine peace deal easing sanctions and concerns over global economic growth and energy demand. US President Donald Trump announced discussions with Russia to end the war, and US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said Ukraine and Europe would be part of any negotiations. Oil prices are expected to trade between US$66 and US$76 due to potential sanction relief and economic slowdown concerns.

site_title: What happens if President Trump defies a judge’s order?
summary: US President Donald Trump's aggressive actions have triggered court rulings blocking several of his orders, including ending birthright citizenship and freezing trillions of dollars in federal spending. Judges have limited tools to enforce compliance, such as fining or jailing officials, but can grant injunctions to block parts of executive orders. Advocacy groups and state officials are alarmed by Trump's actions, which they say pose a threat to the rule of law and checks and balances. Trump has vowed to follow the law and appeal decisions, but his actions have raised concerns about a potential constitutional crisis.

summary: KEPPEL DC Reit is divesting its German data centre, Kelsterbach Data Centre, to an unrelated third party for 50 million euros (S$70.6 million). summary: Australia's Star Entertainment Group received a potential lifeline from Oaktree Capital Management, offering to refinance A$650 million of its debt. The offer is subject to numerous conditions and there's no certainty it will progress. Star has been racing to raise capital after warning its future as a viable business is in doubt due to cash shortages. The sale would reshape the company into a standalone fund management firm, marking a strategic turnaround. The net proceeds for shareholders are uncertain at this stage.

site_title: Australia set for first rate cut since 2020 as trade risks mount
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is set to cut interest rates for the first time in four years, with a 25 basis-point reduction expected, according to economists and traders. The decision aims to ease inflationary pressures amid mounting global trade turmoil and potential election spending in Australia. Despite cooling price pressures, policymakers remain cautious, and a rate cut may be seen as a temporary measure to address near-term inflation concerns. The RBA's level of policy restrictiveness remains in line with its major counterparts, and a 100 basis point cut is expected.

images.alt_text: The RBA will have the December retail sales report, as well as updates on a surprisingly tight labour market before it decides its next move on Feb 18.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 12.16 points or 0.3% to 3,889.66 on Monday, driven by local banking stocks. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 72 to 38 after 35.6 million securities worth S$33.4 million changed hands. Thai Beverage and Genting Singapore were among the most actively traded counters, with gains of 2% and 1.3%, respectively. summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 2.1% in January year-on-year, surprising economists, due to the late Chinese New Year celebrations. This follows two months of growth. Total trade rose 6.7% in January, slowing from the 19% growth in the previous month. The decline is attributed to a high base from January 2024. Experts consider the drop a minor concern, given its timing.

site_title: London faces UK’s worst home sales logjam before stamp duty hike
summary: London faces the UK's worst home sales logjam before a stamp duty hike, with first-time buyers scrambling to complete deals by March, according to Rightmove. The number of first-time buyers trying to complete transactions in the capital is nearly a third higher than last year, with the average completion process taking five months. The stamp duty levy, currently exempt on the first £425,000 of a purchase, will be lowered on April 1, potentially increasing charges for London buyers.

site_title: HSBC investors back CEO’s investment banking retrenchment
summary: HSBC investors support CEO George Elhedery's plan to retrench parts of its investment bank, citing a focus on core Asian markets and cost savings. The move is seen as a response to US tariffs threatening to crimp earnings and a shift towards healthier regional trading prospects. Investors expect cost savings of £1.2 billion to £3 billion, partly achieved through further cuts to management roles. The bank's London-listed shares have risen 11.5% year-to-date, driven by a focus on delivering a sustainable return on tangible equity of around 16%.
