site_title: Malaysia will crack down on fraud in used cooking oil exports, official says
summary: Malaysia plans to crack down on fraud in its used cooking oil exports, following concerns from Western governments that shipments may contain virgin oil. The country's Deputy Commodities Minister, Chan Foong Hin, said the government is reviewing standards and policies to distinguish between used cooking oil and palm industry waste, and strengthening enforcement mechanisms to uphold industry credibility. This comes amid complaints from buyers, such as the European biodiesel industry, and investigations by the US Environmental Protection Agency into the supply chains of renewable fuel producers.

images.alt_text: Apeiron Bioenergy now builds and acquires facilities that turn used cooking oil into biofuel.

site_title: Vietnam says ready to import more US farm goods as trade risks rise
summary: Vietnam is prepared to import more US agricultural products as global trade disputes intensify, including new duties from the US, its largest export market. The country's trade minister, Nguyen Hong Dien, expressed a need for strengthened cooperation in the agricultural sector to diversify products and supply chains. Vietnam is the US's 9th largest export market for agricultural goods, with a record trade surplus of over $123 billion last year. Dien hopes the US will further open its market for Vietnamese farm produce, amid rising trade risks.

site_title: World Bank sees Thai fiscal risks mounting due to spending surge
summary: Thailand's expansionary fiscal policy faces fiscal risks due to rising spending on elderly care, investment, and maintaining sustainable public debt levels. The World Bank's Thailand Economic Monitor report suggests reducing regressive energy subsidies, raising tax revenue, and accelerating public investments in infrastructure, technology, and human capital to enhance fiscal resilience. Pro-growth consumption measures, such as the digital wallet, have added to fiscal pressures, the report states.

images.alt_text: The government has said its “digital wallet” handout scheme and other measures will help spur the economy as it aims for 3.5 per cent growth this year.

site_title: OCBC Cycle returns on May 3-4 with target of 7,000 riders
summary: OCBC Cycle, Singapore's largest mass cycling event, will return on May 3-4 with a target of 7,000 riders. The event features a new virtual ride, where participants must complete a minimum 120 km in a single round-island journey within a 24-hour period. Twelve companies, including Brompton and Decathlon, are supporting the event, which will have 100 virtual ride slots available. Registration opened on February 14, with over 1,000 sign-ups expected in the first three days.

site_title: Maybank upgrades Singtel’s AIS to buy, raises price target on further profit growth expectations
summary: Maybank upgraded Singtel's Thai associate Advanced Info Service (AIS) to a "buy" rating, citing strong outlook and healthy yields. The brokerage forecasts an 11% core profit growth for FY2025 and a 4-5% dividend yield for FY2025 and FY2026. Maybank raised its price target to 307 baht from 301 baht, following a 2% increase in Ebitda forecasts. AIS's record-high core profit for Q4 exceeded forecasts by 14%, driven by strong core service revenue and lower-than-expected admin expenses.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Singtel's upcoming data centre in Tuas. It is designed to support artificial intelligence, as well as drive greater energy and water efficiency.

site_title: Arm recruits from customers as it plans to sell its own chips
summary: Arm, led by CEO Rene Haas, is recruiting executives from licensees, including Apple and Nvidia, in a bid to sell its own chips. This move comes as the company seeks to expand profits and revenues. Arm supplies intellectual property for licensees to create their own CPUs. The company's effort to sell its own chips appears to be ramping up, as it considers various tactics to increase its revenue and profits.

images.alt_text: DeepSeek’s models, which focus on “inference” or when an AI model produces conclusions, optimise computational efficiency rather than relying solely on raw processing power.

site_title: Fraud-hit eFishery slashes over 1,000 jobs as company weighs liquidation
summary: Indonesian aquatech startup eFishery is slashing over 1,000 jobs as it struggles to recover from a financial crisis. The company, which was valued at $1.4 billion in 2023, has been hit by allegations of financial fraud, including inflated revenue by $600 million. Those remaining employees will likely be in core business areas, with a general meeting of shareholders set to determine the company's future. The layoffs are part of a "sterilisation process" at the company's office building, with employees working from home.

images.alt_text: eFeeder, an automatic fish and shrimp feeder created by eFishery.

site_title: A swimming success: Trans-Eurokars Mazda making waves in the pool
summary: Mazda Singapore is partnering with the World Aquatics Championships (WCH) in Singapore, set to take place from July 11 to August 3, as the official automobile partner. Over 100 brand-new cars, including Mazda6 Sedan, CX-5, CX-60, and CX-80 models, will be supplied for athletes and officials. Mazda Singapore managing director Chong Kah Wei, a former competitive swimmer, expressed his passion for the sport and the importance of supporting the event, which is the first major global sporting event in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Modi and Trump agree to trade talks to lower tensions
summary: US President Donald Trump and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi agreed to trade talks, aiming to lower tensions and increase cooperation. Modi expressed interest in purchasing billions of dollars' worth of US defence equipment, while Trump pledged to match India's tariffs and potentially make the US the top supplier of oil and gas. The two leaders also discussed doubling trade between the two countries by 2030, with Modi seeking to make Washington the No. 1 supplier of oil and gas.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump has been promising to introduce reciprocal tariffs, but Thursday’s directive stopped well short of that, instead kicking off what will be weeks or months of investigation into the levies imposed on US goods by other trading partners and then devising a response.

Annual retail inflation in January was at 4.31 per cent, lower than economists’ estimate of 4.6 per cent and 5.22 per cent in the previous month.

site_title: Singapore’s key exports up 0.2% in 2024; 2025 forecast unchanged
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 0.2% in 2024, reversing the 13.1% contraction in 2023, driven by higher electronic shipments that rose 8.2%. Electronic products, such as integrated circuits and PC shipments, contributed to the growth. Non-electronic NODX shrank 1.9%. The 2025 forecast remains unchanged at 1-3% growth, with uncertainties in the global economy posing downside risks.

site_title: Japan to release emergency rice reserves as prices soar
summary: Japan's government will release 210,000 tonnes of rice from its 1 million-tonne stockpile due to soaring prices, the nation's first emergency release. The price of rice has surged to 3,688 yen per 5kg bag, up from 2,023 yen last year, as a shortage triggered by extreme hot weather in 2023 continues to fuel demand. The move aims to improve stagnant distribution and stabilize prices, with the government planning to buy back the released rice from distributors within a year.

images.alt_text: Import prices may rise further as hot US inflation data on Wednesday led to receding market expectations of near-term US interest rate cut.

Japan's overall consumer price index rose 3.6 per cent in December from a year earlier, much faster than a 3.0 per cent gain in the core index that strips away the effect of volatile fresh food prices.

A man talks on his phone outside the headquarters for Japanese company SoftBank Group in Tokyo on May 2, 2024. Japanese investment giant SoftBank Group are expected to announce full year earnings on May 13. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Coinbase fourth-quarter profit beats on crypto rally
summary: Coinbase reported a fourth-quarter profit of $4.68 per share, beating analyst estimates of $1.81 per share. The company's revenue rose 172% to $1.6 billion, driven by higher trading volumes in bitcoin and other digital tokens following the US election, which saw Donald Trump win the presidency and pledge to make the US the "crypto capital of the planet."

images.alt_text: The crypto exchange’s move comes amid a broader industry push to lobby lawmakers for a regulatory framework to support the sector’s growth.

Prosecutors said Seychelles-based KuCoin had been used to facilitate billions of dollars of suspicious transactions, and to transmit potential criminal proceeds including from darknet markets and malware, ransomware and fraud.

After years of ascendancy following bitcoin's emergence, the cryptocurrency industry had fallen into a "crypto winter," plagued by scandals and hostile regulatory oversight. But Trump's impending presidency has spurred an enthusiastic market response, with bitcoin surging more than 25 percent in a week and breaking through the $90,000 mark for the first time. The industry has been calling for years for the SEC to create clear cryptocurrency rules.

site_title: Unit business costs for manufacturing, services up in 2024; labour cost set to keep rising in 2025
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector saw a 0.2% increase in unit business costs in 2024, with the services sector experiencing a 5.8% rise in the first three quarters of the year. Labour costs are expected to continue rising in 2025, driven by slower wage growth offset by moderating productivity growth. The overall economy's unit labour cost rose 1.2% in 2024, with the manufacturing sector's ULC falling as labour productivity gains more than offset an increase in TLC per worker.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Singapore’s 2024 GDP grows by 4.4%, better than advance estimates of 4%
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 4.4% in 2024, exceeding the advance estimate of 4% due to a 5% fourth-quarter growth rate. However, the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) maintains its 2025 growth forecast range at 1-3%, citing trade policy uncertainty and tariffs. Economists, including DBS and Barclays, hold similar forecasts, with some, like Barclays' Brian Tan, slightly raising their projections. The external outlook remains broadly unchanged, with US growth expected to moderate and key South-east Asian economies posting steady growth, but global uncertainties and trade frictions pose risks to the economy.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Electronics shipments grew 8.2 per cent in 2024, compared to a 19.7 per cent contraction in 2023.
Singapore’s economy expanded 4% year on year in 2024,  better than the official forecast of “around 3.5%”.
Singapore's financial sector, led by the top three banks, was a major driver of the country's robust GDP growth.

site_title: Asia: Most stocks rise as US tariffs give breathing space
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Friday as US tariffs, set to be implemented in April, gave traders breathing space. Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, and Manila gained over 1% in response to the news. Investor sentiment remained optimistic, with hopes that many of the tariffs can be negotiated away or reduced. The US president's announcement of Ukraine peace talks with Russia added some optimism, while Commerce Secretary nominee Howard Lutnick said studies on tariffs would be completed by April 1.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares retreat at Friday’s open; STI down 0.2%
The Stoxx 600 index closed 1.09 per cent higher at 553.75 points on Thursday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.8 per cent to 44,711.43 on Thursday.

site_title: More firms want inflation support, funding for digital adoption and sustainability projects in Budget 2025: UOB
summary: A UOB study of 900 SMEs and large enterprises in Singapore found that high inflation (31%), rising operational costs (30%), and manpower costs (29%) are the top macro factors affecting businesses. The study also revealed that firms are seeking support for inflation, digital adoption, and sustainability projects, with 46% wanting grants and funding for digital solutions. Only 14% of firms have applied for the SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit, despite 29% being aware of the scheme.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Trends such as offshoring, talent migration, and a widening artificial intelligence (AI) skills gap could erode Singapore’s long-term competitiveness, noted the association.

site_title: Trump says reciprocal tariffs coming on Thursday
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to unveil reciprocal tariffs on Thursday, which could target every country charging duties on US imports. The move has ratcheted up fears of a widening global trade war and threatened to accelerate US inflation. Trump has already imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, goods from China, and a 30-day hold on tariffs from Canada and Mexico. The White House has not disclosed the timing of the tariff plan, which is expected to be announced before Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit.

site_title: US wholesale inflation exceeds forecast on higher food, energy
summary: US wholesale inflation rose 0.4% in January, exceeding forecasts, driven by higher food and energy costs. This follows a surprising consumer price index report showing underlying inflation at its highest since March. The producer price index increase has reduced odds of the Federal Reserve lowering interest rates in 2025, with some economists expecting no rate cuts. The data also shows that food and energy costs rose 3.5% from a year ago, highlighting limited progress on inflation ahead of tariffs imposed by the Trump administration.

images.alt_text: Canned soup and vegetables in a grocery store in New York City. President Donald Trump's 25% tariff on all steel and aluminium imports into the US would result in higher prices of consumer goods that use the metals, say economists.

site_title: Several Parkway Parade mall tenants leave or downsize amid rising rents
summary: Marks & Spencer will close its Parkway Parade store on Feb 16 after more than 20 years, amid rising rental costs and foot traffic concerns. At least seven other tenants have left the mall in the past year, citing rental increases of up to 30%. The mall, which opened in 1983, is experiencing a decline in tenants due to the opening of the Marine Parade MRT station in June 2024. This marks another significant departure from the 42-year-old mall.

images.alt_text: Boloni's new 5,000 square foot flagship showroom. The brand is targeting the high-end residential market.

site_title: Trump’s tariffs obscure a much bigger challenge for the world
summary: The US economy continues to outperform, surpassing global partners and competitors, despite predictions of its decline. The country's financial pull remains strong, with the dollar's upward march showing little sign of reversing. Emerging markets, such as China and India, are not on track to eclipse the US, with the International Monetary Fund upgrading its global growth projections to include the US. The US economy's recovery to pre-Covid potential is seen as a sign of its ascendant status, leaving other countries struggling to keep up.

site_title: The assets of Japan’s wealthiest jump to record 469 trillion yen
summary: Japan's wealthiest individuals have seen their assets surge to a record 469 trillion yen (S$4.1 trillion) between 2011 and 2023, more than doubling in wealth and tripling in assets held by the ultra-wealthy. In contrast, the majority of Japanese households, accounting for 80% of the population, have only seen their assets grow 42.2% during the same period. The wealth disparity is attributed to gains in stocks and the weak yen, benefiting higher-net-worth households.

Consumer spending in Japan climbed 2.7 per cent in December from a year earlier, data from the internal affairs ministry showed on Friday, better than the median market forecast for a 0.5 per cent uptick.

site_title: The wind beneath China’s wings: New productive forces
summary: China is shifting its economy from investment-driven growth to a sustainable, high-tech, and innovation-based model under President Xi Jinping's leadership. The country aims for technological self-sufficiency, financial stability, and global leadership in strategic industries such as electric vehicles, renewable energy, and artificial intelligence. China is reforming its stock markets, promoting public-private collaboration, and adopting market-driven competition to create globally competitive firms. The goal is to position China as a global leader and ensure long-term economic resilience.

site_title: Yahoo News signs up influencers with promise of shared advertising sales
summary: Yahoo News has partnered with nearly 100 social media influencers on YouTube, TikTok, and Instagram, offering them a share of advertising sales in exchange for posting content on its website. The program, which debuted this month, aims to draw traffic to the site and curate content from creators, with over 190 million users reading Yahoo News each month. The company pays influencers half of the advertising sales generated by their content, with some creators earning up to $3,000 per month.

site_title: Mahathir Mohamad: From humble beginnings to Malaysia’s political titan and father of modernisation
summary: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysia's longest-serving prime minister, will turn 100 in July. Born on July 10, 1925, in a poor neighborhood, he rose to power and served for 23 years and nine months. Notably, he became the world's oldest serving state leader at 92 years and 304 days during his second term. Dr. Mohamad is a self-made leader who broke the mold by not representing the United Malays National Organisation (Umno) as the first Malaysian prime minister. His legacy is marked by modernization efforts, making him a significant figure in Malaysian politics.

site_title: ThaiBev Q1 revenue up 2.4% at 92.3 billion baht
summary: Thai Beverage's Q1 revenue rose 2.4% to 92.3 billion baht, driven by stronger sales of beer, non-alcoholic beverages, and food segments. Beer sales revenue increased 8% to 36.1 billion baht, while non-alcoholic beverages revenue rose 7.2% to 17 billion baht. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) dropped 0.8% to 16.4 billion baht, primarily due to weaker performance in the spirits and others segments.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing grows for first time in two years
summary: New Zealand's manufacturing industry expanded for the first time in almost two years, with the Performance of Manufacturing Index rising to 51.4 in January. Despite some caution due to global trade uncertainty, economists predict a 1% expansion in manufacturing in 2025, driven by a lower New Zealand dollar and falling interest rates.

site_title: Cathay Cineplexes’ rental arrears unlikely to impact FCT’s bottom line
summary: Cathay Cineplexes, a cinema operator, has delayed rental payments to its landlord Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) due to dwindling cinema attendance amid competition from streaming services. The outstanding amount of S$2.7 million is a quarter of the total payment owed between April 2020 and January 2025. Analysts say this could indicate a "structural issue" among cinema operators, potentially leading to consolidation of cinemas to malls with higher footfall. The delayed payments are unlikely to significantly impact FCT's bottom line, but may raise concerns among investors about similar issues among other cinema operators.

site_title: Gold set for seventh weekly gain as trade war risks lift demand
summary: Gold prices held steady at US$2,929.05 per ounce, poised for a seventh consecutive weekly gain, as US President Donald Trump's plans to impose reciprocal tariffs on every country taxing US imports fueled concerns of a global trade war. The market is slightly overbought, which may lead to technical profit booking after reaching the US$3,000 level. Inflation data showed a strong increase in the US producer price index, strengthening views that the Federal Reserve would not cut interest rates before the second-half of the year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 13)

Over the past five years, median monthly household employment income rose 3.6% cumulatively, or 0.7% per annum in real terms. Investment-linked plans drove growth, and the latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield dropped to 2.9%. A pilot mentorship programme was launched by NTUC to support union members with career guidance, and three unions were selected for the initiative.

site_title: Singles’ inferno: Social mixer scene heats up in Singapore as dating apps get cold shoulder
summary: In Singapore, a new wave of event organizers is capitalizing on the growing demand for offline social connections among Gen Z and millennials. Since 2022, the number of singles events hosted on Eventbrite has doubled, with 240 events in 2024. Companies like Timeleft, Unfiltered Presents, and Offline Singapore are offering curated experiences, such as dinner events and mixers, that aim to forge authentic human connections. These events are seen as a response to "dating app fatigue" and offer a more casual and organic way to meet new people. With a growing demand for these events, companies are exploring scaling their business and even hosting overseas events, with potential profit margins ranging from 20 to 30%.

site_title: ‘I’m still around’: Soon to turn 100, Dr Mahathir continues to shape Malaysia’s politics
summary: Malaysia's longest-serving prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, is set to turn 100 in July. Despite no longer in office, he remains a significant figure in the country's politics. Mahathir modernized Malaysia, cultivated billionaires, and championed the "Look East" policy, but his rule was marked by controversy, including cronyism, authoritarian governance, and the dismissal of senior judges. Critics argue that his pursuit of power has contributed to his longevity and sharp mind. Mahathir's legacy is debated, but he will be remembered as the architect of modern Malaysia and a figure whose influence transcends generations.

Investors were influenced by producer prices data and the prospect of Russia-Ukraine peace talks, leading to increased risk-taking.

site_title: Trump eyes summit with Xi-Putin, shaking up world order
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed interest in hosting a summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping, potentially shaking up the world order. Trump stated he would consider the summit "when things calm down" after calling Putin to discuss Ukraine peace talks. He also expressed a desire to have Russia rejoin the G7, which it was suspended from in 2014 after annexing Crimea.

site_title: New AI models risk economic amnesia
summary: AI models are increasingly used in economic analysis and policy-making, but their reliance on recent data risks erasing historical context and leading to economic amnesia. This could result in policymakers failing to detect cyclical patterns and systemic risks that have long defined economic history. As AI-driven models prioritize short-term trends, they may overlook deeper historical cycles, such as the 1994 peso crisis, and exacerbate financial market underestimation of risks with clear historical precedents. The risk is not just that financial crises will recur, but that broader preparedness for systemic crises will erode as day-to-day algorithmic prediction becomes more precise.

images.alt_text: US Securities and Exchange Commission chair Gary Gensler says: "It is likely that regulatory gaps have emerged and may grow significantly with the greater adoption of deep learning in finance."

site_title: Weekend vibes, lively Mexican fare at Tomatillo
summary: Tomatillo, a new Mexican eatery in Singapore, offers casual dining with a lively atmosphere. Chef Tamara Chavez's menu features dishes like nachos chilangos, pollo morcho, and tostadas de pulpo, all with a focus on acidity and in-your-face flavors. The restaurant is welcoming and fun, with food that doesn't stretch the imagination or budget. The standout dish is crepas chidas, thin fluffy pancakes drenched in caramel sauce and paired with sweet plantains and bananas. Tomatillo is a great spot for those seeking a casual dining experience with a Mexican twist.

site_title: Malaysia to relax laws on public protests
summary: Malaysia agreed to relax laws on public protests, removing the requirement for prior permission for demonstrations. The move was welcomed by activists, who cited the provision as a reason for preventing rallies. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim stated that requests for rallies were frequently approved since his takeover in 2022. The change aims to promote freedom of assembly and is seen as a positive step for the country's civil society.

The incidents, which occurred within a week, were caused by signalling faults and a malfunctioning electronic card. LTA aims to improve incident response and has worked with system manufacturer Alstom to develop a software patch, scheduled for deployment this weekend. The three incidents were unrelated, and LTA takes a serious view of the incidents, emphasizing the need for improvement in incident response.

site_title: 📍 Where to invest your money in 2025
summary: Young investors can consider high-yield savings accounts, T-bills, cash management accounts, corporate bond funds, Singapore stocks, Reits, and global stocks based on their financial needs. For short-term needs, savings accounts, T-bills, and cash management accounts offer guaranteed returns, while corporate bond funds and Singapore stocks provide regular dividends. Global stocks are suitable for long-term retirement savings, but beware of home bias. Ultimately, investment predictions are just that - predictions - and what's more important is investing based on individual needs and plans.

summary: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto announced the launch of the Daya Anagata Nusantara (Danantara) sovereign wealth fund on February 24, aiming to boost economic growth to 8% by investing in various sectors. The fund, expected to start with at least $60 billion in assets, will manage more than $900 billion in assets under management, rivaling some of the world's largest sovereign wealth funds. site_title: UK economy unexpectedly picks up in late 2024, outlook for 2025 still 'sluggish'
summary: The UK economy unexpectedly grew by 0.1% in the final quarter of 2024, surpassing economists' expectations of a 0.1% decline. This follows a 0.9% growth in 2024, after 0.4% growth in 2023. However, adjusted for population growth, output per head fell by 0.1%. The economy's growth was driven by a robust services sector, but business investment dropped by 3.2% and household spending remained flat. The outlook for 2025 remains "sluggish" with forecasters predicting 0.75% growth, down from the Bank of England's previous forecast of 1.5%.

site_title: Trump outlines reciprocal tariff plan in latest bid to reshape trade on his terms

The move, announced in a memo, aims to match tariffs imposed by other countries and counter non-tariff barriers such as vehicle safety rules and value-added taxes. The investigation and response are expected to take weeks or months, with a deadline of April 1 for studies to be completed. The move has sparked concerns of a global trade war and inflation, but also offered relief to Wall Street, with US stocks adding to the day's gains.

The development will feature residential, retail, hospitality, healthcare, and education components, and will be a connectivity hub with links to the Bukit Chagar RTS Link station and other transportation systems. While this may pose challenges to local incumbents, it also presents opportunities for innovation and customer engagement. Experts predict that the retail sector will experience modest growth, but competition will intensify, and new entrants will fuel market saturation. Local businesses must up their game in store design, product appeal, and brand storytelling to connect with their target audience.

site_title: No winners in a trade war: US cannot continue to grow if its trading partners shrink
summary: The US economy is at risk of slowing down due to President Trump's trade war policies, which could lead to higher prices of consumer goods and inflation. The tariffs on steel, aluminum, and Chinese imports are expected to add half a percentage point to US consumer inflation this year, potentially bringing year-end inflation to 2.6%. Economists warn that the tariffs will drive up costs for exporters, leading to higher prices for consumers, and that there are no winners in a trade war. The US cannot continue to grow if its trading partners continue to shrink, and the prolonged slowdown in global economic activity in the 1930s is often attributed to a trade war.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s potential as a gaming destination, with casinos proposed in the capital Bangkok, on the holiday island of Phuket, and three other sites, is underpinned by its role as a regional magnet for tourism.

The threat will heap more pressure on officials across Asia to appease Trump to steer their export-dependent economies through a renewed trade war.

site_title: South Korea fines JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley, Nomura and UBS for short selling breaches
summary: South Korea's Securities and Futures Commission fined JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley, Nomura, and UBS for violating short-selling rules in the domestic stock market. The fines were imposed after the companies were found to have engaged in naked short-selling, which is banned under the Capital Markets Act. The decision comes as South Korea plans to lift a market-wide ban on stock short-selling in March, when a system to detect illegal trades is expected to be in place. The exact amount of fines imposed on each company was not disclosed.

site_title: Pension segment and new licence to grow wealth management business: iFast CEO
summary: iFast Global Bank CEO Lim Chung Chun plans to apply for a European Union banking license to expand its wealth management business, rather than acquiring another bank. The company's core wealth management business recovered in 2024 with net inflows of S$3.3 billion and gross unit trust subscriptions of S$7.4 billion. iFast aims to hit assets under administration of S$100 billion by 2028-2030. The company's digital bank, iFast Global Bank, turned profitable in Q4 2024 and is expected to remain profitable through 2025, driven by net interest income.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The group's banking division, iFast Global Bank, reported profit for the first time.
iFast chief executive Lim Chung Chun expects more opportunities for the company to apply for licences at “a couple more locations” to boost its global model.
The new China desk will be launched in Singapore and Hong Kong first.

site_title: Barclays sets new performance goals as 2024 pretax profit rises
summary: Barclays has set new performance goals for 2025 after reporting a 24% rise in annual pretax profit for 2024, beating analysts' forecasts. The bank's investment bank saw strong income growth, while slower interest rate cuts boosted its domestic lending business. Barclays met its 2024 performance targets, including a return on tangible equity of 10.5%, and has raised its 2025 guidance, aiming for a group return on tangible equity (RoTE) of around 11%.

images.alt_text: Barclays is one of the largest UK employers in India, with over 23,000 people spread across its banking, technology and shared services operations.
Several financial firms are vying to replace Goldman, which launched the credit card with Apple in 2019, the sources say.
Barclays has enjoyed a strong year as activity in markets improved and chief executive officer CS Venkatakrishnan ploughed ahead with a multi-year plan to boost returns.
The investment bank has benefited from a surge in debt underwriting fees so far this year as well as a 17 per cent increase in equities trading revenue.
Barclays currently runs booking centres in six locations, including India, the UK and Switzerland.

The fine by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) dates back to the height of the 2008-to-2009 financial crisis, when Barclays scrambled to raise funds from overseas investors including Qatar in order to avoid a state bailout.

site_title: DeepSeek gives China’s chipmakers leg-up in race for cheaper AI
summary: China's chipmakers, including Huawei, are gaining an edge in the domestic market with the integration of DeepSeek's AI models, which focus on "inference" rather than raw processing power. This allows for more efficient computational processing and enables Chinese companies to compete with US processors in the training model process. As a result, Chinese chipmakers are now better positioned to compete in the domestic market, potentially altering the dynamics of the global chip industry.

images.alt_text: The Chinese AI startup’s chatbot not only matched its best-in-class counterparts from US companies like OpenAI and Perpexity AI, it did so at a fraction of the resources required by these companies.
DeepSeek's competitive pricing a critical question - is massive spending the only path to AI supremacy?
The postings offer a glimpse into DeepSeek’s ambition to remain at the forefront of Chinese AI and compete with global rivals.
FILE PHOTO: The Deepseek logo is seen in this illustration taken Jan. 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Former intern becomes billionaire in Australia pharmacy merger
summary: A merger between Chemist Warehouse and Sigma Healthcare in Australia will create one of the country's largest pharmacy chains and wholesalers, valued at over US$4.2 billion. The deal will make three billionaires, including a former Chemist Warehouse intern, Jack Gance, and his brother Sam, and Mario Verrocchi, who rose from an internship to become CEO. The combined entity will own over 900 pharmacies in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland, and supply products to more than 3,500 stores. The merger is seen as a rags-to-riches example of the Australian "battler" sentiment, but also raises concerns about the dominance of low-cost chains in the industry.

images.alt_text: An electronic board displays trading information of Sigma Healthcare Ltd. at the Australian Securities Exchange, operated by ASX Ltd., in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, Feb. 13, 2025. The merger of closely held pharmacy franchiser Chemist Warehouse with publicly traded Sigma Healthcare has created one of Australia’s largest pharmacy chains and wholesalers. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: Ong Beng Seng’s HPL to focus on its other Orchard Road properties after exiting Cuscaden consortium
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd (HPL), owned by tycoon Ong Beng Seng, will focus on developing its other assets after exiting a Temasek-backed consortium that owns Paragon Reit. HPL's subsidiary Tiga Stars ceased holding any shareholdings in Cuscaden Peak on Jan 24, resulting in HPL no longer owning an interest in the Reit. The company plans to allocate its resources to developing its other assets and projects, according to a recent filing.

images.alt_text: Temasek-backed Cuscaden to privatise Paragon Reit at S$0.98 per unit.
Cuscaden Peak’s Times Properties makes an offer to privatise Paragon Reit for S$0.98 per unit.
The Reit's higher revenue for the second half was mainly due to positive rental reversions in its Singapore assets.
The privatisation scheme would allow unitholders “to realise their investment in cash at an attractive valuation with no trading costs”.

site_title: Vietnam to use Chinese loans for US$8.3 billion railway linking both countries
summary: Vietnam plans to use Chinese loans to partly fund an $8.3 billion railway project linking the country to China, with construction expected to start this year and be completed by 2030. The 391 km railway will run from the border city of Lao Cai to Haiphong, a major seaport, and will have a gauge of 1,435 mm, allowing trains to operate at speeds of up to 160 km/h. The project is part of Vietnam's efforts to upgrade its ageing railway systems and support economic development.

images.alt_text: A passenger train leaves Hanoi Railway Station in Hanoi on November 30, 2024. Vietnam will build a $67 billion high-speed railway from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh City, after the country's rubber-stamp parliament gave the go-ahead to the long-awaited project on November 30. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP)

site_title: Alibaba to partner with Apple on AI features, sending shares to 3-year high
summary: Alibaba is partnering with Apple to support iPhones' AI services in China, aiming to help the US company ease declining smartphone sales in its key market. The partnership comes as Apple faces growing competition from domestic rivals, particularly Huawei. Alibaba's chairman, Tsai, said the deal is a recognition of Alibaba's AI capability, while analysts note that the impact for Apple will depend on the speed of rollout of features. The deal is seen as a major win for Alibaba, with its stock price up over 40% so far this year.

images.alt_text: Despite the lingering question marks, Alibaba’s valuations remain attractive to some investors even after the latest rally.
The iPhone maker has not yet unveiled a longer-term partner for its AI offerings in China, after signing a landmark deal with OpenAI to integrate ChatGPT into iPhones.
Alibaba has poured significant resources into its cloud services segment and is engaged in a hot contest to recruit China’s AI developers to use its tools.
Bukalapak has fallen victim to an intense fight for customers in the country of about 280 million people, seen as an attractive market by its bigger international rivals.
Sun Art runs hundreds of hypermarkets across China under brands including RT-Mart.
IM Motors LS6 sport-utility vehicle will go on sale in Singapore in the second half of 2025.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a logo of Alibaba Group at its office building in Beijing, China August 9, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang//File Photo

site_title: Singapore life insurance records higher 2024 sales as annual premium sales climb
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 11.1% year-on-year growth in weighted new business premiums for the fourth quarter, driven by a 27.9% increase in annual premium policies to S$1.2 billion. Integrated shield plans also saw an increase, with about 40,000 more Singaporeans and permanent residents covered. Single-premium policies, however, fell 26.3% to S$322.6 million.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
The Life Insurance Association, Singapore, attributes higher single-premium policy uptake in Q1 to a less-volatile macroeconomic environment.

Data from the CPF Board shows that from 2020 to 2022, 57% of Singaporeans and PRs who paid for higher coverage with IPs to complement their MediShield Life basic health insurance still chose subsidised wards.

site_title: Bezos’ rocket firm bracing for job cuts after years of expansion
summary: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos' space company, is bracing for a large workforce reduction, with hundreds to potentially over 1,000 job cuts, amid a shift to focus on ramping up rocket launches after years of R&D work. The company's CEO, Dave Limp, has noted the success of the recent New Glenn launch, but emphasized that the company's work is just beginning. This move comes after years of delays and development setbacks, and follows a surprise launch of the New Glenn rocket last month. The layoffs are expected to be discussed during an all-hands employee meeting on February 13.

images.alt_text: Thirty storeys tall with a reusable first stage, New Glenn launched around 2 am ET (0700 GMT) from Blue Origin’s launchpad at the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station.
Jeff Bezos (above), ultimately, remains optimistic about Trump’s space policy.

site_title: DBS Foundation Grant awardees use tech to tackle financial literacy, detect elderly falling, improve mental health
summary: DBS Foundation awarded S$4.5 million to 22 businesses, including SpedGrow, SoundEye, and Opsis, to tackle financial literacy, detect elderly falls, and improve mental health. SpedGrow's virtual world app and educational toys aim to teach children and individuals with special needs about financial literacy, while SoundEye's AI-powered fall-detection system helps prevent falls among the elderly. Opsis' AI-based software analyzes facial expressions to determine mental well-being. The grants will support the businesses in scaling up production, expanding globally, and providing essential needs to vulnerable communities.

images.alt_text: Karen Ngui, head of DBS Foundation and group strategic marketing and communications, says: "We need to spark a paradigm shift to tackle ageing holistically."

site_title: Indonesia seeks new deals as ‘shocking’ Trump tariffs roil trade
summary: Indonesia is seeking new trade agreements to diversify its export markets amid US President Donald Trump's plans for tariffs against countries including China, Canada, and the European Union. Deputy Trade Minister Dyah Roro Esti Widya Putri stated that Indonesia will focus on Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreements, such as with Peru, and is also negotiating with Canada and the EU. The country aims to protect its local manufacturers from cheap imports and is prepared to diversify its markets if the US imposes tariffs on Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: President Prabowo Subianto wants to build 3 million affordable houses each year.
The new programme will eventually give Indonesia’s population of more than 280 million people access to preventative screenings for conditions.

Trump-branded hotels, residences and a golf course were part of the blueprint for MNC Lido City – an entertainment park project by a subsidiary of Chinese state-owned construction firm Metallurgical Corporation of China (MCC).

site_title: Jollibee shares rally after foreign ownership cap scrapped
summary: Jollibee shares surged 8.9% on February 13, their largest intraday rise in over four years, after the Philippine Stock Exchange approved the removal of a 40% cap on foreign ownership of the company. The move aligns with changes in Jollibee's articles of incorporation, which remove its ability to own, acquire, or mortgage land. The approval led to a significant gain among large-cap Philippine stocks and outpaced the benchmark index.

images.alt_text: Jollibee tends to grow its presence in countries with a large number of Philippine expats, analysts say.
Jollibee expects to add 750 to 820 stores this year given the consolidation of South Korea’s Compose Coffee which it acquired in July.

site_title: US Bitcoin miners disrupted by Chinese supplier under scrutiny
summary: US Bitcoin miners are experiencing delays in receiving new equipment from Chinese supplier Bitmain due to heightened Customs and Border Protection scrutiny. The delays, which began as early as September, have been exacerbated in the past month and are threatening the competitiveness and profit margins of US miners. The US Commerce Department's blacklisting of Bitmain's artificial-intelligence affiliate Xiamen Sophgo Technologies in January has added to the issue, with US Customs and Border Protection inspecting almost all shipments of Bitcoin mining machines and charging fees that can top $500,000. This has resulted in a 65% decline in imported Bitcoin mining rigs and accessories in January, potentially threatening the competitiveness of US firms.

images.alt_text: World Liberty has been marketed as a DeFi lending platform, it has not become operational yet. So far, the project is known for purchasing niche tokens.
Capital gains on direct Bitcoin purchases are subject to taxes of up to 55 per cent in Japan.

While Bitcoin has been described as a store-of-value similar to gold because of the cryptocurrency’s in-built scarcity – its supply is capped at 21 million – the token has not lived up to the billing.
BlackRock is a leader in ETF issuance, managing more than US$4.4 trillion in assets across such products.
Strategy began its plan in the quarter to raise US$42 billion in capital from equity offerings and fixed-income securities to 2027 as Saylor looks to continue to fund Bitcoin purchases.
While the actions of President Trump towards the deregulation of the US crypto industry have been promising in promoting it, the actions of citizen Trump have been concerning.
Cryptocurrencies trade around the clock, including on weekends, and have lately been sensitive to markets’ broader sentiment.

site_title: MAS review group proposes tax perks to boost Singapore’s equities market as a start
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) review group proposes tax incentives to boost the local equities market, including tax breaks for enterprises and fund managers to list in Singapore. The measures also aim to encourage the launch and growth of funds with substantial investments in local equities. The review group, chaired by Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat, will present more measures later this year to foster longer-term development and growth of the market. While some market players welcome the initiatives, others argue that tax incentives alone may not address the market's fundamental issues, such as pricing and valuation.

images.alt_text: Chee Hong Tat, Minister for Transport, Second Minister for Finance and Deputy Chairman, MAS, delivering a speech at the launch of SIAS Corporate Governance Week 2024 on September 16, 2024
Ranamita Chakraborty

site_title: US inflation data hits regional markets; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% to 3,882.58, with Seatrium leading the gainers, up 10.9% after announcing a MOU with BP Exploration & Production. However, regional markets closed lower, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng and Bursa Malaysia KLCI down 0.2% and 0.7% respectively, following the release of January US inflation data, which showed a hotter-than-expected report.

images.alt_text: Generic picture of SGX Raffles Place, STI showing stock prices on Monday 5 August 2024.
Mia Pei

site_title: Chinese developer rally is already fading after Vanke support
summary: Chinese property developers struggled to maintain a rally in credit and share markets after a brief revival in home sales fizzled, despite government stimulus. A Bloomberg index tracking Chinese builder shares fell 3.3% on Thursday, reversing Wednesday's 8.6% jump. The government's plan to help state-backed China Vanke address a 50 billion yuan funding gap showed optimism, but stopped short of a full bailout, leaving private and defaulted builders without reprieve. The market prices reflect this dichotomy, with defaulted property notes trading at less than 10% of their face value, while Vanke's dollar bonds have risen to about 97 cents from a low of 59 cents.

images.alt_text: Chinese developers are still struggling with a debt crisis.
Vanke and its affiliates would also be allowed to tap other financing sources including new bond sales and bank loans for debt payments.
Despite government support, many buyers prefer second-hand homes due to concerns that developers will still struggle to finish construction on presold projects.
Under the deal, Vanke will provide asset collateral worth up to four billion yuan to Shenzhen Metro through an 18 per cent stake in its property management unit Onewo.

site_title: Cisco raises annual revenue forecast as AI boom boosts networking gear demand
summary: Cisco Systems raised its annual revenue forecast to between $56 billion and $56.5 billion, citing higher demand for its cloud networking gear amid an artificial intelligence boom. The company's shares rose nearly 7% in extended trading. Corporate customers are investing heavily in AI infrastructure, boosting demand for data centers and Cisco's products. The company also approved a $15 billion increase for its share buyback program.

images.alt_text: Cisco’s leadership is trying to ensure that its technology has a place in the rapid build-out of data centres.
The job cuts will reduce Cisco’s headcount of 90,400 by about 7 per cent – a loss of more than 6,300 jobs.

The number of people affected could be similar to or slightly higher than the 4,000 employees Cisco laid off in February, and will likely be announced as early as Aug 14 with the company’s fourth-quarter results.

site_title: Snakes of Singapore: calm, peaceful and surprisingly charismatic
summary: Anthropologist-turned-artist Juliette Yu-Ming Lizeray is painting 30 snakes in 30 days to raise funds for Singapore's wildlife protection group Animal Concerns Research & Education Society (Acres). Lizeray, who has a childhood fascination with snakes, is showcasing the unique qualities of each of the 69 species found in Singapore, many of which are critically endangered. The paintings will be sold or auctioned off on snakesofsingapore.com, with proceeds benefiting Acres. Lizeray hopes her artwork will spark empathy for the snakes and their right to exist alongside humans in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Coming from a broken family, Kim Whye Kee has served three prison sentences.
Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.
Presented by UBS, the premier art fair Art SG featured 105 galleries from 30 countries.

site_title: Singapore’s real median household income growth in 2024 eases to 1.4%
summary: Singapore's median household income growth in 2024 slowed to 1.4% in real terms, down from 2.8% in 2023. In nominal terms, the increase was 3.9%. Headline inflation eased to 2.4% from 4.8% the previous year. Despite lower inflation, household income inequality fell after adjusting for government transfers and taxes, with the Gini coefficient reaching its lowest level since 2000.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Real income growth for 2019 to 2024 was just 0.7 per cent per annum, compared with 3.8 per cent per annum in the five years prior.
In nominal terms, median monthly household income from work rose by 7.6 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Siemens posts better-than-expected profit despite weakness at factory automation
summary: Siemens reported a better-than-expected profit of 2.52 billion euros despite an 8% decline in its industrial profit. Revenue increased 3% to 18.35 billion euros, beating forecasts, while orders came in ahead of expectations. CEO Roland Busch described the start of the 2025 fiscal year as "promising." The results are seen as a proxy for the broader industrial economy, with the company expecting moderate economic growth and full-year sales growth of 3-7%.

images.alt_text: Siemens, whose products range from industrial controllers and software to trains, is targeting comparable sales of 3 to 7 per cent over the next 12 months.

site_title: Baidu to make AI chatbot Ernie Bot free of charge from Apr 1
summary: Baidu, a Chinese search engine leader, announced on February 13 that its AI chatbot Ernie Bot will be made free of charge starting April 1. The move comes as the company faces growing competition in the AI sector, particularly from DeepSeek, which offers comparable AI chatbot services at lower costs. Ernie Bot's latest version, Ernie 4.0, matches OpenAI's GPT-4 capabilities, and Baidu has also launched an advanced search function that will be freely available from April 1. The decision aims to improve technology and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: A safety driver monitors a Lexus vehicle equipped with Pony.ai's autonomous driving system as the car drives on a road during a test event, Beijing, China, May 13, 2021. Pony.ai plans to provide robotaxi commuting services for airport staff within Hong Kong International Airport before expanding into other urban areas in the city, the company said on Friday.
Apple’s long-awaited iPhone 16 launch in September had drawn scorn in China for its lack of artificial intelligence features.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise, oil falls as Trump fans Ukraine peace hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, and Manila all higher, while Singapore, Wellington, and Jakarta fell. The gains were driven by hopes for an end to the Ukraine war, following a phone call between US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin, who discussed peace talks. Oil prices fell, extending losses from the previous day, as investors shifted risk appetite. The US inflation data also showed consumer prices rose 3% last month, above expectations, but did not deter investors, with the euro and pound rallying against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led Asian markets higher thanks to another rally in its tech firms, while Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Jakarta were also up.

site_title: Seatrium jumps 12.6% to S$2.59 after MOU with BP
summary: Seatrium's shares surged 12.6% to S$2.59 after announcing a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with BP Exploration & Production to conduct engineering works on a floating production unit (FPU) in the Gulf of Mexico. The project aims to support BP's deepwater assets in Mexico and New Orleans. The award of the contract is subject to BP's final investment decision, expected later this year.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
In the first phase of development, the Kaskida project will have a capacity to produce 80,000 barrels of crude oil per day.
In the first phase of development, the Kaskida project will have a capacity to produce 80,000 barrels of crude oil per day.

site_title: UK housing demand froze in January market turbulence, say agents
summary: UK housing demand remained stagnant in January due to market turbulence, with benchmark yields reaching levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. Despite this, demand is being propped up by a rush to complete transactions before stamp duty increases in April. Agents report a cooling in agreed home sales, with some areas, like London, expected to see a slowdown. However, RICS' house price index remains on an upward trajectory, and mortgage rates have fallen below 4% in recent weeks, sparking hopes of increased demand.

images.alt_text: A view of residential houses in London, Britain, January 23, 2025. REUTERS/Hannah McKay

site_title: NTUC to pilot mentorship programme to support union members with career guidance
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) will launch a mentorship program to support union members with career guidance, with a pilot initiative set to begin for three unions. The program, called the Company Mentorship Circle, will connect workers with 1,200 mentors and experienced industry leaders for skills and career guidance. The initiative aims to strengthen companies' culture of continuous learning and development, and is part of NTUC's efforts to enhance workers' employability and job security. The program is expected to benefit over 250 workers and is seen as a step towards expanding career mentorship programs for youths and pushing for quality internships.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

NTUC secretary general Ng Chee Meng (centre), assistant secretary-general Desmond Choo (left) and Young NTUC executive secretary Wendy Tan briefed the media about the NTUC youth taskforce's findings after engaging more than 10,000 youth over a year.
From Jan 1, 2025, NTUC will raise the retirement age for its workers to 64 and the re-employment age to 69, it said in a statement on Monday (Dec 9).

site_title: UAE company plans nuclear power plant in Indonesia
summary: UAE company Emirates Global Aluminium (EGA) plans to build a nuclear power plant in Indonesia with a capacity of up to five gigawatts, addressing high electricity prices and a lack of low-carbon electricity. The move comes after EGA met with Indonesia's Economic Minister Airlangga Hartarto to discuss aluminium industry development. The project aims to increase the capacity of an aluminium smelter in North Sumatra by up to 400,000 tonnes per year. The statement was released after the meeting between Hartarto and EGA's CEO in Dubai.

site_title: Seatrium inks MOU with BP for deepwater production unit in offshore US
summary: Seatrium has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with BP for a deepwater floating production unit (FPU) in the Gulf of Mexico. The project will be located 300 miles southwest of New Orleans, supporting BP's deepwater assets. Seatrium will provide engineering, procurement, construction, and commissioning services for the Tiber FPU. The agreement builds on their collaboration on the ongoing Kaskida FPU project, with the Tiber FPU project subject to BP's final investment decision later this year.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
In the first phase of development, the Kaskida project will have a capacity to produce 80,000 barrels of crude oil per day.

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation jumps, reinforcing Bank of Japan rate-hike bets
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation rose to 3% in December, the fastest annual pace in 16 months, reinforcing bets of a near-term interest rate hike by the Bank of Japan. Wholesale inflation jumped 4.2% for the fifth straight month, driven by rising prices for goods such as food, textiles, and non-ferrous metals. The yen's weakness continued to inflate costs, and the two-year government bond yield rose to 0.805%, the highest level since October 2008.

images.alt_text: Japan's overall consumer price index rose 3.6 per cent in December from a year earlier, much faster than a 3.0 per cent gain in the core index that strips away the effect of volatile fresh food prices.

Honda Motor vehicles bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan, Feb 6, 2025. Japan's trade deficit narrowed by 40 per cent to 3.9 trillion yen on brisk exports of automobiles and chipmaking equipment as well as lower costs of energy imports.
The IMF’s warning comes as Japan ramps up spending to address a broad spectrum of needs ranging from bolstering national defence to efforts to raise the birthrate.

Consumer spending in Japan climbed 2.7 per cent in December from a year earlier, data from the internal affairs ministry showed on Friday, better than the median market forecast for a 0.5 per cent uptick.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield drops to 2.9%
summary: Singapore's six-month Treasury bill cut-off yield dropped to 2.9% in its latest auction, receiving S$23.3 billion in applications for the S$7.3 billion on offer, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 3.19. The median yield fell to 2.78% and the average yield to 2.52%. This comes as the Monetary Authority of Singapore plans to issue up to S$450 billion in government securities, with a new limit expected to last until 2029.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Powell says: “We are attentive to the risks to both sides of our dual mandate, and policy is well-positioned to deal with the risks and uncertainties that we face.”
Demand falls for latest Singapore Savings Bond with 10-year average return of 2.82%
DBS analysts say a “wall of money” could soon flow into S-Reits, as retail investors turn away from T-bills.

site_title: BlackRock fund gives up China towers after opting to miss loan
summary: BlackRock's fund has forfeited a Shanghai office complex to Standard Chartered after failing to make a loan payment for the property. The fund had taken out a 780 million yuan (S$144 million) loan for two towers in 2018. This move comes amid weak demand for distressed commercial real estate in China's biggest cities, where rent cuts and a slump in value are triggered by the country's slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Negotiations began before a Feb 10 deadline for BlackRock to sign a so-called passivity agreement to comply with new oversight of its stakes.
BlackRock is a leader in ETF issuance, managing more than US$4.4 trillion in assets across such products.

Vanguard unleashed its largest-ever fee reduction this week, slashing its average asset-weighted expense ratio to just 0.07 per cent across its US$10 trillion under management – a sliver of the industry average of 0.44 per cent.
Blackrock is hiring for its iHubs, as the centres are known, in Mumbai and Gurugram, a satellite town near New Delhi

site_title: Musk will pull OpenAI bid if ChatGPT maker remains a non-profit, lawyers say
summary: Elon Musk's consortium will withdraw its $97.4 billion bid for OpenAI's non-profit arm if the ChatGPT maker drops plans to become a for-profit entity, according to a court filing. Musk's lawyers stated that if the board preserves the charity's mission and removes the "for sale" sign, the bid will be withdrawn. If not, the charity must be compensated by the amount an arms-length buyer would pay for its assets. OpenAI's board has not received a formal bid, and CEO Sam Altman has called the bid "ridiculous."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in front of Elon Musk photo in this illustration taken March 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Sony hikes profit forecast on strong gaming business
summary: Sony has upgraded its annual net profit forecast to 1.08 trillion yen (S$9.44 billion), up from an earlier projection of 980 billion yen, driven by strong sales of its games, music, and financial products in the October-December quarter. The company reported a 18% increase in sales to 4.41 trillion yen, resulting in a 3% increase in net profit to 373.7 billion yen. The boost was also attributed to a weaker yen, providing additional revenue. Sony's annual sales forecast was lifted to 13.2 trillion yen.

site_title: US inflation tops forecasts, bolstering case for Fed to hold
summary: US inflation rose in January, exceeding forecasts, and strengthened the case for the Federal Reserve to hold interest rates steady. The consumer price index (CPI) increased 0.4%, fueled by higher grocery prices, gas costs, and housing expenses. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, also rose 0.4%, exceeding expectations. The data suggests inflation progress has stalled, keeping the Fed on hold for the foreseeable future, and policymakers await further clarity on President Trump's tariffs, which are causing consumer inflation expectations to rise.

images.alt_text: The overall CPI measure is seen also rising 0.3 per cent on a monthly basis, driven by higher prices for energy and food – most notably eggs.
Imports increased 3.5 per cent to an all-time high of US$364.9 billion. Exports fell 2.6 per cent to US$266.5 billion.

site_title: Commerzbank to cut 3,900 jobs, mainly in Germany, as it fends off UniCredit
summary: Commerzbank, Germany's No 2 bank, plans to cut 3,900 jobs by 2028 as part of a strategic revamp to fend off UniCredit's advances for a tie-up. The job cuts, mainly in Germany, will be accompanied by hiring outside the country, keeping the bank's full-time positions steady at 36,700. Commerzbank aims to incur €700m in restructuring charges and raise some of its 2027 targets, including a net profit of €3.8bn and a cost-to-income ratio of 53%. The bank's CEO, Bettina Orlopp, says the strategy update will reveal the "significant value potential" of the bank.

images.alt_text: Unicredit says it expects the BPM deal to add to its earnings per share in the high single digit range within two years following the settlement of the exchange offer.

site_title: Pimco opens office in Dubai as asset managers flock to region
summary: PACIFIC Investment Management Co (Pimco) has opened a Dubai office, becoming the latest major fund manager to deepen its presence in the Middle East. The Newport Beach, California-based firm, managing around $2 trillion, secured a license from the Dubai Financial Services Authority. This move underlines Pimco's commitment to clients in the UAE, particularly the growing wealth sector. Dubai's family offices control over $1 trillion in assets, making it a significant competitor to financial hubs like London and Hong Kong.

site_title: Trump and Putin agree to Ukraine talks in US policy reversal
summary: US President Donald Trump agreed to negotiate an end to the war in Ukraine with Russian President Vladimir Putin in a surprise phone call. The conversation marked a reversal of three years of US policy and caught European officials off guard. Trump stated that the two leaders will start negotiations immediately, with a possible meeting in Saudi Arabia. The move has raised concerns among European allies, who feared it could amount to a giveaway to Putin.

images.alt_text: An LNG plant in Russia. As EU leaders prepare for a potential deal between Moscow and Kyiv, the thorny question of cheaper Russian gas looms large.
Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are seen by Russia as possible venues for a Trump-Putin summit.
Russian President Vladimir Putin last week said Moscow would hold talks with Ukraine, but ruled out speaking directly to Volodymyr Zelensky (pictured).
US President Donald Trump and his administration reportedly believe there are ways of toughening measures to press Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the conflict in Ukraine.

site_title: Audi opens Singapore CBD retail location in pivot to direct sales
summary: Audi has opened its first direct-to-consumer retail location in Singapore, marking a shift away from traditional dealership models. The 10,000-square-foot showroom, Audi House of Progress, offers online sales and a physical retail experience, featuring interactive displays, a bar, and a golf simulator. This move follows Porsche's similar shift in early 2024. Audi's Singapore managing director, Markus Schuster, said the direct-to-consumer approach will enable the brand to interact with customers more effectively and drive sales.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The job cuts are to focus on so-called indirect jobs at Audi, such as in the area of development, where over 2,000 jobs could go.
The Audi Group said that operating earnings slumped 91 per cent to 106 million euros (S$152 million) in the three months through September.
The Yangwang U9, a fully-electric supercar from BYD's sub-brand, with more than 1,000 horsepower, on display at the Singapore Motorshow 2025.
Starting in January 2025, customers in Singapore can shop for their new cars at Audi’s new experience centre downtown.
BMW walked back its outlook in September after a faulty braking system forced it to recall as many as 1.5 million vehicles, which took a particular toll on deliveries in China.
Jaguar's Type 00 concept car presages what the brand's new, fully-electric models could look like.

site_title: South Korea’s tech exports lose growth momentum as risks rise
summary: South Korea's technology exports experienced a contraction in January for the first time in over a year, with a 0.4% decline in shipments compared to the previous year. The decline was primarily driven by a decrease in demand from China, which saw a 9.2% drop in imports of South Korean tech products, including semiconductors. In contrast, the US boosted imports by 24.6% from a year earlier. The contraction raises concerns about the potential impact of protectionism and emerging trends on the semiconductor market.

site_title: US Federal Reserve’s Powell sees a ways to go on shrinking Fed holdings
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell indicated that the central bank's balance sheet reduction process, known as quantitative tightening, has "a ways to go" and is unlikely to end soon. The Fed has reduced its holdings by over $2 trillion since starting the process, aiming to reduce market liquidity while maintaining control over interest rates. Powell expressed concerns about a potential repeat of the 2019 liquidity crisis, which led to aggressive Fed intervention. Some banks have pushed back their end-date estimates for quantitative tightening, with estimates now suggesting it may end in June.

images.alt_text: Powell says: “We are attentive to the risks to both sides of our dual mandate, and policy is well-positioned to deal with the risks and uncertainties that we face.”
The Fed has said it plans to overhaul its stress tests of big banks to smooth out changes in required capital levels from year to year.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.98 points or 0.1% to 3,869.64 at 9:01 am on Thursday, following mixed overnight performance in the US and Europe. Losers and gainers were evenly matched at 53 after 52.1 million securities worth S$57.8 million changed hands. Local banking stocks rose, while offshore company Seatrium rose 1.3% and water treatment company Memiontec fell 21.6%.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
Singapore shares track regional gains; STI up 0.4%

site_title: Singapore in the Intelligent Age
summary: Singapore aims to establish impactful tech leadership in the "Intelligent Age" with initiatives outlined in Budget 2025. The city-state will focus on trusted, purpose-driven advancements, leveraging AI, quantum computing, and other new technologies to drive economic growth and societal benefits. Key measures include investing in structured training programs, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in AI adoption, and promoting industry-wide data standardization. Additionally, Singapore will prioritize a future-ready workforce, embedding sustainability in innovation, and fostering trust through robust governance frameworks to drive responsible innovation.

images.alt_text: Local celebrities Li Nanxing (left) and Gurmit Singh now have AI avatars on idoLive, which can handle endorsements at a fraction of the usual price.

site_title: China land sales show property market stabilising: report
summary: China's property market is showing signs of stabilizing, with land plots in key cities selling at high premiums. Land auctions in Beijing, Zhengzhou, Shenzhen, and Hangzhou have recorded premiums, contrasting with earlier auctions that closed at low prices. A residential plot in Zhengzhou, Henan province, saw an 87.5% premium after 255 rounds of bids, the highest since 2021. Supportive policies and improving market confidence are contributing to the stabilization, according to a report by the Economic Information Daily.

images.alt_text: china land property Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

Analysts expect China property's sales and prices to decline this year, but at a slower pace than in 2024.

site_title: OpenAI plans to simplify AI products in new road map for latest models, CEO Altman says
summary: OpenAI plans to simplify its AI products, merging the o-series and GPT-series models into a single AI system. CEO Sam Altman announced the move, citing a desire to make AI "just work" for users, amidst increased investor scrutiny. The company will release a GPT-5 model incorporating o3 and other technologies, as well as a GPT-4.5 model for complex reasoning tasks. The changes aim to create more versatile AI systems, but no timeline for the release has been shared.

images.alt_text: Inside OpenAI, the training-focused chip is viewed as a strategic tool to strengthen OpenAI’s negotiating leverage with other chip suppliers.

site_title: Ukraine war settlement speculation soars as Munich conference nears
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is reportedly preparing to unveil a plan to end the Ukraine war at the Munich Security Conference, which may include freezing current battle lines and Western security guarantees for Ukraine. The plan could also involve new presidential elections in Ukraine and favorable US access to Ukrainian critical minerals in exchange for support. However, the deal may face opposition from EU leaders who are hesitant to restart Russia's pipeline gas sales to Europe, citing concerns about cheaper Russian gas and the future role of Russian gas in the post-war energy mix.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the liquefied natural gas plant operated by Sakhalin Energy at Prigorodnoye on the Pacific island of Sakhalin, Russia July 15, 2021. Picture taken July 15, 2021.  REUTERS/Vladimir Soldatkin/File Photo

site_title: SMEs must expand overseas, invest in upskilling for long-term growth: DBS
summary: Singaporean SMEs must adapt to rising costs and global uncertainties by expanding overseas and upskilling, according to DBS' managing director and group head for corporate and SME banking, Koh Kar Siong. The bank hopes Budget 2025 will enhance schemes to support SMEs' internationalization and upskilling efforts, and provide short-term relief through an extension of the corporate income tax rebate. Koh also suggests increasing funding for internationalization efforts, such as the Market Readiness Grant, and extending the validity of the SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit and Senior Employment Credit.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Singapore’s economic outlook remains positive, but potential risks loom. Geopolitical tensions, particularly escalating global trade conflicts, could disrupt global supply chains and dampen demand.

site_title: Opec warns that US trade policy risks stoking market volatility
summary: OPEC warns that US trade policies, particularly those imposed by President Donald Trump, risk stoking market volatility and creating supply-demand imbalances. The group's monthly report notes that Trump's tariffs on China and steel/aluminum imports have added uncertainty to markets, affecting crude prices near $76 a barrel. Opec and its allies, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, will decide in the coming weeks whether to resume production halted since 2022, amid concerns about the impact of Trump's policies on global markets.

images.alt_text: One Opec+ source said that the removal of US EIA data was because the agency was not providing communication on the information required and was not driven by politics.

site_title: Meta accounting move on AI servers to boost profit this year
summary: Meta is extending the useful life period of its servers and networking assets from four to five years, reducing depreciation expenses by an estimated $2.9 billion in 2025, or 4% of pre-tax profits. This change is part of the company's efforts to boost profit by building out its AI capabilities, with planned capital expenditures expected to increase by 75% this year. Similar changes have been made by other tech companies, including Microsoft and Oracle, highlighting the challenges of depreciating short-lived assets in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: Job cuts have been consistent at Meta in recent years.
The company uses AI to improve ad targeting and boost user engagement.
Slower digital advertising sales at Meta, responsible for the overwhelming share of its revenue.

site_title: Osim overhauls product details after competition watchdog raises concerns
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has raised concerns over Osim's product information, citing misleading promotional discounts and labelling. The CCCS found that Osim's product suitability information was not clearly disclosed, and refunds were not allowed once consumers opened the packaging. The company also used the "Stanford Medicine" logo in promotional materials, potentially misleading consumers. Osim has since removed the logo and disclosed product suitability information, and agreed to implement an internal compliance policy to ensure adherence to Singapore's fair trading laws.

site_title: Nissan and Honda set to update on relationship after merger talks stall
summary: Nissan and Honda, Japan's third-largest and second-largest automakers, are set to update on their relationship after merger talks stalled. The two companies will formally call off a $60 billion merger plan after negotiations were complicated by growing differences. Nissan is pushing ahead with a restructuring plan that includes cutting 9,000 jobs and reducing global capacity by 20%. The company is now open to working with new partners, with Taiwan's Foxconn seen as a potential candidate.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Logos of Nissan Motor Corporation and Honda are seen at a joint press conference on their merger talks, in Tokyo, Japan, December 23, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Gold inches up on trade war fears, inflation data on tap
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to a record peak of $2,942.70 on Tuesday, driven by concerns over US President Trump's tariff plans that could spark a global trade war and inflation. The US consumer price index increased more than expected, reinforcing the Federal Reserve's message that interest rate cuts would wait until inflation returns to 2% target. Investors await producer price index data for further insights on monetary policy, which may impact gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation.

images.alt_text: Ggold leasing rates in India have doubled within a month to a record high.

site_title: Alibaba becomes China’s new AI darling with US$87 billion rally
summary: Alibaba's shares have surged 46% since January, expanding its market value by nearly $87 billion, making it the best performer in China's Big Tech universe this year. The rally is driven by optimism about Alibaba's efforts to develop its own AI services and platform, which gained traction after Chinese AI startup DeepSeek unveiled technologies that caused a rout on Wall Street. Despite lingering question marks, Alibaba's valuations remain attractive to some investors, with the company's shares trading at 12.2 times forward earnings, below its five-year average.

images.alt_text: The iPhone maker has not yet unveiled a longer-term partner for its AI offerings in China, after signing a landmark deal with OpenAI to integrate ChatGPT into iPhones.

site_title: Adobe launches AI video tool to compete with OpenAI
summary: Adobe has released the Firefly Video Model, an AI tool that generates video clips to compete with OpenAI's Sora and Runway services. The tool is geared towards film and television studios using Premiere Pro, generating 5-second clips at 1080p resolution. Pricing starts at $9.99 for 20 clips per month, with a "Premium" plan for studios to be released later this year. Adobe focuses on quality over longer clips, aiming to create clips that resemble film.

images.alt_text: Adobe says the video model is trained on public domain or licensed content that it has permission to use, and not on any Adobe customer content.
Adobe has staked its future on building models trained on data that it has rights to use, ensuring the output can be legally used in commercial work.
Adobe says the video model is trained on public domain or licensed content that it has permission to use, and not on any Adobe customer content.

site_title: Sorry, T-bills. It’s time to look elsewhere for yields
summary: Singapore's Treasury bills (T-bills) have seen dwindling demand since the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates in September 2024, with cut-off yields for six-month T-bills falling from 4.4% in 2022 to 3.04% in the latest auction. Analysts from DBS Group Research predict a "wall of money" could flow into S-Reits, which offer yields of around 6.2%, as retail investors turn away from T-bills. The analysts estimate S$4 billion to S$7 billion could potentially be reinvested in S-Reits, with yields improving due to the sector's recent decline amid interest rate uncertainty.
