site_title: Gold set for sixth successive weekly gain; US jobs data in focus
summary: Gold prices are set to log their sixth consecutive weekly gain, steadying near record-high levels at $2,859.59 per ounce. The metal's appeal is lifted by trade war jitters and investors await the US non-farm payrolls data for cues on the US economic health. Spot gold has gained over 2% this week, with bullion hitting an all-time high at $2,882.16 earlier this week, and US gold futures added 0.3% to $2,884.20. The US jobs report is expected to offer more clues about the economy's overall strength, potentially impacting interest rates and gold's appeal.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a safe investment during economic and geopolitical turmoil, but higher interest rates reduce the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: India’s central bank delivers first rate cut in nearly five years
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) cut its key repo rate by 25 basis points to 6.25% for the first time in nearly five years, aiming to stimulate the sluggish economy. The decision is in line with economists' predictions, marking the first reduction in India's key rate since May 2020. The RBI governor noted that growth is expected to recover, but at a lower pace, and inflation dynamics have opened space for rate easing. India's government forecasts annual growth of 6.4% in the year ending in March, below initial projections.

images.alt_text: In a bid to avoid President Donald Trump’s growing tariff actions, India has already reduced average import tariff rates to 11 per cent from 13 per cent on several items in the latest budget.
Asia’s third-largest economy has been struggling with slackening consumption.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise ahead of key US jobs data
summary: Asian markets rose ahead of US jobs data, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, and Taipei gaining, while Seoul and Manila declined. Tokyo was weighed by a stronger yen. Investors await the US jobs report, which could boost hopes for an interest rate cut, and are also monitoring the Trump administration's hardball trade agenda, which has sparked retaliatory levies with China and other countries. Despite the uncertainty, analysts say the White House's moves have been less strident than initially feared, and the market is currently enjoying relative calm.

images.alt_text: An electronic stock board displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average outside a securities firm in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, Jan. 28, 2025. site_title: Xiaomi hits new high on China’s subsidy programme boost
summary: Xiaomi's shares surged to a fresh record in Hong Kong after announcing two new products, a high-end vehicle and 15 Ultra phones, set to be released by month-end. The company's existing smartphones also benefited from China's increased consumer subsidies. Analyst Frank He raised Xiaomi's smartphone shipment forecasts by 2% in 2025 and 3% for 2026, citing the subsidy programme and declining AI costs. The stock has rallied 12% this week, following a 120% surge in 2024, driven by the company's strong performance in China's EV market.

site_title: Ride-hailing platform Lyft ties up with Anthropic for AI-powered customer care
summary: Lyft has partnered with Anthropic, an Amazon-backed startup, to integrate AI-powered tools for customer care operations. The Claude AI model has reduced customer service resolution time by 87% and resolves thousands of requests daily. Lyft plans to use AI to resolve initial issues and guide customers to human support if needed. The company emphasizes that human customer support agents will still be necessary, particularly for complex issues like safety and deactivations. The partnership aims to improve operations and potentially benefit both riders and drivers in the future.

images.alt_text: US District Judge Trina Thompson in San Francisco said shareholders in the proposed class action did not show why it was unreasonable for Lyft to need 42 minutes to fix its Feb 13, 2024 release, instead of doing it immediately.
Lyft has implemented several initiatives this year to attract and retain more drivers, including guaranteed minimum earnings and higher pay for longer trips.
Tesla has been under pressure to justify its high valuation and prove it can lead the industry in autonomous vehicle technology.
Lyft had nearly 3,000 employees at the end of last year.

site_title: Trump’s World Liberty Financial plans to create ‘strategic’ token reserve
summary: US President Donald Trump's DeFi project, World Liberty Financial, plans to create a "strategic" token reserve, with the platform having already purchased niche tokens worth millions of dollars. Trump's sons, Donald Jr, Eric, and Barron, are listed as Web3 Advisors to the project. The reserve's objective is unclear, but the move follows Trump's pledge to form a digital asset stockpile and his executive action to evaluate its creation. The project has not yet become operational and has raised questions about potential conflicts of interest for the Trump family.

summary: Peter Kwee, a Singaporean businessman, has been in the news due to his involvement in the automotive and property development industries. He made his fortune through car distributorships, particularly with Renault and Volkswagen, through his company Group Exklusiv in the early 2000s.

site_title: Asean currencies at the mercy of Trump’s tariff twists – here is how they stack up
summary: South-east Asian currencies initially weakened due to the US dollar's gain, but have strengthened against the greenback in recent days. The US dollar index rose 1% ahead of a potential trade war between the US and its trading partners. Analysts expect the currencies to recover in the second half of the year, as the US and its trading partners reach a trade agreement. Vietnam and Malaysia have been particularly affected by the tariffs, with Vietnam seeking a lower rate and Malaysia moving to shield its economy from tariff threats.

site_title: It’s spellbinding! Riveting! A triumphant tour de force!
summary: Simon & Schuster is cutting back on book blurbs, citing the saccharine and often insincere nature of the quotes. The practice, which dates back to the 18th century, has been criticized for exaggerating a book's quality and reflecting the social connections of authors rather than their literary skills. The publisher aims to focus on producing "good books" rather than relying on quotes, and will instead use the time to improve the writing itself.

site_title: Luxury London hotel secures refinancing to avoid being sold
summary: A luxury London hotel, BoTree, has secured a £310 million refinancing to avoid a sale. The five-star hotel, located on Marylebone Lane, was put up for sale in October as lenders sought to recoup £275 million. The refinancing deal, provided by BlueWater Capital and NorthWall Capital, will allow the property's developer, Shiva Hotels Group, to retain control and complete the remaining two floors. The hotel's developer had originally bought the site for £100 million in 2016 and has spent about £375 million on construction.

images.alt_text: Housing prices have surged in Seoul despite recent political instability.

site_title: Salesforce, Workday are hiring more overseas to save cash
summary: Tech companies Salesforce and Workday are shifting hiring outside the US to cut costs. Following investor pressure to focus on margins, they are cutting jobs while highlighting cost savings from international hires. Salesforce's COO Brian Millham suggested considering cheaper locations like India and Mexico City for talent acquisition. This strategy aims to balance AI investment with profit constraints, a trend observed since late 2022.

images.alt_text: More than 1,000 Salesforce roles will be affected.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares rose at Friday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.1% or 5.47 points at 3,835.89. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 64 to 29, with 29.7 million securities worth S$64.3 million changing hands. Local banking stocks were mixed, while international markets closed mostly higher, driven by positive earnings reports from European mining companies.

letting more foreign 
investors buy homes
summary: New Zealand's Foreign Minister Winston Peters hinted at relaxing rules for foreign investors to buy homes, aiming to attract wealthy overseas business people. Currently, only Australians and Singaporeans are allowed to be non-resident homeowners. Peters, who also serves as Deputy Prime Minister, stated that home ownership is part of building the economy, but emphasized that details must be seen first. He proposed a change in stance as the government advances a pro-growth agenda, targeting more foreign investment.

site_title: YouTube is buying TikTok ads to lure creators before US ban
summary: YouTube is running ads on TikTok targeting creators, aiming to lure them away from the app as the US ban, which could go into effect in early April, looms. This effort comes as Meta Platforms' Instagram and X also try to win over TikTok's content creators. YouTube's move is seen as a strategic play to capitalize on TikTok's uncertain future, while Google benefits from a potential ban. Meanwhile, ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, denies any sale of its US operations, despite MrBeast, YouTube's top creator, being in conversations with bidders.

images.alt_text: The new tools include ways to optimise content for display on large screens and offer the content in formats more akin to the TV norm of episodes and seasons.

site_title: Trump wants a sovereign wealth fund for the US. What are they?
summary: US President Donald Trump has signed an executive order to create a sovereign wealth fund, with the goal of generating $1 trillion in returns within 12 months. The fund's type and purpose are unclear, with speculation ranging from a rainy-day fund to a strategic investment fund, potentially used to buy TikTok. The US already has 20 sovereign wealth funds, with a total value of over $13 trillion, but experts warn of risks, including corruption and loss of legitimacy. The fund's success depends on maintaining "arms-length independence" from politicians and making informed investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has said that he was in talks with multiple people over TikTok’s purchase and would likely have a decision on the app’s future in February.

site_title: Scientists claim to have cracked how to cook the perfect egg
summary: Scientists have developed a new method to cook the perfect egg, optimizing its taste and nutritional quality. The method, which involves cooking the egg in cycles between boiling water at 100°C and lukewarm water at 30°C, allows for a stationary state at the centre of the yolk to be reached at a constant temperature of 67°C. This results in a yolk that is cooked to perfection, while the egg white reaches cooking temperature. The method also has a "better advantage over conventional cooking methods in terms of nutritional content," with yolks containing more polyphenols.

images.alt_text: Fiery peppercorn chicken features nuggets of chicken in a bed of dried chilli.
Latido's Colombian-inspired decor.

site_title: US initial jobless claims pick up, still near pre-Covid levels
summary: US initial jobless claims rose by 11,000 to 219,000 in the week ended Feb 1, slightly exceeding the median forecast of 213,000. Despite this increase, the level of initial claims remains near pre-Covid levels, indicating a stable labor market. This aligns with Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's description of the labor market as "pretty stable" and ADP Research's data showing a healthy pace of hiring in January.

images.alt_text: Imports increased 3.5 per cent to an all-time high of US$364.9 billion. Exports fell 2.6 per cent to US$266.5 billion.
The pullback in openings was driven by professional and business services, partially reversing a surge in the prior two months.
The automobile industry is likely to take the biggest hit from tariffs.
Excluding the volatile food and energy components, the PCE price index rose 0.2 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.1 per cent increase in November.

site_title: Fighting global warming in nations’ self-interest: UN climate chief
summary: The UN's climate chief, Simon Stiell, urged nations to combat global warming by focusing on self-interest, citing economic benefits such as stronger growth, jobs, and lower health costs. Despite the US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, Stiell noted that real progress has been made and many countries are working on their new emissions goals. The UN has set a deadline for submissions by September, with Brazil hosting COP30 in November. Stiell emphasized that climate investment has reached $2 trillion, making the clean energy shift unstoppable due to its economic opportunities.

images.alt_text: Glacial ice from the Greenland Ice Sheet flows around mountains into the ocean on the east coast of Greenland, July 21, 2022. At 2 deg C, the impact of climate change would be even greater, including irreversible loss to Earth’s ice sheets, mountain glaciers and snow, sea ice and permafrost.
Sembcorp Energy Storage System (ESS) at Banyan in Jurong Island, on Feb 2, 2023.
Tracking cognitive diversity can help companies combat groupthink.
Rules for ESG fund disclosures in Europe are currently being overhauled, after investors and even national regulators criticised the existing framework.
Banks’ carbon credit offerings will not turn the tide for the struggling market

site_title: Japan needs immediate deficit cut to fix fiscal path, IMF warns
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned Japan that it needs to take immediate action to reduce its public debt and deficit, which is projected to reach 232.7% of gross domestic product this year. The IMF's Japan mission chief, Nada Choueiri, stated that Japan must plan for fiscal spending needs without increasing its deficits, as the nation's debt servicing costs are expected to jump 25% by 2028. The IMF advises Japan to start fiscal consolidation now, amid a weakened government position and increased spending on national defense and social security.

images.alt_text: International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo is seen outside the headquarters building in Washington, U.S., as IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde meets with Argentine Treasury Minister Nicolas Dujovne September 4, 2018. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas/File Photo

site_title: Citadel gives rare glimpse of US$57 billion gains from its largest funds
summary: Citadel, the largest profitable hedge fund firm, has released financial results for its largest funds, showing gains of $56.8 billion from 2021 to 2024. The funds started with $23.6 billion and netted investors $30 billion, with $7.5 billion in management and performance fees and $17 billion in employee compensation. This rare glimpse into Citadel's operations comes after the firm's $1 billion bond offering required the production of a prospectus for investors, providing a glimpse into the firm's financial performance during a lucrative period.

images.alt_text: Spirit will also raise US$350 million through an equity rights offering, which is fully backstopped.

site_title:
Mortgage rates in US decrease for 
third week, slipping to 6.89%
summary: US mortgage rates decreased for the third consecutive week, falling to 6.89% for 30-year loans. Weaker demand is causing for-sale homes to linger on the market for nearly five years, according to Redfin. Despite lower borrowing costs, home prices remain high, squeezing affordability. New listings are up nearly 8% from the same period last year, indicating a slight easing of the housing market gridlock.

site_title: Puma curbs flow of sneakers from China to US as tariffs kick in
summary: Puma is shifting its focus from Chinese-made sneakers to suppliers in Vietnam and Indonesia as US tariffs on Chinese goods increase. The German sportswear brand now imports only about 10% of its US shoe sales from China, down from 30% previously. CEO Arne Freundt attributes this change to the need for agility in navigating the uncertain trade landscape. Puma is also exploring cost-cutting measures, including a program to streamline material procurement and IT and logistics, to offset the expected impact of a stronger US dollar.

images.alt_text: If found at fault, Calvin Klein parent PVH could be added to an “unreliable entity list” that prevents offending foreign companies from trading with China, subjects them to fines or revokes their staff’s work permit, according to a 2020 order.

site_title: Pound slides on Bank of England rate cut as investors fret about ‘stagflation’
summary: The Bank of England lowered interest rates to 4.5% and reduced its growth forecast for this year to 0.75%, sparking concerns about "stagflation" due to rising inflation. Sterling fell 0.8% to its largest daily drop in four weeks, while investors expect further rate cuts. The decision contrasts with the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep borrowing costs steady, and follows global trade tensions and weaker economic growth data.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the Bank of England building, in London, Britain July 3, 2024. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo
British Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves says the government has to do more in order to grow the sluggish economy.
More than half of employers surveyed said they were “extremely likely” to slow their pay increases.

Firms have already started to reduce headcount, as they brace not only for the hike in national insurance contributions, but also a third consecutive increase in the minimum wage that also takes effect in April.

site_title: Industrial property in Singapore among sectors likely to take a hit from JS-SEZ, analysts say
summary: Singapore's industrial property sector is expected to be negatively impacted by the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), with lower costs and manpower advantages in Malaysia making it more competitive. Analysts predict that industries like manufacturing, logistics, and food security may benefit from the SEZ, while retail and office sectors are expected to be less affected. However, the SEZ's completion of the Johor Bahru-Singapore Rapid Transit System (RTS) is expected to boost connectivity between the two countries, potentially affecting the retail sector.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.

The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone creates a "win-win" scenario, with Malaysia having the right resources—renewable energy, land, and emerging talent—while Singapore brings technology and expertise.
Market observers view Johor’s growth is not as competition but as an opportunity for complementary development.
2025 is shaping up to be an action-packed year for Centurion, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

The memorandum of understanding (MOU) was signed by the Singapore Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI), the Associated Chinese Chambers of Commerce and Industry of Malaysia (ACCCIM) and UOB on Thursday (Jan 16).
Malaysia's Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said: "The real potential of Johor and Singapore can only be unlocked if we address the bottlenecks hindering seamless movement."

site_title: L’Oreal sales miss estimates as China demand remains weak
summary: L'Oreal's fourth-quarter sales fell short of estimates, rising 2.5% on a comparable basis, but missing the 3.8% gain anticipated by analysts. The decline was largely due to weak demand in China, where consumer confidence has been hurt by a property crisis and youth unemployment. This slowdown is part of a broader trend affecting the beauty industry, with Estee Lauder Cos also predicting a decline in sales. L'Oreal's operating profit in 2024 rose to 8.69 billion euros, slightly higher than estimates.

images.alt_text: TikTok’s 170 million US users have been especially responsive to the beauty industry.

site_title: Japan’s December household spending beats expectations
summary: Japan's household spending rose 2.7% in December from a year earlier, beating the median market forecast of 0.5% growth. This is the first time spending has increased in five months. On a seasonally adjusted basis, spending rose 2.3% from the previous month. The better-than-expected growth may influence the Bank of Japan's decision on additional interest rate hikes.

site_title: Amazon offers weak outlook on rising spending for AI
summary: Amazon's Q1 profit guidance fell short of analyst estimates, with operating income projected between $14 billion and $18 billion. The company's focus on AI services and cloud computing led to increased spending, with $83 billion in property and equipment purchases in 2024. Despite strong revenue growth, Amazon's shares declined 1% in extended trading. The company's cloud unit, AWS, reported 19% revenue growth, but operating income was below estimates, indicating capacity constraints. Amazon's CEO Andy Jassy has been cutting costs to focus on three business pillars: e-commerce, cloud computing, and advertising.

images.alt_text: AWS is expected to post its strongest revenue increase in eight quarters at 19.3 per cent, according to data compiled by LSEG.

Amazon is in the process of laying off employees in the French-speaking province, and will cut ties with more than 2,600 others who work with delivery partners, according to Quebec’s employment ministry.
Temu and Shein together likely accounted for more than 30 per cent of all packages shipped to the US each day under the de minimis provision.
Customs data from the 27 national authorities will be pooled and a new central EU customs authority (Euca) set up, according to the FT.

site_title: Redefining time
summary: Ulysse Nardin, Urwerk, and Amida have collaborated on unique timepieces that redefine watch design. The Ulysse Nardin Blast (Amoureuxpeintre) features a minimalist aesthetic with a frosted, blurred sapphire dial, while the Urwerk UR-100V "Hunter Green" boasts a full-titanium construction with wandering hour satellites. Amida has also re-released the iconic Digitrend watch, available in three new editions. These innovative designs blend horological innovation and artistic minimalism, showcasing exceptional depth and technical mastery.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
The Franck Muller Silhouette CX Snake is limited to just 28 pieces and is an Asian Pacific exclusive.

site_title: Fiery Hunan fare at Spicy Moment
summary: Spicy Moment, a new restaurant on Duxton Hill, serves authentic Hunan cuisine in tasteful surroundings. The menu features dishes like springy fried noodles, steamed fish head, and spicy braised pork belly. The restaurant's interior is tasteful, making it a must-visit for those seeking a unique dining experience. Spicy Moment is open for lunch and dinner, Tuesday to Sunday, and can be reached at 8068 3598.

images.alt_text: Latido's Colombian-inspired decor.

site_title: Hong Kong gets swept up in Trump’s trade war with China
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade war with China has drawn Hong Kong into its scope, threatening the city's status as a global financial hub. Trump's tariffs on Hong Kong goods, which apply to manufactured goods, are expected to have limited damage to the economy. However, the US actions targeting both Hong Kong and China underscore fresh geopolitical risks for the city. The Hong Kong government has condemned the US tariffs and warned of taking action in the World Trade Organization. The city's business sector is also facing pressure, with companies potentially facing scrutiny in regions where the US is vying for influence.

images.alt_text: Consumers are reluctant to spend after a dip in housing prices, hitting retailers and investment that already suffered from an exodus of international residents and pullback in Chinese spending.

site_title: Seven & i consortium said to tap Bank of America, Citi for financing
summary: A consortium led by Seven & i Holdings' founding family and Itochu has tapped Citigroup and Bank of America for financing in a potential record-breaking management buyout bid. The consortium, valued at around 9 trillion yen, aims to take the company private and is also seeking an equity stake from Thai conglomerate CP All. The deal would allow Seven & i to restructure in private and prevent a takeover by Canadian retailer Alimentation Couche-Tard. Bank financing would cover about 4 trillion yen in equity stakes, with the Ito family and Itochu contributing around 1.5 trillion yen and 500 billion yen, respectively.

images.alt_text: The takeover effort values the sprawling convenience store conglomerate at an estimated US$58 billion.

Seven Bank launches ATM service in Malaysia, marking its fourth overseas venture. From left: Masaaki Matsuhashi, president of Seven Bank; Tan U Ming, executive director and co-CEO of 7-Eleven Malaysia; and Dr R Palan, chairman of SMRT.
Under the current proposal, which is subject to change, Apollo would join the Ito family and Itochu, the operator of FamilyMarts in Japan, as key investors.
Seven & i has been spurred into radical action to fend off Couche-Tard’s approach.

site_title: How liberals lost America
summary: In the 2024 US presidential election, Democrats' focus on moral neutrality and preachiness alienated white working-class voters, contributing to Donald Trump's victory. While centrists blame the "woke agenda" for this, progressives argue that economic populism was the issue. However, policies like keeping China tariffs and providing subsidies to American industries did not resonate with Trump's base. Experts agree that a "condescending" approach to blue-collar workers and a lack of moral connection with voters are key issues. Effective liberal politics must balance moral values with respect and dignity, promoting policies that align with voters' moral intuitions, rather than imposing them.

images.alt_text: Opponents and supporters of Republican presidential nominee and former U.S. President Donald Trump clash on the day of a rally for him that will be held in Madison Square Garden, in New York, U.S., October 27, 2024. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz

Migrants on a boat arriving at the Canary island of El Hierro. Tens of millions of people are likely to flee Africa and Latin America in the coming years, driven by political and economic challenges and climate change.

Populists such as Trump appeal to voters’ deep-seated values and sensibilities by connecting to people’s identities, and by understanding much better than liberals the tribal nature of contemporary politics.
The political attacks on ESG seem to be working—mentions of ESG on earnings calls have fallen of late. Or perhaps companies that are committed to ESG are just being quieter about it.

site_title: F&N Q1 profit up 18.8% at S$52 million as soft drinks, beer sales jump
summary: F&N, a beverage maker, reported a net profit of S$52 million for the first quarter, an 18.8% increase from the same period last year. Revenue rose 16.3% to S$618 million, driven by a 39% jump in soft drinks and beer sales. The company's profit before interest and taxes increased 14% to S$91.9 million, led by earnings from the beverages segment. Shares closed 0.8% higher at S$1.27.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
F&N's FY2024 revenue growth is largely driven by the strong performance of its F&B segment.

site_title: OpenAI’s Stargate AI venture is scouting for US data centre sites
summary: OpenAI is scouting for US data centre sites for its Stargate AI venture, a $500 billion investment in AI infrastructure, to compete with China's growing AI capabilities. The initial data centre in Abilene, Texas, is already under construction, and the company expects to use it later this year. OpenAI is evaluating 16 states for potential sites, with Texas as the flagship location, and may announce more sites in the coming months. The project aims to establish the US as a leader in AI development, but a recent Chinese AI model, DeepSeek, has raised questions about the need for massive data centres.

images.alt_text: The studios and OpenAI have not settled on a deal framework that would work for both sides financially.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon’s family pays S$153 million for serviced apartment block in Orchard area
summary: A Singapore-incorporated company, Grand Prestige Land Pte Ltd, has bought Oakwood Studios Singapore, a serviced apartment block in the Orchard area, for S$152.76 million. The property, formerly known as Chateau Eliza, was converted into a serviced apartment block after the original intention to redevelop it into a residential project was scrapped due to a lacklustre market. The sale price works out to S$1.59 million per apartment unit, with 96 units available.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Indonesian giant property developer Agung Sedayu Group is building a 1,775 hectares tourism estate on the northen coast Jakarta called Pantai Indah Kapuk 2.

site_title: Oil settles down after Trump repeats pledge to boost US supply
summary: US oil prices fell 0.4% to $74.29 a barrel on Thursday after President Donald Trump repeated his pledge to boost US oil production, despite concerns that producers may not be willing to pump more oil. Brent crude futures dropped 0.6% to $70.61, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.6% to $70.61. Analysts question the market's reaction to Trump's comments, citing swelling US crude inventories and volatile global trade.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down US$1.59, or 2.09 per cent, to US$74.61 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Apple’s long-awaited overhaul of iPhone SE nears release
summary: Apple is set to unveil a revamped iPhone SE, its long-awaited overhaul of the lower-cost model, in the coming days. The new device will feature a modern design, Apple Intelligence, and Face ID, marking a significant shift from the outdated 2022 model. The iPhone SE will also be the first to include an in-house cellular modem, a larger screen, and a speedier A18 chip. The release is seen as a bid to boost Apple's iPhone business, which has declined in recent quarters, and is expected to be priced around the same range as entry-level smartphones from Samsung and Google.

images.alt_text: China’s State Administration for Market Regulation is reviewing Apple’s policies, including its up to 30 per cent commission on in-app purchases and restrictions on external payment services and app stores.
Apple's overall sales and profits were boosted by stronger-than-expected sales of iPads and Macs, where new chips helped persuade customers to upgrade.
The company is publicising the porn app to showcase its view that the EU’s rules could harm Apple customers in the region.

site_title: HSBC’s head of global banking for Asia-Pacific is exiting lender
summary: HSBC's Asia-Pacific head of global banking, Christina Ma, is leaving the bank after 2.5 years, amid a restructuring effort to cut costs by at least $3 billion. This move comes as part of a major overhaul under new CEO Georges Elhedery, who combined commercial banking and global banking businesses last year. Ma previously spent 21 years at Goldman Sachs, where she held leadership roles. The bank's restructuring plans also involve winding down investment banking operations in Europe, the UK, and the Americas. Ma's departure is part of HSBC's efforts to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Unstoppable retail crowd breaks US stock buying record despite rout
summary: Retail investors in the US continued to buy stocks despite market volatility, breaking a record for the largest inflow of $3 billion on February 3. This surge in appetite, which has reached its highest level in over two decades, shows no signs of fading. Despite fluctuations in global markets, individual investor exposure to US stocks remains near its highest level since 1997, with the US economy remaining resilient.

images.alt_text: South-east Asian currencies initially weakened as the US dollar gained but have strengthened against the greenback in recent days.

Singapore is considered an attractive location for overseas companies setting up headquarters because of its connectivity and its position as a regional hub, said EDB's senior executives at its annual year in review.

Shanghai, which reopened after a week-long break, and Hong Kong were among the main losers as e-commerce firms took a hit from news that the US Postal Service was suspending inbound parcels from China and Hong Kong.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7 per cent to 44,873.28 while the broad-based S&P 500 climbed 0.4 per cent to close at 6,061.48 on Wednesday.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 hits record high on robust earnings, focus on talk of Ukraine peace plan
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index reached a record high on Thursday, closing 1.17% higher at 544.84 points, driven by upbeat earnings reports from mining companies. Benchmark indexes in Germany, France, Italy, and Spain also rose 1.5% each. The sectoral winner was basic resources, led by ArcelorMittal's 13.3% share surge. Investors also weighed the possibility of a Ukraine peace plan, with equity indexes near Russia jumping 3.4% after a report on preparations for a meeting between Putin and Trump.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished lower 0.3 per cent at 44,747.63 on Thursday.

site_title: Ensuring AI works for the Global South
summary: The Global South risks being left behind in the digital economy due to AI, which has the potential to exacerbate existing divides. However, countries like Vietnam are identifying opportunities to leverage AI, with the goal of becoming top 50 AI countries by 2030. Grounding AI in national priorities, prioritizing talent, and government support are key to ensuring AI works for the Global South. By diversifying AI discussions, strengthening domestic enablers, and playing a key role on the global stage, the region can redefine its development trajectory and drive AI demand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 6)
summary: Singapore attracted S$13.5 billion in fixed asset investment (FAI) commitments in 2024, a 6.3% increase from the previous year. The majority of this investment, over half, was in the electronics sector. This is part of the country's efforts in precision medicine, including AstraZeneca's planned new facility for antibody drug conjugates in cancer treatment.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after big corporate results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the S&P 500 rising 10.7 points, or 0.18%, to 6,072.22. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 75.9 points, or 0.17%, to 44,949.19, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 33.5 points, or 0.17%, to 19,725.827. Investors evaluated earnings from companies like Honeywell and awaited US President Donald Trump's next move on trade restrictions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, ST Engineering, Clar, F&N, BRC Asia, Fu Yu, MM2 Asia, Japan Foods
summary: Singapore stocks to watch on Feb 7, 2025, include Singtel, which secured a S$643 million green loan for a new data centre, and ST Engineering, which secured S$4.3 billion in new contracts. CapitaLand Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (Clar) reported a 3.2% increase in distribution per unit, while Fraser & Neave (F&N) reported an 18.8% increase in net profit. BRC Asia saw a 13.9% increase in profit after tax, and MM2 Asia's cinema chain paid back S$12 million in rent. Japan Foods reported a net loss of S$2.9 million for the nine months ended Dec 31.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 30.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly rise after mixed round of earnings
summary: US stocks rose after a mixed round of corporate earnings, with the Dow Jones down 0.3%, the S&P 500 up 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index up 0.5%. Analysts attributed the market's resilience to underlying buying power, despite concerns over President Trump's trade policy. Individual companies saw varied results, with Honeywell falling 5.6% and Ford slumping 7.4%, but Hershey and Eli Lilly gaining 4.4% and 3.4% respectively.

images.alt_text: View of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at Wall Street in New York on February 3, 2025. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Trump’s tariffs on China bite US bargain-hunting online shoppers
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed 10% tariffs on goods from China, affecting American bargain-hunters who buy directly from Chinese websites like Shein and Temu. This means prices for items such as $5 shirts, $10 lamps, and $20 shoes will rise. A college-age daughter in the US received a $45.19 delivery fee for an order from an Australian seller, prompting her to ask if it was a scam. The tariffs are expected to impact the Asian garment industry and raise pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This photo taken on November 10, 2022 shows a man (L) cleaning the windows of the first permanent showroom of online fast fashion retailer Shein during a media preview in Tokyo. The US Postal Service (USPS) has said it is temporarily suspending inbound parcels from China and Hong Kong, evoking an angry accusation of "unreasonable suppression" from Beijing on February 5, 2025. US officials pointed to the growth of Chinese-founded online retailers Shein and Temu as a key factor behind this surge in shipments claiming the exemption in recent years  -- and the halt on February 4 could delay parcels from both companies from entering the country. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Keeping boards relevant in a changing world
summary: Boards must continually evolve to address industry challenges, shifting regulations, and rising stakeholder expectations. Key considerations for boards include adopting modern skill sets, leveraging collective expertise, and cultivating a learning culture. Boards should balance continuity with fresh perspectives by introducing new directors, promoting continuous learning, and fostering a collaborative culture. Effective succession planning and a strategic approach to learning are also crucial to addressing today's fast-paced challenges and ensuring an organization's long-term success.

images.alt_text: Board evaluations are meant to be an exercise in self-reflection and strategic planning, providing accountability and transparency to stakeholders.

While B Corps alone may not save the world on a grand scale, they are a critical component of the larger movement towards a more ethical and sustainable economy.

site_title: Yen hits 8-week high; sterling drops after BOE cut
summary: The yen reached an 8-week high of 151.81 per dollar, its strongest level since December 12, after a Bank of Japan policy board member advocated for continued interest rate hikes. Meanwhile, the pound dropped 1% to $1.2376, its largest one-day slump since January 2, following the Bank of England's interest rate cut and forecast of higher inflation and weaker growth.

site_title: ST Engineering bags new contracts worth S$4.3 billion in Q4 2024
summary: ST Engineering secured S$4.3 billion in new contracts in Q4 2024, driven by strong demand for aerospace solutions and urban infrastructure projects. The company's commercial aerospace segment won contracts worth S$1.8 billion, including a 15-year exclusive contract with Akasa Air and a six-year airframe maintenance contract. The urban solutions segment secured contracts to provide passenger information systems for Singapore's MRT lines, while the defence and public security segment won orders for land systems and cyber solutions. The company expects no material impact on its financial performance.

ST Engineering Urban Solutions, SP Mobility win tender to deploy public EV charging points
The bus infrastructure upgrading exercise will cover about 5,800 public buses.

site_title: Judge pauses Musk plan for mass cull of US government workers
summary: A federal judge in Massachusetts has temporarily blocked a plan by billionaire Elon Musk to slash the size of the US government by encouraging federal workers to quit through a mass buyout. The deadline, set for midnight on Thursday, was extended to Monday for over 2 million government employees to accept a buyout offer of eight months' pay or risk being fired. The plan, backed by former President Donald Trump, has been met with resistance from labor unions and Democratic lawmakers, who argue that the offer is illegitimate and may be worthless without Congressional approval.

The injunction Elon Musk is seeking could halt the transformation of Sam Altman's OpenAI into a more conventional, for-profit public benefit company, just as it is in talks to raise up to US$40 billion in a funding round led by SoftBank Group.

site_title: The rise of Asian wines: A new era in viticulture?
summary: Asian wines are gaining popularity globally, driven by changing tastes among Asian palates and increased awareness through international competitions. China, Japan, Thailand, and India are leading the charge, producing award-winning wines that rival those from established regions. The rise of Asian wines is not just about replicating Western styles but creating something uniquely Asian, with indigenous grape varieties and traditional winemaking techniques. Despite challenges, including inconsistent quality and stigma, Asian wines are on an upward trajectory, offering new tastes, stories, and experiences to wine lovers.

images.alt_text: Red packets are now coming in ever more fancy packaging.

site_title: Rubio snubs G20 meeting citing South Africa’s focus on equality
summary: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio will skip the upcoming G20 summit in South Africa, citing the country's focus on addressing inequality and expropriating private property. His comments echo President Donald Trump's criticism of South Africa's land policy and risk straining US-South Africa relations. The US has provided over $8 billion in aid to South Africa, but Rubio's remarks add to tensions over the country's close ties with China and its refusal to condemn Russia's invasion of Ukraine. South Africa's government has denied expropriating private property and emphasized its commitment to addressing global inequality.

images.alt_text: People crossing railway tracks in Cubal, Angola. The railway is part of the Lobito Corridor that connects the country with Zambia and the Democratic Republic of Congo.
Microsoft Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
Chinese companies invested in South Africa include Huawei Technologies, Hisense South Africa, Zijin Mining Group and ZTE.
Since the pandemic boosted remote work’s popularity, luxury compounds have drawn more affluent foreign residents.
The Johannesburg bourse is gearing up for an IPO in Pick n Pay Stores’ Boxer unit, expected before the end of the year.

site_title: So much for Susie Wiles containing Trump’s chaos
summary: White House Chief of Staff Susie Wiles faces an uphill battle in maintaining order in President Donald Trump's chaotic administration. Despite her efforts to brand herself as the "Ice Maiden" capable of controlling Trump's chaos, recent events suggest she may be struggling to contain the president's antics. Notable incidents include Trump's wholesale pardoning of Jan 6 convicts, a confusing federal funding freeze, and Trump's ongoing trade war with Mexico and Canada. Experts say Trump's leadership style, which fosters chaos and multiple irons in the fire, makes it difficult for any chief of staff to change.

images.alt_text: (First row from left) Elon Musk, Vivek Ramaswamy, Susie Wiles, Pete Hegseth. (Second row from left) Thomas Homan, Elise Stefanik, John Ratcliffe, Mike Waltz. (From bottom left) Marco Rubio, Lee Zeldin, Stephen Miller, Kristi Noem are all nominees raised by Donald Trump.
The prospect that Trump will be president again is impossible to ignore. For liberals, this fact inspires dread. And for good reason.

site_title: DeepSeek fever fuels patriotic bets on China AI stocks
summary: Chinese investors are rushing into AI-related stocks, betting on the breakthroughs of startup DeepSeek, which has created a buzz for its low-cost services. Shares of Chinese chipmakers, software designers, and data centre operators have surged amid patriotic calls for an upward repricing of Chinese assets. Analysts predict a boom in the sector, with Goldman Sachs estimating AI-enabled efficiency improvement could increase earnings by 2% for Chinese equities and lead to a 20% valuation uplift. This move is seen as a reaction to US President Donald Trump's trade war and tariffs on Chinese imports, with DeepSeek's breakthroughs potentially accelerating Chinese AI innovation and prompting tighter US technology export restrictions.

images.alt_text: BT
FILE PHOTO: The deepseek logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration taken January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
DeepSeek has garnered international attention with its latest models, shocking Silicon Valley and investors with their capabilities and efficiency.
Australia upped the ante overnight banning DeepSeek from all government devices, one of the toughest moves against the Chinese chatbot yet.
FILE PHOTO: The deepSeek logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration taken January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

Sam Altman, chief executive officer of OpenAI, says: "DeepSeek is certainly an impressive model, but we believe we will continue to push the frontier and deliver great products, so we’re happy to have another competitor,”
The primary advantage of DeepSeek's artificial intelligence bots lies in their ability to process data more quickly and efficiently.
If DeepSeek’s claims about its spending are accurate, the startup showed that it could train an AI model at a fraction of the amount that Meta, OpenAI and other major developers spend.
The Fed did what almost everyone expected last week: it held the target range for the federal funds rate unchanged at between 4.25 per cent and 4.5 per cent
In a technical report published by Deepseek, the company claims that it used a cluster of 2,048 Nvidia H800 chips over about two months to produce the Deepseek v3 large model.

site_title: Fu Yu gets second letter calling for EGM; business unit probe reveals unverified payment of about US$3 million
summary: Fu Yu Corp received a second letter from largest shareholder Victor Lim, seeking to requisition an EGM to vote on removing and appointing directors amid the company's poor performance. The company's board says they are reviewing the letter and will take legal advice. A business unit probe revealed an unverified payment of about US$3 million to a third party, with potential conflict of interest issues. The board is also investigating unauthorized usage of an email account and secondment of an individual to a business unit.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

Fu Yu’s IDs Christopher Huang and Royston Tan had previously expressed surprise that Lim, who holds a 29.45 per cent stake in the company, had requisitioned for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Jan 9 to have them removed.
Fu Yu's independent directors noted that Victor Lim's request for a board seat had been rejected.

site_title: Bank of England cuts rates as it sees weaker growth and inflation spike
summary: The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter percentage point to 4.5% on February 6, as it revised its growth forecast to 0.75% for this year, citing weaker business and consumer sentiment. The decision was in line with expectations, but two external members voted for a bigger cut to 4.25%. The central bank expects inflation to peak at 3.7% this year and return to its 2% target by the final quarter of 2027. Governor Andrew Bailey said the bank will monitor the economy closely and take a gradual approach to further rate cuts.

site_title: Japan Foods sinks into the red with 9M loss of S$2.9 million
summary: Japan Foods reported a net loss of S$2.9 million for the 9 months ended Dec 31, 2024, compared to a net profit of S$668,000 in the same period last year. Revenue fell 0.6% to S$64.9 million due to weak sales in November and December. The group attributed the loss to higher operating expenses, mainly due to an increased number of operating outlets. The business environment is expected to remain tough, with weak sales continuing into the new year.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Japan Foods said revenue for the period was lower than the nine months ended Dec 31, 2023, mainly due to weak sales in November and December 2024, despite a higher number of operating outlets.
Storefront of Ajisen Ramen.

site_title: Xi calls for China, Thailand to beef up ties to fight global uncertainties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for China and Thailand to deepen trust and expand cooperation to counter global uncertainties. During a meeting with Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Xi emphasized the importance of strategic interests and supporting each other in the face of unprecedented changes. He also highlighted areas for cooperation such as a high-speed railway and digital economy. The visit comes amid growing concerns over online fraud and safety, following the abduction of a Chinese actor in Thailand. Xi praised Thailand's efforts to combat crime and called for strengthened law enforcement and security cooperation.

images.alt_text: China has remained at the top of Thailand’s tourist numbers list in the first two weeks of January, comprising almost a sixth of the 1.3 million arrivals.
Some Chinese travellers are opting to stay away from Thailand for the eight-day Chinese New Year holiday, which starts on Jan 28, due to safety concerns.

Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra says: “There is no hesitation on this. We can cut off power immediately. We must take care of our people first. This has had a significant impact on Thais and the country’s image.”

Scam compounds have mushroomed in Myanmar’s borderlands and are staffed by foreigners who are often trafficked and forced to work, swindling their compatriots in an industry analysts say is worth billions of dollars.

site_title: IHH unit may seek higher compensation in lawsuit against Japan’s Daiichi Sankyo over Fortis deal
summary: An indirect subsidiary of IHH Healthcare, Northern TK Venture (NTK), has submitted a report to the Tokyo District Court detailing a range of compensation it seeks from Japanese pharmaceutical company Daiichi Sankyo over the 2018 Fortis Healthcare deal. The compensation amount ranges from 4.2 billion to 109.3 billion Indian rupees, with the upper bound being significantly higher than the initial 20 billion yen. NTK had previously filed a lawsuit alleging Daiichi Sankyo caused losses by preventing the open offer to buy a stake in Fortis Healthcare.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Gleneagles Hospital is an asset in Parkway Life Reit's portfolio. Based on the latest appraised values, the Reit’s asset portfolio is worth close to S$2.5 billion.
The quality of foreign operators that come to China will be also crucial for the development of the sector.

site_title: UOL, SingLand, CapitaLand Development market Tampines mega project Parktown Residence; prices start at S$1.07 million
summary: Singapore's UOL, SingLand, and CapitaLand Development are launching Parktown Residence, a 1,193-unit condo in Tampines, with prices starting at S$1.07 million (S$2,311 psf) for one-bedroom units. The development is linked to the future Tampines North MRT station and features retail, food, and beverage spaces, a community club, and a hawker centre. The project is part of a 50-50 joint venture between the three companies, valued at S$1.21 billion. Previews begin on February 7, with bookings starting on February 22, and completion expected by June 2030.

images.alt_text: The commercial and residential site will be integrated with a bus interchange, community club and hawker centre.

site_title: Florida orange juice could be tariffs’ most iconic casualty
summary: Florida's citrus industry, which produces iconic orange juice, is at risk due to President Trump's trade war with Canada. The 25% tariff imposed on American exports from "red states" could devastate the industry, which is already struggling with disease and natural disasters. The Florida Citrus Mutual estimates that 30% of Florida's fruit juice is exported to Canada, and a trade war could lead to a 30% increase in the cost of importing Mexican juice, making it cheaper than Brazilian orange juice. The industry's decline could have a significant impact on the state's economy, with over 33,000 jobs and an annual economic impact of over $6.8 billion at stake.

site_title: Vietnam sees upbeat consumption and softer production growth in January on holiday, trade impacts
summary: Vietnam's economy showed signs of growth in January, with retail sales increasing 9.5% year-over-year, the strongest growth since May 2024. The rise in consumption was driven by the Chinese New Year celebrations. However, production growth slowed due to external trade challenges and holiday-related closures. The US accounted for 40% of the total newly initiated trade investigations against Vietnamese export products between 2017 and 2024. This poses a risk to Vietnam's export industry.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s legal overhaul: 6 key laws set to drive growth, boost investments

A man reads a Vietnamese newspaper with a front page story on the inauguration of US President Donald Trump. While Trump's earlier threats of tariffs are not off the negotiating table yet, pundits say Asean now has more leverage.

site_title: First Greenland, then Gaza: Trump’s new world order
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced plans to take over the Gaza Strip, relocate its 2 million residents to Jordan, Egypt, and other Arab states, and transform the territory into a tourist destination dubbed the "Riviera of the Middle East." Trump claims this will be achieved through "maximum pressure" on Iran to abandon its nuclear ambitions. However, critics argue that the US does not own Gaza and that relocating Palestinians would face strong opposition from Jordan, Egypt, and other Arab nations. The plan also ignores historical conflicts and cultural clashes in the region, raising concerns about the feasibility and potential consequences of such a move.

images.alt_text: As fighting raged in the Gaza war, Palestinians feared they would suffer from another “Nakba”, or catastrophe, referring to the time when hundreds of thousands were dispossessed of their homes in the 1948 war at the birth of the state of Israel.

Palestinians waiting to be allowed to return to their homes in northern Gaza; the vast majority of Gaza’s people have been displaced, often multiple times, by the Gaza war that began after Hamas’s attack on southern Israel on Oct 7, 2023.

site_title: Boeing expects Indian, South Asian airlines to add over 2,800 jets in next 20 years
summary: Boeing expects Indian and South Asian airlines to add over 2,835 commercial aircraft to their fleet over the next 20 years, a four-fold increase over current levels, driven by a rising middle class and healthy economic growth. The region's airlines are expected to take delivery of 2,445 single-aisle aircraft and 370 widebody jets, with air traffic growth projected at over 7% annually through 2043. This represents a significant increase from the previous forecast of 2,705 jets.

images.alt_text: Boeing shares fell 2.5 per cent in after-hours trading as the company projected quarterly revenue of US$15.2 billion, below expectations of US$16.27 billion.

site_title: Maersk eyes 4% market growth in 2025, uncertainty over tariffs and Red Sea
summary: Maersk, a shipping giant viewed as a barometer of world trade, expects 4% growth in global container shipping this year despite US President Donald Trump's tariff threats and uncertainty over the Red Sea. The company's underlying Ebitda rose to $3.6 billion in the fourth quarter, beating forecasts. Maersk's CEO Vincent Clerc attributes the lack of impact from tariffs to consumption, noting that if tariffs lead to inflation, it could reduce volumes. The company expects an Ebitda result of $6-9 billion this year, with a forecast range influenced by the Red Sea situation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Danish shipping company AP Moeller - Maersk names low-emission ship Antonia Maersk, which sails on green methanol, in Aarhus Harbor, Denmark August 9, 2024. Ritzau Scanpix/Mikkel Berg Pedersen via REUTERS    ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. DENMARK OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN DENMARK./File Photo
Maersk no longer go through the Red Sea on the Asia-Europe route because of the risk of attack by Huthi rebels.
Danish shipping company AP Moeller-Maersk's revenue was US$15.8 billion in third quarter, beating the US$14.4 billion forecast by analysts.

site_title: BRC Asia Q1 profit after tax rises 13.9% to S$19.5 million
summary: BRC Asia reported a 13.9% increase in profit after tax to S$19.5 million for Q1 2025, despite a 12.4% decline in revenue to S$349.8 million. Gross profit fell 19% to S$28.7 million. The company's sales order book stood at around S$1.5 billion, with projects up to five years in duration. BRC Asia cited strong forecasts for construction demand in Singapore as a positive outlook for the local reinforcing steel industry.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: Shein, Temu retailers slapped with 30% levy on US bound goods
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed a 30% levy on goods imported from China and Hong Kong to the US, effective immediately. This includes a 10% tariff on goods with a declared value under $800, previously duty-free. Logistics agents are demanding an additional 30% deposit from retailers such as Shein and Temu, which must be returned or topped up based on customs charges. The move is expected to cause logistical delays and potentially harm businesses, with some factories on thin margins, and could decrease China's export growth.

images.alt_text: Tensions are already running high between Shein and Temu and their suppliers and merchants in China.

site_title: Consumers’ prepayment losses more than quadruple to S$1.9 million in 2024: Case
summary: Consumers in Singapore lost over S$1.9 million in prepayments in 2024 due to businesses becoming unresponsive, with the renovation industry accounting for the highest losses at about S$728,000. This is a significant increase from S$476,000 in 2023. The Consumers Association of Singapore (Case) is urging consumers to engage CaseTrust-accredited companies to protect their interests. The association received 14,236 complaints in 2024, with a 4% improvement in resolution rates, and is calling for updates to laws and increased consumer education to better protect online shoppers.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
The total amount of losses was a sharp increase of 24 per cent from S$520,000 in 2021, said the Consumers Association of Singapore.

site_title: Trump administration presses government workers to accept buyout ahead of deadline
summary: The Trump administration is pressuring US government workers to accept a buyout offer ahead of a midnight deadline, with over 40,000 employees having already accepted the offer. The proposal aims to cut the federal workforce by 2%, with the Education Department warning that paychecks could stop at any time. Unions have sued to block the plan, citing potential law violations, and a federal judge is set to consider their request. The move is part of Trump's effort to cut wasteful spending and slim down the bureaucracy, but Democrats argue it is illegal and will have significant consequences for the government.

images.alt_text: White House chief of staff Susie Wiles and US national security adviser Mike Waltz look on as President Donald Trump speaks during a meeting with Israel's prime minister in the White House Oval Office on Feb 4, 2025.

A demonstrator holds fliers encouraging federal workers not to resign during a protest against Elon Musk outside the US Treasury building in Washington, DC, Feb. 4, 2025. The US Treasury Department confirmed Tuesday that Elon Musk’s government efficiency team has been given “read-only” access to “coded data” of the government’s payments system.
On Monday, Elon Musk said USAID will be shuttered, calling the agency which runs relief programmes in about 120 countries a “criminal organisation.”
Speaking more broadly about cutting US expenses and fraud, Elon Musk estimated the Trump administration can cut US$1 trillion from the US deficit next year.

site_title: Cathay Cineplex has paid back S$12 million owed to landlords; remaining S$2.7 million is a quarter of total sum
summary: Cathay Cineplex, operated by mm2 Asia, has paid back S$12 million of its S$14.7 million owed rent to landlords, leaving a remaining balance of S$2.7 million, which is a quarter of the total sum. The cinema chain's slower-than-expected recovery of the industry led to delays in paying arrears. The company is now negotiating with lenders to secure short-term working capital loans.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The cinema chain received the letters of demand on Jan 28.

site_title: Nissan seeking new partners with Honda deal set to collapse: sources
summary: Nissan Motor is seeking a new partner after ending discussions with Honda Motor to form a joint holding company, citing the need for a technology sector partner and US-based entity. The deal, which would have made Honda a subsidiary, was met with strong opposition within Nissan. The company's current plans do not include plant closures, but it is exploring restructuring options, including cutting 9,000 jobs and reducing production capacity. Nissan's shares jumped 8.7% in early trading after news of the deal collapse.

images.alt_text: Before Honda’s move on Nissan, the two inked a partnership to carry out joint research in the area of platforms for next-generation software-defined vehicles.
Honda aims to debut 30 electric models and sell four million electric bikes annually by 2030.

Nissan and Honda have been in talks to explore a merger by 2026, in a historic pivot for Japan’s auto industry that underlines the threat Chinese EV makers are posing to the world’s long-dominant legacy car makers.
Nissan has pledged to cut 9,000 jobs globally and reduce production capacity by 20 per cent.

site_title: US banning trade loophole will cut China’s growth, Nomura says
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to ban Chinese companies from using a US tariff loophole will cut China's growth by 0.2 percentage point this year, according to Nomura economists. The loophole, used by companies like Shein and Temu, allowed them to ship small parcels to the US with minimal tariffs, resulting in $46 billion in exports last year. The new tariff will slash these shipments, cutting total export growth by 1.3 percentage points and reducing China's GDP growth this year.

site_title: Workday to cut nearly 2,000 workers on profit focus
summary: Workday, a software company, is cutting approximately 8.5% of its workforce, resulting in about 1,750 job losses. CEO Carl Eschenbach cited the need for a new approach due to the company's size and scale. The cuts are part of Workday's focus on durable growth, with plans to hire in strategic areas such as artificial intelligence and expand overseas.

images.alt_text: The technology industry has long paid workers a large chunk of their compensation in company stock.

site_title: Malaysia rolls out bold tax perks for Johor-Singapore SEZ with an eye on tech, talent
summary: Malaysia has rolled out a tax incentive package for the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), offering 5% special tax rate for up to 15 years and 100% investment tax allowance on qualifying capital investments over five years. The package aims to attract investors and strengthen cross-border economic ties, focusing on advanced manufacturing, global services, tourism, and smart logistics. The incentives are available to both new and existing companies operating within the JS-SEZ's flagship zones, with applications open until December 2034.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Business across sectors including manufacturing, logistics and the digital economy can benefit from the improved cross-border flow of goods and people, said the Singapore minister of state.

The memorandum of understanding (MOU) was signed by the Singapore Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI), the Associated Chinese Chambers of Commerce and Industry of Malaysia (ACCCIM) and UOB on Thursday (Jan 16).
Market observers view Johor’s growth is not as competition but as an opportunity for complementary development.
Numerous project launches surrounding the upcoming RTS station are in the pipeline.

Khairussaleh Ramli, Maybank's group president and chief executive officer, says the Corporate Renewable Energy Supply Scheme in place in the special economic zone to give businesses there access to green electricity will make it an attractive destination for sustainable and transition finance.
Malaysia's Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said: "The real potential of Johor and Singapore can only be unlocked if we address the bottlenecks hindering seamless movement."
The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.

Malaysia's Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli speak at the Malaysia Economic Forum 2025 in Kuala Lumpur on Jan 9. He said the  implementation details of the Infrastructure Fund for the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone is currently under discussion.

site_title: A fifth of Melbourne’s offices are empty as home working endures
summary: A fifth of Melbourne's offices are empty, with 18% of office space vacant, according to data from the Property Council of Australia. This is 4.3% above the national average, with Sydney and Brisbane also experiencing high vacancy rates. Melbourne recorded its highest period of negative demand since 2022, indicating a decline in office space demand.

site_title: Bank of Japan must raise rates to 1% by latter half of fiscal 2025, board member Tamura says
summary: Bank of Japan board member Naoki Tamura stated that the central bank must raise short-term interest rates to at least 1% by the second half of fiscal 2025 to contain inflation risks. Tamura, known as a hawkish member, believes that inflationary risks are building up and require lifting the policy rate to levels deemed neutral to the economy. This move is aimed at achieving Japan's 2% inflation target, which is expected to be sustainably achieved by the latter half of fiscal 2025.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit H2 DPU rises 3.2% to S$0.07681
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's second-half distributable income rose 3.4% to S$338 million, with a DPU of S$0.07681, a 3.2% increase from the previous year. Despite a 1.1% decline in revenue to S$753 million, net property income rose 1.4% to S$521.5 million. The company plans to invest S$800 million in redevelopment projects, aiming for a 3-4% revenue boost in the next two to three years.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Ry-Anne Lim
CICT, which purchased a 50 per cent interest in Ion Orchard and its connecting underpass last year,

The fall in revenue was partially offset by improved performance in CapitaMall Grand Canyon, Rock Square (pictured) and CapitaMall Yuhuating, following the completion of asset enhancement initiatives.
The properties are located in Senai Airport City, an industrial and manufacturing hub in the Senai region, which is part of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone in Malaysia.

site_title: Michael Saylor’s Strategy has another loss before accounting shift kicks in
summary: MicroStrategy, formerly known as Strategy, reported a fourth consecutive quarterly loss of US$670.8 million, or US$3.03 a share, due to a US$1 billion impairment charge on its Bitcoin holdings. The company's cash holdings fell to US$38.1 million, and its Bitcoin holdings now total 471,107 tokens, worth around US$46 billion. MicroStrategy aims to raise US$42 billion in capital by 2027 to fund Bitcoin purchases. The company will implement new accounting for crypto assets, which could trigger a 15% corporate alternative minimum tax.

images.alt_text: The firm uses regulated exchanges such as Coinbase to purchase Bitcoin, Michael Saylor says.

site_title: Nomura soars to 16-year high as profit jump cements recovery
summary: Nomura Holdings' shares surged to a 16-year high, reaching 1,077 yen, after the Japanese brokerage reported a 101.4 billion yen (S$889.5 million) profit in the third quarter, more than doubling from the previous year. The company's revenue from global markets, fixed-income, and equities rose 39%, 35%, and 45%, respectively, beating market estimates. Despite scandals affecting the company, CEO Kentaro Okuda has steered Nomura to an earnings recovery, with a cost savings measure reaching a four-year low.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a branch of the Nomura financial services group in Tokyo, Japan, April 28, 2016. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo
Nomura’s bounce back in the fourth quarter was echoed on Wall Street.
Japan’s biggest brokerage had completed most of those steps by March, including structural changes at its wealth management business at home.
Shares of Nomura opened lower in Tokyo trading on Friday, falling as much as 2.7 per cent.

site_title: HSBC upgrades Grab to ‘buy’ on attractive valuations, growth drivers ahead
summary: HSBC upgraded its rating on Grab to "buy" due to attractive valuations and intact growth drivers, citing a 14% compound annual growth rate in on-demand gross merchandise value from 2024 to 2026. The bank predicts robust growth, with earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) expected to rise 66% to US$533 million in 2025. Maybank also maintained its "buy" call, citing potential synergies from a Grab-GoTo merger, although the bank noted regulatory challenges.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The unprofitable firms have held on-and-off talks for years, targeting a combination that would reduce costs and competitive pressure in the region.

site_title: Far East, Perennial to unveil Aurea residential tower at prices starting from S$1.92 million
summary: Far East Organization and Perennial Holdings will unveil the 45-storey Aurea residential tower in Beach Road, Singapore, with prices starting from S$1.92 million (S$2,750 per square foot). The tower, part of the transformed Golden Mile Complex, will feature 188 units and be completed in 2029. Early-bird pricing for commercial units starts at S$3,100 per square foot. The complex will also include offices, medical units, and retail spaces, and is a five-minute walk from Nicoll Highway MRT station.

images.alt_text: URA granted developer GMC Property permission to add four storeys of office space to the conserved Golden Mile Complex.
Golden Mile Singapore is an integrated development which includes The Golden Mile and Aurea, a new residential tower.

site_title: Gold firms near record peak as trade war concerns linger
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,867.79 per ounce, near an all-time high, amid Sino-US tariff war concerns and ahead of US payrolls data. Investors sought safe-haven assets as trade tensions lingered. Higher interest rates reduced gold's appeal, but the metal's price remained stable, with US gold futures shedding 0.2% to $2,887.10. The recent record high of $2,882.16 was maintained in the previous session.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.2 per cent at US$2,847.33 per ounce.

site_title: Bain is said to near 500 billion yen deal for Mitsubishi pharma unit
summary: Bain Capital is nearing a deal to buy Mitsubishi Chemical Group's pharmaceutical unit, Mitsubishi Tanabe Pharma, for over 500 billion yen (S$4.4 billion). The US-based private equity firm has outbid other investment funds, with talks still ongoing. A deal could be announced as soon as Friday, Feb 7, after Nikkei first reported the news last month.

site_title: Saudi Aramco boosts prices to Asia as Middle Eastern crude soars
summary: Saudi Aramco has raised the price of its Arab Light oil to Asia by $2.40 a barrel, the largest increase since August 2022, amid surging premiums for Middle Eastern crude and improving refinery margins. The price hike is attributed to US sanctions on Russian oil and increasing demand for Middle Eastern crude. Refining margins in Asia have also improved, with some processors cutting back production, making the price increase more justifiable. The move affects all regions, with larger increases seen in Europe and smaller ones in the US.

images.alt_text: US sanctions on Russian crude tankers may impact over two million barrels, but it is too early to assess market tightness, according to Saudi's Aramco CEO Amin Nasser.
FILE PHOTO: Oil tanks seen at the Saudi Aramco headquarters during a media tour at Damam city November 11, 2007.    REUTERS/ Ali Jarekji/File Photo
The Opec+ alliance has been curtailing output to prop up the market with group-wide cuts in production extending throughout next year.

(FILES) This picture shows Aramco tower (C) at the King Abdullah Financial District (KAFD) in Riyadh on April 16, 2023. Saudi oil giant Aramco on August 6, 2024 reported net profit of $29.07 billion in the second quarter, a slight drop from the same period last year as output remained subdued. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)

site_title: SocGen doubles Q4 profit as retail unit rebounds
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) has reported a 28% increase in fourth-quarter profits to 1.04 billion euros, exceeding analyst estimates. Revenue grew 11.1% to 6.6 billion euros, driven by a recovery in its retail bank and increased equity market trading. The bank also announced a higher-than-expected share buyback program of 872 million euros and will pay out 50% of its net income to shareholders. CEO Slawomir Krupa's turnaround plan appears to be paying off, with the bank's cost-to-income ratio falling to 69.4% and return on tangible equity reaching 6.9%.

images.alt_text: epa11872788 A man passes by French banking group Societe Generale's headquarters in the Paris financial district of La Defense, France, 03 February 2025. EPA-EFE/CHRISTOPHE PETIT TESSON

site_title: Tariffs not the only driver of investment decisions, ‘too early’ to predict impact on Singapore: EDB
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) says it's too early to predict the impact of US tariffs on investments in the country. EDB Managing Director Jacqueline Poh notes that companies consider long-term factors, such as growth opportunities, competition, and stability, when deciding to invest. While tariffs could affect global trade and growth, EDB Chairman Png Cheong Boon emphasizes that Singapore remains an attractive location due to its connectivity, manufacturing base, and regional hub status.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
EDB managing director Jacqueline Poh and chairman Png Cheong Boon at the agency's annual year in review.

site_title: eFishery backers to weigh liquidation, buyout among options
summary: eFishery, an Indonesian agritech company, faces an internal probe alleging revenue and profit inflation over several years. An adviser has recommended investors decide on liquidation, buyout, or restructuring by the end of the month. Shareholders will vote on a course of action, while staff union pushes for cancellation of mass job-cut plans. An independent review will assess eFishery's cash flow, loans, and assets before the decision is made, with a timeline still fluid. The outcome will significantly impact the company's future.

The allegations of fraud may be damaging for Indonesia’s startup scene, and come at a critical time as young companies and investors in the country struggle to raise new funding.

site_title: 👾 Can AI create a better resume than the average young adult? We try it out
summary: A recent test involved uploading a resume to AI chatbot ChatGPT to assess its ability to create a better resume than an average young adult. The results showed that while ChatGPT provided some useful suggestions, such as reorganizing experience and using bullet points, its generic advice was often unhelpful. The chatbot struggled to provide industry-specific jargon and was unable to track the user's day-to-day progress at work. Experts warn that relying solely on AI tools for resume help can lead to a lack of personalized touch and inflated appearances at the interview stage. Instead, jobseekers should focus on crafting a clear, KPI-led resume that reflects their unique skillsets.

site_title: Nippon Steel 9-month profit slides 18%, says no surety US Steel deal will close
summary: Nippon Steel, Japan's largest steelmaker, reported an 18% drop in nine-month net profit to 362 billion yen due to sluggish steel demand in Japan and overseas. The company maintains its fiscal year forecast at 310 billion yen despite its bid for US Steel being blocked by former US President Joe Biden, with no guarantee the transaction will close. Nippon Steel attributes the decline to unchanged real demand and margins at home and abroad.

site_title: Sonos cuts 12% of workers in bid to improve product organisation
summary: Sonos is cutting 12% of its workforce, approximately 200 employees, to streamline its product teams and improve collaboration. The move comes after the company parted ways with CEO Patrick Spence and follows a failed mobile app revamp that negatively impacted sales. Interim CEO Tom Conrad plans to reorganize the company into functional groups, focusing on cross-functional project teams to deliver new products and improve the core experience. The restructuring is expected to result in $15-18 million in charges.

images.alt_text: Sonos first sued Google for patent infringement in Los Angeles and at the US International Trade Commission in 2020, accusing the tech giant of copying its technology during their collaboration in devices including Google Home (pictured) and Chromecast Audio.

site_title: SGX’s H1 net profit rises 20.7% to S$340 million following high growth in all revenue segments
summary: SGX posted a 20.7% net profit rise to S$340 million for the first half of 2025, driven by growth across all business segments. Revenue increased 15.2% to S$682.2 million, with cash equities and equity derivatives leading the group's broad-based performance. The interim quarterly dividend was declared at S$0.09 per share, payable on February 21. The company expects some moderation of macro tailwinds in the near term, but remains optimistic about its medium-term outlook.
