site_title: EU sees a path to negotiate with Trump to avoid a tariff fight
summary: The European Union is preparing to negotiate with US President Donald Trump to avoid a tariff fight, following his delayed decision to broaden tariffs on Mexico and Canada. The EU has prepared extensive retaliatory lists, but a major hurdle is establishing good contacts with the US administration, as some key trade posts are still awaiting Senate approval. Commission President Ursula von der Leyen vowed a firm response if targeted unfairly, and the EU is planning to target politically sensitive constituencies in the US for tariffs.

images.alt_text: France's President Emmanuel Macron speaks during the annual "Fete de la musique" one-day music festival in the courtyard of the Elysee presidential palace in Paris on June 21, 2024. June 21, marks the annual start of  'Fete de la Musique', a tradition marking the first day of summer, during which music is encouraged to be played outdoors. (Photo by Bertrand GUAY / AFP)

site_title: Toyota raises full-year profit outlook by 9% to 4.7 trillion yen, to establish EV, battery unit in China
summary: Toyota, the world's top-selling automaker, raised its full-year profit forecast to 4.7 trillion yen (S$41.5 billion), a 9% increase from its previous estimate of 4.3 trillion yen. The company cited progress in improving product competitiveness as the reason for the upward revision. This move suggests confidence in its ability to withstand potential US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The automaker plans to continue pursuing driver-assistance technology for use in consumer automobiles.
Factoring in parallel imports, Toyota was the top selling car brand in Singapore, but BYD was number one in authorised dealer sales.
Sales of Toyota’s parent-only vehicles fell 1.4 per cent from a year earlier in 2024 to 10.2 million vehicles due to a double-digit decline in Japan.
Before Honda’s move on Nissan, the two inked a partnership to carry out joint research in the area of platforms for next-generation software-defined vehicles.
Nissan has two plants in Mexico, where it makes the Sentra, Versa and Kicks models for the US market.
Honda aims to debut 30 electric models and sell four million electric bikes annually by 2030.

site_title: South Korea inflation accelerates to six-month high amid weak currency
summary: South Korea's consumer price index rose 2.2% in January, a six-month high, exceeding market expectations. The inflation rate accelerated for the fourth consecutive month, surpassing the central bank's 2% target. A weak local currency contributed to the increase, which was fueled by a 0.7% monthly rise in the CPI. The Bank of Korea has signaled that it will wait for domestic turmoil to stabilize before making further interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: South Korea's output rose for the first time in December last year since August, thanks to accelerated growth in new export orders, despite sluggish domestic demand, sub-indexes showed.
South Korea is one of the world’s biggest exporters with technology products at the core of its earnings.
The impact of levies on China are also set to dent activity in the world’s second-largest economy, with spillovers across the region.

site_title: Singapore’s solar energy deployment on track to meet Green Plan targets, but waste to landfill reduction lags
summary: Singapore has achieved 1.35 GWp of solar energy deployment, on track to meet its 2025 target under the Singapore Green Plan 2030. However, progress to reduce waste sent to landfill has stalled, with waste to landfill per capita per day remaining the same as pre-pandemic levels in 2018. Lower recycling rates, attributed to higher freight costs, import restrictions, and lower demand for recycled materials, are cited as the main reason for the stagnation. The government plans to strengthen efforts, including introducing a beverage container return scheme in 2026 and exploring the use of landfill mixed materials.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Budget 2025 provides an opportunity to bolster green investments by introducing tailored financial tools, refining existing green finance initiatives, and allocating carbon tax revenue transparently.

site_title: Chipmakers say Trump’s tariff threats cloud their outlooks
summary: Chipmakers, including Infineon Technologies, NXP Semiconductors, and STMicroelectronics, expressed cautious optimism despite US President Donald Trump's tariff threats. Infineon's forecast, released on Tuesday, predicted a slight revenue uptick in 2025, excluding the impact of a potential trade war. The US has restricted high-tech chip sales to hobble Chinese technology development, leading to a slump in the industry. Despite this, China remains a bright spot, with EV sales remaining robust, and companies like Infineon and NXP benefiting from market share growth in the region.

images.alt_text: A conversation between China President Xi Jinping (right) and US President Donald Trump (left) is seen as key to a potential easing or delay of tariffs, as conversations with Mexican and Canadian leaders did on Monday.
US exports to China have fizzled as the Asian country struggles to revive its economy and as its shift to electric vehicles dims demand for motor fuels.
Xi has been relying on manufacturing and overseas sales to keep growth ticking along as he moves to burst a property bubble, all while dealing with increased deflationary pressure.

site_title: Thailand to roll out next phase of handout scheme in Q2, plans more stimulus
summary: Thailand's government plans to roll out the third phase of its 450 billion baht stimulus scheme in the second quarter of 2025, providing an additional 10,000 baht to an estimated 45 million people through its digital wallet scheme. Since its launch in September 2024, about 17.5 million people have received payments, with the goal of stimulating the economy this year. The government also plans to discuss further measures later this month to support economic growth.

images.alt_text: Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra says: “There is no hesitation on this. We can cut off power immediately. We must take care of our people first. This has had a significant impact on Thais and the country’s image.”
A view of the port of Bangkok, Thailand May 26, 2016.  REUTERS/Jorge Silva
Domestic auto sales in 2024 fell 26.2 per cent annually to the lowest level in 15 years, and the FTI said the rejection rate for auto loans reached 70 per cent.

Thailand's economy may have expanded close to 2.7 per cent in 2024, with the final-quarter pace weaker than forecast, at north of 3 per cent, Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput said in an interview.

site_title: Singapore aware of companies’ worries about Johor-Singapore SEZ, will monitor impact: Alvin Tan
summary: Singapore's government is aware of potential concerns about the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) and is monitoring its impact. Minister of State Alvin Tan acknowledged worries from industries, particularly the transport and logistics sector, which may be affected by Malaysian logistics entering Singapore. However, Tan emphasized that businesses across sectors can benefit from the improved cross-border flow of goods and people, and companies can set up operations on both sides of the border, with headquarters and research functions in Singapore.

site_title: Australia bans DeepSeek AI program on government devices
summary: Australia has banned the Chinese chatbot DeepSeek from all government devices, citing privacy and malware risks. The decision, made on the advice of security agencies, is one of the toughest moves against the AI program. The ban was issued by the Department of Home Affairs Secretary Stephanie Foster, who deemed the use of DeepSeek products an "unacceptable level of security risk" to the Australian Government. The ban applies to non-corporate Commonwealth entities, requiring them to remove existing instances of DeepSeek on government systems and mobile devices.

site_title: GM’s Cruise to cut 1,000 jobs as robotaxi service shuts down
summary: General Motors (GM) is cutting approximately 1,000 jobs at its Cruise driverless car unit as part of a strategic shift away from the robotaxi business. The company will halt robotaxi service and absorb operations into its broader business, with several top executives leaving the unit, including CEO Marc Whitten. GM plans to continue pursuing driver-assistance technology for consumer automobiles, focusing on share buybacks and its electric vehicle business. The move is expected to save the company around $500 million this year.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor Group, including Hyundai Motor and Kia, ranks third in global vehicle sales behind Toyota Motor and Volkswagen.
GM is pulling back just as Alphabet’s Waymo expands into more cities and Tesla plans to start its robotaxi business in 2026.
GM expects to write down the value of its joint-venture operations in China by as much US$2.9 billion.

site_title: Zelensky says would agree to direct talks with Putin: interview
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said he would agree to direct talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the war, which has lasted almost three years. Zelensky stated that he would participate in talks with four participants, including Russia, Ukraine, the EU, and the US. The talks come amid anticipation and are seen as a potential breakthrough in the conflict. Zelensky expressed skepticism about the possibility of Ukraine regaining lost territory and emphasized the need for a NATO membership roadmap to ensure security guarantees.

images.alt_text: “We’d like to see denuclearisation ... and I will tell you President Putin  (R)really liked the idea of cutting way back on nuclear. And I think the rest of the world, we would have gotten them to follow, and China would have come along too,” says Trump(L).
US President Donald Trump and his administration reportedly believe there are ways of toughening measures to press Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the conflict in Ukraine.

Many of the high-end projects being developed are located in central areas near the city’s biggest attractions and have vast onsite parks.

site_title: Top climate scientist declares 2 deg C climate goal ‘dead’
summary: Top climate scientist James Hansen declares the 2-degree Celsius climate goal as "dead" due to increased greenhouse gas emissions and a recent decline in sunlight-blocking aerosol pollution. The target, set by the Paris climate accord, is now considered impossible, with temperatures projected to stay at or above 1.5 degrees Celsius in the coming years and rise to 2.0 degrees Celsius by 2045. The shutdown of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) within 20-30 years will trigger devastating sea level rise and other problems.

Meeting Indonesia's pledge to phase out coal power in just 15 years and reach net-zero emissions by mid-century is a "daunting task" that will require immediate and ambitious action, experts warn. Indesia's President Prabowo Subianto offered a surprise commitment at the November 2024 G20 summit to close hundreds of coal and fossil-fuel power plants by 2040, a bold pledge from one of the world's top coal producers and consumers. site_title: US Postal Service ends China parcel suspension, works to reduce disruption
summary: The US Postal Service has lifted its temporary suspension on parcels from China and Hong Kong, allowing shipments to resume after President Trump's administration ended the "de minimis" exemption for low-value packages duty-free. The USPS and Customs and Border Protection are working together to implement a new collection mechanism to minimize disruption to package delivery. This change affects retailers such as Shein and Temu, which rely on the exemption to ship products to the US without paying duties, potentially leading to increased scrutiny and costs for logistics providers.

images.alt_text: Shanghai, which reopened after a week-long break, and Hong Kong were among the main losers as e-commerce firms took a hit from news that the US Postal Service was suspending inbound parcels from China and Hong Kong.
Temu and Shein together likely accounted for more than 30 per cent of all packages shipped to the US each day under the de minimis provision.

The semiconductor industry has long been a part of the ongoing trade war between the US and China, starting in Trump’s first administration and continued by Biden.

site_title: Panama considers cancelling port deal with Hong Kong firm
summary: Panama is considering cancelling its contract with Hutchison Ports, a Hong Kong-based company operating ports near the Panama Canal, amid President Donald Trump's threats to counter China's influence. The potential move is seen as a concession to Trump, who has expressed concerns about China's control over the canal. Hutchison Ports operates two of the five ports adjacent to the canal, with 75% of cargo transiting through the canal going to or from the US. A court challenge to the contract is also underway, with attorneys alleging it violates the constitution.

images.alt_text: The scrutiny comes as Trump accuses Panama of allowing China to meddle in the canal.

A cargo ship transiting through the Panama Canal in Panama City, Panama, Feb 1, 2025. US Secretary of State Marco Rubio told Panama that President Donald Trump had determined that the country had violated terms of the treaty that handed back the crucial waterway in 1999.
CK Hutchison counts most of its revenue from overseas regions including Europe, the Americas and the Middle East.

site_title: From the heartlands to downtown, Tang Tea House brings halal dim sum to more diners
summary: Tang Tea House, a halal dim sum restaurant chain, has expanded to its fifth outlet in Marina Square, Singapore, with a sixth to open in Tampines. Founded 20 years ago by siblings Johnny and Sharonne Tan, the business aims to cater to a wider range of customers, including younger diners. The chain has invested in a central kitchen to improve scalability and consistency, and now generates 40% of its revenue through food delivery. With plans to open more outlets and retail spaces, Tang Tea House seeks to sustain its commitment to halal Chinese cuisine and find a successor to take the brand forward.

site_title: Keppel H2 profit from continuing operations up 19.9% at S$527.9 million
summary: Keppel, a Singapore-based asset manager, reported a 19.9% increase in profit from continuing operations to S$527.9 million for its second half, driven by growth in its real estate and connectivity segments. Revenue rose 3.9% to S$3.4 billion. The group proposed a final cash dividend of S$0.19 per share, unchanged from the previous year. Despite a 6% decline in full-year profit from continuing operations, the company expects opportunities from emerging trends, including artificial intelligence and digitalization.

Despite higher net property income, Keppel Reit's distributable income fell due to higher management fees and borrowing costs.

site_title: South Korea plans 34 trillion won fund to support battery and biotech
summary: South Korea plans to invest at least 34 trillion won (S$31.7 billion) in cutting-edge technologies in the battery and biotech sectors, citing rising geopolitical tensions and competition from China. The government will set up a new fund under the Korea Development Bank to offer low-interest loans and buy stakes in the high-tech industries. The announcement comes amid uncertainty over President Donald Trump's threats to impose tariffs on South Korea, a major chip exporter. Details on the fundraising and timeline for the investments are not specified.

site_title: Singapore investors lead Asean peers with 22% surge in purchase of gold bars, coins in 2024
summary: Singapore investors led the Asean region in purchasing gold bars and coins, with 6.5 tonnes bought in 2024, a 22% surge from the previous year. This surpasses Thailand's 39.8 tonnes. Malaysia and Indonesia also saw increased demand, with 6.4 tonnes and 24.5 tonnes purchased, respectively. The World Gold Council's report indicates rising investment demand for physical gold in Asean markets despite soaring prices.

site_title: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust’s H2 DPU remains at S$0.0545
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a stable second-half distributable income (DPU) of S$0.0545, unchanged from the previous period, driven by contributions from its Ion Orchard retail mall. Total DPU for FY2024 rose 1.2% to S$0.1088. CICT's revenue and net property income (NPI) grew 1.2% and 1.3% respectively, driven by improved performance of existing portfolios. The trust's portfolio value rose 6.2% to S$26 billion, but was partially offset by the sale of 21 Collyer Quay. CICT's CEO Tony Tan expressed confidence in the trust's position, citing improved portfolio occupancy and rental reversion.

site_title: Rates likely to fall over medium term, says senior Fed official
summary: US Federal Reserve Vice-Chair Philip Jefferson says interest rates are likely to fall over the medium term, citing a good US economy outlook. He expects inflation to slow, and economic growth and labor market conditions to remain solid. Jefferson also notes that policymakers don't need to rush their next rate cut, and a gradual reduction in monetary policy restraint is the most likely outcome.

site_title: China’s Chinese New Year box office reaches record US$1.3 billion
summary: China's Chinese New Year box office reached a record US$1.3 billion, with box office sales rising 18% to 9.5 billion yuan. Sequels to popular movies dominated, with "Ne Zha 2" and "Detective Chinatown 1900" taking the top spots. Imax China shattered records, with US$53 million in sales and 4% market share. The surge in box office sales is attributed to efforts by Chinese officials to boost consumer spending, including subsidies and cinema vouchers.

site_title: IBM gives long-term sales growth outlook that tops expectations
summary: IBM has given a stronger-than-expected long-term sales growth outlook, with revenue projected to increase more than 5% annually. The company's software business is expected to gain about 10% annually, while the infrastructure unit is expected to see a 1-3% increase. Consulting, a division that has struggled, is expected to grow ahead of the market. The outlook is seen as cautious, with the consulting segment's gains not expected to rebound in the near term.

images.alt_text: The company's software segment recorded its biggest revenue jump in five years, as customers prioritised spending on cloud infrastructure amid a rush to adopt the data-intensive generative AI technology.
IBM has worked to transform itself from a conventional computer company into one focused on high-growth software and services.
“Granite 3.0” models will be made open-source, similar to other versions in IBM’s Granite family of AI models.

site_title: BlackRock plans to hire 1,200 people for ramp-up in India
summary: BlackRock plans to hire approximately 1,200 people for its iHubs in Mumbai and Gurugram, India, as the company ramps up its presence in the country. This move is expected to bolster headcount by about a third, adding to the roughly 3,500 staff in the Gurugram and Mumbai offices. The new hires will focus on building out the company's artificial intelligence capabilities in India. The move comes as India is projected to become a $110 billion market for Global Central Banks (GCCs) by 2030, employing over 4.5 million people.

images.alt_text: The BlackRock headquarters in New York, US, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2025. BlackRock is scheduled to release earnings figures on January 15. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan’s service activity grows thanks to Asian demand: PMI
summary: Japan's services industry expanded for a third straight month in January, driven by a rebound in new export business on Asian demand. The final au Jibun Bank Service Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 53.0, the highest level since September last year. This growth offset some weakness in the manufacturing sector, providing a positive sign for Japan's economy.

site_title: China tariffs on US oil come as exports have slumped from peak
summary: China has imposed 10% retaliatory tariffs on US oil imports, marking the first round of sanctions, but US oil exports to China have already declined significantly. US oil exports to China peaked at 450,000 barrels a day in 2020 but have since fizzled. China has turned to other suppliers, including Russia and Iran, and may expand to the Middle East, Brazil, and Guyana to replace US oil. The tariffs enter into effect on February 10, but traders speculate that the move may not significantly impact US oil exports.

site_title: Coinbase urges US regulators to clear path for banks to offer crypto services
summary: Coinbase, a leading crypto exchange, urged US regulators to clarify or revise their stance on banks offering cryptocurrency services and potentially collaborating with digital asset firms. The move comes as the industry pushes for a regulatory framework to support growth. Most US banks have avoided digital asset firms due to a lack of regulatory clarity, with Coinbase's chief policy officer stating that regulators' unilateral and undemocratic stance has barred banks from offering crypto services for years.

images.alt_text: Payments are part of an effort by Coinbase to diversify its business away from its heavy reliance on crypto trading fees and towards other services.
Brokerages said trading activity in Singapore spiked after Trump emerged victorious from the US elections last Tuesday (Nov 5).
Fairshake has sought to push both Republican and Democratic candidates to take crypto seriously.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, Keppel, FLCT, Sabana Reit
summary: Key developments in Singapore stocks include: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) posting a distribution per unit of S$0.0545 for the second half ended December, unchanged from the previous period. Keppel reported a 19.9% profit increase to S$528 million for the second half ended December. Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) leased 175,000 square meters of space with a portfolio occupancy rate of 94.3% in the first quarter. Sabana Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) faces opposition from its internalisation committee and incoming directors to certain resolutions in an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Gold hits record high as China-US tariff war drives safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices hit a record high of US$2,848.94 on February 5, driven by safe-haven demand amid the ongoing US-China tariff war. The trade tensions, triggered by President Trump's 10% tariffs on Chinese imports, have boosted gold prices, traditionally seen as a hedge against inflation and geopolitical turmoil. The US Federal Reserve is expected to carefully assess the economic impact of the tariffs before making its next interest rate move, according to San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly.

images.alt_text: Gold may turn out to be the real proxy for the global geopolitical outlook and the only accurate measure of general anxiety about the future.

site_title: Apple debuts Invites app, AppleCare+ changes in subscription push
summary: Apple has launched the Invites app for creating event invitations and made changes to its AppleCare+ customer support for iPhones, aiming to generate more subscription revenue. The Invites app requires an iCloud+ subscription, starting at $0.99/month, and can customize invitations, create playlists, and generate shared photo albums. Apple is also changing how it sells AppleCare+, now only offering monthly or annual payment options, with the pricier Theft & Loss plans prioritized. This shift is part of Apple's broader push to prioritize services and subscriptions.

images.alt_text: The company is publicising the porn app to showcase its view that the EU’s rules could harm Apple customers in the region.
Apple’s Vision Pro headset Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Apple's overall sales and profits were boosted by stronger-than-expected sales of iPads and Macs, where new chips helped persuade customers to upgrade.

site_title: UK grand strategy faces formidable post-Brexit test
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer faces a post-Brexit test as he navigates the country's grand strategy amidst shifting US and EU alliances. Starmer's attempts to align with the US under President Donald Trump's administration, particularly on climate change and security, are at odds with the UK's ties to the European Union. A visit to Washington for talks with Trump is expected, where these challenges will be discussed, potentially influencing the UK's future foreign policy direction. The outcome may impact the country's ability to maintain a balance between its relationships with the US and EU.

images.alt_text: (From left) US President Donald Trump, seen here in a montage with Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer, held out the prospect of a settlement with London, saying that “I think that one can be worked out.”

site_title: Singapore shares down on tariffs drag; STI dips 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares declined for the third consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.2% to 3,815.37, due to US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on China, a key trading partner. The top four constituent stocks of the STI, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, all closed lower, with OCBC experiencing the steepest decline of 0.5%. Despite the downturn, 1.3 billion securities worth S$1 billion changed hands across the broader market.

images.alt_text: CICT's higher distributable income was driven mainly by contributions from Ion Orchard, which it acquired a 50% stake in last year.

site_title: Walmart to cut hundreds of jobs, relocate staff to main hubs
summary: Walmart is eliminating hundreds of corporate jobs and relocating staff to its main hubs in Arkansas and California as part of a consolidation effort. The company is also closing its office in Charlotte, North Carolina. Employees based in smaller offices, including Hoboken, New Jersey, will be asked to move to Bentonville, Arkansas, or Sunnyvale, California. The move aims to "put key capabilities together, encouraging speed and shared understanding," according to a memo from Walmart's chief people officer.

site_title: New Zealand jobless rate rises to four-year high after recession
summary: New Zealand's unemployment rate rose to a four-year high of 5.1% in the fourth quarter, driven by a sharp recession. Employment fell 0.1% from the previous quarter, and annual wage inflation slowed for a seventh straight quarter. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) can continue cutting interest rates, expected to drive a modest economic recovery this year. The RBNZ has already lowered interest rates 125 basis points since August, with a possible third 50-point cut planned for February 19.

images.alt_text: New Zealand’s economy suffered a deep recession last year, contracting 2.1 per cent in the six months to September.

site_title: eFishery fiasco: Are state-linked investors risking their reputation investing directly in startups?
summary: State-linked investors, such as Singapore's Temasek and Malaysia's KWAP, are considering their approach to investing in startups, particularly Indonesian unicorn eFishery, which has been accused of faking revenue. While direct investing offers the chance to understand disruption through innovative technologies, the reputational fallout from a failed startup may not be worth the risk. Temasek has a fund-of-funds strategy, but direct investing may still be too high-risk, especially given the high-profile failures of state-linked investors in the past. A more diversified approach may be necessary to balance risk and returns.

site_title: Accountancy education must evolve quickly to prepare for a sustainable future
summary: Accounting education must evolve to prepare for a sustainable future, as extreme weather and natural phenomena increase the importance of sustainability reporting. The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) aims to establish global standards for sustainability reporting, mirroring the success of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Accountants, with their expertise in financial measurement, are well-positioned to lead the reporting of sustainability matters. To remain relevant, accounting students and professionals need to acquire sustainability skills and knowledge, with many institutions already incorporating this into their curriculum.

images.alt_text: More companies in the Asia-Pacific  now appear to be disclosing their process for managing climate-related risks and opportunities.

site_title: Democratic senators urge probe of Musk team’s US Treasury access
summary: Democratic Senators Elizabeth Warren and Ron Wyden have called for an investigation into how Elon Musk's team gained access to the US Treasury's payment system, handling $6 trillion annually. The Treasury Secretary, Scott Bessent, approved Musk's team's access, reportedly after a career official was put on administrative leave. The investigation aims to determine who was granted access, why, and how, raising concerns over privacy and potential misuse of taxpayer information.

site_title: Scandal-hit unicorn eFishery ropes FTI Consulting into acting management team
summary: eFishery, an Indonesian aquaculture startup, has involved FTI Consulting in its acting management amid allegations of systemic fraud and revenue inflation. The move aims to facilitate a thorough business review to determine the best path forward. Several employees under the workers' union staged a protest in late January demanding transparency and an investigation. The company's board stated that FTI Consulting will provide material updates to stakeholders as the review progresses.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s rate likely to go higher than consensus, ex-official says
summary: Former Bank of Japan executive director Hideo Hayakawa expects the BOJ's benchmark rate to exceed current market consensus, with a terminal rate around 1.5% in this cycle. He forecasts two more rate hikes this year, possibly in July and end-of-year, citing the central bank's neutral rate estimate and inflation risks. Hayakawa's views contradict the median private economist estimate of 1% terminal rate, and come as the market awaits the next policy normalisation pace after the recent rate hike.

images.alt_text: Overall CPI rose 3.6 per cent in December from a year earlier, much faster than a 3.0 per cent gain in core CPI and a 2.4 per cent increase in "core-core" CPI.
With inflation exceeding 2 per cent for nearly three years, the slow pace of BOJ rate hikes have kept Japan’s real borrowing costs deeply negative.

“There’s no change to our stance, which is to continue raising interest rates and adjust the degree of monetary support if the economy and prices move in line with our forecasts,” Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda said.

site_title: KKR raises offer for Fuji Soft in US$4.3 billion tussle with Bain
summary: KKR raised its tender offer for Fuji Soft to 9,850 yen per share, surpassing Bain Capital's planned offer of 9,600 yen per share. The deal values Fuji Soft at around 664 billion yen (S$5.8 billion). KKR will extend its tender offer period to February 19, despite initial support from the company's board, which has backed the firm's lower offer price. This move marks a rare hostile bid in Japan and highlights the growing competition in the country's booming buyout market.

images.alt_text: KKR will pay 9,451 yen (S$81.49) for each Fuji Soft share, an increase from the 8,800 yen it originally offered and one yen more than Bain’s proposal.

KKR now owns enough Fuji Soft shares to be able to block Bain Capital’s privatisation bid.
Fuji Soft’s board in August came out in support of the KKR bid.

site_title: Trump in no hurry to talk to Xi amid new tariff war
summary: US President Donald Trump has stated he is not in a hurry to speak with Chinese President Xi Jinping to resolve a new trade war sparked by 10% tariffs on Chinese imports. China retaliated with targeted tariffs on US imports, including Google, and imposed export controls on metals. Trump has suspended tariffs on Mexico and Canada for 30 days in exchange for concessions on border and crime enforcement. China's measures are seen as a measured response, and a conversation between Xi and Trump is considered key to a potential easing or delay of tariffs.

site_title: KKR quarterly profit beats expectation on dealmaking revival
summary: KKR reported a 33% increase in adjusted net income to $1.19 billion, beating analyst expectations, driven by a rebound in dealmaking activity following the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts and Donald Trump's return to the White House. Fee-related earnings jumped 25% to $843 million, while assets under management rose 15% to $638 billion. The firm also announced plans to increase ownership in three existing investments and reported several new deals, including the acquisition of a 25% stake in Eni's biofuel business.

summary: The number of owner-occupied private homes in Singapore increased by 27,000 units from 2020 to 2024, tripling the growth of investment homes during the same period. Non-owner-occupied residential properties rose by 8,000 units. site_title: Xi’s reply to Trump tariffs shows China has more to lose
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has taken a cautious approach in responding to US tariffs, avoiding a major escalation in the trade war. Beijing announced additional tariffs on US products, launched an antitrust investigation into Google, and tightened export controls on critical minerals. China's retaliation is seen as a calculated move, with Beijing having more to lose from a full-blown tariff war. Xi's strategy is to respond mainly through domestic stimulus, rather than engaging in a tit-for-tat trade war. Talks between US and Chinese leaders are underway, with Trump seeking a deal that could include concessions on trade, security, and technology issues.

The club, owned by Peter Kwee's Group Exklusiv, is being sued over its financials, with claims including breach of directors' duty, clawback of assets disposed of at undervalue, and clawback of debts paid or assets disposed of by unfair preference. site_title: Singapore grants 3,000 One Passes for top foreign talent in 2024

site_title: Europe: Shares rise with earnings in focus; tariff worries prevail

Caution remains over potential US tariffs, with the EU seeking swift engagement with the US over Trump's planned tariffs.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust leases 175,000 sq m in Q1, posts 94.3% occupancy rate

The company expects demand for modern logistics facilities driven by strategic locations, population growth, and e-commerce growth, with higher inventory levels and nearshoring expected to drive warehouse demand.

site_title: Oil mixed as Trump restores pressure on Iran, tariff drama caps prices
summary: US President Donald Trump has restored pressure on Iran, aiming to drive its oil exports to zero, amidst ongoing tariff drama between the US and China. Oil prices mixed, with US West Texas Intermediate crude settling down 46 cents, or 0.63%, at $72.70 a barrel, while global benchmark Brent crude futures rose 24 cents, or 0.32%, to $76.20. site_title: Singapore’s Syfe makes A$65 million bid for Australian investing platform SelfWealth
summary: Syfe, a Singapore-based digital wealth platform, has made a non-binding indicative offer to acquire SelfWealth, an Australian-listed digital investing platform, for A$65 million (S$54.7 million), a 12% premium over an existing offer. site_title: US job openings decline to 7.6 million, lowest since September

This marks a gradual slowdown in the labor market, with professional and business services, healthcare, and finance experiencing large declines. The hiring rate held at 3.4%, among the lowest in the past decade, and the quits rate remained at 2%. The decline in job openings supports the Federal Reserve's assertion that the job market is no longer a source of inflationary pressure.

site_title: ‘America first’ showcases Trump’s currency confusion
summary: US President Donald Trump has issued an "America first" executive order on trade policy, focusing on investigating the causes of the country's large and persistent annual trade deficits in goods. However, the US current account deficit is primarily a macroeconomic phenomenon, driven by the country's savings and investment gap. The dollar's strength, driven by the US economy and Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts, exacerbates the deficit. Trump's plan threatens to worsen the fiscal deficit, further complicating the issue. The Treasury Department's investigation and proposed measures are seen as ineffective, and the administration's push on currency policy is likely to stir up controversy.

Diageo, a drinks maker, estimates a $200 million hit to its operating profits if tariffs are enforced from March 1. ZF, a German auto supplier, plans to increase prices due to the tariffs. The tariffs, which include 25% on Mexican and Canadian goods and 10% on Chinese goods, pose a fresh challenge for companies already facing weak demand.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.7% and 1.4%, respectively. Palantir Technologies surged 36% after reporting strong artificial intelligence growth. Estee Lauder and PepsiCo also saw significant declines, with Lauder dropping 16.1% and PepsiCo falling 4.5%. Market analysts attributed the gains to President Trump's decision to delay tariffs on Canada and Mexico, as well as investors' cautious optimism about earnings.

Anwar emphasized the need for proactive steps to expand trading partners and counter the impact of US tariffs on Malaysia.

site_title: US: Wall St muted at open after China’s retaliatory tariffs

site_title: Pope Francis offers Hope in a fractured world
summary: Pope Francis has released his autobiography, "Hope", marking the first time a pope has written his biography. The book, spanning over 300 pages, features candid anecdotes and reflections on social justice, including his grandparents' near-death experience on the "Italian Titanic" and his journey to becoming the 266th pope. Written with a focus on hope, the book delves into his vocation, progressive papacy, and vision for a more inclusive Church. The book is available in over 80 countries and serves as a timely reminder of the enduring power of hope in a chaotic world.

summary: Mattel, the parent company of Barbie, forecasts annual profit above Wall Street expectations, driven by steady holiday demand for action figures and Hot Wheels vehicles. The company expects a profit per share in the range of $1.66 to $1.72, above analysts' average estimate of $1.58. Mattel aims to mitigate potential impacts of President Trump's tariffs on China, Mexico, and Canada through supply chain optimization and price increases. site_title: Number of compulsory wind-ups rise more than 50% in 2024
summary: The number of compulsory wind-ups in Singapore increased by 52.7% in 2024, reaching 307 companies, compared to 201 in 2023. The Insolvency Office also received 399 wind-up applications, a 46.2% rise from 2023. Meanwhile, 4,521 bankruptcy applications were filed in the first 11 months of 2024, with over 1,100 orders issued and 740 discharges. site_title: Singapore unlikely to be on ‘hit list’ of direct US tariffs: Vivian
summary: Singapore is unlikely to be directly targeted by US tariffs, but its small and open economy may be indirectly affected if global supply chains and trade are disrupted. Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan warned that the world is at a "new inflection point" with a lack of strategic trust between the US and China, and that Singapore must adapt to a changing global economy. He emphasized the importance of consistent and reliable engagement with multiple poles of power, including the US, China, and other countries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 4)
summary: Singapore's tourism spending is expected to exceed pre-Covid levels in 2025, with tourist arrivals potentially staying slightly below those of 2019 due to ongoing recovery efforts. Employment outcomes for polytechnic graduates in 2024 were uneven, with some courses experiencing worse outcomes than others.

site_title: Singapore’s 2025 tourism receipts to exceed pre-Covid levels, but arrivals still playing catch up
summary: Singapore's tourism receipts are expected to reach a new record high of $29 billion to $30.5 billion in 2025, surpassing pre-Covid levels, according to the Singapore Tourism Board (STB). The country is forecast to receive 17 million to 18.5 million international visitors, slightly below the 2019 record of 19.1 million. The 30-day mutual visa exemption with mainland China and strong air connectivity growth contributed to the continued recovery in visitor arrivals.

site_title: Japan PM to meet Trump on Feb 6-8 US trip
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba will meet US President Donald Trump from February 6-8, aiming to build a strong relationship of trust and boost the US-Japan alliance. Ishiba plans to discuss increasing US shale gas imports and the bid by Nippon Steel to buy US Steel, blocked by former President Joe Biden. He also intends to ask Trump to visit Japan at the earliest opportunity, following a series of meetings between Ishiba and Trump's advisors. The meeting is seen as crucial for regional stability, given China's military build-up in the Asia-Pacific and Trump's "America First" policies.

site_title: Worse employment outcomes for poly grads in 2024 are not across the board: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Employment outcomes for Singapore's polytechnic graduates in 2024 worsened, with a 45% of economically active graduates experiencing lower full-time permanent employment rates and higher unemployment rates compared to 2023. However, this was not uniform across all courses, with tech-related poly courses seeing a rise in unemployment. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing stated that the government will continue to monitor the situation closely, with "full confidence and support" for the polytechnic sector's mission to stay relevant.

images.alt_text:

site_title: Spotify forecasts profit above estimates on subscriber growth, price increases
summary: Spotify forecasted first-quarter profit above estimates, driven by steady user growth, price hikes, and cost-cutting measures. The company expects operating income of 548 million euros, surpassing analysts' average estimate of 450.6 million euros. Spotify forecast monthly active users of 678 million and premium subscribers of 265 million, exceeding Visible Alpha estimates. Revenue is expected to reach 4.2 billion euros, slightly above estimates, with gross profit jumping 40% to 1.37 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Spotify has been expanding in recent years to include audiobooks, podcasts and other offerings besides its core music catalogue.
FILE PHOTO: A smartphone is seen in front of a screen projection of Spotify logo, in this picture illustration taken April 1, 2018. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The company is showing the benefits of workforce cuts taken late last year, along with the tailwind from continued growth.

site_title: Amazon to face legal action after laying off 1,900 in Quebec
summary: Amazon is facing legal action after laying off 1,900 employees in Quebec, Canada. The Federation of National Trade Unions is petitioning a court to annul the layoffs and order the reopening of the warehouses, seeking payment of compensation and damages. The union claims Amazon's decision to close the warehouses and terminate workers is a violation of Quebec's Labour Code. The company had been negotiating with the union to create a collective agreement for 300 employees, but the closures were announced less than a year after the workers unionized.

images.alt_text: Amazon will phase out operations across seven sites in the province — the only location in Canada with unionised Amazon employees — over the next two months.
Amazon fuels North America's most severe warehouse shortage

site_title: Infineon more positive on revenue outlook after Q1 stronger than expected
summary: Infineon, a German chipmaker, revised its full-year revenue outlook to flat to slightly up compared to the prior year, after initially expecting a decline due to a weaker euro. The company reported a 8% fall in first-quarter revenue to 3.4 billion euros, beating analyst forecasts. Infineon's segment result margin also exceeded expectations at 16.7%, with CEO Jochen Hanebeck stating the company has held up well in a weak market environment.

site_title: UBS has cut 10,000 jobs since Credit Suisse takeover in 2023
summary: UBS has cut over 10,000 jobs since its takeover of Credit Suisse in 2023, with a peak job cut of over 3,000 in the third quarter of 2023. The bank's global headcount now stands at 108,648, down from a peak of 119,100 in June 2023. CEO Sergio Ermotti aims to complete the integration by the end of 2025, with expected costs of around $14 billion, and has already achieved $7.5 billion in total savings from the acquisition.

images.alt_text: The UBS Group AG logo on the former Credit Suisse headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, Feb. 4, 2025. UBS said it aims to buy back up to $3 billion of its own shares this year, with Chief Executive Officer Sergio Ermotti returning more cash to investors amid progress in integrating Credit Suisse. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia races to secure new funding for energy transition after US exit from Paris Agreement
summary: Indonesia faces uncertainty in securing funding for its energy transition after the US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement. The country, aiming to phase out coal and increase renewable energy, is turning to Japan, South Korea, and China to finance the early decommissioning of 13 coal-fired power plants, estimated at $4.6 billion. Despite US withdrawal, Indonesia remains committed to its net-zero ambitions, with President Prabowo Subianto accelerating climate goals, and the government seeking alternative financing and strengthening regulatory frameworks to support the energy transition.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta

Trump said the WHO had failed to act independently from the “inappropriate political influence of WHO member states” and required “unfairly onerous payments” from the US that were disproportionate to the sums provided by other, larger countries, such as China.

site_title: Thailand orders power cut to Myanmar in blow to scam centres
summary: Thailand's government has ordered a power cut to suspected areas in Myanmar where cyber scams are believed to operate, cutting off electricity, internet, and oil supplies to five areas including Myawaddy and Tachileik. The move prioritizes the safety of Thai people and the country's image, following a high-profile trafficking case of a Chinese actor. The National Security Council made the decision, with the Foreign Ministry notifying Myanmar's military government ahead of the suspension, which will take effect on February 5.

images.alt_text: China has remained at the top of Thailand’s tourist numbers list in the first two weeks of January, comprising almost a sixth of the 1.3 million arrivals.

Some Chinese travellers are opting to stay away from Thailand for the eight-day Chinese New Year holiday, which starts on Jan 28, due to safety concerns.

Scam compounds have mushroomed in Myanmar’s borderlands and are staffed by foreigners who are often trafficked and forced to work, swindling their compatriots in an industry analysts say is worth billions of dollars.
While the call-centre scams have been around for years, the issue recently took on greater importance, especially for officials in Beijing and Bangkok.

site_title: Thailand weighs imports of more US goods to cut trade surplus
summary: Thailand aims to reduce its trade surplus with the US by increasing imports of US ethane and agricultural products. The government has asked Thai petrochemical companies to buy at least 1 million tons of US ethane, valued at around $200 million, to cut the surplus. This move is part of efforts to strengthen defense and security relations with the US amid trade tensions. Thailand lists the US as its second-largest trading partner, with a surplus of around $35.4 billion in 2024.

images.alt_text: Domestic auto sales in 2024 fell 26.2 per cent annually to the lowest level in 15 years, and the FTI said the rejection rate for auto loans reached 70 per cent.

site_title: Temasek and CenterSquare launch US$100 million commercial real estate debt co-investment vehicle
summary: Temasek and CenterSquare Investment Management have launched a $100 million commercial real estate debt co-investment vehicle, focusing on multifamily assets and high-quality subordinate real estate loans. The vehicle, which will have $200 million to deploy, aims to generate risk-adjusted, equity-like returns through mezzanine loans and debt-like preferred equity investments. The first tranche of capital will invest alongside CenterSquare's recent debt fund in pre-identified deals, capitalizing on a favorable market environment with borrowers seeking "gap capital" in the current higher-rate climate.

images.alt_text: Temasek owns a S$389 billion total portfolio as at Mar 31, and has focused on long-term investments with themes such as digitisation and sustainability.

site_title: Volatility set to rise in year of wood snake; investors should diversify
summary: This year, 2025, is the Year of the Green Wood Snake, the sixth animal in the Chinese zodiac calendar, which is expected to bring volatility. Historically, the Year of the Snake has been the worst performing of the twelve zodiac animals since 1920. Meanwhile, the Trump administration has agreed to delay tariffs on Canada and Mexico goods for a month, which could dampen US economic growth and add to US inflation.

images.alt_text: A "Make America Great Again" hat in front of the White House.
Singapore must be a consistent reliable and a trustworthy host to enterprises from all over the world, including the US and China in a changing global economy, says Dr Balakrishnan.
Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said Malaysia could not act hastily in countering tariffs as there remained many geopolitical uncertainties.

Additional 10 per cent tariff across all Chinese imports into the US came into effect at 12.01 am ET on Tuesday (0501 GMT) after Trump repeatedly warned Beijing it was not doing enough to halt the flow of illicit drugs into the US.

site_title: BNP plans US$1.1 billion buyback as trading strength lifts profit
summary: BNP Paribas, a French lender, reported a 30% jump in equities trading and 34% higher revenue from fixed income in the fourth quarter, exceeding analysts' expectations. The bank plans a $1.1 billion share buyback as part of a pledge to return 60% of profit to investors. BNP Paribas also boosted its dividend to 4.79 euros per share and confirmed a key profitability target for the next year. The bank's CEO, Jean-Laurent Bonnafe, announced a new strategic plan for the commercial and retail banking unit, which will provide more details in June.

images.alt_text: BNP’s expansion into the leveraged and acquisition finance market comes at a time when activity is picking up in Asia Pacific.

site_title: Indonesia approves Bill to set up investment firm managing 1,000 trillion rupiah in assets
summary: Indonesia's parliament has approved a bill to establish Danantara, a state-owned investment agency aimed at managing 1,000 trillion rupiah (S$83.2 billion) in assets. The agency, under President Prabowo's direct oversight, will drive the country's 8% economic growth goal and oversee dividends from state-owned enterprises. Danantara will operate with broad authority to make investments, manage state assets, and wield capital injections and restructuring power. The agency's establishment has raised concerns about potential political influence and bureaucratic delays, but analysts see it as a strategic move to optimize state-owned enterprises' role in driving the economy forward.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Prabowo’s push to create Danantara is seen as a shrewd strategy to better manage the nation’s investment assets.
Indonesian parliament members sit as President Joko Widodo delivers a speech ahead of Independence Day, at the parliament building in Jakarta, Indonesia, August 16, 2019. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

(FILES) This picture taken on October 31, 2023 shows the Suralaya coal-fired power plant in Cilegon, Indonesia's Banten province. Meeting Indonesia's pledge to phase out coal power in just 15 years and reach net-zero emissions by mid-century is a "daunting task" that will require immediate and ambitious action, experts warn. Indesia's President Prabowo Subianto offered a surprise commitment at the November 2024 G20 summit to close hundreds of coal and fossil-fuel power plants by 2040, a bold pledge from one of the world's top coal producers and consumers. site_title:
Majority of Singapore SMEs plan to 
invest in GenAI 
solutions: DBS survey
summary: More than 70% of Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) plan to invest in generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) solutions to stay competitive amid macroeconomic uncertainty. 73% intend to inject capital and 72% to upskill employees. 32% are already using GenAI tools in areas such as marketing and communications. The top resources needed for internationalisation are market insights, trade law guidance, and access to reliable suppliers and distributors. Despite this, sustainability efforts remain relatively low, with only 36% of respondents actively working on sustainability.

images.alt_text: IMDA said that while 44 per cent of larger enterprises implemented some sort of AI technology in 2023, just 4.2 per cent of SMEs had done the same.

From left: IMDA assistant chief executive of the sectoral transformation group Leong Der Yao; Senior Minister of State for Digital Development and Information Tan Kiat How; DBS group head of corporate and SME banking Koh Kar Siong; and EnterpriseSG executive director Simon Lim, at the launch of Spark GenAI.

site_title: UBS trounces profit forecasts, US$3 billion share buyback conditional on capital rules
summary: UBS Group posted a fourth-quarter profit of US$770 million, beating forecasts by a wide margin. The bank plans to repurchase up to US$3 billion in shares this year, conditional on no major changes to Swiss banking regulations. UBS has made progress in integrating Credit Suisse and expects to achieve integration milestones by the end of 2026. The bank's shares rose 3% after the announcement, marking its fourth consecutive quarter of profit.

images.alt_text: UBS seeks to shed another US$5.5 billion in costs in addition to the US$7.5 billion already achieved since the deal, CEO Sergio Ermotti said.
Concerns are growing over the financial state of New World Development controlled by the family of Hong Kong tycoon Henry Cheng.
(From left) UBS Asia Pacific chairman Edmund Koh, Country Head of UBS Singapore Jin Yee Young, Minister of State Alvin Tan, and Ong Eng Huat from the Singapore Book of Records.

site_title: Trump is sowing the seeds of an anti-American alliance
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs targeting allies and neighbors are playing into China's hands, threatening the unity of the Western alliance and sowing the seeds of an alternative grouping. European policymakers rely on Chinese electric vehicles, batteries, and solar panels to meet green transition targets, making cooperation with the US increasingly difficult. The US's "shoot-from-the-hip" tactics pose significant economic and strategic risks, including higher inflation and industrial disruption, as well as the destruction of the Western alliance and the rise of an alternative grouping.

images.alt_text: Additional 10 per cent tariff across all Chinese imports into the US came into effect at 12.01 am ET on Tuesday (0501 GMT) after Trump repeatedly warned Beijing it was not doing enough to halt the flow of illicit drugs into the US.

France's President Emmanuel Macron speaks during the annual "Fete de la musique" one-day music festival in the courtyard of the Elysee presidential palace in Paris on June 21, 2024. June 21, marks the annual start of  'Fete de la Musique', a tradition marking the first day of summer, during which music is encouraged to be played outdoors. (Photo by Bertrand GUAY / AFP)

site_title: Seeds Capital sets aside S$150 million for co-investments into deep-tech startups
summary: Seeds Capital, the investment arm of Enterprise Singapore, has set aside S$150 million over three years to co-invest in Singapore-based deep-tech startups, with a focus on the sustainability sector. The move is part of the Startup SG Equity scheme, which aims to generate at least S$300 million in investments. New co-investors include Temasek-backed Xora and ST Engineering Ventures, bringing the total number of co-investors to 52. This injection is seen as a smart move by the government to support the growth of Singapore's startup ecosystem and nurture a strong core of deep-tech startups.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The rise of DeepSeek is both an inspiration and a shot across the bow, says Andreessen Horowitz general partner Vijay Pande.
From L-R: Mahesh Kumar, co-founder and interim CEO of 129Knots and Vikash Dhanuka, founder and CEO, Sing Fuels
The fund has already deployed capital into a number of startups including Aevice and Gush.

site_title: Nintendo cuts outlook for final months before Switch 2 debut
summary: Nintendo has cut its operating income forecast for the fiscal year to March, slashing over 20% from its previous estimate, due to a decline in profit and revenue over the holiday period. The company now expects 280 billion yen ($2.44 billion) in operating income, down from 340 billion yen. The decline is attributed to the Switch's success, which is driving investors' focus on the upcoming Switch 2 console, expected to be released later this year, and its potential to boost sales.

images.alt_text: Players have long been hungry for news on a follow-up to Nintendo’s hybrid Switch console, which can be handheld or connected to a TV screen.

site_title: Gold holds steady near all-time high amid US tariff concerns
summary: Gold prices hovered near a record high on Tuesday, edging up 0.1% to $2,816.64 per ounce amid US tariff concerns. Investors fear the tariffs on Canada, China, and Mexico will fuel inflation and hinder economic growth, driving demand for safe-haven assets. Global bullion banks are flying gold into the US from Asian trading hubs, capitalizing on the high premium of US gold futures over spot prices. The tariffs are expected to be challenged by China at the World Trade Organization, adding to market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index hovered near a three-week peak, making greenback-priced gold more expensive for foreign buyers.

site_title: Nippon, US Steel say Biden blocked merger amid ‘sham’ review
summary: Nippon Steel and US Steel have sued the US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, claiming former President Joe Biden unfairly blocked their $14.1 billion merger by conducting a "sham" national security review. The companies allege Cfius ignored its procedures and violated due process rights after Biden's March 2024 statement blocking the deal. They seek a new review, claiming the Cfius review was "predetermined" and motivated by interests other than national security.

images.alt_text: On an adjusted basis, US Steel lost 13 cents per share during the quarter ended Dec 31, in line with analysts’ estimates, according to data compiled by LSEG.
Nippon Steel and US Steel said on Saturday the Biden administration delayed until June an order for the Japanese company to abandon its US$14.9 billion bid for US Steel.

site_title: Singapore bucks regional showing as Trump defers tariffs on neighbours; STI slips 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,823.01, bucking regional trends, as US President Donald Trump delayed tariffs on Mexico and Canada but not China. Despite this, global markets remained volatile, with US tariffs on China triggering retaliatory moves. Analysts warn of potential collateral damage to Singapore's economy, citing degradation in global supply chains and trade.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Chong Xin Wei
Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, Suntec Reit, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Lendlease Global Reit

site_title: AI and more: These tech firms top the list of Singapore’s 100 fastest-growing companies
summary: Singapore's 100 fastest-growing companies, as per a study by Statista, include tech firms dominating the IT and software sector, which accounts for about 40% of the list. Top companies include Focus Digital Technology Group, ranked second with a 219.28% CAGR, Wiz.AI, ranked third with a 202.97% CAGR, and Gozem, ranked fifth with a 170.25% CAGR. These companies leverage growing demand for cloud and cybersecurity support, AI, and automation to drive revenue growth.

images.alt_text: The rollouts are part of a broader industry push towards agents, or AI software that can complete multi-step tasks for users with minimal supervision.
The primary advantage of DeepSeek's artificial intelligence bots lies in their ability to process data more quickly and efficiently.

site_title: China may loosen grip on yuan as Trump reignites trade war
summary: China is expected to loosen its grip on the yuan as US President Donald Trump's tariffs on China take effect. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) may allow the yuan to weaken to a fixing rate of 7.2 or lower, contrary to its current tight grip. Analysts expect a weaker yuan to offset the impact of higher tariffs and offset capital outflows, but also warn of potential risks, including broader spillover effects on Asian currencies and assets.

images.alt_text: China's one-year loan prime rate (LPR) was kept at 3.1 per cent, while the five-year LPR was unchanged at 3.6 per cent.
Complicating matters for the PBOC is pressure on the yuan and government bond yields from concerns about China’s economic prospects as a potential trade war looms.

Financial institutions offered 18.09 trillion yuan (S$3.4 trillion) of new loans in 2024. The total was lower than the previous year’s volume of 22.75 trillion yuan, representing the first annual drop in 13 years.

site_title: Guinness-owner Diageo scraps medium-term goals as tariffs cloud outlook
summary: Diageo, the owner of Guinness, has withdrawn its medium-term sales growth target due to uncertainty surrounding US tariffs, which are expected to impact the company's operating profit by $200 million in the second half. The company cited macroeconomic and geopolitical uncertainty as factors slowing recovery, and investors have welcomed the removal of unrealistic expectations. However, shares dropped 4% in early trade, hitting their lowest since 2020, as investors remain concerned about long-term growth prospects.

site_title: China hits back with tariffs on US goods after Trump imposes new levies
summary: China retaliated against the US by imposing tariffs on US imports, including coal, LNG, crude oil, farm equipment, and big-engine sedans. China also initiated an anti-monopoly investigation into Alphabet's Google and imposed export controls on rare earths and metals. The new tariffs, which will take effect on February 10, are a response to the US's decision to impose additional tariffs on Chinese goods. The move raises concerns about the escalation of the trade war between the two economies, with the US dollar strengthening and global markets becoming increasingly volatile.

images.alt_text: New levies on China imports came into effect at 12.01 am ET on Tuesday (0501 GMT).

site_title: Hundreds of US government sites go offline
summary: Hundreds of US government websites, including those of major departments and agencies, went offline on Monday, including USAID, citing a "temporary" issue. The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency reported over 350 sites were unavailable. The development comes amid the Trump administration's efforts to shrink the US government. Elon Musk, leading the cost-cutting efforts, announced the shutdown of USAID, calling it a "criminal organisation." Key health information, including HIV and LGBTQ resources, have also disappeared from the US CDC website, sparking concerns.

images.alt_text: Speaking more broadly about cutting US expenses and fraud, Elon Musk estimated the Trump administration can cut US$1 trillion from the US deficit next year.

site_title: BNP expands Australia presence by hiring banker for leverage finance market
summary: BNP Paribas has expanded its presence in Australia's leveraged finance market by hiring senior banker Peter Medynski in Sydney. Medynski joins the bank in a newly-created role, reporting to Chris Ruffa and Anshul Gupta, amid a strong start to the year for the Australian leveraged finance market. Loan volumes backing M&A transactions reached US$35 billion last year, with notable financings including DAZN Group's A$1.8 billion loan to Foxtel Group and Pacific Equity Partners' A$700 million borrowing to acquire Freight Management Holdings.

site_title: Salesforce cutting 1,000 roles while hiring salespeople for AI
summary: Salesforce is cutting over 1,000 roles as its latest fiscal year begins, despite hiring salespeople for new AI products. The company is focusing on maintaining profit margins after pressure from activist investors. Salesforce had nearly 73,000 workers as of January 2024. The layoffs are part of the company's efforts to get more efficiencies and invest in scaling its business. Salesforce's third-quarter revenue beat expectations, driven by strong cloud demand. The company is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings around the end of February.

site_title: US tariffs on Chinese imports take effect after Trump reprieves Canada and Mexico
summary: US tariffs on Chinese imports took effect on Tuesday, with 10% levies coming into effect at 12.01 am ET. The move risks a renewed trade war between the US and China, with President Donald Trump punishing China for not halting the flow of illicit drugs. Trump had previously suspended tariffs on Canada and Mexico, but not China, after agreeing to a 30-day pause in exchange for concessions on border and crime enforcement with the two neighboring countries. The move has sent global markets into a tailspin, with the Canadian dollar soaring and US stock index futures gaining.

site_title: Singapore finds its seat at the China+1 table
summary: Singapore has emerged as a key alternative location for multinationals seeking to diversify their supply chains away from China, with the city-state's largest lender, DBS Group, considering a major investment in Malaysia's Alliance Bank. The proposed deal, if approved, would allow DBS to expand its presence in the region and take advantage of Singapore's Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone, which is seen as an ideal location for companies looking to reduce their reliance on China.

images.alt_text: The Johor-Singapore Causeway is one of the busiest land border crossings in the world.
Johor’s proximity to Singapore’s market and infrastructure is a major factor behind the SEZ's appeal.
The SEZ is located just across the Causeway, the world's busiest land crossing.

site_title: GIC makes senior leadership changes, appoints new group CIO
summary: GIC appoints Bryan Yeo as new group CIO, succeeding Jeffrey Jaensubhakij after nearly three decades. Yeo, 46, will oversee the sovereign wealth fund's total investment portfolio, while Boon Chin Hau, 50, will take on the role of CIO for infrastructure. Both appointments take effect on April 1. Yeo, who joined GIC in 2003, previously served as CIO for public equities and deputy CIO, while Hau, appointed deputy CIO for infrastructure last year, succeeds Ang Eng Seng.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng

Jaensubhakij’s departure will mark the end of a near 30-year career at the firm, which has seen him run everything from North American equities to European operations and investments across the globe.

site_title: Bank of Japan aims to achieve 2% inflation as measured by overall CPI: Ueda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda announced the central bank aims to achieve 2% inflation as measured by the overall consumer price index (CPI) on a sustained basis. The recent overall CPI rose 3.6% in December from a year earlier, surpassing the 3.0% gain in core CPI and 2.4% increase in "core-core" CPI. Ueda emphasized the focus on underlying inflation, excluding one-off factors, but acknowledged the process can be challenging.

images.alt_text: The average transaction price of rice produced last year jumped 55 per cent to 23,715 yen (S$208) per 60 kg from the previous year, according to government data.
MUFG is ahead of some competitors on these measures, but there is still a big distance from the top banks.

With inflation exceeding 2 per cent for nearly three years, the slow pace of BOJ rate hikes have kept Japan’s real borrowing costs deeply negative.

site_title: US manufacturing rebounds, tariffs could derail tentative recovery
summary: US manufacturing has rebounded for the first time in over two years, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) rising to 50.9 in January, its highest reading since September 2022. However, the recovery is short-lived due to President Trump's imposition of tariffs on Canadian, Mexican, and Chinese goods, which could further raise raw material prices and disrupt supply chains. Economists warn of supply chain disruptions, weak economic growth, or even a recession, and the automobile industry is expected to take the biggest hit from tariffs.

images.alt_text: Excluding the volatile food and energy components, the PCE price index rose 0.2 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.1 per cent increase in November.
The US economy has broadly held up in the face of high interest rates, helped by a robust labor market with low unemployment and still-growing wages.
Consumer spending is expected to have retained much of the July to September momentum, when it grew at a 3.7 per cent rate.

site_title: India’s Modi invited to meet with Trump next week: White House official
summary: US President Donald Trump has invited Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to visit the White House next week, according to a White House official. The meeting comes after a discussion on immigration, security equipment, and bilateral trading ties between the two leaders on January 27. The visit aims to enhance trade relations and avoid tariffs, as India is keen to maintain a strong strategic partnership with the US and avoid tariffs on US products. The two countries have a significant trade surplus, with the US being India's largest trading partner.

site_title: New Zealand residential building approvals fall to six-year low
summary: New Zealand's residential building approvals plummeted to a six-year low in 2024, reaching 33,600 in the 12 months to December, according to Statistics New Zealand. This decline is attributed to high interest rates and a recession, which spooked home buyers and stalled developments. Consents for apartments and retirement villages fell to their lowest levels since 2014 and 2013, respectively. Despite this, experts predict a gradual recovery in the housing market and house prices, driven by lower borrowing costs and a strengthening housing market, as interest rates continue to fall.

The New Zealand government released an updated list of minerals seen as essential to the country’s economy and in demand by international partners, to include gold and metallurgical coal.
The change applies to all visitor visas, including tourists and people visiting family, as well as partners and guardians on longer-term visas.

site_title: Rice stockpile eyed as Japan PM orders swift relief from rising prices
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has ordered swift relief from rising food prices, including releasing stockpiled rice to bring down costs. The average price of rice last year increased 55% to 23,715 yen (S$208) per 60 kg. This move aims to alleviate suffering among citizens and address the unexpected surge in rice prices, which have been accompanied by rising prices of vegetables and other living costs.

site_title: Chinese tea drinks firm Guming aims to raise US$202 million in Hong Kong IPO
summary: Chinese tea drinks firm Guming Holdings aims to raise US$202 million in a Hong Kong IPO, selling 158.6 million shares in a price range of HK$8.68 to HK$9.94 each. The company, with 9,000 stores across mainland China, had previously planned to raise up to US$500 million. Its IPO application lapsed in 2024 due to regulatory delays, but five cornerstone investors have subscribed to the IPO for up to US$71 million. The stock will begin trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange on February 12.

site_title: OpenAI, Kakao to jointly develop AI products for South Korea
summary: OpenAI and Kakao, South Korea's dominant chat app operator, have announced a strategic partnership to develop AI products for the Korean market. Kakao will use OpenAI technology for its products, and the two companies will collaborate on AI services. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman also expressed interest in investing in and joining Korea's AI computing centre project, stating that the US company is "actively considering" the move. The partnership aims to create AI products for the Korean market, with many Korean companies expected to contribute to the ecosystem of the US Stargate data centre project.

site_title: High-tech spin for samurai-era ukiyo-e artist Hokusai at Tokyo exhibit
summary: A new Tokyo exhibition, "Hokusai: Another Story in Tokyo," uses cutting-edge technology to bring to life the work of iconic artist Katsushika Hokusai. The immersive attraction, running from February 4 to June 1 at Tokyu Plaza Shibuya, features digital imagery and haptic plates to recreate the washi paper texture of Hokusai's prints. The exhibition aims to provide an experience beyond mere sight, allowing visitors to feel the scenery Hokusai depicted. With its interactive elements, the exhibit has drawn both locals and tourists, with many praising its ability to evoke emotions and create a sense of connection to Japan's cultural past.

site_title: US: Stocks join global selloff on Trump tariffs
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, joining global markets in a selloff, after President Donald Trump announced tariffs on Canada, Mexico, and China. The Dow Jones fell 0.3%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite shed 1.2%. Trump later suspended the tariffs on Mexico for 30 days. Analysts say the tariffs will likely push prices higher and growth lower, and the market is adapting to more tariff-related risks.

site_title: Dutch lender ING looking for acquisitions to grow in Germany, Italy and Spain, says CEO
summary: ING Group, a Dutch lender, is exploring acquisitions in Germany, Italy, and Spain to expand its presence in these markets, according to CEO Steven van Rijswijk. This move follows a wave of consolidation in the European banking sector, driven by record profits and soaring stock markets. ING aims to acquire businesses that offer specific products and operate in geographical markets where it already has a strong digital presence. The bank's expansion plans could alter the European banking landscape, particularly in Germany, where ING is considering a potential deal with Commerzbank.

site_title: Oil prices close at one-month low as US pauses tariffs on Mexico
summary: US President Donald Trump paused tariffs on Mexico for one month after Mexico agreed to reinforce its northern border to stem the flow of illegal drugs. This move led to a decrease in oil prices, closing at a one-month low, as Brent futures rose 29 cents and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 63 cents. The tariffs on Canada and China were set to kick off a trade war, potentially denting global growth and reigniting inflation, but Trump's pause on Mexico's tariffs may mitigate some of the effects.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 logs biggest daily drop in 2025 as US tariffs rattle investors
summary: The Stoxx 600 index plummeted 0.87% to 534.85 points, its largest daily drop in 2025, amid US President Donald Trump's latest tariffs on Canada and Mexico, which investors fear could escalate into a broader trade war. Automakers, luxury goods makers, and spirits companies led declines, while euro zone bonds rose as investors sought safer assets. The US tariffs, set to take effect Tuesday, affect $1.3 trillion of goods, and Trump warned of tariffs on Europe, further rattling investors.

site_title: China can draw lessons from first trade war in tariffs countdown
summary: China, anticipating higher US tariffs, has adopted a relatively restrained response, similar to its playbook during Donald Trump's first trade war. The country now exports fewer products directly to the US and relies on countries like Brazil for farm imports. China has a range of new tools at its disposal to escalate the situation, putting pressure on policymakers as its GDP growth is expected to slow, further complicating the trade standoff.

site_title: Japan’s biggest lender MUFG posts 32% jump in Q3 profit
summary: Japan's largest lender, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG), reported a 32% increase in quarterly net profit to 490.74 billion yen ($4.29 billion) in the October-December period. The bank has reached 99.9% of its annual profit guidance of 1.75 trillion yen and is narrowly trailing analysts' average annual estimate. Rising interest rates, a buoyant stock market, and a weak yen are driving profits, with MUFG's share price rising to levels unseen since its 2001 listing. CFO Jun Togawa aims to sustain profit growth and catch up with global rivals by investing in growth and balancing shareholder returns.

site_title: Indonesian fund, Mitsui vie for US$300 million stake in toll operator RKE: sources

The sale comes as global investors show interest in infrastructure assets in South-east Asia, driven by growth prospects in the region. CVC Capital Partners, a Luxembourg-based investment firm, initiated the sale process for its 25% stake in RKE International, which could value the company at up to US$1 billion. The potential transaction is part of a growing trend of investors seeking infrastructure assets in the region.

Trump also announced talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping to pause levies on Chinese goods. The news lifted the Mexican peso and Canadian dollar, alleviating trade war concerns and boosting investor confidence.

Excluding special distributions, DPU rose 1% to S$0.0195. Revenue increased 24.6% to S$1.2 billion, driven by revenue from Australian bus company Ventura and higher chemical products sales.
