site_title: Sembcorp to miss 2025 target on green business profits, drops metric from 2028 strategy
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a Singapore-based energy company, will miss its 2025 target of having 70% of its net profit come from its sustainable solutions business due to strong growth in its gas business. The missed target, one of three energy transition targets set in 2021, means management will not receive compensation tied to this goal. However, the company has achieved its other two 2025 targets, including increasing installed renewables capacity to 25 GW and lowering emissions intensity to 0.15 tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent per megawatt-hour.

Rescuers have identified 55 victims, with dozens pulled from the icy Potomac River. The National Transportation Safety Board is expected to compile a preliminary report within 30 days, while US Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy vows to address staffing shortages in air traffic control. The incident is being investigated, with concerns raised about helicopter night-vision goggles and airport staffing.

site_title: India reviewing crypto position due to global changes, senior official says
summary: India is reviewing its stance on cryptocurrencies due to global changes, according to a senior government official. The review follows crypto-friendly policy announcements by US President Donald Trump, which may delay the publication of a discussion paper on cryptocurrencies. India's Economic Affairs Secretary Ajay Seth stated that the country's stance cannot be unilateral, as cryptocurrencies "do not believe in borders." This move comes after India's Financial Intelligence Unit issued show-cause notices to offshore cryptocurrency exchanges and the nation's central bank maintained that private digital currencies represent a macroeconomic risk.

site_title: China denounces Trump tariff: ‘Fentanyl is America’s problem’
summary: China's government denounced the Trump administration's 10% tariff on Chinese imports, calling it "America's problem." Beijing will challenge the tariff at the World Trade Organization and take unspecified "countermeasures." The move, which takes effect on Tuesday, marks a symbolic gesture rather than an immediate escalation. China's exports have been growing faster in volume than value, suggesting manufacturers are discounting to win overseas sales. The response stops short of the more aggressive language used during China's trade showdown with Trump in his first term.

site_title: Australian house prices fall further led by Sydney and Melbourne
summary: Australian house prices fell 0.2% in January for the second straight month, according to CoreLogic. The decline was led by Sydney and Melbourne, with prices dropping 0.4% and 0.6% respectively. The Reserve Bank is expected to ease interest rates at its Feb 17-18 meeting, which could support house prices in coming months. However, affordability constraints and a potentially gradual easing cycle suggest a low likelihood of significant growth over the next year, according to research director Tim Lawless.

images.alt_text: Houses in Sydney. Pollster Gallup says underinvestment in housing and high immigration levels created one of the world’s most expensive markets.

site_title: Why Europe will power a big and beautiful 2025 for stocks
summary: European stocks are expected to shine in 2025, contrary to the pessimistic sentiment, according to Ken Fisher. Fisher believes that despite global uncertainty, European companies are better positioned for growth, making 2025 a "big and beautiful" year for stocks.

site_title: ESG funds hit by worst-ever redemptions as backlash deepens
summary: ESG funds are experiencing a record outflow of assets, with European funds registering 7.3 billion euros in redemptions in the final three months of 2024. This is the fifth straight quarter of withdrawals, with equity funds in the EU's strictest ESG category, Article 9, being the hardest hit. Despite the challenges, ESG fund managers remain committed to complying with existing regulations, and the European Commission is working to recalibrate its ESG framework. The EU's new commissioner for financial services, Maria Luis Albuquerque, has stated that the bloc remains committed to its landmark Green Deal, but will adjust the pace of regulation to address investor concerns and regulatory fatigue.

site_title: AstraZeneca cancels UK plant after subsidies cut
summary: AstraZeneca has cancelled plans to build a £450 million vaccine plant in Liverpool, citing "timing" issues and lower public subsidies offered by the Labour government, which is proposing £40 million in subsidies compared to the £90 million offered previously. The decision is a blow to the government's plans to revive the UK economy. The company will continue to produce flu vaccines at the site, unaffected by the decision.

summary: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio warned Panama of consequences if it doesn't reduce Chinese influence over the Panama Canal, which the US claims has violated terms of the 1999 treaty. President Jose Raul Mulino rejected the threat, saying Panama is a free and sovereign nation, and proposed technical-level talks to clear up concerns. Rubio did not specify what measures the US may take, but Trump has threatened to take back the canal if changes aren't made. The US has imposed tariffs on China and Mexico, citing the potential for catastrophic consequences if the canal is shut down in a conflict.

Bonnefont will oversee software in the future as part of operations streamlining, and Chairman John Elkann is searching for a new CEO. Elkann aims to patch relations with dealers and governments and bolster the manufacturer's hybrid vehicle offerings. A new CEO is expected to be appointed in the second quarter, with Richard Palmer working closely with Elkann to determine the company's shortcomings and find a suitable replacement.

site_title: Euro set for deeper decline as market sees more ECB cuts
summary: The euro is expected to decline further as traders predict three more European Central Bank (ECB) cuts by the end of the year, with a 20% chance of a fourth reduction. The currency fell to its lowest in nearly two weeks following soft inflation readings from Germany and France, which strengthen the argument for continued monetary easing. The US dollar remains attractive due to the Federal Reserve's decision to keep rates on hold, setting the euro on a path for further weakness.

images.alt_text: In the first Federal Open Market Committee meeting of the year, the Fed kept rates steady, and repeated that it was “in no hurry” to adjust its policy stance.

site_title: Singapore-based office S-Reits report stronger operational performance
summary: Singapore-based office S-Reits have reported stronger operational performance in Q4 2024, with leasing activities in quality office developments improving. The model is designed to answer complex questions in coding, math, and science, following the release of an open-source model from China's DeepSeek, which has gained popularity due to its efficiency and cost-effectiveness. This move is seen as a response to the industry panic over DeepSeek's gains, with OpenAI's o3-mini model available via ChatGPT chatbot and API.

site_title: Trump's oil tariffs a boost for European and Asian refiners
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed 25% tariffs on Canadian and Mexican oil imports and 10% on Chinese goods, offering European and Asian refineries a competitive advantage against US rivals. The tariffs will raise costs for US refineries, cutting their profitability and potentially forcing production cuts. This could lead to higher US diesel exports supporting European margins and more opportunities for European and Asian refiners to make up the difference, with some analysts predicting a positive impact for European refiners but not for consumers.

site_title: Tariffs worry Wall Street over earnings hit, inflation pressure
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order imposing 25% tariffs on goods from Mexico and Canada and 10% on imports from China, set to take effect on Tuesday. The move is expected to hit US corporate profits and inflation, causing markets to react with potential selloffs and declines in stocks. Analysts estimate a 2.8% drag on S&P 500 earnings and a 0.7% increase in core inflation, with some predicting a 3-5% move in the index in the short term.

site_title: Blackstone president Jon Gray calls the bottom after office-market rout
summary: Blackstone president Jon Gray says the US office market has reached its bottom, with valuations having tumbled 50-70% from their peak. The company, which has traditionally retreated from the office market, is now evaluating fresh office bets, including a potential purchase of a Midtown Manhattan tower. Gray also expressed confidence in the importance of digital infrastructure, despite a new AI startup, DeepSeek, challenging the idea that AI requires increasing amounts of power and infrastructure.

summary: China's "AI temple fair" in Beijing's Haidian district combines centuries-old traditions with high-tech products, showcasing artificial intelligence (AI) applications in various industries. The event features life-size humanoid robots, automated musicians, and robotic arms creating traditional calligraphy. Local technology firms display their products, including robots capable of performing tasks such as cooking and serving. While some exhibits demonstrated advanced AI capabilities, others highlighted the need for further research and development to improve robot functionality and safety. The fair aims to promote the country's AI industry and nurture traditional culture with modern technology.

images.alt_text: The o3-mini and o3 models are meant to answer complicated questions related to topics such as coding, math and science.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau slaps 25% tariffs on C$155 billion of US goods in retaliation for Trump's tariffs
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced retaliatory tariffs of 25% on C$155 billion of US goods in response to US President Donald Trump's tariffs, including 10% on energy. Mexico also announced retaliatory measures, while China is turning to the World Trade Organisation. The tariffs will affect US exports such as beer, wine, food, and appliances, and will impact Canada's economy, with business groups expressing outrage and dismay. Trudeau urged Canadians to buy locally made products and skip US vacations, warning of economic turmoil.

images.alt_text: The flags of Mexico, the United States and Canada fly in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico. The three countries are being hit by tariffs of 10-25 per cent following a written order by US President Donald Trump.  PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: How new US AI export controls supposed to work
summary: The US has introduced export restrictions on advanced artificial intelligence (AI) computational power, requiring licenses for exports of high-performance GPUs and AI model weights. The regulations, which come into effect immediately with a 120-day grace period, target countries such as China, which face particularly stringent limitations, due to the risk of misuse. The Bureau of Industry and Security aims to curb the proliferation of advanced AI technologies that could pose risks to US national security or foreign policy interests.

images.alt_text: The Nvidia CEO had floated meeting with Trump earlier this month, when he signalled hope for a lighter regulatory touch from the new administration.

site_title: Apple scraps work on Mac-connected augmented reality glasses
summary: Apple has cancelled its project for advanced augmented reality (AR) glasses that would pair with its devices, following the weak launch of its $3,499 Vision Pro headset. The cancelled product, which would resemble normal glasses with built-in displays, was intended to appeal to everyday users. The move comes after the Vision Pro's poor reception, with many finding it too cumbersome and pricey. The cancellation marks the latest setback in Apple's efforts to create a consumer-friendly AR headset.

images.alt_text: Apple’s US$3,499 Vision Pro headset, released in February, is seen as too cumbersome and expensive to become a mainstream product.

site_title: Giving crosses US$100 billion as foundation assets hit a record
summary: US private foundations surpassed $100 billion in giving for the first time in 2024, with assets reaching an all-time high of $1.64 trillion. This growth reflects strong investment performance and a shift in how foundations think about their money, with many focusing on meeting community needs rather than just meeting the 5% annual giving requirement. The number of foundations with limited lifespans also increased, with 13% of foundations now having a deadline to give away their assets.

images.alt_text: Vincenzo Vinzi, dean and president of Essec Business School (left) and Tony Soh, chief executive of NVPC, at the MOU signing.
Chew Sutat, chairman of ComChest, says: "We hope to enable Singaporeans to express solidarity in a more accessible and sustainable manner."

site_title: China's market regulator says 'stabilising confidence' key
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission head Wu Qing emphasizes stabilizing market confidence and expectations as the government works to provide better financing access for innovative technology companies. This comes after Beijing rolled out stimulus measures in late September to restore confidence in the market. The goal is to support China's aim of becoming a "financial power" and creating capital-market funding opportunities, aligning with President Xi Jinping's vision.

images.alt_text: DeepSeek has proved that not only can AI breakthroughs happen at a fraction of the cost, but also despite the web of export controls aimed at holding China back.

site_title: USAid website goes dark with future of US assistance in doubt
summary: The US Agency for International Development (USAid) website went dark due to a network error or blank page, amid the Trump administration's review of its future and US foreign aid. The review follows an executive order by President Trump to halt and reevaluate US foreign aid, freezing billions of dollars in assistance. A waiver has been issued for "live-saving humanitarian assistance" as a three-month review is carried out to determine which projects align with Trump's vision. The move has raised concerns among aid recipients and lawmakers, who warn that eliminating USAid's independence would be illegal and benefit China.

images.alt_text: The Trans Mountain pipeline expansion (TMX) in Canada; higher TMX shipments to China could substitute imports from Venezuela and Saudi Arabia, trading sources say.

site_title: Trump’s tech buddies won’t escape US scrutiny, Texas ally warns
summary: US Attorney General Ken Paxton warns tech giants that they cannot escape legal enforcement under President Donald Trump's administration, despite their recent attempts to curry favor with him. Paxton, who has a history of suing tech companies, says Trump realizes the importance of the tech industry to the US economy but will not turn a blind eye to antitrust and censorship issues. Paxton's comments come after Trump's comments at the World Economic Forum in Davos, where he described EU fines against Silicon Valley as "a form of taxation."

images.alt_text: DeepSeek has claimed it took just two months and cost under US$6 million to build an AI model using Nvidia’s less-advanced H800 chips. An app powered by the V3 model became the top iPhone download in the US on Monday.

site_title: Volkswagen sues India to quash ‘enormous’ US$1.4b tax demand, legal filing shows
summary: Volkswagen has sued the Indian government to quash a US$1.4 billion tax demand, claiming the demand is "impossibly enormous" and contradictory to India's import taxation rules. The company argues it mis-classified imported car parts as individual parts to pay a lower duty, rather than importing them in unassembled condition. The tax dispute puts at risk Volkswagen's US$1.5 billion investments in India and could lead to a payment of US$2.8 billion if the company loses the case.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Volkswagen Taigun compact SUV car is on display after it was unveiled at an event in New Delhi, India, February 3, 2020. Picture taken February 3, 2020. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo

While the latest tax cuts may help urban consumers, who took some steam out of the economy as weak wage growth and high living costs curtailed their spending habits, economists see deeper problems that need to be addressed.

site_title: Trump tariffs target loophole used by Chinese online retailers
summary: US President Donald Trump's new trade levies against China, Canada, and Mexico include a 25% tariff on Canada and Mexico, and a 10% duty on China, targeting a long-held exemption for packages worth less than $800. The "de minimis" exemption allowed small packages to enter the US without tariffs, benefiting Chinese e-commerce retailers. The change affects retailers like Alibaba, JD.com, and Shein, who imported $48 billion worth of shipments from China last year, and may hurt lower-income consumers. The tariffs take effect on February 4.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump’s executive order imposes a 25 per cent tariff on goods entering the US from Mexico and Canada and 10 per cent on imports from China, with what the White House described as “tentative plans” for these to come into effect on Tuesday.

site_title: Unilever weighs New York as venue for ice cream unit listing
summary: Unilever is considering listing its ice cream business in New York, a move that could trigger backlash in the Netherlands. The company is evaluating options, including a US listing, Amsterdam, and London, weighing factors such as tax implications and accounting requirements. A single or multiple exchange listing is being considered, with the company expected to make a final decision based on advantages and disadvantages. The move comes as the US is the biggest market for Unilever's ice cream brands like Ben & Jerry's and Breyers.

images.alt_text: A shopper buys Pepsodent tooth paste, a product of PT Unilever Indonesia, at a supermarket in Jakarta, Indonesia, Wed., May 20, 2009. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg News

site_title: Meta posts longest rally since 2015 as Wall Street cheers AI bet
summary: Meta's platforms shares posted their longest streak of daily gains since 2015, with a 10th consecutive day of gains, following its latest earnings report. The stock rose 0.3% and gained 13% over the streak, hitting records, driven by investor confidence in its AI strategy. Meta uses AI to improve ad targeting and boost user engagement, with investors betting on its growth as AI becomes more mainstream. This marks Meta's best month since February, with a 18% climb.

images.alt_text: DeepSeek’s quick progress has stirred doubts about the lead America has in AI with models that it claims can match or even outperform Western rivals at a fraction of the cost.

site_title: Exxon, Chevron succumb to oil-refining slump as tariffs loom
summary: US-based oil giants Exxon Mobil and Chevron have reported a significant decline in refining profits due to slumping fuel margins and the threat of US tariffs on oil suppliers. Exxon's refining profits plummeted 67% in 2024, while Chevron's declined 72%. The tariffs, which could impact Canadian and Mexican oil supplies, threaten to worsen the refining business. Both companies' shares fell, with Chevron dropping 2.5% and Exxon rising 0.8%. The tariffs could lead to a knock-on effect for other types of crude, potentially curbing fuel production.

images.alt_text: The Brent and WTI benchmarks has lost 2.1 per cent and 2.9 per cent, respectively, marking the second straight week of losses.

site_title: China home prices, sales slip further in January: report
summary: China's new housing sales and existing residential unit prices declined in January, with average prices down 7% and sales by top 100 developers down 17% from last year. The decline is expected to slow in 2025 compared to 2024, according to analysts. China's property market, which once drove 25% of economic output, is now a major economic concern, weighing on households, investors, and policymakers. The government has stepped up efforts to boost sentiment and promote new home purchases.

site_title: Singapore will continue to work with US counterparts to comply with export controls: MTI
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) stated that the country's customs and law enforcement agencies will continue to work with US counterparts on export controls. This comes after reports raised questions about whether DeepSeek, a US company, obtained Nvidia chips from Singapore intermediaries that were subject to US export controls. MTI expects US companies, including Nvidia, to comply with US export controls and local domestic legislation, with Nvidia explaining that many US and European companies purchase chips through their Singapore business entities destined for Western nations.

DeepSeek has said it used Nvidia’s H800 chips, which it could have legally purchased in 2023.

site_title: ‘Big Short’ traders reuniting for hedge-fund week are long
summary: Four "Big Short" traders, Porter Collins, Steve Eisman, Vincent Daniel, and Danny Moses, gathered for a panel discussion, showcasing their long positions in emerging markets and value names, despite the prevailing bearish consensus. They cited diversification and contrarian approaches as key strategies, with Moses favoring gold and Daniel expecting a weakening US dollar. The panelists, who made a killing betting against mortgage-backed debt before the financial crisis, expressed a lack of bearish conviction, reflecting the shrinking short-selling universe and industry woes.

images.alt_text: Oslo Taxi's Tesla model Y (L) and the NIO ET5 electric vehicle from Nio Inc, a Chinese multinational electric car manufacturer, drive through the Norwegian capital Oslo, on September 27, 2024. site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for January 31, 2025, reveals a subdued week for the tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market declined, with the BCI 5TC index falling from $7,946 to $6,977, before recovering to $7,252. The Pacific market remained under pressure due to Chinese New Year holidays, while the South Atlantic showed more resilience with a steady flow of cargo. The North Atlantic faced a thinning cargo list and declining rates. The Panamax market was curtailed by Asian holidays, and the Ultramax/Supramax market struggled due to a lack of demand. The Clean market saw a downward trajectory, with LR2 rates falling by WS11.11. The MR market saw bearish movement, with the MR Atlantic Triangulation Basket TCE dropping from $25,803 to $23,012.

site_title: InnoTek shifts gears to AI, EVs to capture industry changes
summary: InnoTek, a precision components manufacturer, is shifting its focus to artificial intelligence (AI) and electric vehicles (EVs) to capitalize on growing industry demand. The company, which previously sold its core business, has identified AI-related business as a fourth major sector. Its chairman Neal Chandaria aims to scale the business and attract investors by entering promising sectors. InnoTek is considering expansion into Malaysia, following its existing presence in China, Thailand, and Vietnam.

iFast chief executive Lim Chung Chun expects more opportunities for the company to apply for licences at “a couple more locations” to boost its global model.
InnoTek is looking to leverage its "deep domain knowledge" in the automobile industry and has secured a steel stamping project with a "leading" electric vehicle battery producer.

site_title: Nvidia CEO Huang meets Trump at White House on Friday
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang met with US President Donald Trump at the White House on Friday, discussing semiconductors and AI policy. The meeting comes amid US preparations to impose tariffs on semiconductors and probe whether Chinese AI startup DeepSeek skirted export controls to obtain Nvidia products. Trump confirmed plans to impose tariffs on chips, which would heavily impact Nvidia, and discussed strengthening US technology and AI leadership. The meeting is part of a rocky week for Nvidia, which saw its shares plummet after DeepSeek released a competitive AI chatbot model.

images.alt_text: DeepSeek has said it used Nvidia’s H800 chips, which it could have legally purchased in 2023.

site_title: BlackRock’s once-mighty inflation-hedge ETF is losing its crown
summary: BlackRock's inflation-hedge ETF, iShares TIPS Bond ETF, is losing its crown as the largest inflation-hedging product. The fund, which tracks a broad index of Treasury inflation-protected securities with an average maturity of seven years, incurred losses in 2022 due to rising interest rates. As a result, BlackRock shifted its LifePath target-date retirement funds to a shorter-dated version, iShares 0-5 Year TIPS Bond ETF, which is less vulnerable to yield increases. This marks a 10-year gap between BlackRock and rival Vanguard Group, which made the switch in 2013.

images.alt_text: As the US economic cycle continues to defy the naysayers and an ostensibly business-friendly White House touts tax cuts and deregulation to drive animal spirits ever-higher, the outlook for the short-selling investor remains murky.

site_title: Ex-Fed adviser accused by US of stealing secrets for China
summary: A former senior adviser to the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, John Harold Rogers, 63, was arrested on charges of conspiring to steal US government trade secrets to benefit China. Rogers shared sensitive data, including policy deliberations and interest-rate decisions, with Chinese co-conspirators who posed as graduate students. This data could allow China to manipulate the US market in a manner similar to insider trading, posing a risk to the country's financial stability. Rogers advised the Fed's Division of International Finance from 2010 to 2021.

site_title: Agatha Christie’s ‘Witness for the Prosecution’ celebrates 100 years
summary: Agatha Christie's 100-year-old short story "Witness for the Prosecution" celebrates its anniversary, still thrilling audiences with its twists and turns of a murder trial. First published in 1925, the story has been adapted for theatre, film, and television, including a stage production running in London County Hall since 2017. The play taps into timeless themes of human judgment and prejudice, showcasing Christie's skill at surprising her audience with unexpected plot twists. The current production runs until September 28.

site_title: Trump imposes tariffs on Mexico, Canada and China, risking trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed 25% tariffs on Canadian and Mexican imports, and 10% on Chinese goods, sparking a potential trade war. The tariffs, which take effect on February 4, are aimed at addressing the national emergency over fentanyl and illegal immigration. Canada and Mexico have vowed retaliation, while China has not yet commented. Economists warn that the tariffs could slow global growth and reignite inflation, with the US stock market and currency experiencing volatility.

site_title: First major chunk breaks off world's biggest iceberg
summary: A 19 km long piece has broken off from the world's largest and oldest iceberg, A23a, marking a possible first sign of the behemoth from Antarctica crumbling. The iceberg, which is over twice the size of Greater London and weighs nearly one trillion tonnes, had been drifting towards the remote island of South Georgia, raising concerns about potential disruptions to feeding grounds for baby penguins and seals.

site_title: Steel, aluminium tariffs will impact millions of tonnes of imports
summary: US tariffs on steel and aluminium will impact millions of tonnes of imported metal, affecting the country's construction and manufacturing industries. The tariffs, enacted during President Trump's first term, will also increase domestic prices for local buyers of these materials. Canada is the top source of imported steel and aluminium, accounting for 56% of aluminium imports and 13% of steel imports in 2023. The US steel industry is facing its worst year since Trump's first term, with domestic steel mills saying a renewed uptick in imports is hurting profits and production.

images.alt_text: On an adjusted basis, US Steel lost 13 cents per share during the quarter ended Dec 31, in line with analysts’ estimates, according to data compiled by LSEG.

site_title: Taiwan bans government agencies from using DeepSeek
summary: Taiwan has banned government agencies and critical infrastructure facilities from using DeepSeek, a Chinese AI chatbot, due to concerns over national security. The Ministry of Digital Affairs cited "cross-border transmission and information leakage" as reasons for the ban. This move comes amid growing scrutiny over DeepSeek's data practices, with several countries, including South Korea, Ireland, and Italy, investigating the company. The ban is part of Taiwan's broader efforts to protect national information security, following previous restrictions on information and communication technology products and services.

images.alt_text: The Nvidia CEO had floated meeting with Trump earlier this month, when he signalled hope for a lighter regulatory touch from the new administration.

site_title: Interview with Catherine Wu
summary: Singapore's City Developments Ltd (CDL) may split its board due to a disagreement over the company's cybersecurity measures. Secretary-general of GeekCon International, Catherine Wu, was named by CEO Sherman Kwek as the trigger for the split. Wu discussed cybersecurity with Money FM 89.3, emphasizing the importance of safeguarding computer systems, networks, and data from unauthorized access. Wu introduced the GeekCon cybersecurity competition and conference to Singapore last year, with Kwek supporting the cause. The move may impact CDL's operations and future decisions.

site_title: Solar power capacity meets 2025 target; carbon credit transfer agreement inked with Bhutan: SM Teo
summary: Singapore has met its 2025 target of 1.5 gigawatt-peak (GWp) of solar power, placing the country on track to meet its 2030 goal of 2 GWp. The city-state has also signed a carbon credit transfer agreement with Bhutan, the third country to do so, aiming to promote sustainable development and deliver tangible benefits to local communities. This agreement, signed in 2024, sets out a legally binding framework for the generation and international transfer of carbon credits between Singapore and Bhutan, aligned with the Paris Agreement.

site_title: X, TikTok and others in EU 'stress test' ahead of Germany's vote
summary: Germany's digital regulator and the European Commission conducted a simulation exercise with major platforms, including X and TikTok, to test their capacity to combat disinformation ahead of national elections on February 23. The test aimed to assess platforms' readiness to address potential infringements and practised reporting procedures and information exchange. The EU's Digital Services Regulation requires platforms to mitigate risks to electoral processes. A similar test was conducted in April last year, and the EU is also investigating TikTok and X over disinformation and content manipulation.

site_title: Here’s the few foreign markets set to win on Trump’s return
summary: US President Donald Trump's return to the White House has created uncertainty in global markets, particularly for developing economies. However, some countries with strong ties to the US, such as Argentina, Ecuador, and Turkey, are expected to benefit from the Trump administration's policies. These countries have seen gains in their dollar bonds, with returns of at least 11% compared to a 2.3% return for a benchmark index of developing-nation credits. In contrast, Asian economies, particularly Vietnam, Malaysia, and Thailand, are at risk due to high trade surpluses against the US and potential tariffs.

images.alt_text: The US economy has broadly held up in the face of high interest rates, helped by a robust labor market with low unemployment and still-growing wages.

site_title: Bonds gain in January as Trump’s return drives topsy-turvy month
summary: US Treasury bonds rose 0.6% in January, defying market expectations, as investors waited for clarity on President Trump's pro-business policies. The Bloomberg US Treasury index recovered after a rollercoaster stretch, with benchmark yields near their lows for the year. Trump's announcement of tariffs on Mexico and Canada boosted Treasuries, but the market remains cautious, with yields potentially rising if data strengthens. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep rates unchanged, with some traders betting on a cut in mid-year, but higher inflation and fiscal uncertainty could lead to rate hikes.

site_title: PepsiCo’s Apac CEO Tan Wern-Yuen to join Hillhouse Investment
summary: PepsiCo's Asia-Pacific CEO Tan Wern-Yuen is set to join private equity firm Hillhouse Investment in March, where he will lead the global consumer and retail team. Tan spent nearly five years as PepsiCo's Asia-Pacific CEO and over a year as its global chief commercial officer. His departure comes as the F&B industry in Asia faces a tough macroeconomic environment and rising competition from Chinese brands. PepsiCo has yet to announce Tan's replacement, following his LinkedIn post announcing his departure from the company in February.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
PepsiCo hires Singaporean Tan Wern-Yuen as Asia-Pacific CEO

site_title: JPMorgan plans US$4 billion US gold delivery amid tariff fears
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to deliver over US$4 billion worth of gold bullion to meet physical delivery for February's gold contracts, amid rising prices and tariffs fears. The delivery, valued at 30 million troy ounces, is the second-largest ever, and follows similar moves by other banks. The move is seen as an arbitrage opportunity, as spot prices in London have surged over Comex prices, with traders flying silver into the US due to similar pricing dynamics. The deliveries come as physical inventories in Comex depositories have swelled by 14 million ounces.

images.alt_text: The Brent and WTI benchmarks has lost 2.1 per cent and 2.9 per cent, respectively, marking the second straight week of losses.

site_title: South Korea exports stay resilient as Trump tariff threat looms
summary: South Korea's exports maintained a 7.7% growth in January, driven by technology products, despite domestic turmoil and US President Donald Trump's tariff threat. Exports fell 10.3% in headline figures, but the actual increase was 7.7% due to the Lunar New Year holiday. The trade deficit widened to $1.9 billion, with imports decreasing 6.4%. The economy is facing concerns over slowing growth, with the central bank cutting its forecast and the government considering measures to shore up the economy.

site_title: Podcaster debut marks new era for White House press room
summary: The White House has introduced a new policy allowing podcasters, TikTokers, and other content creators to apply for press credentials on a rotation basis, marking a shift towards a more diverse press corps. The first non-traditional outlet to occupy the coveted "new media" seat was Ruthless Podcast, which was granted the first question at a press briefing. Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt described the media as "out of touch" with Americans, echoing former President Donald Trump's criticism of traditional media. The move aims to increase public trust in the press, but some critics worry that it may open the door to sycophants rather than genuinely independent voices.

site_title: Heavy selling wipes nearly a billion dollars off Yangzijiang Shipbuilding’s value as its shares plummet 9%
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's shares plummeted 9% to S$2.44, wiping nearly a billion dollars off its value, amid US Trade Representative's proposal to charge fees of up to US$1.5 million on Chinese-built vessels entering US ports. The stock had already fallen 31% in a week. The proposed fees are part of investigations into China's rising dominance in global shipbuilding and logistics sectors.

images.alt_text: For the full year, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a net profit of 6.6 billion yuan, a 62 per cent increase from 4.1 billion yuan in the year ago period.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was one of the Singapore Exchange’s top-performing stocks in 2024.

site_title: Oil falls, settles at two-month low as US fuel inventories rise
summary: Oil prices fell to two-month lows, with Brent crude settling at $72.53 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures at $68.62, as US fuel stockpiles rose unexpectedly. A surprise build in US fuel inventories and prospects for a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine contributed to the decline. Analysts attributed the decrease to demand weakness and potential sanctions being lifted on Russia, which could remove supply uncertainty from the market.

site_title: Andre Chiang serves souped-up hotpot at Raffles City
summary: Celebrity chef Andre Chiang has launched Bon Broth, a Taiwanese hotpot restaurant in Singapore's Raffles City, offering eight signature broths and a premium set featuring fresh seafood. The restaurant's elegant interiors and unique concept aim to revolutionize the traditional hotpot experience, with a focus on high-quality ingredients and expertly brewed broths. However, diners have reported discomfort due to the counter seating arrangement and lack of variety in the premium set, which starts at S$110. Despite some drawbacks, Bon Broth's innovative approach to hotpot has received positive reviews, with a rating of 6.5 out of 10.

site_title: GM to increase dividend by 25%, buy back another US$6 billion of shares
summary: General Motors (GM) plans to increase its quarterly dividend by 25% to 15 cents per share, effective April 2025, and repurchase US$6 billion of shares, with US$2 billion to be completed by the first half of this year. The move aims to return excess cash and increase shareholder value. GM expects to narrow EV operating losses by US$2 billion this year, with projected net income of US$11.2-12.5 billion for 2025.

site_title: WP chief Pritam Singh calls for help with business rents, questions GST hike at start of Budget debate
summary: Leader of the Opposition Pritam Singh called for government support for local businesses struggling with rising rents, particularly in the food and beverage industry, amidst competition from cash-rich foreign players. He questioned the government's fiscal marksmanship, citing the 2023 and 2024 GST hikes, and warned that such poor planning could fuel public cynicism in future tax hikes. Singh also suggested expanding SG60 vouchers to support small businesses and argued for an independent parliamentary budget office to track public spending.

site_title: OCBC, UOB poised to gain most from JS-SEZ; DBS could seek to expand Malaysia footprint: analysts
summary: Singaporean banks OCBC and UOB are poised to benefit from the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) as facilitators of investment and trade, given their sizeable operations in both markets. The zone, signed in January, is expected to create 100 projects and 20,000 jobs across 11 sectors, strengthening cross-border cooperation and enabling the banks to gain from stronger investment flows. DBS, the largest bank in Southeast Asia, may consider expanding its presence in Malaysia to narrow the gap with its Singaporean peers, but analysts note that this move alone may not bridge the gap immediately.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The incentives by the Malaysian Investment Development Authority are available to both new and existing companies operating within the JS-SEZ’s flagship zones.
Business across sectors including manufacturing, logistics and the digital economy can benefit from the improved cross-border flow of goods and people, said the Singapore minister of state.
Industries that are manpower or space intensive could achieve significant cost savings by relocating to the Johor-Singapore SEZ.
Malaysia's Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said: "The real potential of Johor and Singapore can only be unlocked if we address the bottlenecks hindering seamless movement."

site_title: Starbucks cuts 1,100 corporate jobs in bid to speed turnaround
summary: Starbucks is eliminating 1,100 corporate jobs, approximately 7% of its global non-store employees, to increase efficiency and revitalize the company. The cuts, announced in January by CEO Brian Niccol, will be phased in with affected workers receiving pay and benefits until May 2, followed by severance based on tenure. The restructuring is part of the company's effort to speed up changes after declining sales.

images.alt_text: Signs outside a Starbucks in New York City on January 14, 2025. Wall Street stocks mostly fell early January 13, 2025 as Treasury bond yields lingered at a high level while markets looked ahead to earnings and economic data releases. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Trump shakes transatlantic alliance with Russia pivot
summary: US President Donald Trump's shift on Ukraine has shaken the transatlantic alliance, with European leaders seeking to convince him to stick by Kyiv. Trump's nationalist approach, favoring a great power game with Moscow and Beijing, has caused panic in European capitals that the bond forged from World War II is on the verge of collapse. Trump's meetings with French President Emmanuel Macron and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer this week will be testy, with fears growing that the US is abandoning its traditional role as a rules-based world order.

images.alt_text: Trump denounced Zelenskiy as “a dictator without elections" after the latter said the US President was trapped in a Russian disinformation bubble.
US President Donald Trump has put pressure on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy to agree an end to the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
Trump (left) himself has struck a less belligerent tone on China, telling reporters that a trade deal was “possible” and again trumpeting his “very good relationship” with Xi (right).
In 2016, US journalists and commentators famously observed that Trump's critics took him literally but not seriously, while his supporters took him seriously but not literally.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky reacted to US President Donald Trump’s attacks by accusing him of succumbing to Russian “disinformation.”

site_title: UOL unit, partner win tender for residential site in Shanghai
summary: UOL's unit, Qin Rui Jia (Shanghai) Realty Co, has won a 9 billion yuan (S$1.7 billion) tender for a 19,319 sqm residential site in Shanghai's Hongkou district. The joint venture, with China Jinmao Holdings Group, will acquire the land-use rights and develop the site. The acquisition expands UOL's development footprint in China and will be financed via existing funds and external borrowings. The transaction is not expected to have a material impact on UOL's earnings for the 2025 financial year.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The new condo Parktown Residence is part of an integrated development featuring a retail mall, the future Tampines North MRT station and a community club

site_title: A colourful, whimsical journey: Treasure hunting the Van Cleef & Arpels way
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has unveiled its latest high jewellery collection, "Treasure Island," inspired by Robert Louis Stevenson's classic novel. The collection features whimsical pieces with intricate details, including a nautical adventure and land expedition theme. The maison's artisans have crafted exquisite pieces with interchangeable motifs, such as golden maps, emerald palm trees, and diamond-encrusted ships. The collection showcases the maison's savoir faire and artisans' skill in crafting pieces with high jewellery techniques, including the patented Mystery Set. The collection's universality goes beyond Western references, celebrating gems in happy hues and featuring a vast palette of colourful stones.

images.alt_text: Just  one of several magnificent necklaces from Van Cleef & Arpels' Treasure Island high jewellery collection.

site_title: Intel says new ASML machines are in production, with positive results
summary: Intel has successfully produced 30,000 wafers using ASML's high numerical aperture (NA) lithography machines, surpassing the production of earlier machines. The new machines, which print features onto chips using fewer exposures, have shown reliability twice that of earlier models. Intel plans to use these machines to develop its 18A manufacturing technology, scheduled for mass production later this year, and expects to put them into full production with its next-generation 14A technology.

images.alt_text: Intel was among the largest beneficiaries of the US push to onshore critical chip manufacturing led by former president Joe Biden’s administration.
Intel, once dominant in the chip industry, has struggled to regain its technological edge and lost market share to rivals in recent years.

site_title: Wee Ee Cheong raises UOB stake after FY2024 record net profit
summary: UOB deputy chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong raised his stake in the bank after it reported a record net profit of S$6 billion for FY2024. Wee highlighted the bank's strong fee, trading, and investment income, as well as its long-term investments in regional platforms, which are expected to drive continued revenue growth. UOB also announced a new share buyback program worth S$2 billion.

images.alt_text: S-Reits, industrials lead institutional outflow

site_title: EDB managing director Jacqueline Poh named  JTC’s new CEO
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) announced that Jacqueline Poh, managing director of the Economic Development Board (EDB), will be appointed as the new CEO of JTC Corporation, replacing Tan Boon Khai, who is stepping down on March 31. Poh, who has led EDB to achieve strong investment commitments since 2020, will assume the top role on April 1. She will also be appointed as a member of the JTC board in an ex officio capacity.

site_title: Seven & i Holdings picks Bain as preferred buyer in asset sale: report
summary: Seven & i Holdings, the operator of 7-Eleven convenience stores, has chosen Bain Capital as its preferred buyer for its non-core assets, including supermarket operations, in a stake valued at over 700 billion yen (S$6.3 billion). Bain is competing with rival private equity firms KKR and Japan Industrial Partners for the stake in York Holdings. The retailer plans to spin off York Holdings, which will house 31 subsidiaries, including superstores and baby goods stores. The sale is part of Seven & i's efforts to separate non-core businesses.

site_title: Apple to launch new lower-cost iPhone to capture a broader market
summary: Apple is set to launch a new, lower-cost iPhone model, the fourth generation iPhone SE, to capture a broader market share, particularly in the mid-range smartphone segment. The new model is expected to be priced at a premium to the outgoing iPhone SE, which starts at US$429. The launch comes as Apple forecasts strong sales growth and rolls out artificial intelligence features to more regions and languages. The move aims to fend off competition from Samsung and Huawei, and capitalize on the growing demand for affordable smartphones with AI tools.

images.alt_text: Apple is also adding a new app to the Vision Pro for viewing spatial content tailored to the device, including 3D images and panoramas aggregated from outside sources.
Apple is working with Alibaba Group Holding and Baidu to create a system that passes muster with Chinese regulators.
Apple confirmed that TikTok will return to its US app store on Thursday evening.
Alibaba has become a Chinese AI favourite among investors early in 2025, with its stock price up over 40 per cent so far this year.
Taking this step suggests that Apple is trying to boost the appeal of TV+ and challenge streaming services such as Netflix and Disney+.
The iPhone maker is likely to stop offering encrypted storage in the UK, rather than break the security promises it made to its users everywhere.
Apple is planning a broader shake-up to the iPhone lineup this year

China’s State Administration for Market Regulation is reviewing Apple’s policies, including its up to 30 per cent commission on in-app purchases and restrictions on external payment services and app stores.
Apple's overall sales and profits were boosted by stronger-than-expected sales of iPads and Macs, where new chips helped persuade customers to upgrade.

site_title: Rex International falls 21.9% to S$0.168 on heavy trading after profit warning
summary: Rex International shares plummet 21.9% to S$0.168, their lowest point since January 2024, after the company warned it expects a net loss for FY2024 due to non-cash items related to impairment of assets. The company had previously posted net losses for FY2022 and FY2023, and was last profitable in FY2021. Its unaudited financial results for FY2024 are expected to be released on or before March 1, 2025.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
XXX

site_title: Singapore shares muted at Friday’s open; STI down 0.02%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.02% at 3,926.83. Global markets declined overnight, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 falling 1% and 0.4%, respectively. Banking stocks rose, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB advancing 0.3%, 0.2%, and 0.2%, respectively. The broader market saw 66 gainers and 62 losers, with 64.7 million securities traded worth S$118.4 million.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
A Singapore Airlines Boeing 737 approaches for landing at Singapore Changi airport in Singapore on November 5, 2024. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN and ROSLAN RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: UOB looks to ‘resilient’ Asean to continue to drive growth as Q4 profit beats estimates
summary: UOB posted a net profit of S$1.52 billion for Q4 2024, up 8.6% from S$1.4 billion in the same period last year, beating estimates. The bank remains confident in Asean's resilience amid geopolitical tensions and tariff concerns. UOB is focusing on mega trends like supply chain diversification, digitalization, and the green economy to drive growth. The lender aims to maintain a 2% net interest margin and has proposed a S$3 billion capital distribution package, including a special dividend and share buyback program.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Chong Xin Wei
UOB announced the establishment of a S$3 billion capital distribution package and its fourth-quarter results on Wednesday morning.
UOB beats expectations with Q4 profit up 8.6% to S$1.52 billion; announces S$3 billion capital distribution package

The local banking trio are due to report their fourth quarter and full year 2024 results in February, with DBS on Feb 10, UOB on Feb 19 and OCBC on Feb 26.

site_title: Sing Investments & Finance H2 net profit up 21% at S$20.3 million
summary: Sing Investments & Finance (SingFinance) reported a 21% increase in net profit to S$20.3 million for the half-year ended Dec 31, 2024. This comes as revenue edged 3% higher year on year to S$77.1 million. The lender's board recommended a final dividend of S$0.065 per share, up from S$0.06 per share in the previous period. Despite significant challenges and uncertainties in the local and global economies, SingFinance sees growth opportunities in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: HP to acquire parts of Humane, Ai Pin startup from ex-Apple managers, for US$116 million
summary: HP will acquire assets from Humane, a startup founded by ex-Apple managers, for $116 million. The deal includes Humane's software platform and intellectual property, as well as the majority of its employees. The acquisition will form a new division at HP to integrate AI into personal computers, printers, and connected conference rooms. Humane's wearable device business, which faced negative reviews and quality issues, will be wound down. The deal is expected to close by the end of the month.

images.alt_text: Dell fell 13 per cent in trading before the bell, with the company set to shed nearly US$13 billion from its US$99.50 billion market value, after it forecast quarterly revenue below estimates.
PC makers had hoped that new machines touted as better for artificial intelligence workloads would spur demand.

site_title: Shein executive seeks to reassure investors after Trump crackdown on low-value imports
summary: Shein's executive chairman Donald Tang reassured investors that the company's growth remains strong despite the US ending the duty-free treatment of low-value e-commerce packages from China. The move, triggered by President Trump's decision, has raised concerns about Shein's business model and potential price hikes. Tang stated that Shein will maintain its edge in the competitive US market by investing in supply chain advancements and logistics to ensure faster deliveries. The company is set to cut its valuation in its London IPO to around $50 billion.

images.alt_text: Shein shareholders are suggesting that an adjustment is needed to help get its potential initial public offering in the UK over the line.

Prices will rise for Americans who buy US$5 shirts, US$10 lamps and US$20 shoes on direct-from-China shopping sites like Shein and Temu after US President Donald Trump this week imposed 10 per cent tariffs on goods from China.
FILE PHOTO: Shein and Temu app icons are seen in this illustration taken August 22, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
Tensions are already running high between Shein and Temu and their suppliers and merchants in China.

site_title: Japanese star Takuya Kimura learnt to cook from this top chef for his hit TV show
summary: Chef Kei Kobayashi, owner of Paris-based Restaurant Kei, lent his culinary expertise to the sequel of the hit TV series "La Grande Maison Tokyo," which follows Japanese chefs pursuing three Michelin stars in Paris. Kobayashi, who earned three Michelin stars in 2020, worked closely with the cast and production team to create an authentic fine-dining world. The film reflects Kobayashi's own journey to success, overcoming obstacles and discrimination as a Japanese person cooking French cuisine. The sequel aims to energize the restaurant industry and showcase the culinary world.

images.alt_text: A bird's eye view from The Ritz-Carlton Osaka's Club Lounge.

site_title: Singapore Exchange veterans leave amid stock market revival push
summary: Veteran Singapore Exchange staff, including Frieda Choong, June Sim, and Nico Torchetti, are leaving the bourse amid efforts to revive the nation's stock market. The departures come as some insiders have questioned the feasibility of a government-led revival plan, which includes doubling new listings and preventing delistings. Eliza Tan and Michael Tang will take over their positions. The changes mark the latest shake-up at SGX, following Matthew Song's departure in 2024 and recent departures of less senior IPO staff.

images.alt_text: Ng Chin Hwee and Chng Lay Chew were appointed non-executive, independent directors of SingPost effective Feb 17 the company said in a bourse filing on Monday (Feb 17).
In 2024, a total of 20 companies delisted from the Singapore Exchange, with just four new entrants to the Catalist board.

site_title: South Korea’s early exports sputter ahead of Trump’s tariffs
summary: South Korea's exports, led by semiconductor shipments, lost momentum in February, growing 16% in headline figures but 2.7% in adjusted terms. The Lunar New Year holidays affected the data, and the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariff plans is causing uncertainty. The trade surplus increased to $804 million, but economists warn of a decline in exports unless tariffs are eased. The country's economy is also hampered by stagnant consumption, political turmoil, and a heavy reliance on trade, prompting the central bank to cut its growth forecast for 2025.

images.alt_text: Containers are seen stacked up near a berthed cargo vessel at a terminal in the southeastern port city of Busan on November 24, 2024. (Photo by ANTHONY WALLACE / AFP)

site_title: Zegna unveils the most luxurious wool you’ve never heard of
summary: Italian luxury brand Zegna has unveiled its Vellus Aureum collection, featuring the finest wool in the world, sourced from pure-bred merino sheep. The wool is finer than cashmere, with a diameter of 12-13 microns, making it incredibly soft. The collection is 100% traceable via the Aura blockchain, ensuring transparency and ethical sourcing. The brand's commitment to sustainability and craftsmanship is reflected in its cutting-edge technology, allowing consumers to track the entire life cycle of their garments.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.
Siam Motors Group's scion Pranai Phornprapha, CEO of Kaleido Lifestyle, is boldly innovating Thai food and beverages.

site_title: Chinese rivals seize on Illumina’s blacklisting to woo clients
summary: Chinese companies are seizing on Illumina's blacklisting to woo its clients, offering free trials and subsidies to switch to domestic machines. MGI Tech, a local manufacturer, is offering free trials to existing Illumina customers, while Cygnus Bio and Zhengzhou Sikun Biological Engineering are also promoting their products. The blacklisting, in response to US President Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods, is accelerating Illumina's loss of market share to local companies, with Citigroup predicting Chinese machines will take the "absolute majority" of the market in about three years.

images.alt_text: If found at fault, Calvin Klein parent PVH could be added to an “unreliable entity list” that prevents offending foreign companies from trading with China, subjects them to fines or revokes their staff’s work permit, according to a 2020 order.
FILE PHOTO: A sign at the front entrance to the global headquarters of Illumina is pictured in San Diego, California, U.S., November 28, 2022. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: UK wage growth jumps, cementing gradual rate cut path
summary: The UK's annual growth in employees' average regular earnings rose to 5.9% in the three months to December, its highest in eight months, reinforcing expectations of a gradual interest rate cut path by the Bank of England. This data suggests the economy remains strong, despite UK businesses warning of potential lower wages and reduced hiring due to tax increases. The Bank of England has already cut interest rates three times in six months, signaling a careful approach to further rate cuts amid economic developments and US tariff threats.

images.alt_text: A separate survey from the Federation of Small Businesses showed confidence among its members fell in late 2024 to its lowest level since the first quarter of 2020 when the Covid-19 pandemic hit Britain.

site_title: The Philippines pauses easing cycle, signals jumbo RRR cut soon
summary: The Philippine central bank kept the key interest rate unchanged at 5.75% on February 13, pausing a potential rate cut due to rising global uncertainties. Governor Eli Remolona stated that borrowing costs will continue to decrease, with a planned 200 basis points reduction in the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) to 5% in the first half of the year. This decision is influenced by global market volatility, including US President Donald Trump's tariff policy, and domestic inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: The BSP has flagged a fourth consecutive 25 basis point rate cut at its Feb 13 meeting.
Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas will review the key rate on Feb 13.

site_title: Budget 2025: Tax rebates, exemption, to draw companies and fund managers to list in Singapore
summary: Singapore has introduced tax incentives to encourage companies and fund managers to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The incentives include a 20% corporate tax rebate for primary listings and a 10% rebate for secondary listings, with a cap of S$6 million per year. Newly listed fund managers will receive a 5% concessionary tax rate on their qualifying income, with a cap of S$3 million per year. These incentives aim to strengthen the attractiveness of the local bourse and encourage economic growth.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
More incentives to spur innovation in the Singapore economy are expected
Singapore Budget 2025: The current term of government runs from FY2021 to FY2025.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as Trump holds off on immediate tariffs
summary: US stocks rose 0.8% on Thursday, driven by President Trump's decision to hold off on immediate tariffs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 44,711.43. Trump unveiled a "fair and reciprocal plan" for trade, aiming to address perceived unfair conduct by trading partners. The move alleviated concerns about tariffs, allowing stocks to rebound despite disappointing inflation data.

images.alt_text: A person walks past the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at Wall Street in New York on February 3, 2025. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - FEBRUARY 10: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on February 10, 2025 in New York City. Despite continued uncertainty with the Trump administration's proposed tariffs, stocks were up over 100 points in morning trading. site_title: Xi’s new frontline corporate guard showcases his priorities, control
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has rallied key tech and private sector leaders to support his goals of achieving technological self-reliance and supply-chain security. The gathering, attended by founders of Huawei, BYD, Alibaba, Tencent, Xiaomi, and AI start-up DeepSeek, reflects a shift in Beijing's priorities as it navigates a deepening technology war with the US. Analysts say Xi's focus on private sector companies is a recognition of their contribution to economic growth, and the upcoming Private Economy Promotion Law aims to create a legal environment that ensures equal treatment and protection of private companies.

images.alt_text: Since 2023, Xi’s government has eased off on the campaign and indicated that it still sees the trillion-dollar technology sector as an important part of the country’s economy.

Chinese President Xi Jinping “stressed that the difficulties and challenges currently faced by the development of the private economy have generally appeared during the process of reform and development, and industrial transformation”.
Xi Jinping has long stressed the need for China to achieve self-sufficiency in semiconductors and wants the country to use AI to drive economic development.
One major driver of the rally is Alibaba Group Holding contributing to a surge of almost 60 per cent since Jan 13.
Attendance by Jack Ma at the planned symposium has the potential to boost business confidence.

site_title: Red roses reign, but alternatives are blooming
summary: Roses remain a popular choice for Valentine's Day, with the global rose industry valued at $32.99 billion and projected to grow 6.94% annually. However, shifting trends and rising costs are leading to a growing interest in non-red roses, with pastel colors like blush pink and lavender gaining traction. Florists report a 15% year-on-year increase in orders for roses, with alternative colors accounting for about a quarter of total rose sales. Despite this, red roses remain the quintessential symbol of romance, with demand remaining strong.

images.alt_text: Darcel Al Anthony
This Valentine's Day, enjoy decorating chocolates with your sweetheart.

site_title: Why Nissan will struggle without Honda’s helping hand
summary: Nissan's financial struggles worsened, with a 94% net income slump in the six months to Sept 30, primarily due to declining sales in the US and China. The company's outdated model lineup and failure to adapt to changing market trends, such as the shift towards hybrid vehicles, contributed to its woes. Honda, which had considered a potential merger with Nissan, ended talks after disagreements over how to combine the two businesses. The setback leaves Nissan vulnerable to potential acquisition by Taiwanese company Foxconn, which has expressed interest in the automaker.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Logos of Nissan Motor Corporation and Honda are seen at a joint press conference on their merger talks, in Tokyo, Japan, December 23, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Nissan is pushing ahead with a restructuring plan announced in November that includes cutting 9,000 jobs and reducing global capacity by 20 per cent.
A source told Reuters that Nissan is open to working with Taiwan’s Foxconn, the world’s largest contract electronics maker.
The levies add to an already difficult time for carmakers that are grappling with weaker demand in key markets.
Japanese carmakers are losing ground to BYD as the Chinese EV giant finds inroads to key markets in South-east Asia, and even starts to build a foothold on their home turf.

site_title: SoftBank posts third-quarter loss of US$2.4 billion
summary: SoftBank Group reported a net loss of US$2.4 billion in the October-December quarter due to falling valuations at its Vision Fund investment arm. This loss raises questions about the company's plans for a US$40 billion investment in OpenAI, with SoftBank also committing to a US$15 billion investment in Stargate. The Vision Fund unit posted an investment loss of 352.7 billion yen, following a run of two consecutive quarters in the black.

images.alt_text: The logo of SoftBank is displayed at a company shop in Tokyo, Japan January 28, 2025.  REUTERS/Issei Kato
SoftBank's discussions come as hyperscalers tap new financing methods to pay for soaring costs of AI hardware.

site_title: Europe: Shares log longest weekly streak of advances in a year
summary: Europe's main stock index, the Stoxx 600, closed lower on Friday, ending a four-session winning streak, but still logging its eighth consecutive weekly gain, the longest streak since the first quarter of 2024. The index rose 0.2% for the week, driven by luxury stocks, which advanced after Hermes reported strong earnings. The Stoxx 600 is up over 8% for the year, outperforming US peers. Goldman Sachs raised its 12-month price forecast for the index, citing lower risk premiums and stronger economic growth.

images.alt_text: German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, February 13, 2025.    REUTERS/Staff
The Stoxx 600 index closed 1.09 per cent higher at 553.75 points on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Tuesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by a positive reaction to US President Donald Trump's announcement of reciprocal tariffs on other countries. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 11.69 points to 3,886.82. Local banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, advanced, while Addvalue Technologies and Rex International were among the top gainers. The market also followed Wall Street's lead, with tech shares driving gains and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 1%.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: Reducing food waste, one pineapple tart at a time
summary: Singapore's Chinese New Year festivities often result in a significant amount of unsold food, contributing to a "food mountain." To address this issue, experts suggest implementing public education campaigns, encouraging businesses to offer sustainable options, and introducing legislation to support waste management. South Korea's successful "jongnyangje" waste disposal system, which achieves nearly 100% food-waste recycling, can serve as a model. By working together, Singapore can reduce its food waste and promote sustainability.

images.alt_text: Lee Su Shyan
The Future of Food analyses food sustainability through food-tasting sessions and panel discussions.

site_title: Gucci sales tumble as Kering turnaround fails to take shape
summary: Gucci's quarterly sales plummeted 24% on a comparable basis in the fourth quarter, according to Kering's latest earnings report. This marks a significant setback for the luxury brand, which has been struggling to regain momentum. The departure of Gucci's designer, Sabato De Sarno, after just two years, is the latest sign of turmoil at the brand. Kering's annual recurring operating income fell 46% to 2.6 billion euros, the lowest since 2016, with Gucci accounting for almost two-thirds of the profit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of fashion house Gucci is seen outside a store in Cannes, France, May 16, 2024. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo

site_title: BYD shares hit record high, trouncing Tesla’s stock; to integrate DeepSeek and broaden self-driving tech
summary: BYD shares hit a record high, surpassing Tesla's stock price, as the Chinese electric vehicle leader announces plans to integrate advanced driver-assistance features in most future models at no additional cost. BYD will also integrate AI startup DeepSeek's software and install its "God's Eye" autonomous driving system in at least 21 models. The move is expected to further intensify competition in China's EV market and could lead to a new price war. BYD aims to deliver 5-6 million EVs and hybrids this year, up from 4.27 million in 2024.

images.alt_text: Investors are keenly watching BYD’s smart-car plans after the automaker last year pledged to invest 100 billion yuan to develop advanced technology.
The Yangwang U8 sport utility vehicle on display at the Japan Mobility Show in late 2023.
BYD is targeting sales of between five and six million EVs and hybrid cars this year, up from 4.27 million delivered last year.

site_title: Investors cautious ahead of Powell’s address, US inflation data; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks retreated 0.4% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,860.76 points, after investors remained cautious ahead of Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's testimony and US inflation data. Losers outnumbered gainers 267 to 238, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion changing hands. The top gainer was Sats, up 1.9%, while Mapletree Industrial Trust fell 3.3%. Markets expect Powell to adopt a cautious approach despite pressure to lower interest rates, citing solid US growth and sticky inflation.

site_title: Trump’s acting CFPB chief shutters headquarters, halts supervision
summary: US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's (CFPB) Washington headquarters will be closed for the coming week, following a decision by acting CFPB chief Russell Vought to suspend all activities, including supervision of companies. Vought, a Trump appointee, has granted access to agency IT systems to representatives of billionaire Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency, sparking concerns over a potential conflict of interest. The move is part of the Trump administration's efforts to neutralize the CFPB, which was created after the 2008 financial crash to prevent unfair, deceptive, and abusive practices.

images.alt_text: Two-thirds of people in the US say his administration has not focused enough on lowering prices, according to the poll.

US Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s remarks add further strain to relations between the US and South Africa, which counts America as its second-biggest trading partner, after China.
While the actions of President Trump towards the deregulation of the US crypto industry have been promising in promoting it, the actions of citizen Trump have been concerning.
